                         Glasgow Daily Times (Kentucky)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                              May 24, 2010 Monday

Monroe County farm families eligible for FSA emergency loans

BYLINE: Gina Kinslow, Glasgow Daily Times, Ky.

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 467 words


May 24--GLASGOW -- Monroe County is one of seven counties in Kentucky where farm
families are eligible for Farm Service Agency emergency management loan
assistance due to the May 1-2 flooding.

"We had a lot of fence damage, about what Barren County had," said Dawn Gentry,
county FSA executive director. "We both asked for the same amount of money. We
had several fields that were covered in gravel bars. So far no one has turned in
any animals."

As for crops damaged in the flood, Gentry said there weren't very many affected,
she said.

Emergency management loans are made to farmers who own or operate land located
in a county declared federally as a disaster area or designated by the State
Secretary of Agriculture as a disaster area or quarantine area; are established
family farm operators and have sufficient farming or ranching experience; area
citizens or permanent residents of the United States; have suffered at least a
30 percent loss in crop production or a physical loss to livestock, livestock
products, real estate, or chattel property; have an acceptable credit history;
are unable to receive credit from commercial sources; can provide collateral to
secure the loan; and have repayment ability, according to a handout issued by
FSA.

Emergency management loans may be used to restore or replace essential property,
pay all or part of production costs associated with the disaster year; pay
essential family living expenses; reorganize the farming operation; and
refinance certain debts, the handout stated.

The loans are based on the amount of loss farmers sustained.

"We would have to asses what kind of loss to determine whether it is physical or
production loss," said Debbie Turner, farm loan officer with FSA.

Producers can qualify up to 100 percent of actual production or physical losses
or up to $500,000 in emergency loan funds, she said.

The current annual interest rate for emergency loans is 3.75 percent.

Agriculture Commissioner Richie Farmer advises Kentucky farmers affected by the
floods to seek relief.

"Kentucky farmers have lost thousands of acres of crops, and some had farm
equipment and fences damaged," he said in a press release. "I want them to know
they are not alone. There are several programs available through the Farm
Service Agency to assist them in their recovery."

For more information about emergency management loans, call 629-2081.

                          The Oskaloosa Herald (Iowa)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             June 24, 2008 Tuesday

Farm Service Agency loans available: Emergency low interest loans are available
to repair or replace damaged or destroyed physical property essential to the
success of farming operations.

BYLINE: Michael Schaffer, The Oskaloosa Herald, Iowa

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 426 words


Jun. 24--OSKALOOSA -- Mahaska County Farm Service Agency, through the United
States Department of Agriculture, now has emergency loans available for eligible
farm families with qualifying production and other losses due to recent natural
disasters.

Physical loss low interest loans are available to repair or replace damaged or
destroyed physical property essential to the success of farming operations,
including farm buildings, fixtures, equipment, livestock, perennial or stored
crops, and fruit- and nut-bearing trees.

The Presidential Major Disaster Declaration amended on June 18 added 13 Iowa
counties as primary disaster areas, including Mahaska County, and was the
trigger mechanism for the loans. Forty-five counties contiguous to the 13 are
also considered part of the disaster area.

Joe Rieck, Mahaska County Farm Service Agency county executive director, said
qualifying production and physical losses have to be a result from severe
storms, tornadoes and flooding.

The incidence period for disaster losses started after May 25 and is continuing,
with Feb. 18 the last day to submit loan applications. Rieck said farmers who
think they might qualify should call the Mahaska County Farm Service Agency at
(641) 673-3476.

The amount of emergency loan money available for individual farms has yet to be
determined, he said.

"We're going through a time now where some of those limits are raising now, so I
don't know what they are for sure," Rieck said.

The interest rate for the emergency loans is 3.75 percent. Repayment for most
loans is seven years and can be for up to 40 years, if applied to replacement
for real estate fixtures.

Besides emergency loans, other Farm Service Agency programs will be available
because of the disaster declaration.

Rieck said the extent of those programs is still unclear because of the new Farm
Bill in Washington.

"But it looks like because of this declaration, we have three or four or five
programs that are going to become available," Rieck said. He mentioned programs
for debris cleanup and livestock losses.

Herald City Editor Michael Schaffer can be reached by email at
mschaffer@oskyherld.com

                         Corning Observer (California)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             August 17, 2012 Friday

Tehama County eligible for emergency farm loans

BYLINE: Corning Observer, Calif.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 248 words


Aug. 17--Tehama County is eligible for US Department of Agriculture emergency
farm loans because of damages and losses caused by the drought occuring Feb. 21
through May 14, according to the Farm Service Agency.

In all, 43 California counties and contiguous counties were named eligible for
the emergency loans, including Colusa, Glenn, Butte and Shasta.

Farmers in all named counties have eight months to apply for the loans to help
cover part of their actual losses. Some of the eligibility requirements are:

--Have suffered at least a 30 percent loss of normal production directly related
to the above-cited cause,

--Be able to repay the loan and any other loans,

--Be unable to obtain credit elsewhere,

--Have adequate security,

--Have multi-peril crop insurance, if available, and

--Meet other eligibility criteria.

All applicants must complete a certification of disaster losses, which reflects
the exact date and nature of the designated disaster and how it caused the loss
or damage. Crop insurance field reports may be a source for documenting losses
directly related to the cited cause.

The authorization for Farm Service Agency to accept emergency loan applications
under this authorization expires on March 12, 2013.

Applications should be filed with the FSA Service Center at 2 Sutter St., Red
Bluff, CA 95988 or call 527-3013.

                           The Ottawa Herald (Kansas)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                               May 7, 2010 Friday

Farm damaged by winter storms? You may be eligible for emergency loan

BYLINE: The Ottawa Herald, Kan.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 343 words


May 7--Emergency loans are available for farmers in Franklin and surrounding
counties.

Farmers in Anderson, Coffey, Douglas, Franklin, Johnson, Linn, Miami, Osage and
Shawnee counties who suffered crop or livestock losses because of severe winter
storms and snowstorms Dec. 22 and Jan. 8 now can apply for Farm Service Agency
(FSA) emergency loans, FSA Farm Loan Manager Stacy L. Kull said in a news
release.

Applications for assistance will be accepted by FSA until Nov. 9.

FSA loans covering physical losses may be used to replace installations,
equipment, livestock or buildings, including homes, lost through this disaster,
Kull said.

FSA loans covering production losses may be used to buy feed, seed, fertilizer,
livestock or to make payments on real estate and chattel debts, she said.

"Loans covering physical and/or production losses may be made at a 3.75-percent
interest rate and are scheduled for repayment as rapidly as feasible, consistent
with the applicant's reasonable ability to pay," Kull said.

To be eligible for an emergency disaster loan, an applicant must be operating a
family size farm or ranch, must be unable to get credit elsewhere and must have
suffered a qualifying physical and/or production loss from the disaster.

"Funds can also be used for other essential operating and living expenses," Kull
said.

Farmers who suffered at least a 30-percent reduction to at least one cropping
enterprise may have a qualifying production loss.  Emergency disaster production
loss loans cover 100 percent of qualifying losses.

Farmers and ranchers who think they may eligible should contact the FSA county
office in Ottawa at (785) 242-3527.

                          Mineral Wells Index (Texas)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                              June 20, 2008 Friday

Farmers, ranchers eligible for help as part of area disaster declaration

BYLINE: Libby Cluett, Mineral Wells Index, Texas

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 449 words


Jun. 20--Local farmers and ranchers affected by fires and high winds earlier
this year could be eligible for emergency loan assistance from the U.S.
Department of Agriculture's Farm Service Agency.

"Palo Pinto County is included in a natural disaster area as designated by the
Secretary of Agriculture on May 15 according to information [I] received this
week," County Judge Mike Smiddy stated in a press release.

Ten counties, including Young County, comprise the primary disaster area, he
stated. In addition, 53 contiguous counties are included in the natural disaster
area for damages and losses caused by fires and high winds beginning on Jan. 1.

"This designation makes farm operators eligible to be considered for
low-interest emergency loans from the Farm Service Agency," Smiddy said. "Loan
applications will be received through Jan. 15, 2009 for production and physical
losses."

For details on the FSA loan program, contact Farm Loan Manager Cynthia Kruger at
the Erath County Farm Loan Program Team located in Stephenville. Her number is
(254) 965-3169.

Kruger said agricultural operators must meet certain eligibility and feasibility
requirements to be eligible for emergency loans through the FSA.

"The number one thing is a 'test for credit,'" she said. "If person who
sustained a loss is eligible for credit through regular commercial lenders, then
they are ineligible for FSA loan assistance."

"In order to be also eligible, you have to have shown you sustained a 30 percent
loss in what your operation does -- [for example] wheat, peanut, melons, cattle
or hay. This designation also covers physical losses," she added. "You have to
show proof that you had damage or losses.

The current interest rate on a regular direct FSA loan is 3.125 percent and the
emergency loan rate is 3.75, according to Kruger.

"There might not be a benefit to utilizing the emergency loan when the direct
loan has a lower interest rate," she said. "However, we are able to loan more
money through the emergency loan program; the maximum principle indebtedness is
$500,000. We now have a $300,000 cap for the direct loan program."

"The emergency loan program applicant must be willing to pledge any and all
assets for collateral for the debt until the loan is repaid," Kruger added.

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                            April 26, 2006 Wednesday

County eligible for USDA emergency farm loans

SECTION: BUSN; Pg. B03sc

LENGTH: 385 words


St. Charles County family farmers may be eligible to apply for low-interest
emergency loans from the Farm Service Agency (FSA) because the county is
adjacent to one designated by the U.S. Department of Agriculture as a primary
disaster county after a series of powerful storms swept across the state in
March. On March 24, U.S. Agriculture Secretary Mike Johanns declared 27 Missouri
counties - including Lincoln County - primary disaster areas following the
severe storms, tornadoes and flooding that occurred March 11 through 13. Another
55 counties, including St.

Charles and Warren counties, were named in the declaration because they are
contiguous to one or more of the primary disaster counties. "The Consolidated
Farm and Rural Development Act permits family farmers in counties that are
contiguous to a primary disaster county to apply for emergency loans if they
meet eligibility requirements," the FSA's Bob Noellsch said in a news release.
Noellsch is the agency's farm loan manager for St. Charles, Lincoln, Warren and
Pike counties. Emergency loan applications will be accepted through Nov. 24. To
be eligible, producers must have suffered at least a 30 percent loss in crop
production or a physical loss to livestock, livestock products, real estate or
chattel. They must also have an acceptable credit history, be able to provide
collateral, be able to repay the loan and be unable to obtain credit from
commercial sources. Noellsch said eligible producers could borrow up to 100
percent of actual production or physical losses, to a maximum amount of
$500,000. Loans for crop, livestock and non-real estate losses usually are
repaid in one to seven years. Loans for physical losses to real estate usually
are repaid in 30 years. The current interest rate for emergency loans is 3.75
percent. "We look at each loan application on its own merits, taking into
account the extent of losses, security available and repayment ability,"
Noellsch said. FSA emergency loans may be used to restore or replace essential
property, pay production costs associated with the disaster year, pay essential
family living expenses, reorganize the farming operation and refinance certain
debts. For more information, visit the agency's Web site at www.fsa.usda.gov or
call Noellsch at (573) 324-3313, extension 2.

                       The Natchez Democrat (Mississippi)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             October 6, 2008 Monday

County farmers may get emergency loans

BYLINE: Vershal Hogan, The Natchez Democrat, Miss.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 305 words


Oct. 6--NATCHEZ -- Farmers, ranchers and other producers in the area may be
eligible for emergency loans following the recent presidential disaster
declaration.

Adams County was one of eight Mississippi counties that are included in the
areas eligible for aid following the presidential declaration of disaster in the
wake of Hurricane Gustav, Farm Service Agency Farm Loan Manager David K. Smith
said in a statement.

The loans will be available through the Lincoln and Pike County office of the
Farm Service Agency.

Those who qualify for the emergency loans have the option of borrowing as much
as 100 percent of their actual production loss, or they may borrow whatever
amount is needed to return their operation to its condition before the disaster,
depending on which one is less.

However, the loans and the principal outstanding balance of any other loan owned
by an individual borrower or a borrower within a business entity cannot exceed
$500,000.

Loans from the Farm Service Agency are designed to cover losses from designated
disasters, and are offered to farmers who cannot obtain credit from other
lending agencies in the area.

The Lincoln County FSA office can be reached at 601-833-9321 extension 2, and
the Pike County office can be reached at 601-684-2584 extension 2.

Other counties included in the disaster designation include Amite, Claiborne,
Copiah, Franklin, Lawrence, Lincoln and Pike Counties.

                        Watertown Daily Times (New York)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           October 18, 2007 Thursday

Emergency farm loans offered in Jefferson County, N.Y., due to dry spell

BYLINE: Rachael Hanley, Watertown Daily Times, N.Y.

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 398 words


Oct. 18--They've welcomed recent rain, and now Jefferson County farmers may
receive another form of relief after a six-month dry spell.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture will offer disaster emergency loan assistance
through the local Farm Service Agency. The decision comes after the north
country experienced a severe drought, with a rain deficit of almost 6 inches
between May and October.

The disaster emergency loan assistance was put in place Oct. 12 "due to damages
and losses caused by drought which occurred on May 1, 2007 and continuing,"
according to the FSA news release.

Under the program, which is run by the service agency (formerly Farmers Home
Administration), local farmers will be able to receive financial assistance for
crop shortcomings.

To qualify, farmers must show evidence that they have lost at least 30 percent
of their production as a result of the drought.

They can then qualify for loans of up to 80 percent of the actual losses, the
amount needed to stay in business, or a maximum principal balance of $500,000,
whichever is less. The interest rate on the loans is 3.75 percent and the loans
typically extend over a seven-year term.

Farmers also must show that they cannot receive a similar loan at a commercial
bank.

Larry M. Laribee, farm loan manager at the Watertown FSA, said his agency does
not yet know how many farms will apply. He said the loans cover fruit and
vegetable crops, but are likely to be used most by dairy farmers with production
losses for hay, corn and other forage crops.

This is the first time in more than 20 years that such loans have been made
available to farmers after a north country drought, said Laribee.

"We've done emergency loans for ice storm damage and also during a microburst,
when a couple of barns burned down," said Laribee. "There's been nothing for
drought in this area."

Applications for the emergency loans will be accepted until June 12. The local
FSA office is at 21168 Route 232, town of Watertown.

                                August 16, 2012

Some Farmers With Physical Loss May Be Eligible for Emergency Loan

BYLINE: Lyon County News, Inc. staff

LENGTH: 317  words


County Executive Director, Carol Groen, announced that farm operators who have
suffered physical losses caused by high winds on May 27, 2012 may be eligible
for an emergency loan. Applications for assistance should be completed at the
Osceola County FSA Office located at 1672 Highway 60 Blvd, Sibley, Iowa.

"This Administrator's Notification for Lyon county has been issued as a primary
disaster county, thus making producers eligible for emergency loans", said
Groen.

The Farm Service Agency may make Emergency Loans to eligible family farmers
which will enable them to return to their normal operations if they sustained
qualifying losses resulting from natural disasters. Physical loss loans may be
made to eligible farmers to enable them to repair or replace damaged or
destroyed physical property essential to the success of the farming operation.
Examples of property commonly affected include; essential farm buildings,
fixtures to real estate, equipment, livestock, perennial crops, fruit and nut
bearing trees and harvested or stored crops.

Applicants must be unable to obtain credit from other usual sources to qualify
for the Farm Service Agency Farm Loan Program assistance. The intereste rate for
the emergency loans is 3.75%. Each applicant applying for credit will be given
equal consideration without regard to race, creed, color, marital status or
national origin.

The repayment schedule for most disaster loans are based on the useful life of
the security, the applicant's repayment ability, and the type of loss. If the
loan is secured only on crops, it must be repaid when the next crop year's
income is received. Loans to replace fixtures to the real estate may be
scheduled for repayment up to 40 years.

The final date for making applications is March 4, 2013.

For more information on these and other FSA programs, please contact us at
712-754-3643 or visit FSA on-line at www.fsa.usda.gov.

FSA emergency loans available

BYLINE: West Lyon Herald staff

LENGTH: 236  words


Farm operators in Lyon county who have suffered major forage/crop production
and/or physical losses caused by severe storms and flooding occurring July
21-July 30, 2010, may be eligible for an emergency loan. Applications for
assistance should be completed at the Lyon County Farm Service Agency office,
710 N. Second Ave. East, Rock Rapids.

The agency may make emergency loans to eligible family farmers which will enable
them to return to their normal operations if they sustained qualifying losses
resulting from natural disasters.

Physical loss loans may be made to eligible farmers to enable them to repair or
replace damaged or destroyed physical property essential to the success of the
farming operation. Examples of property commonly affected include: essential
farm buildings, fixtures to the real estate, equipment, livestock, perennial
crops, fruit and nut bearing trees and harvested or stored crops.

Applicants must be unable to obtain credit from other usual sources to qualify
for Farm Service Agency Farm loan program assistance. The interest rate for the
emergency loans is 3.75 percent.

Most of the disaster loans may be for up to seven years; however, if the loan is
secured only on crops, it must be repaid when the next crop year's income is
received. Loans to replace fixtures to the real estate may be scheduled for
repayment up to 40 years.

The final date for making applications is May 23, 2011.

                               September 10, 2015

Emergency Loans Available from FSA

BYLINE: Western Kansas World staff

LENGTH: 428  words


"Farmers in Rooks and Graham Counties, who suffered crop losses due to drought,
winter kill, and insect infestation occurring January 1, 2015 and continuing may
now apply for Farm Service Agency (FSA) emergency loans," FSA Farm Loan Manager,
Randal R. Thiel, said today. Applications for assistance will be accepted by FSA
until April 26, 2016.

"Loans covering physical and/or production losses are scheduled for repayment as
rapidly as feasible, consistent with the applicant's reasonable ability to pay,"
said Thiel. The current interest rate is 3.625 percent but is subject to monthly
changes until the loan is approved.

FSA's Farm Loan Programs staff is committed to new and existing customers, FSA
customer goals and our rural communities. FSA's service extends beyond the
typical loan, offering FSA customers ongoing consultation, advice and creative
ways to make your farm business thrive. At the Farm Service Agency, we want to
be your lender of first opportunity to overcome these adverse weather conditions
and rebuild your operation to get back on track. FSA's loan staff can refer
customers to other public and commercial financing sources that can serve as a
blend with FSA's farm loan programs.

FSA loans covering physical losses may be used to replace installations,
equipment, livestock, or buildings (including homes), lost through this
disaster.

FSA loans covering production losses may be used to buy feed, seed, fertilizer,
livestock, or to make payments on real estate and chattel debts. "Funds can also
be used for other essential operating and living expenses," Thiel said.

To be eligible for an emergency disaster loan, an applicant must be operating a
family size farm or ranch, must be unable to get credit elsewhere, and must have
suffered a qualifying physical and/or production loss from the disaster.

Farmers who suffered at least a 30 percent reduction to at least one cropping
enterprise, may have a qualifying production loss. Emergency disaster production
loss loans cover 100 percent of qualifying losses.

Farmers and ranchers that think they may eligible should contact the FSA County
Office in Hill City, Kansas or call 785-421-2115 for additional information and
how to apply. USDA is an equal opportunity provider and employer. To file a
complaint of discrimination, write: USDA, Office of the Assistant Secretary for
Civil Rights, Office of Adjudication, 1400 Independence Ave., SW, Washington, DC
20250-9410 or call (866) 632-9992 (Toll-free Customer Service), (800) 877-8339
(Local or Federal relay), (866) 377-8642 (Relay voice users).

                               February 18, 2010

Deadline for FSA emergency disaster loan applications

BYLINE: The Prairie Post staff

LENGTH: 415  words


The expiration dates for filing applications for Emergency Disaster (EM) loans
by farmers and ranchers in Chase, Greenwood, Lyon, Marion, Morris, Wabaunsee and
Woodson Counties are February 25, 2010, for those needing farm credit as a
result of severe storm's, flooding, winds and tornadoes from April 14-May 16,
2009; and February 24, 2010, for those needing farm credit as a result of severe
winter storm with snow from March 26-29, 2009, and who think they are eligible
for FSA assistance. They should make their applications at the FSA County
Office, 3020 W. 18th Avenue, Emporia, KS 66801, before the expiration date.

According to Jane Armitage, Farm Loan Manager, for the FSA, "Loans covering

Lauderdale County farmers eligible for emergency loans

BYLINE: The Meridian Star, Miss.

Nov. 04--Emergency loans for farmers, ranchers and operators are available
through the Lauderdale County Office of the Farm Service Agency, according to

Secretary Tom Vilsack's Oct. 21 declaration of a major disaster in Mississippi

pre-disaster condition, whichever is less, an FSA press release states.

The new emergency loan and outstanding principal balance of any existing
emergency loan owed by the applicant or any individual member of an entity
cannot exceed $500,000, according to the press release.

FSA emergency loans cover losses from designated disasters and are made to
qualified farmers who cannot obtain credit from other lenders in the local area.

BYLINE: Taylor Aswell, The Natchez Democrat, Miss.

Jan. 03--NATCHEZ -- Adams County farmers who have experienced losses this year
are eligible for disaster loans through the U.S. Department of Agriculture.

"Emergency loans for farmers, ranchers and operators are available through the
Lincoln and Pike County Office of the Farm Service Agency," David K. Smith, FSA
Farm Loan Manager said in a press release.

The loans are to help farmers dealing with problems caused by the current
drought period that began March 23.

Any farmers who experienced damages or losses due to the drought are eligible
for the loan.

Adams, Claiborne, Jefferson and Wilkinson counties are contiguous to the primary
natural disaster area in Louisiana that was declared on Nov. 30, making the
counties eligible for Federal Disaster assistance pursuant to the Consolidated
Farm and Rural Development Act.

Representatives from the Lincoln County FSA said farmers have until Aug. 1 to
apply for the loans, and that affected farmers need to take advantage of the
program.

While there is no FSA office in Adams County, farmers in the county can contact
their local farm agents or visit the loan offices in Pike and Lincoln counties
for an application.

According to the press release, farmers qualifying for the emergency loans may
borrow up to 100 percent of their actual production loss, or the amount needed
to restore their operation to its pre-disaster condition.

Farmers will receive aid in whichever amount is less.

The new emergency loan and outstanding principal balance of any existing
emergency loan owed by the farmer applying for the loan cannot surpass $500,000.

Emergency loans from the FSA cover the losses from designated disasters and are
made to farmers who qualify but cannot receive credit help from other local
lenders in the area.

                    Quay County Sun (Tucumcari, New Mexico)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            January 15, 2013 Tuesday

Officials offering emergency farm loans

BYLINE: Thomas Garcia, Quay County Sun, Tucumcari, N.M.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 380 words


Jan. 15--Federal officials are offering emergency loans after declaring eastern
New Mexico a disaster area due to extreme drought conditions.

Curry, Quay and Roosevelt counties are among 19 in New Mexico designated as a
primary natural disaster areas Secretary of Agriculture Tom Vilsack.

According to drought data from the USDA, Quay, Curry, Roosevelt and much of
eastern New Mexico has been listed in D3 (drought extreme) conditions since Nov.
20, 2012.

Under a new USDA initiative, severe drought disasters are declared when any
portion of a county meets the D2 (Drought-Severe) intensity for eight or more
consecutive weeks or D3 (Drought-Extreme) or higher at any time during the
growing season.

Portions of Curry and Roosevelt have been listed as D4 Exceptional.

U.S. Rep. Ben Ray Lujan highlighted efforts by the federal government to assist
farmers and ranchers who have been negatively impacted by the severe drought in
New Mexico and across much of the country.

"Last year was the hottest year ever in the United States, leaving farmers and
ranchers across New Mexico struggling in the face of devastating drought
conditions. We have also been impacted by a lack of rain and snowfall during the
monsoon and winter months," Lujan said. "The disaster declarations by the
Secretary of Agriculture will make important resources available to help farmers
make ends meet during this difficult time."

Lujan said the designation makes all counties in New Mexico's Third
Congressional District eligible for assistance from the Farm Service Agency
(FSA), including FSA emergency loans.

Farmers and ranchers in Curry, Roosevelt and Quay County have until Sept. 9 to
apply for emergency loan assistance, said Bob Ledingham, FSA farm loan manager
in Clovis.

Ledingham said emergency loan funds may be used to:

--Restore or replace essential property

--Pay all or part of production costs associated with the disaster year

--Pay essential family living expenses

--Reorganize the farming operation

--Refinance certain debts, excluding real estate

Those wanting to apply for the loans can contact the FSA office in Clovis at 575
762 4769 Ext. 2.

Seven SC counties qualify for USDA emergency loans

Aug. 31--SALUDA -- Saluda and Edgefield Counties are eligible for USDA
assistance as a result of a U.S. Department of Agriculture disaster designation
declared for one primary and six contiguous counties in South Carolina.

Wilfred L. Pace, state executive director of the USDA Farm Service Agency, said
the disaster designation is a result of losses caused by drought that occurred
from Aug. 9.

The decision makes all qualified farm operators in the designated areas eligible
for low-interest emergency loans from USDA's Farm Service Agency.

the designated counties are eligible for EM loans, provided eligibility
requirements are met. Farmers in eligible counties have eight months from the
date of the declaration to apply for loans to help cover part of their actual
losses.

FSA will consider each loan application on its own merits, taking into account
the extent of losses, security available and repayment ability. FSA has a
variety of programs, in addition to the emergency loan program, to help eligible
farmers recover from adversity.

USDA has also made other programs available to assist farmers and ranchers,
including the Federal Crop Insurance and the Noninsured Crop Disaster Assistance
Program.

Interested farmers can contact their local USDA Service Centers for further
information on eligibility requirements and application procedures for these and
other programs. Additional information is also available at
disaster.fsa.usda.gov.

                   The Record-Eagle (Traverse City, Michigan)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             June 7, 2008 Saturday

Farmers consider emergency assistance

BYLINE: Victor Skinner, The Record-Eagle, Traverse City, Mich.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 442 words


Jun. 7--BUCKLEY -- A months-long drought left Wayne and Carol Bancroft in the
dust last summer amid the ruins of alfalfa, corn and wheat crops on their
600-acre farm in Grand Traverse County.

The dry stretch prompted the U.S. Department of Agriculture last year to
designate the entire state a natural disaster area and offer emergency loans to
farmers who experienced significant crop loss.

The deadline to apply for loans is next month, leaving farmers like the
Bancrofts just over a month to weigh options.

"I know that we have considered it ... but we haven't fully gone through with it
yet," Carol Bancroft said. "There is no question if we are eligible because of
our grossly diminished harvest from last year, but ... what if the same thing
happens this year and now you have taken on an additional loan that you can't
repay."

Weather-related events affected more than 1,000 growers across northwest
Michigan last year and those who lost more than 30 percent of their crops are
eligible for emergency loans.

The deadline to apply for loans associated with the drought is July 7, said
James Monroe, farm loan manager with the Farm Service Agency in Traverse City.

Emergency loans also are offered to area farmers whose crops were damaged from
frost between April 4 and June 13, 2007, as well as hail, rain or high wind
damage between May 15 and September 11, 2007, Monroe said.

Farms in Grand Traverse, Benzie, Leelanau, Kalkaska and Antrim counties are
eligible for those loans. Loan applications for frost damage must be submitted
by July 14. July 21 is the deadline for loans to cover hail, rain or wind
damage.

Farmers are charged 3.75 percent interest over terms ranging from one to seven
years, depending on the collateral, Monroe said.

Monroe, who thus far has processed about 10 applications for last season, said
the low-interest loans can be a viable way to keep farm operations rolling after
a rough year, but it isn't something most farmers take on without pause.

"You are borrowing to cover what you lost and paying for it with future
earnings," he said. "I think the farmer has a natural tendency to try not to
burden themselves more than they have to, but the loans are available if they
feel that there is a need."

To see more of The Record-Eagle or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.record-eagle.com/. Copyright (c) 2008, The Record-Eagle, Traverse
City, Mich. Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For reprints,
email tmsreprints@permissionsgroup.com, call 800-374-7985 or 847-635-6550, send
a fax to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group Inc., 1247 Milwaukee
Ave., Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

                                August 17, 2010

Three more counties eligible for Farm Service Loans

BYLINE: The Ortonville Independent staff

LENGTH: 370  words


On April 4, 2010, Pesident Obama declared a Presidential Major Disaster in
Minnesota due to flooding occurring March 1, 2010 and continuing. Eighteen
counties and the Tribal Nation of the Upper Sioux Community in Minnesota were
declared primary disaster counties eligible for Federal disaster assistance,
including Farm Service Agency (FSA) Emergency (EM) loans for eligible family
farmers. Lac qui Parle and Yellow Medicine Counties were declared primary
disaster counties.

In addition to the primary disaster counties, 28 Minnesota counties were named
as contiguous disaster counties where eligible family farmers may qualify for
FSA EM loan assistance. Lincoln and Lyon counties were designated as contiguous
disaster counties.

This determination is coded Ml900. Em loan applications will be accepted through
Dec. 20, 2010 for physical and

production losses.

Emergency loan funds may be used to:

Restore or replace essential property;

Pay all or part of production costs associated with the disaster year;

Pay essential family living expenses;

Reorganize the farming operation; and

Refinance certain debts. Emergency loans may be made to

farmers and rancher who:

Own or operate land located in a county declared a disaster area;

Are established family farm operators and have sufficient farming or ranching
experience;

Are citizens or permanent residents of the United States;

Have suffered at least a 30 percent loss in crop production; or Physical loss to
livestock, livestock products, real estate or farm chattel property;

Have an acceptable credit history;

Are unable to receive credit from commercial sources;

Can provide collateral to secure the loan; and

Have repayment ability.

Producers can borrow up to 100 percent of actual production or physical losses
not to exceed $500,000. The Emergency Loan (EM) interest rate is 3.75 percent.
EM loans are normally repaid over a 1-7 year period. However, in special
circumstances terms of up to 20 years may be authorized. Loans for physical
losses to real estate are normally repaid within 30 years. In certain
circumstances, repayment may be made over a maximum of 40 years.

For further information contact Farm Service Agency, Farm Loan Programs at
507-537-1401 Ext. 104, Marshall, MN.

                               The New York Times

                 July 12, 1987, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

The Biggest Farm Debt: $68 Million and Growing

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1, Column 2; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 3448 words

DATELINE: BAKERSFIELD, Calif.


ALL that is left of the Tex-Cal Land Management grape and almond farm lies
behind an old winery near the San Joaquin Valley town of Delano, where acres of
junked tractors, pickup trucks, earth scrapers and plows gather dust under a
scorching sun.

And all that remains for the Farmers Home Administration, the Agriculture
Department's farm lending agency and Tex-Cal's biggest creditor, is an enormous
debt - $68 million - that is growing by nearly $13,000 a day.

It is, by far, the largest sum ever owed to the United States by a single farm,
and there is little likelihood, say Agriculture Department officials, that even
a tiny portion of it will ever be recovered.

The unpaid debt represents the most glaring failure of two farm agency emergency
loan programs, which were designed to save distressed farmers but produced
nearly $6 billion in uncollectible loans. The vast majority of the delinquent
loans resulted from the depression in agriculture that began in 1981. But the
Tex-Cal case illustrates a darker side of the programs, which critics have
attacked for their easy lending policies and lax oversight.

Tex-Cal collapsed four years ago amid allegations that much of the money it
borrowed was improperly diverted for personal and other uses through a complex
network of sister companies. The Tex-Cal affair has left deep scars in Delano,
the nearby Kern County seat of Bakersfield and elsewhere in the southern part of
the valley, the nation's richest and most diverse agricultural region.

Several labor contractors who were owed hundreds of thousands of dollars by
Tex-Cal have gone bankrupt and others who did business with the company have
suffered severe financial distress following the collapse. More than 20 lawsuits
alleging fraud, deceit and theft have been filed in the state courts, pitting
the company's founder, Dudley M. (Bud) Steele Jr., against his son and other
former Tex-Cal executives. The Department of Justice has brought a civil fraud
suit against the company, Mr. Steele and others, and is pursuing a criminal
investigation. And private banks have become wary of lending to other growers in
the region, situated more than 100 miles northwest of Los Angeles, and have
rejected some loans that ordinarily would have been approved.

''It's like a house fire that just won't go out,'' said Jack Pandol, of the
Delano-based Pandol Brothers Inc., a farm and produce marketing company.

Tex-Cal's failure has also had an effect far beyond the valley. By highlighting
the severe management and control problems at the Farmers Home Administration,
the collapse reaffirmed the Reagan Administration's efforts to sharply limit the
emergency loan programs.

One of the programs gave farmers who had sustained damage from natural disasters
unlimited long-term, low-interest financing to reorganize operations and
refinance debts. The other, a short-lived program for ''economic emergencies''
tied to market fluctuations, provided up to $400,000 in financing.

But the liberal terms of the two programs encouraged many farmers to take on
enormous debt in the 1970's and early 1980's, when farm prices and incomes began
to plummet. The programs thus may have hastened the failures of tens of
thousands of farmers, state and Federal farm economists say.

At the same time, the huge number of delinquencies seriously weakened the loan
portfolio of the agency, the nation's second-largest farm lender after the Farm
Credit System, a nationwide network of lending institutions owned by farmers
that is also in serious financial trouble.

Nowhere did farmers take greater advantage of the emergency loan programs than
in Kern County, which produced crops, including fruits, vegetables, nuts and
cotton, valued at $1.4 billion last year.

The vast irrigated desert that lies between the Coast Range and the purple
flanks of the Sierra Nevada is home to some of the biggest farms in the nation.
The farm operated by Tex-Cal Land Management Inc., for instance, consisted of
7,300 acres divided into 40 parcels that sprawled for 80 miles through Kern and
nearby Tulare County. A typical Kern County farm employs hundreds of workers and
large fleets of tractors, crop dusters and other equipment, and it is not
unusual for it to report annual sales of $10 million or more. In short, Kern
County farmers practice a form of power agriculture found in few other regions
of the world.

In the winter of 1978, a brutal wind blew into the valley, carrying with it
torrential rains that ruined many harvests. The damage caused hundreds of
growers to descend on the Farmers Home Administration office in Bakersfield,
many of whom had only recently become eligible for the loans when the programs
were opened up to bigger farm operations. [See box.] The farmers discovered what
thousands of others had already found in other local offices of the agency: tiny
staffs, ill-prepared to handle a torrent of applications.

In order to qualify for loans, the farmers needed to produce two letters from
banks showing that commercial loan requests had been denied. They were required
to sign a statement certifying that their damage was caused by storms. And they
were asked to estimate the value of the destruction.

The agency did not audit the damage claims before granting loans, and only in a
few instances were claims investigated after loans were made, according to
agency officials.

''We were concerned, but we did not perceive it to be a cause for alarm,'' said
Jerry Byington, a former farmer programs specialist in the agency's California
headquarters in Woodland. ''In hindsight, maybe we could have done some things
differently.''

More than half of the $425 million lent to California farmers in 1979 under the
emergency loan programs was awarded by the Bakersfield office. In 1977, only $12
million in such loans were issued in all of California.

In Kern County, some of the wealthiest and most influential farmers took
advantage of the Government programs. ''There was cheap money to be had and some
farmers said let's go get all we can,'' said J. Hodge Black, a University of
California farm specialist based in Bakersfield.

Five of the 12 farms in the nation that still owe the Government more than $10
million from emergency loans are in Kern County. But only the one operated by
Tex-Cal Land Management has been accused of fraud.

Tex-Cal was established by Bud Steele in 1973 to manage his farm, which at that
time amounted to about 1,700 acres. Mr. Steele, then 47 years old, had been a
prominent farmer for years in Delano and was voted Man of the Year in 1964 by
the Chamber of Commerce.

Many of the bigger growers in the San Joaquin Valley had also formed separate
management companies, said lawyers familiar with the valley's farming practices.
The companies, set up with little or no assets in their own names, provided
growers with a ''corporate veil'' that shielded their land from such legal
problems as claims brought by farm laborers for injuries or back wages. The
structure also made it harder for outsiders, including lenders, to get a clear
picture of a farm's finances.

Through Tex-Cal Land Management, Mr. Steele borrowed nearly $18 million between
1973 and 1979 from the Wells Fargo Bank, the Aetna Casualty and Surety Company
and the Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company.

Mr. Steele used the funds to expand his farm operation to more than 7,000 acres
and the lenders took first liens on all of the property as collateral. In 1978,
the management company reported crop sales of almost $9 million from 20 acres of
kiwis, 160 acres of prunes, 900 acres of almonds and more than 6,000 acres of
wine and table grape vineyards. The company had about 300 full-time employees
and brought in about 1,200 more during peak harvest periods.

For years, however, Mr. Steele often missed paying annual installments on his
commercial loans, his creditors' records show. At the time that Mr. Steele and
his only son, Dudley R. (Randy) Steele, applied for the Federal emergency loans
in 1979, claiming that flooding had damaged their crops, Bud Steele's creditors
already were threatening to foreclose on the property.

The Federal loans were granted that summer. Farmers Home Administration
documents show that Randy Steele signed, and his father co-signed, promissory
notes for a 20-year, $250,000 loan at 3 percent interest, and two 40-year $6
million loans at 9 percent.

The infusion of Federal funds allowed the Steeles to refinance their bank debts.
Wells Fargo's loan was retired, while Aetna and Northwestern remained creditors
holding first liens on the land. The farmers' lending agency received a second
lien on the land, which then had a market value that far exceeded the combined
Federal and commercial loans.

The Federal aid also allowed the Steeles to reorganize the farm's operations.
Within two years, more than half a dozen sister corporations sprouted around
Tex-Cal Land Management, forming a network with several other associated
operations already in place. Several of the new companies had no assets at all.

The network included Tex-Cal Sales, which sold crops directly to markets; a cold
storage company to store the crops; a pesticide spraying operation; a materials
supply company; an air carrier, and an accounting firm to manage the books of
each corporation. Most of the sister corporations were either owned or
controlled by Bud Steele, according to corporate records and the Government.

In court papers, Bud Steele said that he turned over ownership and control of
Tex-Cal Land Management to his son in 1979 and that responsibility for all
Federal loans rested with Randy. Bud Steele insisted the other companies were
legally separate from Tex-Cal Land Management.

In essence, Mr. Steele was building a vertically integrated operation that paid
itself for services and materials, a structure modeled after many other major
farm operations in the southern San Joaquin Valley, although more intricate than
most. Bob Cox, a reporter who has covered Tex-Cal for The Bakersfield
Californian, labeled the corporate maze a ''Steele web.''

But Mr. Steele was putting his empire together with Government loans, the
Justice Department fraud suit alleges. Using such loans to enlarge farm
operations is prohibited under the emergency aid programs, Government lawyers
contend.

OVER the next four years, despite increasing misgivings about the size of
Tex-Cal's debt and its failure to repay most of the annual installments, the
Farmers Home Administration approved additional loans to the company of more
than $39 million, all secured by crop sales. The agency's former administrator,
Charles Shuman, later explained that $15.2 million of those final loans were
approved as ''protective advances'' because the agency feared it would lose
everything if the company was not kept solvent.

Tex-Cal went out of business in late 1983, however, having repaid only $9
million of its Federal loans, according to agency records. Yet in its last four
years of operation, Tex-Cal reported to the agency that it had sold crops valued
at $52 million. (Several former executives of Tex-Cal have testified in court
cases that the company hid millions of dollars in additional sales from the farm
agency.) In all, that added up to at least $104 million that Tex-Cal took in
through loans and crop sales between 1979 and 1983. The Government contends in
its lawsuit that that was more than enough to enable Tex-Cal to recover from the
flood damage and keep up with its payments. The only reason it could not, the
Government says, is that millions of dollars were diverted for other purposes,
including the purchase of the old winery near Delano where the farm's equipment
now lies collecting dust. Tex-Cal still owes the Government nearly $43 million
in principal and $25 million in interest.

In a recent interview, Bud Steele denied that he had done anything wrong and
insisted that the money was simply ''farmed up.'' But even in Kern County, where
farmers regularly spend $2,600 an acre to raise grapes and almonds, it is
unlikely that Tex-Cal sank $100 million into its land and crops in four years,
said Mr. Black, the University of California farm specialist. In fact, during
its last four years of operation, Tex-Cal's vineyards were overgrown and poorly
maintained, Jack Pandol and other Delano growers said in interviews, indicating
that the farm was not spending enough on irrigation, fertilizer and labor.

Another explanation for missing funds emerged in the spring of 1983 when Randy
Steele and Robert G. Bartholomew, the chief financial officer of Tex-Cal, said
publicly that they had uncovered evidence that the company's books had been
altered to disguise diversions of funds by Bud Steele. Randy Steele reported the
alleged alterations to the farm agency and called his father a thief in a sworn
statement filed in connection with one of the lawsuits in the case.

Bud Steele responded by accusing his son and Mr. Bartholomew of trying to
disguise their own mismanagement. The charges and countercharges led to a tangle
of ongoing lawsuits that have turned father and son into enemies.

The allegations of fraud and mismanagement also led to the start of several
Federal investigations, first by the Agriculture Department's Office of
Inspector General and then by the Department of Justice.

On May 2, 1986, the Government filed a civil suit in Fresno, Calif., against
Tex-Cal Land Management, two of the sister companies, Bud Steele and Betty
Kruger, Tex-Cal's secretary-treasurer. The suit accuses them of conspiracy,
fraud, conversion and violations of the False Claims Act. At the heart of the
Government's case is the contention that Bud Steele never actually relinquished
control of the management company to his son and that he is responsible for the
wrongdoing and is liable for the loans. The Government is seeking full repayment
and other damages, but it is unclear how Mr. Steele could pay since he filed for
personal bankruptcy earlier this year and all of the sister companies are either
out of business or in bankruptcy themselves.

In the suit, the Government charged that ''substantial amounts'' of the Federal
loans were used for such purposes as improvements on Bud Steele's house in
Delano, personal expenses of Bud Steele and Mr. Bartholomew and the ''funding of
other business entities all owned or controlled by'' Bud Steele. (Neither Randy
Steele nor Mr. Bartholomew has been named as a defendant in the lawsuit.) The
loan proceeds were ''co-mingled'' with funds of the sister corporations, the
Government contends in the suit, which is still in the pretrial stage. Moreover,
an unknown amount of funds was ''converted'' in the form of checks made out to
people and businesses that did not exist.

THE Government also charges that Bud Steele conspired with Betty Kruger and the
other defendants to make false statements on loan applications about the farm's
income.

In a related criminal investigation by the Internal Revenue Service, one of Mr.
Steele's bookkeepers pleaded guilty last year to tax evasion charges stemming
from tens of thousands of dollars in payments she made to herself from Farmers
Home Administration funds.

Bud Steele, who is now 60 years old, said the farm agency ''was conned, but it
wasn't by me.'' Mr. Steele blamed his son and Mr. Bartholomew for the collapse
of the company and said ''they may have gotten away with some dough.''

Randy Steele, who is 37 years old, and Mr. Bartholomew, 45, declined requests
for interviews. But Mary Jane Steele, Randy's wife, denied that her husband was
involved in any wrongdoing. ''We're hoping to put this nightmare behind us,''
she said. Randy Steele now works as a supervisor in a fruit packing house near
Fresno.

Theda Bartholomew said that her husband, who is now a financial consultant in
Bakersfield, was himself a victim of the Tex-Cal collapse. Bud Steele, she said,
''has to blame somebody for what happened, so he's saying these things about my
husband and his own son.''

Mrs. Kruger declined through her lawyer, John Patrick Moore of Fresno, to be
interviewed. Mr. Moore insisted, however, that she, too, had done nothing wrong.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Justice Department are continuing to
investigate the case and a Federal grand jury is hearing evidence in Fresno.

These days, Bud Steele is spending his nights in the Tulare County Correctional
Facility in Visalia, an hour north of Delano, serving a six-month work-furlough
term for contempt of a Superior Court judge's order. The contempt charges stem
from repeated violations of state agricultural labor laws on Tex-Cal's farmland.

Earlier this year, Aetna and Northwestern took over almost all of the land in
separate foreclosure actions. Because of sharply lower land values, the second
liens held by the Farmers Home Administration turned out to be worthless.

TURNING THE LENDING SPIGOT ON AND OFF

The Farmers Home Administration began to help growers hurt by natural disasters
in 1949, when Congress authorized low-interest, long-term loans to small farm
operators wiped out by storms.

In 1972, after Hurricane Agnes swept across the East and South, Congress
increased funding for the emergency disaster loan program and loosened some of
its lending rules. Six years later, when storms caused more widespread damage,
Congress made even the biggest corporate growers eligible for loans. It also put
into place a new ''economic emergency'' loan program for farms that suffered
losses from changes in market conditions that were beyond their control.

The agency's lending soared. In 1971, it lent farmers a total of $700 million -
$127 million in emergency loans and the rest in traditional farm ownership and
operating loans. In 1981, it approved $8.1 billion in new loans, $6.5 billion of
which was emergency lending.

The dramatic spurt in lending worried some observers, including several
prominent agricultural economists. They were particularly concerned that the
loans were secured by land valued at inflated prices and by incomes driven by
inflation.

''If the earnings of farmers suddenly leveled off or fell, the value of land
would then come tumbling down,'' said Emanuel Melichar, an agricultural
economist with the Federal Reserve Board who issued a warning in 1977. ''That
would leave the Government with nothing,'' he said recently, adding, ''This is
essentially what has happened with the emergency loans.''

The Reagan Administration, concerned about mounting losses, tightened the
emergency disaster program in 1982 and discontinued the economic emergency loans
two years later. Last year, only $218 million in new emergency loans were made
out of total lending of nearly $4.4 billion.

Also in 1982, the Administration directed farm lending officials to pursue tens
of thousands of delinquent borrowers. (As of last month, delinquencies amounted
to $7.8 billion of the agency's $28 billion in total outstanding debt.

The emergency loan programs accounted for nearly $6 billion of the
delinquencies.) But the agency's efforts to recover some of the funds by
foreclosures and other actions have met resistance from Congress, the courts and
leaders of rural communities. Critics argue that large-scale foreclosures would
be devastating to already depressed rural areas.

Earlier this month, Congress approved a measure sponsored by Representative
Jamie L. Whitten, a Democrat of Mississippi, that calls for the farm lending
agency to temporarily forgive the debts of thousands of its borrowers and give
them new operating loans. To qualify, the growers must demonstrate that they are
strong enough financially to pay back the new loans after one year. In effect,
the new program requires the agency to make loans to farmers even if they owe
the Government substantial amounts and are far behind in their payments. The
measure is part of a supplemental appropriations bill that is awaiting President
Reagan's signature.

Vance L. Clark, the agency's administrator, said the program would force the
Government to continue to throw good money after bad. ''It's a terrible way to
do business,'' he said. ''We're trying to be prudent lenders. But even after all
that we've been through with bad loans and losses, Congress still doesn't think
too kindly of what we're trying to do.''

Representative Whitten, however, believes the Administration's aggressive
repayment policy is ill-advised. ''The law establishing Farmers Home is very
plain,'' he said. ''It says the FmHA must do everything it can to help farmers
get started again. If the FmHA isn't going to do that, we are going to require
them to do it.''

                       Gainesville Daily Register (Texas)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             June 26, 2008 Thursday

County to get farm aid

BYLINE: Andy Hogue, Gainesville Daily Register, Texas

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 599 words


Jun. 26--Cooke County was one of several counties recently named by the
Secretary of Agriculture as eligible for loans to cover damages from a recent
round of severe spring storms.

Emergency farm loans applications are being accepted from agricultural producers
reporting damages from storms -- which resulted in tornadoes and flooding --
between April 9-28.

The applications are for production and physical losses. The final day to apply
is Jan. 9, 2009.

Applications are available and are being accepted at the Farm Service Agency
(FSA) Office located in Stephenville, Cynthia Kruger, FSA Farm Loan Manager said
in a statement Tuesday.

Farm Service Agency is a credit agency of the U.S. Department of Agriculture,
and provides disaster emergency loans to recognized farmers who work at and rely
on farming for a substantial part of their living.

Chance Fenoglio, of the Gainesville FSA, said it would be better for local
farmers and ranchers to contact the Stephenville office or visit it in person
(see contact information below).

"Those farm loan offices are more like regional offices, and our county is
served out of Erath county," Fenoglio said.

He said Cooke County crops seem to be in good shape, in general.

"The wind didn't blow any crops over, I heard no reports of hail damage," he
said. "Wheat and fall crops were better than average, though we could use some
more rain soon."

Fenoglio said the corn crop is starting to get dry -- the stalks becoming a dull
green rather than the healthy bright green.

The Milo crop looks pretty good. It can tolerate those drought conditions," he
added. "If we get a rain right now, I don't think the crops will be hurt."

Kruger said in her statement farmers may be eligible for loans up to 100 percent
of their actual losses or the operating loan required to continue in business,
whichever is less.

For farmers unable to obtain credit from private commercial lenders, the
interest rate is 3.75 percent.

"As a general rule, a farmer must have suffered at least 30 percent loss of
production to be eligible for a FSA Emergency Loan," Kruger said. "Farmers
participating in the Federal Crop Insurance Program will have to figure in
proceeds from those programs, in determining their loss."

Applications for loans under these emergency designations will be accepted until
the designated final date, but farmers should apply as soon as possible, Kruger
said. Delays in applying could create backlogs in processing and possibly over
into the new farming season.

Individual farmers who are U.S. citizens are eligible for assistance, as are
farming partnerships, corporations or cooperatives in which U.S. citizens hold a
majority interest, according to Kruger's statement.

The FSA Office in Gainesville is located at 2200 North Grand Ave., and is open
from 8 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. Monday through Friday. The office may be contacted at
668-7794.

The Erath County FSA Service Center in Stephenville is located and may be
written at: 245 S. Virgina St., Stephenville, TX, 76401-0210. The office may be
contacted at 1(254)965-3715. The office fax number is 1(254)965-4910.

Reporter Andy Hogue may be contacted at andyhoguegdr@ntin.net

To see more of the Gainesville Daily Register or to subscribe to the newspaper,
go to http://www.gainesvilleregister.com/. Copyright (c) 2008, Gainesville Daily
Register, Texas Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For
reprints, email tmsreprints@permissionsgroup.com, call 800-374-7985 or
847-635-6550, send a fax to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group
Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave., Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

                                October 10, 2012

Walsh County farmers now eligible for USDA Disaster Emergency Loans

BYLINE: Walsh County Press staff

LENGTH: 240  words


PARK RIVER, N.D. Fanners in Walsh County who suffered physical and production
losses because of drought conditions occurring September 25, 2012 and continuing
may now apply for Farm Service Agency Emergency Loans, Farm Loan Manager Don
Tongen said today.

Walsh County is eligible to receive EM loans because it was declared as a
contiguous county in North Dakota that was designated a major disaster area.

The time allowed to file EM loan applications is eight months. For Walsh County
farmers, this means the deadline for applications to be filed is June 3, 2013.

Although the authority for Emergency Loan processing has been given, all
potential EM loan applicants must be aware that they will be unable to complete
an application for loan processing until after all information for their farm
operation pertaining to actual physical losses and production losses, crop
insurance benefits, and to any other crop production compensation, is available
and can be documented.

Tongen said farmers who suffered a qualifying production loss of at least 30%
from normal and are unable to get credit elsewhere, may apply for reduced
interest loans to cover up to 100% of their losses. Farm Service Agency
Emergency loans currently carry a 2.125 percent interest rate. To qualify for
physical losses, there does have to be a qualifying loss amount.

Farmers who think they are eligible may apply for assistance at the FSA County
office at Park River. ND.

                        Lincoln Journal Star (Nebraska)

                            December 23, 2005 Friday
                                  City Edition

State Briefs

SECTION: B; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 840 words


3 FARM COUNTIES ELIGIBLE FOR EMERGENCY LOANS

Family farmers in three counties can apply for low-interest emergency loans due
to losses caused by drought and other bad weather in 2005.

The Farm Service Agency announced Wednesday emergency loan eligibility for
Chase, Dundy and Perkins counties.

The three counties became eligible for the loans because they are bordering at
least one of 10 counties in Colorado that were designated for emergency loans on
Dec. 19.

Loans for production losses can be used to buy feed, seed, fertilizer or
livestock, as well as to refinance certain debts.

To qualify, farmers must prove they incurred qualifying losses and that they are
established family farm operators. Applications must be submitted through a
local Farm Services Agency office before Aug. 21.

$1.8 MILLION WILL GOTO FIRM TO STAY IN STATE

SCOTTSBLUFF - A mortgage service firm will stay in the area after being offered
$1.8 million in economic development funds by the city.

The Scottsbluff City Council on Monday approved offering Aurora Loan Services
the money, along with additional funds coming from tax incentives.

Aurora will receive the $1.8 million over the next three years. The grant is the
most economic development funding ever offered by the city council.

Aurora considered moving to Colorado but the state of Nebraska and Twin Cities
Development created a funding package to persuade the firm to stay, said Rawnda
Pierce, executive director for Twin Cities Development.

Aurora said it will add at least 150 new employees in the next two years. Aurora
also agreed to purchase 12 acres near Western Nebraska Community College's Harms
Advanced Technology Center where it will build a new facility.

The firm's old location in Scottsbluff will be given to the city when the new
complex is completed.

CATHOLIC CHARITIES EVENT CANCELS VILLAGE PEOPLE

OMAHA - A Catholic Charities fund-raising event has decided to play it straight
- so the Village People aren't coming to town.

The group was scheduled to perform at Irish Fest in March. But Omaha Catholic
Charities Executive Director Scot Adams said that enough people expressed
concerns about appropriateness that the band was canceled.

A lot of people were worried about the band's homoerotic lyrics, Adams said.

Adams and others reviewed some of the band's lyrics before making a final
decision, he said.

The Family Stone Experience, which includes members of the 1970s psychedelic
funk band Sly and the Family Stone, has been hired as a replacement.

Adams said he's aware of reported drug use in Family Stone Experience, but the
band better fits the event's themes.

"We realize not everything a band does is perfect," he said. "We're not looking
for someone on the merits of their lifestyle."

LEGAL HELP LINE GETTING ABOUT 12 CALLS A DAY

OMAHA - A legal aid phone line for Nebraskans over 60 has handled about a dozen
calls a day since opening last week.

Legal Aid of Nebraska's Elder Access Line started Dec. 12 for senior citizens
who want help with hard-to-answer legal questions. An attorney and a paralegal
are handling the calls.

"In just 10 days we've established there's a significant demand out there for
basic legal information, particularly among people who really can't afford a
lawyer," said Annette Farnan of Legal Aid's Omaha office. "We're getting calls
from all over the state, from older women and men - and even their grown
children who have powers of attorney for their parents."

Some questions can be answered quickly, and more complicated cases are referred
to the nearest Legal Aid office.

Elder Access Line is operating out of Omaha under a $296,000 two-year federal
grant.

The agency also operates a statewide help line for low-income Nebraskans that
fields about 50,000 calls a year, executive Doug German said.

ATTORNEY GETS PROBATION FOR DEPOSIT VIOLATION

OMAHA - An attorney indicted on 15 counts related to the alleged laundering of
$175,000 in drug money to help finance an Internet gambling and pornography site
has been sentenced to house arrest and probation.

David S. Wintroub, 38, was sentenced Wednesday in U.S. District Court to five
months of probation, including five months' house arrest, on one count of
evading federal reporting requirements.

The U.S. Attorney's Office said there wasn't enough evidence to convict Wintroub
of the other 14 counts in the indictment. Those counts were dismissed, and
Wintroub pleaded guilty to structuring transactions to evade reporting
requirements.

Wintroub had received payments from convicted drug dealer Gary A. Storey to
start the Web site. Wintroub made three cash deposits, each slightly less than
$10,000, three straight days in August 2000. Banks are required to report cash
transactions of more than $10,000 to the government.

U.S. District Judge Lyle Strom ruled that, based on taped conversations between
Wintroub and Storey, Wintroub knew the deposits were to be "kept quiet."

Wintroub served as manager for former state Auditor John Breslow's unsuccessful
campaigns for governor in 1990 and 1998.

--From staff and wire reports

Emergency farm loans are available

BYLINE: El Paso Times Staff

SECTION: BUSINESS

LENGTH: 130 words


EL PASO -- Farmers in Culberson, El Paso, Hudspeth, Loving, Reeves and Winkler
counties may qualify for emergency farm loans for losses caused by drought and
high winds.

Applications for the emergency loans are being accepted at the Farm Service
Agency office in Fort Stockton, William H. McAnally, farm loan manager for the
U.S. Department of Agriculture, said in a statement.

Eleven counties in Texas were recently named by U.S. Secretary of Agriculture
Thomas J. Vilsack as eligible for loans to cover part of actual production,
physical losses or both resulting from drought and high winds.

"As a general rule, a farmer must have suffered at least a 30 percent loss of
production to be eligible for an FSA emergency loan," McAnally said.

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                April 1, 1999, Thursday, FIVE STAR LIFT EDITION

FARMERS MAY GET EMERGENCY AID

SECTION: BUSINESS, Pg. C7

LENGTH: 215 words


Missouri farmers are running into a financial squeeze because federal loans and
loan guarantees from a farm lending agency have been exhausted. But the
executive in charge of the lending agency, Dan Gierseke, said emergency loans
may be available as early as today.

The emergency aid could provide enough aid to Missouri farmers until April 16,
when Congress reconvenes to consider providing more farm assistance, said
Gierseke, speaking at a farm management training session in Columbia, Mo.

Missouri has already made more loans in the first six months than in all of last
year, said Gierseke, farm loan chief for the Farm Services Agency (FSA). "At
this rate, we will lend more money this year than we did in all of the last five
years," he said.

Gierseke said Missouri's FSA has $ 8 million in approved loans still waiting for
funding from Washington, and another 99 applications are still being processed
in FSA offices throughout the state.

Most of the emergency loans waiting to be processed are for farmers in the
Bootheel, where farmers have been hurt by low commodity prices and, last year,
by a drought and low yields.

Farmers seeking an update on the loan situation should contact their local FSA
office or call a toll-free hotline at 1-877-363-3659.

                               December 31, 2013

Farmers and ranchers qualify for natural disaster designation

BYLINE: Weiser Signal American staff

LENGTH: 877  words


Recently the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) announced that 16 counties in
Idaho were designated as primary natural disaster areas due to damages and
losses caused by the 2013 drought. However, almost all of Idaho's 44 counties
had attained this designation prior to December. All Idaho counties with the
exception of Bonner, Boundary, Kootenai, and Benewah qualify for natural
disaster assistance.

"Our hearts go out to those Idaho farmers and ranchers affected by recent
natural disasters," said Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack. "President Obama and
I are committed to ensuring that agriculture remains a bright spot in our
nation's economy by sustaining the successes of America's farmers, ranchers, and
rural communities through these difficult times. We're also telling Idaho
producers that USDA stands with you and your communities when severe weather and
natural disasters threaten to disrupt your livelihood."

"Farmers across Idaho have had to deal with severe weather conditions this past
year making them eligible for federal disaster programs," said Aaron Johnson,
Acting State Executive Director for Idaho. "Although our five major disaster
programs have not been funded due to lack of a farm bill, the Farm Service
Agency has emergency loans available at a reduced rate."

When a county receives a natural disaster designation from the Department of
Agriculture, all qualified farm operators in the designated areas are eligible
for low interest emergency (EM) loans from USDA's Farm Service Agency (FSA),
provided eligibility requirements are met. Farmers in eligible counties have
eight months from the date of the declaration to apply for loans to help cover
part of their actual losses.

FSA will consider each loan application on its own merits, taking into account
the extent of losses, security available and repayment ability. FSA has a
variety of programs, in addition to the EM loan program, to help eligible
farmers recover from adversity.

The Obama Administration remains committed to helping the thousands of farm
families and businesses struggling with natural disasters.

Actions taken by Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack in 2012 and 2013 to provide
assistance to producers impacted by the drought included:

Extended emergency grazing on Conservation Reserve Program (CRP) acres, freeing
up a record 2.8 million acres and as much as $200 million in forage and feed for
ranchers during a challenging time.

Purchased $170 million of pork, lamb, chicken, and catfish for federal food
nutrition assistance programs, including food banks, to help relieve pressure on
American livestock producers and bring the nation's meat supply in line with
demand.

Reduced the emergency loan rate, from 3.75 percent to 2.875 percent, as well as
making emergency loans available earlier in the season.

Allowing haying or grazing of cover crops without impacting the insurability of
planted 2013 spring crops.

USDA worked with crop insurance companies to provide flexibility to farmers, and
one-third of all policyholders took advantage of the extended payment period.

Authorized $16 million in existing funds from the Wildlife Habitat Incentive
Program (WHIP) and Environmental Quality Incentives

Program (EQIP) to target states experiencing exceptional and extreme drought.

Transferred $14 million in unobligated program funds into the Emergency
Conservation Program (ECP) to help farmers and ranchers rehabilitate farmland
damaged by natural disasters and for carrying out emergency water conservation
measures in periods of severe drought.

Authorized haying and grazing of Wetlands Reserve Program (WRP) easement areas
in drought-affected areas where haying and grazing is consistent with
conservation of wildlife habitat and wetlands.

Lowered the penalty on CRP acres used for emergency haying or grazing, from 25
percent to 10 percent in 2012.

Simplified the Secretarial disaster designation process and reduced the time it
takes to designate counties affected by disasters by 40 percent.

Additional programs available to assist farmers and ranchers include the
Emergency Conservation Program, Federal Crop Insurance, and the Noninsured Crop
Disaster Assistance Program.

Interested farmers may contact their local USDA Service Centers for further
information on eligibility requirements and application procedures for these and
other programs. Additional information is also available online at
http://disaster.fsa.usda.gov.

Sec. Vilsack also reminds producers that Congress has not funded the five
disaster assistance programs authorized by the 2008 Farm Bill. These are SURE;
the Livestock Indemnity Program (LIP); the Emergency Assistance for Livestock,
Honey Bees, and Farm-Raised Fish (ELAP); the Livestock Forage Disaster Program
(LFP); and the Tree Assistance Program (TAP). Production losses due to disasters
occurring after Sept. 30, 2011, are not eligible for disaster program coverage.

Our hearts go out to those Idaho farmers and ranchers affected by recent natural
disasters. President Obama and I are committed to ensuring that agriculture
remains a bright spot in our nation's economy by sustaining the successes of
America's farmers, ranchers, and rural communities through these difficult
times."

-Tom Vilsack U.S. Department of Agriculture secretary

                               November 24, 2011

Pembina County Farmers Now Eligible for USDA Disaster Emergency Loans

BYLINE: Valley News & Views staff

LENGTH: 255  words


Farmers in Pembina County who suffered physical and production losses due to
combined effects of spring snowstorms, frosts and freezes in late spring and
early fall, excessive rain, flooding, ground saturation, landslides, high winds,
hail, tornadoes, periods of unseasonably cool spring temperatures, excessive
summer heat, and weather related insects that occurred January 1, 2011 and
continuing may now apply for Farm Service Agency Emergency loans, Farm Manager
Linda Werven announced last week.

The time allowed to file loan applications is eight months for Pembina County
farmers, meaning the deadline for applications to be filed is June 25, 2012.

Although the authority for Emergency Loan processing has been given, all
potential Emergency Loan applicants must be aware that they will be unable to
complete an application for loan processing until after all information for
their farm operation pertaining to actual physical losses and production losses,
disaster payments to crop insurance benefits, and to any other crop production
compensation is available and can be documented.

Farm Loan Manager Werven said farmers who suffered a qualifying
productionlossofatleast30% from normal and are unable to get credit elsewhere,
may apply for reduced interest loans to cover up to 100% of their losses. The
loans carry a 3.75 percent interest rate. To qualify for physical losses there
does not have to be a qualifying loss amount.

Farmers who think they are eligible may apply for assistance at the FSA County
Office at 701-265-4333.

BRIEF: Family-sized farm operators eligible for low-interest emergency loans

BYLINE: Greeley Tribune, Colo.

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 163 words


July 20--Gov. John Hickenlooper declared all Colorado counties as primary or
contiguous disaster counties due to drought and related disasters that have
occurred in 2012. This designation makes all family-sized farm operators in
primary and contiguous counties eligible to be considered for low-interest
emergency loans from Farm Service Agency, provided eligibility requirements are
met.

The deadline for filing an application is March 4, 2013.

The Farm Service Agency will consider each loan application, taking into account
the extent of losses, security available, repayment ability and other
eligibility requirements.

For applications and further information, contact your local Farm Service Agency
county office.

The Weld County office is located at 4302 9th St. Road in Greeley, and can be
reached at (970) 397-8097 ext. 2.
