                             July 1, 2015 Wednesday

Upstate farmers can apply for crop damage loans from USDA

BYLINE: Chris Lavender, Herald-Journal, Spartanburg, S.C.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 304 words


July 01--Upstate farmers can now apply for emergency loans for crop damage
through the U.S. Department of Agriculture.

The money will help growers to recover some of the financial losses they
suffered because of crop damage from cold weather earlier this year.

On June 17, the USDA designated a disaster area that includes Spartanburg,
Cherokee, Greenville, Union, Abbeville, Anderson, Chester, Fairfield, Laurens,
Newberry, Pickens and York counties.

Farmers in the designated disaster area can qualify for low-interest emergency
loans from the USDA's Farm Service Agency.

Glenn Thomas, executive director for the USDA Farm Service Agency, said Tuesday
he encourages farmers to apply for emergency loans if they suffered a loss due
to the cold weather. Thomas said it only takes one crop loss to potentially
qualify.

Crops that may have suffered damage during the period of Jan. 8 through March 29
include peaches and strawberries, he said. The deadline to apply for an
emergency loan is Feb. 17, 2016.

The Farm Service Agency will consider the extent of the losses, security
available and repayment ability for each loan applicant. Funding through the
Federal Crop Insurance and Noninsured Crop Disaster Assistance Program also is
available.

Thomas said in most cases, crops weren't a total loss during the designated
period. However, he said some farmers suffered losses during the time frame.

Farmers seeking assistance may contact their local USDA Service Centers for more
information. Additional information also is available online at
http://disaster.fsa.usda.gov. Thomas said farmers may also call the USDA at
864-814-2471 for more information.

FSA offers storm help

BYLINE: Athens Daily Review, Texas

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 444 words


Dec. 14--The storms that hit Henderson County in late October caused
considerable flooding in the area, but the Farm Service Agency may be able to
help.

The FSA announced Monday applications for emergency farm loans for losses caused
by severe storms, tornados, straight-line winds, and flooding that occurred
between Oct. 22, through Oct. 31, are being accepted at the Farm Service Agency
office located in Tyler as of Monday.  The peak of the precipitation in
Henderson County came on Oct. 24, when Athens recorded 10.38 inches of rain.

Henderson County is one of 42 counties in Texas recently named by President
Obama as eligible for loans to cover part of actual production and/or physical
losses resulting from the disaster.

FSA official Joseph Grier stated that farmers may be eligible for loans of up to
100 percent of their actual losses, or the operating loan needed to continue the
agricultural business, whichever is less. For farmers unable to obtain credit
from private commercial lenders, the interest rate is 2.375 percent.

"As a general rule, a farmer must have suffered at least a 30-percent loss of
crop production, or suffered any physical loss to be eligible for a FSA
emergency loan under the disaster designation," Grier said.

Producers participating in the Federal Crop Insurance Program will have to
consider proceeds from those programs in determining their production loss.
Additionally, any insurance proceeds received by producers as a result of the
physical loss must be considered in determining their total loss.

"Applications for loans under this emergency designation will be accepted until
July 25, 2016, but farmers should apply as soon as possible," Grier said.
"Delays in applying could create backlogs in processing, with possible delays
into the new farming seasons."

FSA is a credit agency of the U.S. Department of Agriculture. It is authorized
to provide disaster emergency loans to recognized farms who work at, and rely on
farming for a substantial part of their living. Eligibility is extended to
individual farms who meet U.S. citizenship requirements, and to farming
partnerships, corporations or cooperatives in which U.S. citizenship
requirements are met by individuals holding a majority interest.

The FSA office is located at 4209 Republic Dr., Tyler, TX  75701. The telephone
number is 903-561-2050, with office hours from 8 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.  Additional
information regarding Disaster Assistance Programs may be found online at
http://disaster.fsa.usda.gov.

St. Croix drought now officially a disaster

BYLINE: Lauren Krizansky, The Virgin Islands Daily News, St. Thomas

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 581 words


Aug. 31--ST. CROIX -- U.S. Agriculture Department Secretary Tom Vilsack has
designated St. Croix a primary natural disaster area.

"We are pleased to announce that the USDA has designated St. Croix a disaster
area," said V.I. Delegate to Congress Stacey Plaskett in a press release. "Our
office has been working closely with local farmers and with the Farm Service
Agency in hopes of achieving this end."

The Florida/V.I. Farm Service Agency, Plaskett and the U.S. Agriculture
Department requested the primary county disaster designation on Aug. 11 due to
drought damage dating back to April 1. The declaration was approved on
Wednesday.

"It is our hope that this is a first step in a closer collaboration, which will
grow our agricultural base and create a vibrant farming community," said
Plaskett, who helped arrange visits with drought-stricken farmers.

The decision comes after the department's review of the island's loss assessment
reports and determination of sufficient production losses, according to a press
release.

Now with formal designation, farm operators are eligible to be considered for
assistance from the Farm Service Agency provided they are able to meet the
requirements, according to the press release. The assistance includes Farm
Service Agency emergency loans that farm operators must apply for within eight
months of the disaster declaration.

Each application is considered on its own merits, taking into account the extent
of production loss on the farm, and the security and repayment ability of the
operator, according to the press release. Farm Service Agency emergency loan
funds may be used to:

- Restore or replace essential property

- Pay all or part of production costs associated with the disaster year

- Pay essential family living expenses

- Reorganize the farming operation

- Refinance certain debts, excluding real estate

The maximum loan amount for a Farm Service Agency emergency loan is $500,000.

The Farm Service Agency also administers a Livestock Forage Disaster Program,
which is separate from the emergency loan program.

The Livestock Forage Disaster Program provides compensation to eligible
livestock producers that have suffered grazing losses for covered livestock on
land that is native or improved pastureland with permanent vegetative cover or
is planted specifically for grazing. The grazing losses must be due to a
qualifying drought condition during the normal grazing period for the county.

The farmers, however, must own or lease grazing land or pastureland physically
located in an area the U.S. Drought Monitor rates, according to the Farm Service
Agency. The Virgin Islands are not covered by the U.S. Drought Monitor and St.
Croix is designated a "natural disaster area" that does not have a drought
monitor classification, which is a part of the program's eligibility
requirements.

V.I. Agriculture Department Commissioner Carlos Robles started conversations
earlier this month to include the territory in the drought monitor.

St Croix' precipitation since last October is severely below average. The
rainless days caused fields to dry up, leaving much livestock without enough
food, which resulted in at least 100 animal fatalities, according to the V.I.
Agriculture Department.

- Contact Lauren Krizansky at 714-9130 or email lkrizansky@dailynews.vi

Islands Daily News (St. Thomas, VIR) at www.virginislandsdailynews.com

               March 6, 1985, Wednesday, Late City Final Edition

FARM CREDIT BILL IS PASSED BY HOUSE

BYLINE: By SETH S. KING, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 5; National Desk

LENGTH: 772 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 5


Ignoring threats of a Presidential veto, the House of Representatives today
passed an emergency measure on farm credit that could provide some immediate
cash to financially distressed farmers preparing to plant their spring crops.

By a 255-to-168 vote, the House accepted a bill passed last week by the Senate
that provides advances on loans to grain and cotton farmers who would normally
not receive the money until harvest time, as well as $100 million to help rural
banks lower interest rates on troubled farm loans.

In the voting, 225 Democrats and 30 Republicans supported the measure and 150
Republicans and 18 Democrats opposed it. About half the Republicans in favor
were from Farm Belt states. Most of the Democrats voting no were from urban
districts.

The measure also makes it easier for bankers to get Government guarantees on
commercial farm loans in danger of default if the banks agree to reduce the
monthly charges on the loans by at least 10 percent.

Agriculture Secretary John R. Block, the Republican leaders of the House and
Senate and the press spokesman for the White House all have said that President
Reagan would veto the measure soon after it reaches the White House Wednesday.
They argued that the bill was too costly and was not needed to save farmers in
the worst financial condition.  The Senate majority leader, Bob Dole of Kansas,
today told a group of Missouri farmers lobbying for the emergency credit bill
that he was sure a veto could be sustained in the Republican-controlled Senate.
That would kill the sections aiding farmers as well as a measure to provide $175
million for famine relief in Africa. The farm amendments were attached to the
famine bill.

House Republican leaders, arguing against accepting the Senate's emergency
credit bill, accused the Democrats of taking advantage of Farm Belt difficulties
to embarrass Mr. Reagan by forcing him to veto a ''budget-busting'' measure.

The House minority leader, Robert H. Michel of Illinois, said the ''need and
urgency'' of many farmers was evident.

''But it seems the Democrats are more interested in harvesting votes than in
harvesting crops,'' he said. ''The Senate bill the Democrats are pushing will
cost billions more than the emergency credit bill this House passed last week.
If we could have gone to conference, we would have modified these proposals
enough to persuade the Presdent to accept them.''

Earlier, the Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. of Massachusetts, told
the House: ''The President can veto the farm bill before you, but he can't veto
the problem. If we can spend hundreds of billions putting missiles in the
ground, we can spend half a billion to put seed in the ground.''

Estimates of the cost of the emergency credit provisions have ranged from a
House Democratic figure of $279 million over the next five years, to Secretary
Block's figure of at least $8.7 million in this year alone. The Congressional
Budget Office estimated that the advance payments on crop loans alone could
reach $7.26 billion this year, but they would not be repeated next year unless
Congress approved them again next spring.

Factors Determining Cost

In the end, the total cost of the measure passed today will depend on how many
of guaranteed loans and interest reductions the banks agree to and how many of
the guaranteed loans fail. The cost of the advance loan payments will depend on
how many farmers take the loans and how many are not paid back in cash when they
are due.

Under the interest-reduction section of the bill, if a commercial bank agreed to
reduce the interest rate on a threatened farm loan by two percentage points, the
Government would pay the bank the equivalent of an additional two percentage
points. This, in effect, would lower the farmer's interest rate by four
percentage points. The bill provides $100 million for this program.

The bill adopted today also adds $1.85 billion to the $650 million the Reagan
Administration has already allocated for interest guarantees on commercial farm
loans in danger of default.

If Mr. Reagan vetoes the measure and that veto is sustained, the advance
payments on the crop loans would be the only thing the farmers would lose.

The loan guarantees have been available since last October, though the
regulations for granting them are more restrictive than those provided today.

The Administration has already promised to increase the original $650 million
allocation by any amount needed for additional loan guarantees. So far, only
about $67 million in guarantees has been committed, Representative Michel said
today.

                                US Official News

                           August 28, 2013 Wednesday

Utah: USDA Designates Curry County in Oregon as a Primary Natural Disaster Area
With Assistance to Producers in California

LENGTH: 810  words

DATELINE: Salt Lake City


Department of Agriculture Farm Service Agency, The State of Utah has issued the
following news release:

Department of Agriculture (USDA) has designated Curry County in Oregon as a
primary natural disaster area due to losses caused by the recent drought.


"Our hearts go out to those Oregon farmers and ranchers affected by recent
natural disasters," said Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack. "President Obama and
I are committed to ensuring that agriculture remains a bright spot in our
nation's economy by sustaining the successes of America's farmers, ranchers and
rural communities through these difficult times. We're also telling Oregon
producers that USDA stands with you and your communities when severe weather and
natural disasters threaten to disrupt your livelihood."


Farmers and ranchers in the following counties in Oregon also qualify for
natural disaster assistance because their counties are contiguous. Those
counties are:


Coos

Douglas

Josephine



Farmers and ranchers in the following counties in California also qualify for
natural disaster assistance because their counties are contiguous. Those
counties are:


California
Del Norte


All counties listed above were designated natural disaster areas Aug. 28, 2013,
making all qualified farm operators in the designated areas eligible for low
interest emergency (EM) loans from USDA's Farm Service Agency (FSA), provided
eligibility requirements are met. Farmers in eligible counties have eight months
from the date of the declaration to apply for loans to help cover part of their
actual losses. FSA will consider each loan application on its own merits, taking
into account the extent of losses, security available and repayment ability. FSA
has a variety of programs, in addition to the EM loan program, to help eligible
farmers recover from adversity.


Additional programs available to assist farmers and ranchers include the
Emergency Conservation Program, Federal Crop Insurance, and the Noninsured Crop
Disaster Assistance Program. Interested farmers may contact their local USDA
Service Centers for further information on eligibility requirements and
application procedures for these and other programs. Additional information is
also available online at http://disaster.fsa.usda.gov.


The Obama Administration remains committed to helping the thousands of farm
families and businesses struggling with natural disasters. Actions taken by
Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack in 2012 to provide assistance to producers
impacted by the drought included:

Extended emergency grazing on Conservation Reserve Program (CRP) acres, freeing
up a record 2.8 million acres and as much as $200 million in forage and feed for
ranchers during a challenging time.

Purchased $170 million of pork, lamb, chicken, and catfish for federal food
nutrition assistance programs, including food banks, to help relieve pressure on
American livestock producers and bring the nation's meat supply in line with
demand.

Reduced the emergency loan rate, from 3.75 percent to 2.50 percent, as well as
making emergency loans available earlier in the season.

Allowing haying or grazing of cover crops without impacting the insurability of
planted 2013 spring crops.

USDA worked with crop insurance companies to provide flexibility to farmers, and
one-third of all policyholders took advantage of the extended payment period.

Authorized $16 million in existing funds from the Wildlife Habitat Incentive
Program (WHIP) and Environmental Quality Incentives Program (EQIP) to target
states experiencing exceptional and extreme drought.

Transferred $14 million in unobligated program funds into the Emergency
Conservation Program (ECP) to help farmers and ranchers rehabilitate farmland
damaged by natural disasters and for carrying out emergency water conservation
measures in periods of severe drought.

Authorized haying and grazing of Wetlands Reserve Program (WRP) easement areas
in drought-affected areas where haying and grazing is consistent with
conservation of wildlife habitat and wetlands.

Lowered the penalty on CRP acres used for emergency haying or grazing, from 25
percent to 10 percent in 2012 and again in 2013.

Simplified the Secretarial disaster designation process and reduced the time it
takes to designate counties affected by disasters by 40 percent.



Secretary Vilsack also reminds producers that Congress has not funded the five
disaster assistance programs authorized by the 2008 Farm Bill. These are SURE;
the Livestock Indemnity Program (LIP); the Emergency Assistance for Livestock,
Honey Bees, and Farm-Raised Fish (ELAP); the Livestock Forage Disaster Program
(LFP); and the Tree Assistance Program (TAP). Production losses due to disasters
occurring after Sept. 30, 2011, are not eligible for disaster program coverage.

For further information please visit: http://www.fsa.usda.gov/

Grant farmers eligible for emergency loans

BYLINE: Grant County Press staff

LENGTH: 321  words


Alfred J. Lewis, West Virginia Farm Service Agency (FSA) state executive
director, has announced the designation of 17 counties in West Virginia for FSA
Emergency (EM) Loans.

"The counties of Berkeley, Brooke, Doddridge, Hampshire, Hancock, Hardy,
Jefferson, Marion, Marshall, Morgan, Ohio, Pocahontas, Preston, Ritchie, Tucker,
Tyler, and Wetzel were designated for emergency loans by President Obama because
of damages caused by severe winter storms and snowstorms occurring Feb. 5-11,"
stated Lewis.

"This designation was made to enable FSA to provide financial assistance to
those farm families who suffered severe losses as a result of the severe winter
storms and snowstorms," he added.

"Public Law 98-258 provides for counties that are contiguous to another county
that has been designated as a disaster area, to also be eligible for EM loans,"
stated Lewis. Barbour, Calhoun, Gilmer, Grant, Greenbrier, Harrison, Lewis,
Mineral, Monongalia, Pendleton, Pleasants, Randolph, Taylor, Webster, Wirt, and
Wood counties are contiguous to the designated counties and are therefore
eligible for assistance," Lewis explained.

To be eligible for an emergency loan, the farmer must have suffered at least a
30 percent production loss or a physical loss, be able to evidence adequate
repayment ability and be unable to obtain adequate credit from other sources.

Loans to one operation are limited to $500,000 or the calculated production loss
plus the physical loss, whichever is less. Loans are also limited to owners
and/or operators of not larger than family-sized farming operations.

"Farmers in the above counties may apply for EM loans through Dec. 23," added
Lewis. "Applications should be filed in the FSA County Office which serves the
county in which the farmer lives," he concluded.

For Grant, Hardy, Pendleton, Randolph and Tucker counties, contact Terry L.
Weese, farm loan manager out of the Petersburg office at 304-257-4702.

            Intelligencer Journal/New Era (Lancaster, Pennsylvania)

                          September 17, 2014 Wednesday

Funds Shrink For Chemical-Spill Training

BYLINE: Joe Hainthaler

SECTION: B; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 535  words

DATELINE: Lancaster, PA


Staff Writer

jhainthaler@lnpnews.com

Lancaster County Commissioners said Tuesday that they want to keep an eye on the
resources the county has available for responding to chemical spills.

They also approved privately funded loans that will allow farms in Colerain
Township and Rapho Township to be passed along to the next generation.

The chemical spill issue came up when Randy Gockley, the county's emergency
management coordinator, was asking the commissioners' approval to seek a $33,073
state grant to provide insurance and training for the county's first responders
so they're ready to respond to chemical spills.

The grant from the Pennsylvania Emergency Management Agency is 19 percent less
than last year's, Gockley told the commissioners.

And that's not necessarily because Pennsylvania businesses are using hazardous
chemicals any less, he said.

The funds for the grant are down, Gockley said, because fewer businesses are
keeping 10,000 pounds of chemicals on hand on any given day - the condition that
requires a payment into the PEMA fund that provides for chemical spill training.

Gockley said he believes businesses are keeping their inventories of chemicals
down in order to reduce liability costs, rather than reducing the amounts of
chemicals they're using.

The county this year has collected $96,475 from businesses storing chemicals,
down 7.4 percent from the $104,225 collected in 2003, according to county
records.

Commissioners approved the grant request at their meeting Tuesday night at the
Terre Hill Community Center, one of the commissioners' quarterly meetings at
sites across the county. As a result, there will be no commissioners meeting
this morning in Lancaster.

At Tuesday morning's work session, commissioners also approved three tax-exempt
loans through the state's Next Generation Farm Loan program.

The loans - which involve no public funds - were the first approved by Penn
Township's new industrial development authority, which was formed in August.
Lancaster County's previous Next Generation Farm loans were approved by Chester
County's IDA.

Despite its name, the program does not require family-to-family sales but only
that the buyer be a beginning or first-time farmer.

An IDA approves tax-free loans permitted under state law for economic
development. Such loans must be approved by a local IDA and then the highest
local governing body, in this case the Lancaster County Board of Commissioners.

The tax-free loans approved Tuesday, all with Fulton Bank, will be for:

n $350,000 of the $650,000 purchase price for Abner and Suvilla King to buy a
46-acre farm in the 100 block of Sproul Road, Colerain Township, from Abner
King's father, Christian.

n $500,000 of the $1.2 million purchase price for Dustin and Cody Musser to buy
their parents' 124-acre farm - located on two parcels in the 1100 and 600 blocks
of Newcomer Road, Rapho Township.

n $509,000 (the maximum-allowed Next Generation Farm Loan amount) of the $1.575
million purchase price for Rustin and Heather Herr to buy a 71-acre farm in the
first block of Sproul Road, Colerain Township.

According to the most recent state data, Lancaster County accounts for most of
the loan money and most of the farms in the program.

                         Brattleboro Reformer (Vermont)

                            February 2, 2007 Friday

USDA offers emergency loans for area farmers

BYLINE: Reformer.com

SECTION: LOCAL

LENGTH: 253 words


COLCHESTER -- The purpose of USDA's Farm Service Agency (FSA) Emergency Loans is
to help farmers recover from losses suffered due to severe weather conditions
including excessive rainfall and flooding.

Emergency loans may be made to farmers who have suffered at least a 30 percent
loss to a crop that comprises a basic part of the farm operation or a physical
loss to the operation.

The eligibility criteria for this program can be found at www.fsa.usda.gov/FSA /
or by stopping in or contacting a loan officer at the local FSA office.

The excessive rainfall earlier this past summer has created a mix of problems
for many farmers.

Low prices and increased costs make the issue even more complex. The amount of
credit we can extend is based on comparing your typical operation (three-year
average) to the disaster year and physical losses to the operation.

To assess the impact of the loss and amount of credit available, the FSA will
need to see specific information for each farm. For dairy operations this will
include the purchased feed needs to effectively utilize feed produced in 2006
which will require information provided by a qualified third party.

Deadlines for filing emergency loan applications in Windham County is May 1 and
May 14 for Bennington County.

Farmers and other interested parties who would like to discuss emergency loan
financing, contact a a local FSA office at one of these locations: St. Albans,
(802) 527-1296, Newport, (802) 334-6573, Middlebury, (802) 388-6748, White River
Jct., (802) 295-7942.

Pembina County Farmers Eligible for USDA Disaster Emergency Loans

BYLINE: Valley News & Views staff

LENGTH: 209  words


Farmers in Pembina County who suffered physical and production losses because of
flooding that occurred February 14, 2011, and continuing may now apply for Farm
Service Agency Emergency Loans, Farm Loan Manager Werven announced.

The time allowed to file loan applications is eight months. For Pembina County
farmers, this means the deadline for applications to be filed is January 10,
2012.

Although the authority for Emergency Loan processing has been given, all
potential EM loan applicants must be aware that they will be unable to complete
an application for loan processing until after all information for their farm
operation pertaining to actual physical losses and production losses, disaster
payments, to crop insurance benefits, and any other crop production
compensation, is available and can be documented.

FLM Werven said farmers who suffered a qualifying production loss of at least
30% from normal and are unable to get credti elsewhere, may apply for reduced
interest loans to cover up to 100% of their lossses. The loans carry a 3.75
percent interest rate. To qualify for physical losses, there does not have to be
a qualifying loss amount.

Farmers who think they are eligible may apply for assistance at the FSA County
Office at 701-265-4333.

                                  May 25, 2011

Walsh County Farmers Now Eligible for USDA Disaster Emergency Loans

BYLINE: Walsh County Press staff

LENGTH: 210  words


PARK RIVER, N.D. -- Farmers in Walsh County who suffered physical and production
losses because of flooding that occurred February 14, 2011, and continuing may
now apply for Farm Service Agency Emergency Loans, Farm Loan Manager Donald
Tongen said.

The time allowed to file loan applications is eight months. For Walsh County
farmers, this means the deadline for applications to be filed is January 12,
2012.

Although the authority for Emergency Loan processing has been given, all
potential EM loan applicants must be aware that they will be unable to complete
an application for loan processing until after all information for their farm
operation pertaining to actual physical and production losses, disaster
payments, to crop insurance benefits, and to any other crop production
compensation is available and can be documented.

Tongen said farmers who suffered a qualifying production loss of at least 30%
from normal and are unable to get credit elsewhere, may apply for reduced
interest loans to cover up to 100% of their losses. The loans carry a 3.75
percent interest rate. To qualify for physical losses, there does not have to be
a qualifying loss amount.

Farmers who think they are eligible may apply for assistance at the FSA County
Office at Park River.

                       Sydney Morning Herald (Australia)

                           September 3, 1994 Saturday
                                  Late Edition

PRESCRIPTIONS FOR OVERCOMING THE DROUGHT

SECTION: NEWS AND FEATURES; Letters; Pg. 34

LENGTH: 665 words


We need our farmers, and now our farmers need us.

Our farmers must not be allowed to fail because of no fault of their own.

When a farmer has no income and cannot pay his bank loan, the bank forecloses
and another farmer is consigned to the scrap-heap, another farm sold and it
rarely regains its previous productivity.

This drought should be declared a state of emergency so that special concessions
can be implemented to save our farmers. These conditions would apply only for
the duration of the state of emergency.

1) Introduce emergency legislation to put all farm loans on hold; no payments by
the farmer until the farmer is again earning an income. A Government subsidy
could be paid to the banks to cover net interest-only needs of the bank at cost
(not the commercial interest charged on the loan). The farmer would still be
liable for the loan, which would resume when conditions allow.

2) Allow the farmer to claim the dole when there is clear evidence of no income,
and of need. This would apply without the need to sell his property or to have
his bank account completely empty. He still needs money to keep the farm
running, but may need assistance to actually feed his family.

3) Remove Government excise on fuel for farm use.

4) Provide free transport for emergency fodder.

Remember, if an uncontrolled number of farms are allowed to fail, Australia will
miss out on valuable export income and prices will rise because of shortages.

A country that cannot feed itself, and cannot defend itself is in mortal danger.

Neil Matthews,

September 1 Yarrawarra.

As a nation, we Australians seem to take bizarre delight in clicking our tongues
and shaking our heads when disaster strikes us. In recent times, I have read
much about "The Drought", every article factual but seasoned with despair and
indifference. What miserable bedfellows these make. Can't we kill them off?

Eighteen months ago, I returned to Australia after an absence of 16 years and
was unprepared for the changes in both society and in the physical appearance of
our land. In both instances I saw erosion.

Unbelievably, the great Murray, Hawkesbury, Nepean and Shoalhaven Rivers were
all dying or under threat; vast tracts of land west of the Great Divide from
Queensland to South Australia becoming one big dust bowl; our sheep and cattle
starving; the

wheat harvest failing and becoming poorer each year; the land and all who live
in it, suffering. What a disaster |

City people do not yet realise what is happening because they have, for the
moment, an abundant water supply. Their gardens blaze with colour and parks are
kept green. They think that this drought doesn't affect them but should the dam
system fail, it will. Two hours' drive from Sydney, the land is grey and it gets
worse the further west one travels. But let's get rid of despair and
indifference and stir ourselves to do something positive to halt the drought's
advance.

May I throw down the gauntlet of challenge to every person in Australia having
an active faith in God known as Creator of heaven and earth, to pray for
life-giving rain?

Vicki Brookes,

August 29 Bathurst.

The continuing coverage of the drought affecting most of NSW certainly sends
shivers down the spine of this urban person. The farmers and those who rely on
farmers in the country are in need of support from all the community.

In order to gain more funding from the State Government, I suggest that all
farmers assassinate their local Members of Parliament. The Government will then
call by-elections. During the run-up to the elections, the Government will
suddenly find millions of dollars and will offer to provide services and cash
for any project that looks like it will buy votes. This is the pattern from the
recent Parramatta by-election. Alternatively, now that the Fahey Government has
lost that by-election, the money promised in return for votes will probably not
be spent in Parramatta and could be diverted to assisting those in the country.

Peter Short,

August 31 Dangar Island.

                              The American Banker

Farm Loans Seen Declining 66%

                           January 23, 1979, Tuesday

By JOSEPH D. HUTNYAN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


Agricultural loans are expected to decline by 66% in fiscal year 1980, according
to President Carter's budget submitted to Congress Monday.

The projected decrease results from an expectation of more normal weather
conditions, and because of expiration of several farm loan programs, the
document stated.

The section of the budget dealing with farm lending programs noted that
agricultural loans -- including emergency loans from the credit insurance fund
--rose sharply in fiscal year 1978 because more than two-thirds of the counties
in the nation were declared eligible for emergency financial assistance/because
of adverse weather conditions.

It said that the $3.6 billion loan volume recorded for these programs in 1978
would shrink to $3.3 billion in fiscal year 1979.

During fiscal year 1980, the 12-month period/starting, next Oct. 1 and ending
Sept. 30, 1980, the Agriculture Department expects loan volume to drop to $1.3
billion.

In addition to expectations of improved weather for crops, the decline also will
result from expiration of the emergency livestock loan guarantee and economic
emergency loan programs, the budget stated.

The document also included a recommendation for abolishing agricultural loan
programs currently administered by the Small Business Administration.

It said the SBA's farm credit programs overlap with those offered by the Farmers
Home Administration.

                        Henderson (N.C.) Daily Dispatch

                     Distributed by Tribune Content Agency

                            February 26, 2016 Friday

USDA loans available for qualified farmers

BYLINE: Henderson (N.C.) Daily Dispatch

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 271 words


Feb. 26--Farmers in the Tri-County may qualify for disaster assistance loans
from the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Farm Service Agency, according to a
press release from the USDA.

Earlier this month, the USDA designated Franklin County as primary natural
disaster areas because of damages and losses caused by excessive rain and
flooding that began Sept. 24, 2015, and continues.

Farmers and ranchers in Vance, Granville, Warren, Halifax, Johnston, Nash, and
Wake counties also qualify for low-interest emergency loans because those
counties are contiguous to Franklin County.

Christeen Crudup, director of the Farm Service Agency's Vance County office,
said local farmers have expressed interest in the loans.

"A lot of producers and farmers have been calling," Crudup said.

She said Tri-County farmers who own livestock or produce a crop on more or less
than 10 acres of land can qualify for the loans.

"It could apply to almost anyone who farms," she said. "It's a very low interest
rate so this is another resource they have."

Farmers in eligible counties have eight months from the date of the declaration
to apply for loans to help cover part of their losses.

Other FSA programs that can provide assistance but do not require a disaster
declaration include the emergency conservation program; livestock forage
disaster program; livestock indemnity program, emergency assistance for
livestock, honeybees, and farm-raised fish program; and the tree assistance
program. Additional information is available online at disaster.fsa.usda.gov.

                           Lowell Sun (Massachusetts)

                          September 7, 2016 Wednesday

Some farms are dust bowls. The state's offering $1M to help

BYLINE: By Katie Lannan, State House News Service

SECTION: BREAKING

LENGTH: 420 words


BOSTON -- Up to $1 million in micro-loans will now be available to Massachusetts
farmers struggling under the impacts of a widespread and historic drought.

The launch of the Drought Emergency Loan Fund, announced Wednesday, is one of a
series of steps Gov. Charlie Baker and his administration are taking in response
to five months of abnormally dry weather.

Comparing it to a similar effort that made loans available to assist businesses
after record snowfall in 2015, Baker said in a statement that the fund "will
provide affordable working capital to small businesses grappling with the
aftermath of extreme weather."

Massachusetts has been under its own official drought declaration since July 1
and the arid conditions have been blamed for contributing to wild fires, an
outbreak of gypsy moths, higher rates of ant infestation, smaller than usual
apples, loss of crops, and an elevated population of mosquitoes carrying West
Nile virus.

Loan amounts range from $5,000 to $10,000 and are available to
Massachusetts-based family farms and "farm related businesses," according to the
application. Businesses "involved in real estate investment, multi-level
marketing, adult entertainment or firearms" are ineligible.

The new drought loan program is anticipated to run through November. The
Massachusetts Growth Capital Corporation will be responsible for funding the
loan, managing the loan portfolio and collecting interest and principal
payments.

State officials first announced plans to create an emergency loan fund at an
Aug. 18 press conference at North Andover's Smolak Farms, where owner Michael
Smolak said his strawberry plants and Christmas tree seedlings were suffering
under the dry conditions.

Smolak said this year's drought was "as bad as I've ever seen it, and I was born
in 1952, so I've been around for a few years."

As of Aug. 19, Massachusetts farmers had lost nearly $14 million in crops due to
the drought. The U.S. Department of Agriculture Farm Service Agency's state
emergency board has submitted a request for disaster declaration for some
Massachusetts counties, which would make federal assistance available.

Farmers in Essex, Franklin, Middlesex and Worcester counties qualify for federal
aid by virtue of a USDA disaster declaration in the New Hampshire counties they
border.

The Massachusetts Drought Management Task Force meets Thursday morning and plans
to get updates on conditions around the state and consider changing the drought
level classification for some parts of the state.

END

09/07/2016

Pembina County Farmers Eligible for USDA Disaster Emergency Loans

                       Charleston Gazette (West Virginia)

                            June 6, 2007, Wednesday

Farm Service Agency emergency loans available in southern West Virginia

SECTION: METRO NORTH; Pg. P5

LENGTH: 304 words


Eighteen counties in West Virginia are eligible for Farm Service Agency
emergency grants, according to Robert P. Ferrebee, FSA state executive director.

"The counties of Barbour, Boone, Cabell, Gilmer, Grant, Hardy, Lewis, Lincoln,
Logan, McDowell, Mingo, Pendleton, Pocahontas, Putnam, Upshur, Wayne, Webster,
and Wyoming were designated for Emergency Loans by the Secretary of Agriculture
because of damages caused by severe storms, flooding, landslides, and mudslides
beginning April 14, 2007," stated Ferrebee.

"This designation was made to enable FSA to provide financial assistance to
those farm families who suffered severe losses as a result of severe storms,
flooding, landslides, and mudslides," he added.

"Public Law 98-258 provides for counties that are contiguous to another county
that has been designated as a disaster area, to also be eligible for EM Loans,"
said Ferrebee.

The 17 counties that are contiguous are Braxton, Calhoun, Doddridge, Greenbrier,
Hampshire, Harrison, Kanawha, Mason, Mercer, Mineral, Nicholas, Preston,
Raleigh, Randolph, Ritchie, Taylor and Tucker. They are therefore eligible for
assistance," Ferrebee explained.

To be eligible for an emergency loan, the farmer must have suffered at least a
30-percent production loss or a physical loss, be able to evidence adequate
repayment ability and be unable to obtain adequate credit from other sources.

Loans to one operation are limited to $500,000, or the calculated production
loss, plus the physical loss, whichever is less. Loans are also limited to
owners and/or operators of not larger than family-sized farming operations.

"Farmers in the above West Virginia Counties may apply for EM Loans up through
Jan. 10, 2008," added Ferrebee.

"Applications should be filed in the FSA County Office which serves the county
in which the farmer lives."

                    The Free Press (Kinstin, North Carolina)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                          September 22, 2007 Saturday

USDA declares statewide natural disaster for farmers

BYLINE: David Anderson, The Free Press, Kinston, N.C.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 508 words


Sep. 22--Once again, extreme weather conditions have forced federal agriculture
officials to de-clare a disaster in North Carolina and provide assistance funds
for farmers.

U.S. Agriculture Secretary Mike Johanns declared a secretarial major disaster in
May after an April cold snap cost the state's produce farmers millions of
dollars in crop losses, including farmers in Lenoir and Greene counties.

Johanns issued a natural disaster declaration for North Carolina on Sept. 12
because of this year's extended drought and extreme heat. Local agriculture
officials announced the declaration Friday.

Lenoir, Greene and Jones are among 85 of the state's 100 counties that have been
desig-nated "primary disaster counties," according to a news release. Farmers
who live in the primary counties, plus 11 eastern "contiguous" counties, can
apply for emergency loans from the USDA's Farm Service Agency.

Pat Williams, county executive director of the FSA's Lenoir office, said Friday
that the emergency loans are currently the only loans available to farmers for
this year.

Farmers who have lost 35 percent or more of their "row crops" -- corn, soybeans,
tobacco, cotton, peanuts -- are eligible for the federal disaster loans, said
Carl Bond, farm loan manager for Greene's FSA office.

"Right now it's too early to say who's going to come in because they haven't
finished with the harvesting of their crops," Bond said Friday.

The amount of loan money each farmer is eligible for depends on the amount lost,
how large of a crop insurance payment he or she receives and other factors, Bond
explained. The amount of crops lost also varies from field to field, since some
parts of Lenoir and Greene had more precipitation than others this year.

Farmers must also have collateral such as equipment or real estate to be
eligible for the emergency loans.

David Anderson can be reached at (252)559-1077, or danderson@freedomenc.com

Projected 2007 crop yields as of Sept. 12:

Flue-cured tobacco: 330 million pounds, 2 percent increase from 2006

Burley tobacco: 6.4 million pounds, compared with 6.46 million in 2006

Cotton: 611 pounds per acre, compared with 713 pounds per acre in 2006

Corn for grain: 91.67 million bushels, 6 percent drop from 2006

Soybeans: 30.1 million bushels, 31 percent drop from 2006

Peanuts: 211.6 million pounds, 21 percent drop from 2006

-Source: U.S. Department of Agriculture

                                US Official News

                             July 25, 2013 Thursday

Utah: USDA Designates Silver Bow County in Montana as a Primary Natural Disaster
Area

LENGTH: 626  words

DATELINE: Salt Lake City


Department of Agriculture Farm Service Agency, The State of Utah has issued the
following news release:

Department of Agriculture (USDA) has designated Silver Bow County in Montana as
a primary natural disaster area due to damages and losses caused by the recent
drought.


"Our hearts go out to those Montana farmers and ranchers affected by recent
natural disasters," said Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack. "President Obama and
I are committed to ensuring that agriculture remains a bright spot in our
nation's economy by sustaining the successes of America's farmers, ranchers, and
rural communities through these difficult times. We're also telling Montana
producers that USDA stands with you and your communities when severe weather and
natural disasters threaten to disrupt your livelihood."


Farmers and ranchers in Beaverhead, Deer Lodge, Jefferson and Madison counties
in Montana also qualify for natural disaster assistance because their counties
are contiguous.


All counties listed above were designated natural disaster areas July 24, 2013,
making all qualified farm operators in the designated areas eligible for low
interest emergency (EM) loans from USDA's Farm Service Agency (FSA), provided
eligibility requirements are met. Farmers in eligible counties have eight months
from the date of the declaration to apply for loans to help cover part of their
actual losses. FSA will consider each loan application on its own merits, taking
into account the extent of losses, security available and repayment ability. FSA
has a variety of programs, in addition to the EM loan program, to help eligible
farmers recover from adversity.


The Obama Administration remains committed to helping the thousands of farm
families and businesses struggling with natural disasters. Actions taken by
Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack in 2012 to provide assistance to producers
impacted by the drought included:

Extended emergency grazing on Conservation Reserve Program (CRP) acres, freeing
up a record 2.8 million acres and as much as $200 million in forage and feed for
ranchers during a challenging time.

Purchased $170 million of pork, lamb, chicken, and catfish for federal food
nutrition assistance programs, including food banks, to help relieve pressure on
American livestock producers and bring the nation's meat supply in line with
demand.

Reduced the emergency loan rate, from 3.75 percent to 2.250 percent, as well as
making emergency loans available earlier in the season.

Allowing haying or grazing of cover crops without impacting the insurability of
planted 2013 spring crops.

USDA worked with crop insurance companies to provide flexibility to farmers, and
one-third of all policyholders took advantage of the extended payment period.

Authorized $16 million in existing funds from the Wildlife Habitat Incentive
Program (WHIP) and Environmental Quality Incentives Program (EQIP) to target
states experiencing exceptional and extreme drought.

Transferred $14 million in unobligated program funds into the Emergency
Conservation Program (ECP) to help farmers and ranchers rehabilitate farmland
damaged by natural disasters and for carrying out emergency water conservation
measures in periods of severe drought.

Authorized haying and grazing of Wetlands Reserve Program (WRP) easement areas
in drought-affected areas where haying and grazing is consistent with
conservation of wildlife habitat and wetlands.

Lowered the penalty on CRP acres used for emergency haying or grazing, from 25
percent to 10 percent in 2012.

Simplified the Secretarial disaster designation process and reduced the time it
takes to designate counties affected by disasters by 40 percent.

For further information please visit: http://www.fsa.usda.gov/

                                 March 18, 2010

Farm Service Agency (FSA) Emergency Loans Available

BYLINE: The Boise City News staff

LENGTH: 235  words


Farmers and ranchers in 74 Oklahoma counties including Cimarron County and Texas
County, who suffered physical and production losses as a result of combined
effects of extreme weather, including drought, floods, hail, freeze, fire, and
high winds that began September 1, 2008, and ended June 30, 2009 are reminded of
the upcoming loan application deadline. According to Stephen Vaughan, Farm Loan
Officer, producers have until April 13, 2010, to apply. The loans will be made
to assist farmers in recovering from physical and production losses. Farm and
ranch operators, who have suffered qualifying losses, may be eligible for FSA
emergency loans to cover actual physical and production losses.

Emergency loan funds may be used to purchase seed, fertilizer, fuel, and
repairs. "A farmer can use the money for the most essential operating and living
costs," Mr. Vaughan said. To be eligible for a loan, an ap-plicant must have
suffered losses as a direct result of the disaster and be unable to obtain
credit from other sources. Loans covering actual losses are at an interest rate
of 3.75 percent per annum. The amount of the loan is determined by actual
certification of loss less any compensation received, repayment capacity of the
borrower, and availability of security. Please contact the Cimarron County FSA
Office at 210 S. Cimarron, PO Box 165, Boise City, OK 73933, 580-544-2401 for
additional details.

Walsh County Farmers Now Eligible for USDA Disaster Emergency Loans

BYLINE: Walsh County Press staff

LENGTH: 236  words


PARK RIVER, N.D. Farmers in Walsh County who suffered physical and production
losses because of flooding that occurred March 16, 2011, through May 25, 2011,
may now apply for Farm Service Agency Emergency Loans, Farm Loan Manager Donald
Tongen said today.

Walsh County is eligible to make EM loans because it is bordering a county in
Minnesota that was designated a major disaster area.

The time allowed to file loan applications is eight months. For Walsh County
fanners, this means the deadline for applications to be filed is January 24,
2012.

Although the authority for Emergency Loan processing has been given, all
potential EM loan applicants must be aware that they will be unable to complete
an application for loan processing until after all information for their farm
operation pertaining to actual physical and production losses, disaster
payments, to crop insurance benefits, and to any other crop production
compensation is available and can be documented.

Tongen said farmers who suffered a qualifying production loss of at least 30
percent from normal and are unable to get credit elsewhere, may apply for
reduced interest loans to cover up to 100 percent of their losses. The loans
carry a 3.75 percent interest rate. To qualify for physical losses, there does
not have to be a qualifying loss amount.

Farmers who think they are eligible may apply for assistance at the FSA County
Office at Park River, ND.

                 The Daily News (Jacksonville, North Carolina)

                           December 4, 2010 Saturday

USDA designates farmers eligible for disaster assistance

BYLINE: Suzanne Ulbrich, The Daily News, Jacksonville, N.C.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 629 words


Dec. 04--Farmers in 67 North Carolina counties -- including Onslow, Carteret,
Jones and Duplin -- are eligible for federal assistance for this year's losses.

Based on history, however, a local farm loan manager doesn't expect a large
number locally to seek the financial aid.

"Typically we do not have a very large turnout, because you have to go through
the other channels first," said Robert Grady, a farm loan manager with FSA,
serving Onslow, Duplin, Pender and New Hanover counties.

On Wednesday, U.S. Department of Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack designated
the 67 counties as disasters agriculturally due to drought and excessive heat
from May 1 to Oct. 1. The declaration makes farmers and producers in those
regions eligible for emergency loan assistance.

Since loss is determined on total harvest Grady said he doesn't expect calls
from those interested in applying to start coming in until the beginning of next
year.

"Many farmers are still getting soybeans and cotton crops out of the field, so
it will probably be January or later before they start calling and applying,
since that's when they'll be able to look at what their total crop losses were,"
he said.

There are also eligibility requirements that have to be met.

"To use this loan you've got to be financially unable to get help elsewhere --
you have to be financially unable to get a loan from the bank or farm credit in
order for Farm Service Agency to be in a position to help you," he said.

The emergency loan program is designed for farmers and producers who have had
significant loss, said Sue Aman Smithwick, a farm loan manager who serves
Carteret, Jones, Lenoir, Craven and Pamlico counties.

"There has to be a 30-percent loss or more of production after all insurances
and compensations," she said. "The government will provide a loan at 3.75
percent up to $500,000 per operation."

The loan is designed to refinance carry-over debt and production losses as a
result of the natural disaster, she said.

"Basically it is designed to take what went wrong and make it better," she said
"They can operate on it and pay due bills on it -- but they can't buy a piece of
farm equipment with it. There are limitations on how the money can be used."

She pointed out there was another agriculture disaster designation made Oct. 14,
which included Onslow, Lenoir, Carteret and Jones counties to cover damage
caused by the severe storms, flooding and straight line winds in late September.

"I cannot stress enough, any farmer who feels they have been affected by the
drought or the flooding should contact their local Farm Service Agency office
and we'll try to figure it out," she said.

Farmers have eight months from the date of the disaster declaration to apply for
emergency loan assistance.

The North Carolina counties that received agriculture disaster designations are:
Alamance, Anson, Beaufort, Bertie, Bladen, Brunswick, Camden, Carteret, Caswell,
Chatham, Cherokee, Chowan, Clay, Columbus, Craven, Cumberland, Dare, Davidson,
Davie, Duplin, Durham, Edgecombe, Forsyth, Franklin, Gates, Granville, Greene,
Guilford, Halifax, Harnett, Hertford, Hoke, Hyde, Jackson, Johnston, Jones, Lee,
Lenoir, Macon, Martin, Montgomery, Moore, Nash, New Hanover, Northampton,
Onslow, Orange, Pamlico, Pasquotank, Pender, Perquimans, Person, Pitt, Randolph,
Richmond, Robeson, Rowan, Sampson, Scotland, Stanley, Tyrrell, Vance, Wake,
Warren, Washington, Wayne and Wilson.

To see more of The Daily News, or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.jacksonvilledailynews.com. Copyright (c) 2010, The Daily News,
Jacksonville, N.C. Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For
more information about the content services offered by McClatchy-Tribune
Information Services (MCT), visit www.mctinfoservices.com.

                              The American Banker

Rural Front: Hope -- and a Defeat;
 Minnesota Farmers May Get Federal Emergency Credit

                          February 21, 1985, Thursday

Special to the American Banker

DATELINE: FULDA, Minn.


Farm customers of a bank closed here late last week by regulators may be the
first beneficiaries of a recently announced federal emergency credit assistance
program.

The Citizens State Bank of Fulda was ordered closed Friday Feb16 after
regulators determined that ''alleged lending irregularities'' and problem farm
loans had completely depleted its net worth.

One regulator said he hopes the Farmers Home Administration (FmHA) will follow
through on plans to have several loan specialists on hand to provide emergency
credit assistance to farmers who may have trouble refinancing substandard loans.

The emergency credit plan is one portion of a three-part program announced early
this month by Agriculture Secretary John Block.

Under the plan, the FmHA would guarantee 90% of a bank loan, thus making the
farmer more of an attractive loan customer.

''This could be the first attempt to implement the program,'' said Craig Rice,
the liquidator in charge of the assets of the Fulda bank. ''We're going to push
to get them here.''

The program also offers a more attractive loan guarantee plan to banks, which
would require them to write down the interest rate on substandard loans, as well
as to write off up to 10% of the asset, in return for the guarantee.

The program also calls for federal regulators to ease pressure on farm banks.

Only farmers with viable businesses are extended the emergency credit.

''We aren't in the business of lending, but we may free up funds, if it will
protect our collateral, such as money for cattle feed,'' said Allen Whitney, a
spokesman for the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., who was at the Fulda bank
late last week.

Bank Problems Linked to Farm

More than half the failed bank's $30 million in loans were made to farmers in
the southwestern Minnesota community, and another one-fourth were commercial
loans made to agriculture-related businesses.

''The problems of the bank [are] directly related to the problems of the farm
community,'' said Michael Hatch, state commerce commissioner.

However, he added that the Fulda bank was not representative of the industry's
condition in the area.

A failed bank's loan customers are often the ones to suffer the most, according
to Mr. Hatch, since the FDIC often recalls the troubled loans it cannot sell
off, and customers have trouble finding other financing sources.

Mr. Hatch mentioned a case last year in which a farmer had his grain seized by
the FDIC while delivering it to a terminal.

Increasing criticism of these FDIC practices is part of the reason why
regulators have taken several steps to aid farm customers of failed banks. One
of those steps is the new program.

The FDIC also has adopted a more lenient attitude toward farm customers of
failed banks. It began extending emergency credit to some borrowers in Nebraska
earlier this year and may do the same in the Fulda case.

The FDIC's forbearance allows some farmers to continue their businesses and find
other sources of financing, and enhances the agency's chances to recover more of
the assets.

24 State Banks Remain 'Problems'

Citizens reopened Tuesday as the Fulda State Bank.

The failed bank's $35 million in insured deposits were purchased for $301,000 by
Frank Farrar, a former South Dakota governor who has an interest in about 20
institutions in Minnesota, South Dakota, Wisconsin, Illinois, and Iowa.

Twenty-four state-chartered institutions remain on Minnesota's ''problem bank''
list. Many are in agriculture communities, according to Mr. Hatch.

Despite the depressed farm economy, Minnesota's rural banks are doing better
than those in other farm states, such as Nebraska and Iowa, according to Milos
Konjevich, regional director of the FDIC.

Citizens' ''unsafe and unsound'' management practices also contributed to its
problems, Mr. Hatch said.

The institution's executive vice president, R.E. Howe, was removed from his
position after examiners found ''alleged lending irregularities'' totaling
$1.625 million, according to Mr. Hatch.

Apparently, people listed as loan recipients did not receive money from the
bank, Mr. Hatch said.

The bank is insured against misappropriation of funds and other questionable
practices by its officers, but that coverage has a $1 million limit.

Prosecutor Investigates

Mr. Hatch referred the case to the prosecutor's office of Murray County, where
Fulda is located. Neither R.E. Howe, nor R.P. Howe, the bank's president, were
available for comment.

The failed bank, which had $36 million in deposits, had a negative net worth of
$1.275 million.

Although Mr. Hatch doubted any of the bank's more than 5,200 depositors would
lose money, Citizens is the first Minnesota bank failure in which some
depositors have been uninsured.

About 15 accounts exceeded the $100,000 maximum in deposits insured by the FDIC.
About $331,000 was uninsured. Those customers will have to wait for their money,
just as any other creditor, according to Mr. Whitney.

The bank, which ended the year with total assets of $39 million, lost $293,000
last year. The bank also ended the year with $7.1 million in nonperforming
loans, of which $4.8 million were more than 90 days past due.

Of the $542,000 the bank had to charge off last year, $330,000 was in
agricultural loans, according to the bank's yearend financial report.

Citizens was the 13th bank and the seventh agricultural institution to fail in
the nation this year. Last year, Minnesota had four bank failures.

                                 March 13, 2014

Donley eligible for FSA loans

BYLINE: The Clarendon Enterprise staff

LENGTH: 238  words


Donley County was declared as a primary natural disaster area on February 12,
2014, and is eligible for Farm Service Agency (FSA) disaster emergency loans.

Generally, that means that farmers who have lost at least 30 percent of their
production due to the damages and losses caused by drought, that occurred from
December 17, 2013 and continuing may be eligible for FSA loans. Proceeds from
crop insurance are taken into consideration when determining eligibility.

Armstrong, Collingsworth, and Hall counties are named contiguous counties where
eligible family farmers may qualify for FSA EM loan assistance, pursuant to
section 321 (a) of the Consolidated Farm and Rual Development Act.

FSA Farm Loan Manager Tonya R. Watson and Farm Loan Officer Debbie Roberts
Hillis is urging farmers who are interested in receiving an emergency loan to
submit their applications into FSA as soon as possible.

Mrs. Watson said, "We hope farmers will get their applications in early rather
than waiting until near the deadline, which is October 14, 2014, for production
and physical losses. The longer they wait, the more chance there is for long
delays. If the applications come in early, we can avoid backlogs and speed up
the process."

The FSA office is located at 305 Ave B, NW in Childress or the Donley County
office located at 321 S. Sully St. in Clarendon. The telephone number is in
Childress is 940-937-8624 and in Clarendon is 806-874-3561.

states experiencing exceptional and extreme drought.

Conservation Program (ECP) to help farmers and ranchers rehabilitate farmland
damaged by natural disasters and for carrying out emergency water conservation
measures in periods of severe drought.

Authorized haying and grazing of Wetlands Reserve Program (WRP) easement areas
in drought-affected areas where haying and grazing is consistent with
conservation of wildlife habitat and wetlands.

Lowered the penalty on CRP acres used for emergency haying or grazing, from 25
percent to 10 percent in 2012 and again in 2013.

Simplified the Secretarial disaster designation process and reduced the time it
takes to designate counties affected by disasters by 40 percent.

For further information please visit: http://www.fsa.usda.gov/

                        The Bemidji Pioneer (Minnesota)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             October 9, 2009 Friday

12 Northwest counties declared disaster area

BYLINE: Brad Swenson, The Bemidji Pioneer, Minn.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 501 words


Oct. 9--Twelve northwest Minnesota counties, including Beltrami County, were
declared a disaster area Thursday by U.S. Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack.

Kittson, Koochiching, Lake of the Woods, Marshall, Pennington, and Roseau
counties were designated as primary natural disaster areas. Beltrami,
Clearwater, Itasca, Polk, Red Lake, and St. Louis counties have been designated
as contiguous agricultural disaster counties, Gov. Tim Pawlenty said Thursday in
a statement.

The designation makes farm operators in each county eligible for low-interest
emergency loans from the federal Farm Service Agency. The gvernor requested the
designation on Sept. 15, due to excessive snow and rain, flooding and
unseasonably cool temperatures, that occurred between April 1 and June 30.

"Many farmers in northern Minnesota struggled this year because of difficult
conditions," Republican Pawlenty said. "We want to ensure Minnesota farmers who
suffered losses earlier this year have access to assistance that will help them
manage through this agricultural disaster."

U.S. Sen. Al Franken, DFL-Minn., followed Pawlenty's request with a letter to
Vilsack also requesting the disaster area designation.

"I am relieved that Secretary Vilsack recognized the urgency of the situation
here on our farms in northern Minnesota," said Franken. "Protecting Minnesota's
family farms and farming communities is incredibly important to me."

Farmers in the designated six counties are now eligible to be considered for
low-interest emergency loans from the Farm Service Agency and the Supplemental
Revenue Assistance Program.

The Loss Assessment Report submitted by the counties and approved by the FSA
showed that farms in the affected counties experienced crop losses of 30 percent
or more due to prevented planting of corn, soybeans, wheat, canola, sunflowers,
flax, and barely, Pawlenty said.

Farmers located in the designated counties should contact their local FSA office
for more information about the available assistance. This assistance includes
FSA emergency loans and the Supplemental Revenue Assistance Payments Program,
which was approved as part of the Food, Conservation, and Energy Act of 2008.

Emergency loan funds may be used to restore or replace essential property, pay
all or part of production costs associated with the disaster year, pay essential
family living expenses, reorganize the farming operation and refinance certain
debts. FSA considers each application on its own merit by taking into account
the extent of losses, security available, and repayment ability.

                     The Chronicle (Centralia, Washington)

                             June 30, 2015 Tuesday

Disaster Designation for Drought Makes Federal Loans Available to Farmers,
Ranchers in Lewis County

BYLINE: The Chronicle, Centralia, Wash.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 338 words


June 30--Lewis County farmers and ranchers facing hardship due to the drought
can now apply for federal financial assistance.

The secretary of agriculture automatically activated a disaster designation for
multiple Washington state counties on June 24 when eight counties reached severe
drought conditions as determined by the U.S. Drought Monitor.

The eight primary disaster counties are: Adams, Columbia, Grant, Walla Walla,
Benton, Franklin, Klickitat and Yakima.

Because Lewis County borders Yakima County, farmers and ranchers are also
eligible for low-interest emergency loans. Farmers in Douglas, King, Okanogan,
Skamania, Garfield, Kittitas, Lincoln, Pierce and Whitman counties also qualify
for help.

"If drought worsens in our country, we may be implementing additional disaster
relief programs," said Martha Dorsey, county executive director for the Farm
Service Agency. "It's important that farmers and ranchers report damage and
losses to the FSA office to help us assess the overall drought situation in case
we need to request approval to offer additional programs."

Farmers and ranchers can apply for low-interest emergency loans from the U.S.
Department of Agriculture's Farm Service Agency. The loans can be used to
restore or replace property, pay associated production costs, living expenses,
reorganize operations or refinance debts.

Farmers have eight months to apply for the loans to help cover part of their
losses from June 24. The up to 40-year loans have a 3.375 percent interest rate.
Each application will be considered based on the extent of losses, security
available and repayment ability.

The Livestock Forage; Emergency Conservation; Livestock Indemnity; Emergency
Assistance for Livestock, Honeybees and Farm-Raised Fish; and the Tree
Assistance programs also offer assistance to farmers and ranchers.

For additional information visit disaster.fsa.usda.gov.

                           Lowell Sun (Massachusetts)

                           September 8, 2016 Thursday

$1M loan fund for farmers launched

BYLINE: By Katie Lannan, State House News Service

SECTION: NEWS; Local

LENGTH: 418 words


BOSTON -- Up to $1 million in micro-loans will now be available to Massachusetts
farmers struggling under the impacts of a widespread and historic drought.

The launch of the Drought Emergency Loan Fund, announced Wednesday, is one of a
series of steps Gov. Charlie Baker and his administration are taking in response
to five months of abnormally dry weather.

Comparing it to a similar effort that made loans available to assist businesses
after record snowfall in 2015, Baker said in a statement that the fund "will
provide affordable working capital to small businesses grappling with the
aftermath of extreme weather."

Massachusetts has been under its own official drought declaration since July 1
and the arid conditions have been blamed for contributing to wild fires, an
outbreak of gypsy moths, higher rates of ant infestation, smaller than usual
apples, loss of crops, and an elevated population of mosquitoes carrying West
Nile virus.

Loan amounts range from $5,000 to $10,000 and are available to
Massachusetts-based family farms and "farm related businesses," according to the
application. Businesses "involved in real estate investment, multi-level
marketing, adult entertainment or firearms" are ineligible.

The new drought loan program is anticipated to run through November. The
Massachusetts Growth Capital Corporation will be responsible for funding the
loan, managing the loan portfolio and collecting interest and principal
payments.

State officials first announced plans to create an emergency loan fund at an
Aug. 18 press conference at North Andover's Smolak Farms, where owner Michael
Smolak said his strawberry plants and Christmas tree seedlings were suffering
under the dry conditions.

Smolak said this year's drought was "as bad as I've ever seen it, and I was born
in 1952, so I've been around for a few years."

As of Aug. 19, Massachusetts farmers had lost nearly $14 million in crops due to
the drought. The U.S. Department of Agriculture Farm Service Agency's state
emergency board has submitted a request for disaster declaration for some
Massachusetts counties, which would make federal assistance available.

Farmers in Essex, Franklin, Middlesex and Worcester counties qualify for federal
aid by virtue of a USDA disaster declaration in the New Hampshire counties they
border.

The Massachusetts Drought Management Task Force meets Thursday morning and plans
to get updates on conditions around the state and consider changing the drought
level classification for some parts of the state.

Brown Announces USDA Disaster Designation Status for 22 Ohio Counties

LENGTH: 305  words

DATELINE: Washington


Office of the Senator Sherrod Brown, U.S Government has issued the following
news release:

New federal assistance is available for Ohio agricultural producers in 22
northeastern and southern Ohio counties who experienced crop or production loss
due to a recent freeze. U.S. Sen. Sherrod Brown (D-OH) today announced that the
United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) has designated Ashtabula, Geauga,
Jackson, Lake, Lorain, Portage, and Summit Counties as primary natural disaster
counties after they experienced freezing weather conditions between January 2,
2014 and April 17, 2014. The USDA has also designated Ashland, Cuyahoga, Erie,
Gallia, Huron, Lawrence, Mahoning, Medina, Pike, Ross, Scioto, Stark, Trumbull,
Vinton, and Wayne Counties as contiguous disaster counties.

"Ohio producers whose livelihoods are threatened by no fault of their own rely
on the FSA's emergency loan program to manage risk on their farms and continue
to provide a reliable food supply for Ohio and the world," said Brown. "This
federal assistance will help them rebuild and get back on their feet."

With this disaster designation, primary and contiguous counties are eligible to
be considered for assistance from the Farm Service Agency (FSA), including
emergency loans. Eligible farmers have eight months from the date of the
official disaster declaration to apply for emergency loans and can receive
guidance in applying for these loans from their local FSA office.

Brown is the first Ohioan to serve on the Senate Agriculture Committee in more
than 40 years. In 2014, he was part of the Senate Farm Bill Conference Committee
that successfully negotiated a five-year farm bill that had been stalled for
more than three years.

                          Corsicana Daily Sun (Texas)

                     Distributed by Tribune Content Agency

                             July 14, 2015 Tuesday

Disaster assistance available for Texas farmers, ranchers

BYLINE: Corsicana Daily Sun, Texas

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 523 words


July 14--AUSTIN -- When disasters such as the May 4 through June 19 storms and
floods strike, farmers and ranchers have options for help.

Farmers and ranchers affected by the May 4 to June 19 storms, tornadoes,
straight-line winds may be eligible for assistance from several agencies and
should apply today.

The Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) may assist survivors who are
farmers and ranchers with some immediate needs including:

Grants to pay for temporary housing and minor home repairs,

Grants to replace personal property, including clothing,

Grants to pay for serious immediate needs not covered by insurance.

The U.S. Small Business Administration (SBA) may offer low-interest loans to
farmers and ranchers to rebuild or repair their primary home and replace lost or
damaged personal property.

To begin the application process, call FEMA at 800-621-FEMA (3362), TTY
800-462-7585, or for those who use 711 or Video Relay Services (VRS), call
800-621-3362. Survivors may also apply online at www.DisasterAssistance.gov

Other programs through the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Texas Farm Service
Agency (FSA) include:

Emergency loans may be used to:

Restore or replace essential property,

Pay all or part of production costs associated with the disaster year,

Pay essential family living expenses,

Reorganize the farming operation, and

Refinance certain debts, excluding real estate.

Provide loan applicants up to 100 percent of their total actual production
and/or physical losses. Production losses must not exceed 30 percent. The
maximum loan is $500,000.

Non-Insured Crop Disaster Assistance Program provides financial assistance for
non-insurable crops when low yields, loss of inventory, or prevented planting
occur due to natural disasters, including grass for grazing. Eligible producers
must have purchased coverage for 2015.

Livestock Indemnity Program with payments to eligible producers for livestock
death losses in excess of normal mortality due to the disaster,

Tree Assistance Program for nursery tree growers, vineyards and orchardists.

Emergency Assistance for Livestock, Honeybees and Farm-Raised Fish Program that
provides emergency relief for feed losses (including lost grazing days and baled
forage) and/or water shortages, due to a disaster.

Emergency Conservation Program that provides emergency funding to rehabilitate
land severely damaged by a natural disaster, including fencing.

Texas leads the nation in the number of farms and ranches with 248,800 farms and
ranches covering more than 130 million acres. The economic impact of food and
fiber grown in Texas amounts to more than $100 billion per year.

To date, the FSA has identified dozens of disaster counties and contiguous
counties where farmers and ranchers are eligible for FSA emergency loans. To get
more information on FSA services, go online to the U.S. Department of
Agriculture website at: www.fsa.usda.gov.

To locate your nearest FSA County office, visit: http://offices.usda.gov.

Farm agency offers loans for tornado damage

Family farmers in Erie County have been declared eligible for disaster emergency
loan assistance from the Farm Service Agency for damage and losses caused by the
tornado that struck July 25 in neighboring Genesee County.

Under the program, farmers may be eligible for physical loss loans of up to 100
percent of their actual losses, the operating loan amount needed to continue
business, or a maximum principal balance outstanding of $500,000, whichever is
less.

Farmers must be unable to obtain credit from private commercial lenders to
receive the loans. The interest rate on the emergency loans is 3.75 percent.

Applications will be accepted until April 7. The FSA office is located at 3542
Turner Road, Jamestown. For more information call 664-2351.

***

Downtown Fredonia hosts Farm Festival

FREDONIA -- The Fredonia Farm Festival is this weekend at Barker Commons.

Today's events include a farmers' market and craft, art and food vendors, a
children's pet show at 10 a.m. and a '50s sock hop, including a hula hoop
contest at noon at the park gazebo. At 5 p.m. there will be a pie contest, pie
auction, youth cookie contest and youth cookie auction. Music in the gazebo gets
under way at 7 p.m.

On Sunday, vendors will be on hand at the farmers' market and throughout the
park, with a parade getting under way at 1 p.m.

At 4 p.m. there will be a concert by country musician Sean Patrick McGraw.

PORTVILLE -- The Pfeiffer Nature Center, at 1974 Lillibridge Road, is host to
two events this month that are open to the public.

"Interesting Insects," with Bill Shelp, is scheduled from 10 a.m. to noon today.

"Owl Prowl," with Hawk Hideaway is planned for 7 to 9 p.m. Aug. 29. There is a
$5 fee.

To register, call (716) 933-0187. For information, visit
www.pfeiffernaturecenter.org.
