                           Ruidoso News (New Mexico)

                             July 14, 2011 Thursday

Rain does not end drought

BYLINE: By Dianne Stallings dstallings@ruidosonews.com

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 290 words


Lincoln County is among 16 in northern and central New Mexico declared disaster
areas by the Obama Administration because of severe drought.

The rain that fell Tuesday and Wednesday won't change the longer-term
designation of drought hanging over the area.

Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack said as a result of the declaration, all New
Mexico counties are eligible for assistance. A secretarial disaster designation
makes farm operators in both primary and contiguous counties eligible to be
considered for assistance from the Farm Service Agency, provided eligibility
requirements are met. This assistance includes FSA emergency loans and the
Supplemental Revenue Assistance Payments Program. Farmers in eligible counties
have eight months from the date of a secretarial disaster declaration to apply
for emergency loan assistance.

FSA officials will consider each emergency loan application on its own merits,
taking into account the extent of production losses, security available and
repayment ability. SURE Program applications for 2011 crop losses will be
accepted in 2012, when the 2011 farm revenue data required by statute becomes
available.

Earlier this summer, U.S.D.A. officials approved an emergency application that
allows ranchers from Curry, Harding, Lea, Quay, Roosevelt, Union, De Baca,
Torrance and Colfax counties to graze their livestock on lands not typically
used for grazing.

The 16 counties covered by the current declaration and eligible to apply for
drought disaster assistance are Lincoln, Bernalillo, Harding, Rio Arriba, Taos,
Cibola, San Miguel, Torrance, Colfax, McKinley, Sandoval, Union, Guadalupe,
Mora, Santa Fe, and Valencia. Last month, USDA declared more than a dozen other
counties drought disaster areas.

                          The Capital (Annapolis, MD)

                             June 28, 2011 Tuesday

Business Notes

SECTION: HOMETOWNANNAPOLIS.CO; Businesss; Pg. B1

LENGTH: 473  words


ARINC Incorporated is marketing its portable flight information display system
microFIDSTM to the hospitality industry.

The system is a wireless version of airport display technology used around the
world that provides up-to-the-minute flight arrival and departure information in
an economical way that's easily applied in places like hotel lobbies, business
centers, reception areas and other common spaces.

The system is already operating in several New York hotels.

***

Heritage Harbour Health and Rehabilitation Center has received a 2011 recipient
of the Bronze Commitment to Quality National Quality Award for its performance
in the health care profession. The award, presented by the American Health Care
Association and National Center for Assisted Living highlights facilities from
across the nation that have demonstrated their intention to pursue a rigorous
quality improvement system.

***

To help local families better prepare for an emergency, the local Home Instead
Senior Care office is making available at no cost a senior emergency kit that
includes items such as a checklist of important contact names and information, a
medication tracker, allergies/conditions worksheet, a senior health tracker
magnet and a wallet card to carry when away from home.

The file also allows for the storage of important documents in an emergency,
such as a health care proxy, advance directives, insurance polices, insurance
cards and more.

These materials also can be accessed and downloaded by the public at
www.senioremergencykit.com. Contact the local Home Instead Senior Care office at
410-349-2320 to obtain a specialized senior kit.

***

BJ's Wholesale Clubs began offering Maryland-grown produce last Friday.

The Farm to Club program, which BJ's created in partnership with the Maryland
Department of Agriculture, will provide its members with fresh-from-the-farm
zucchini, cucumbers and yellow squash that was grown on three Maryland farms.

BJ's intends to soon include locally grown tomatoes, green peppers and corn.

The participating Maryland farms are Arnold Farms, LLC in Chestertown, Butler
Farms in Marion Station and Miller Farms in Clinton.

BJ's intends to roll out its Farm to Club program in six other states later this
summer.

***

Fixed mortgage rates were mostly unchanged last week, hovering near yearly lows.

Freddie Mac says the average rate on the 30-year loan held steady at 4.50
percent. It hit 4.49 percent two weeks ago, the lowest level this year.

The Associated Press reports that the average rate on the 15-year fixed
mortgage, popular for refinancing, inched up to 3.69 percent. Last week it
reached a yearly low of 3.67 percent.

Rates typically track the yield on the 10-year Treasury note, which has been
dropping in recent weeks based on weak data that points to a slower economy.

                         Brattleboro Reformer (Vermont)

                           November 10, 2011 Thursday

Stop procrastinating

SECTION: OPINION

LENGTH: 581 words


Thursday, November 10, 2011

Time is running out. With the Nov. 15 deadline to register and apply for federal
assistance fast approaching, Vermonters affected by Tropical Storm Irene can no
longer afford to keep procrastinating.

The Small Business Administration's disaster loan program makes low-interest,
long-term loans available to businesses, homeowners and renters harmed by
disasters. Loan applications are issued to all those who register with the
Federal Emergency Management Agency.

So far, the number of Vermonters submitting applications has been low. Of the
1,826 SBA disaster loan applications issued to affected businesses, only 219
have been returned as of late Sunday. Fewer than 20 percent of homeowners and
renters who have registered with FEMA have returned the SBA application - only
789 of the 4,183 applications issued, according to Carl Sherrill, one of SBA's
on-the-ground disaster staffers in Vermont.

U.S. Sen. Patrick Leahy and Gov. Peter Shumlin are urging all Vermonters
affected by the flooding from Tropical Storm Irene to register with FEMA and get
their SBA applications in before Tuesday's deadline.

"Vermonters have one shot at tapping federal recovery help in Irene's aftermath,
and it is about to pass many Vermonters by," Leahy said.

Many business owners have said they cannot afford more debt. But Leahy said SBA
disaster loans have longer terms and lower rates than some commercially
available products, making them affordable to more businesses. Payments can be
as reasonable as $50 a month under the program.

Leahy also noted that nearly 3,400 Vermont homeowners and renters who have not
returned their applications may be missing out not only on low-interest loans,
but also on additional grants.

Filling out an application does not obligate the applicant to accept a loan if
offered, but once the deadline passes there will be no opportunities to apply
later.

"It is critical that anyone who has sustained damage from Irene register with
FEMA and complete the SBA application, even if at this point you're not sure you
need the financial help," said Shumlin.

In addition to the FEMA and SBA deadline, other federal disaster assistance
deadlines coming up in the next week or two include: - Nov. 18: U.S. Department
of Agriculture/Natural Resources Conservation Service deadline for
municipalities to apply for Emergency Watershed Protection Projects.

- Nov. 20: U.S. Department of Agriculture/Farm Service Agency deadline to apply
for Non-Insured Crop Assistance Program for coverage in case of future
disasters; and NAP deadline on forage such as hay, and perennial crops such as
strawberries and blueberries for the 2012 production season.

- Nov. 23: U.S. Department of Agriculture/Farm Service Agency deadline to apply
for cost share assistance through the Emergency Conservation Program for damage
to farm land.

Since Tropical Storm Irene hit more than two months ago Vermonters have been
working at a frantic pace to repair the damage before the onset of winter. It's
understandable that deadlines which seemed far off two months ago would be put
on the bottom of one's do-to list. Now it's time to put FEMA registration and
SBA applications first on that list.

"We want Vermonters whose homes or businesses were impacted by the storm to
access every penny available to help them on the road to recovery," said
Jennifer Hollar, chair of the Irene Housing Task Force.

For more information, call 800-621-FEMA (3362) or go online at
www.DisasterAssistance.gov.

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                            April 12, 2006 Wednesday

Final day to apply for emergency farm loans is April 24

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A06

LENGTH: 159 words


The final day to apply for Farm Service Agency emergency loans, because of the
2005 draught, is April 24. Bob Noellsch, farm loan manager for Lincoln, Pike,
St. Charles and Warren counties said applications are available at the Farm
Service Agency, 1220 S. Business 61, Bowling Green. Loans are for physical and
production losses caused by the draught. Loans for physical losses must be used
to compensate the farmer for losses of basic livestock, stored crops or supplies
on hand and equipment. Loans for production losses may be used to buy feed,
seed, fertilizer, livestock or to make payments on real estate or chattel debt.
In order to qualify, a farmer must have suffered a 30 percent loss in production
or an actual physical loss that was essential to the successful operation of the
farm. Loans for actual losses are made with a 3.75 percent interest rate to
eligible applicants who are unable to obtain the actual credit needed from
another source.

                              The Washington Post

                    April 11, 1984, Wednesday, Final Edition

Suit to Gain Farm Loan Casts Light on Policies

BYLINE: By Ward Sinclair, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: First Section; The Federal Report; A19

LENGTH: 777 words


Willie Ole Knute Kjeldahl, a farmer from Brooten, Minn., was on shaky financial
ground in 1982 when he went to his local Farmers Home Administration (FmHA)
office seeking an economic emergency loan.

Even though the loan program was on the books, and the Agriculture Department
still hadn't spent the $600 million that Congress had allocated for the program
in 1981, the FmHA told Kjeldahl it was not accepting applications because no
money was available.

Kjeldahl's commercial lender foreclosed on his mortgage, and, as a last-ditch
move to stall total collapse, he filed for bankruptcy. In the meantime, he and
other farmers in similar situations around the country went to federal court
here to try to pry open doors at the FmHA.

Their suit, before U.S. District Court Judges Thomas A. Flannery and Thomas
Penfield Jackson, has cast a sharp new light on Reagan administration farm
-credit policies and the inability of members of Congress that represent farmers
to hold the administration's feet to the fire of public opinion and the law.

The suit, filed in late 1982 and nearing final resolution, resulted in an order
last fall by Flannery directing Agriculture Secretary John R. Block to reopen
the emergency loan program, which he said Block had shut down arbitrarily in
1981 in an abuse of his powers.

But Flannery's order was not the end of it. The Office of Management and Budget
then decreed that only a fraction of the $600 million, about $50 million, would
be used for direct loans. The rest, OMB ruled, would have to be used to
guarantee loans that the government expected rural banks to make to farmers.

Therein lay a catch. Rural banks had little interest in guarantees. The program
meant more paper work and the assumption of part of the risk of each loan made
to farmers already rejected by commercial banks.

At that point, Douglas Huron, a local attorney for Kjeldahl and his
co-defendants, went back to court seeking an order to undo the OMB rule. He
argued that about 95 percent of the $6.6 billion loaned under the economic
emergency program since 1978 had been in direct loans and that the rule was an
attempt to rewrite history.

Judge Jackson, agreeing to a Huron motion to add OMB Director David A. Stockman
as a co-defendant with Block, has directed the FmHA to explain its refusal to
handle the direct-loan portion of the program as it had done previously.

One document already on file in the case, a report from FmHA chief Charles W.
Shuman, said the decision was made by OMB--even though Shuman and his boss,
Undersecretary Frank W. Naylor Jr., refused to admit that in a congressional
hearing in February.

Under severe criticism by members of Congress, who pressed the issue for a day
and then basically dropped it, Shuman and Naylor insisted that emergency loans
weren't really needed because plenty of other farm credit was available. In any
case, they told the House Agriculture subcommittee hearing, they were overseeing
the program according to law.

There wasn't much new in that. Since the administration took office in 1981, its
direction of the FmHA has been controversial. The FmHA lends money to farmers
who can't get credit elsewhere. And as economic distress has gripped much of
farm country, the agency has been caught in a vise. As loan demand has
intensified, the FmHA has tried to hold down spending and has tightened its
handling of loan accounts of farmers on the economic margin.

Many of those FmHA policy moves have been challenged in the courts by a small
cadre of lawyers around the country who have contended, generally with success,
that the agency routinely has violated its own regulations for dealing with
farmers' applications and appeals.

Although the FmHA has taken steps to comply with these rulings, some critics
charge that it has done so with such lassitude that loan-seeking farmers are
left out in the cold, too far gone to be helped.  One of the critics, Sen.
Walter D. Huddleston (D-Ky.), ranking Democrat on the Senate Agriculture
Committee, has stressed that point repeatedly in efforts to get Block and
Stockman to keep farm credit programs funded and responsive to farmers' needs.

Huddleston was instrumental in forcing the administration, as part of a newly
passed package of farm support legislation, to accept language requiring the
FmHA to spend at least $310 million of the original $600 million on direct
loans. Notably, his negotiating was with Stockman rather than Block.

Huddleston, angered by OMB's hard line, complained that Stockman, by agreeing to
the increase only if Congress would cut other programs, had turned distressed
farmers into "bargaining chips."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Picture, CHARLES W. SHUMAN . . . says plenty of credit is available

                              The Bismarck Tribune

                           September 18, 2006 Monday

S.D. farmers qualify for help

SECTION: DAKOTA WIRE; Pg. 1b

LENGTH: 129 words


HURON, S.D. (AP) - Farmers in 13 South Dakota counties can sign up for
low-interest emergency loans to cover losses caused by a severe storm that hit
central South Dakota on Aug. 24, according to the Farm Service Agency.

High winds, hail and tornadoes caused the most damage in Beadle, Hand and
McPherson counties. But other counties also were affected, including Brown,
Clark, Hyde, Miner, Walworth, Buffalo, Edmunds, Jerauld, Sanborn, Campbell,
Faulk, Kingsbury, and Spink.

Farm Service Agency Executive Director Steve Cutler said applicants for
emergency loans must be family farmers and unable to get credit elsewhere.

The emergency loans, for up to $500,000, can be used to repair or replace
property that was damaged by the storm.

The deadline to submit applications is May 13.

Washington: Oklahoma counties named natural disaster areas due to drought

LENGTH: 288  words

DATELINE: Washington


Texas and Southwestern Cattle Raisers Association has issued the following news
release:

The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) has designated Hughes, Mayes, Okmulgee
and Wagoner counties in Oklahoma as primary natural disaster areas due to a
recent drought.

Farmers and ranchers in the following counties in Oklahoma also qualify for
natural disaster assistance because their counties are contiguous. Those
counties are Cherokee, Coal, Craig, Creek, Delaware, McIntosh, Muskogee,
Okfuskee, Pittsburg, Pontotoc, Rogers, Seminole and Tulsa.

All counties listed above were designated natural disaster areas on July 16,
2014, making all qualified farm operators in the designated areas eligible for
low interest emergency (EM) loans from USDA's Farm Service Agency (FSA),
provided eligibility requirements are met. Farmers in eligible counties have
eight months from the date of the declaration to apply for loans to help cover
part of their actual losses. FSA will consider each loan application on its own
merits, taking into account the extent of losses, security available and
repayment ability. FSA has a variety of programs, in addition to the EM loan
program, to help eligible farmers recover from adversity.

Additional programs available to assist farmers and ranchers include the
Emergency Conservation Program, The Livestock Forage Disaster Program, the
Livestock Indemnity Program, the Emergency Assistance for Livestock, Honeybees,
and Farm-Raised Fish Program, and the Tree Assistance Program. Interested
farmers may contact their local USDA Service Centers for further information on
eligibility requirements and application procedures for these and other
programs.

For further information please visit: http://tscra.org

                               September 2, 2010

Emergency Loan Designation

BYLINE: Monroe County Appeal staff

LENGTH: 262  words


Mr. Edward J. Hamill, State Executive Director, Farm Service Agency announces
effective Aug. 20, ninety-five counties in Missouri will have FSA disaster loans
available due to excessive rainfall, flash flooding, flooding and high winds
which occurred Feb. 1 through July 15. Applications for assistance will be
accepted at the county office of the Farm Service Agency in Monroe, Marion,
Ralls and Shelby Counties for physical and production losses caused by this
disaster. Applications will be accepted through April 20, 2011.

Loans for physical losses must be used to replace or repair damage to buildings,
fences or to compensate the farmer for losses of basic livestock, stored crops
or supplies on hand, equipment, etc., that was lost due to the disaster. Loans
for production losses may also be used to buy feed, seed, fertilizer, livestock
or to make payments on real estate or chattel debts. Generally, loans for
production losses cannot be approved until crops have completed their production
cycle or have been harvested.

In order to qualify, a farm must have suffered a 30% loss in production or an
actual physical loss that essential to the successful operation of the farm.

Loans for actual losses are made at an interest rate of 3.75% for emergency
loans to those eligible applicants who are unable to obtain the actual credit
needed from another source. All loan programs of the Farm Service Agency are
conducted on a non-discriminatory basis.

Sheila L. Osbourne, Farm Loan Manager, may be contacted at: 18771 Highway 15,
Paris, MO 65275, 660-327-4737, ext. 102.

California: Disaster Loans Available to Farmers, Ranchers and Small Businesses
in El Dorado County

LENGTH: 286  words

DATELINE: New York



 Sacramento: County of EL Dorado, The State of California has issued the
followin news release:



   President Donald J. Trump issued a major disaster declaration on February 14,
2017 due to Severe Winter Storms, Flooding and Mudslides that occurred January
3-12, 2017. As a result the U.S. Department of Agriculture has emergency loans
available for farms and businesses in El Dorado County.





 Emergency farm loans for up to a maximum of $500,000 are available for both
physical and crop production losses as a direct result of the disaster. The
loans are available to farmers and ranchers who conduct family-sized farming
operations.



 Agriculturalists interested in these loans can contact the local Farm Service
Agency (FSA) office in Elk Grove at (916)714-1104.



 In addition, when an agricultural disaster designation is declared, Economic
Injury Disaster Loans (EIDLs) of up to $2 million are available through the U.S.
Small Business Administration (SBA). Businesses primarily engaged in farming or
ranching are not eligible for SBA disaster loans. Some of the businesses that
may qualify for severe storm disaster EIDLs are small agricultural cooperatives,
nurseries, private nonprofit organizations and other small businesses that
depend on farmers and ranchers or have been directly impacted from the disaster.




 Applicants may apply for a SBA loan online using the Electronic Loan
Application at https://disasterloan.sba.gov/ela. Businesses can also e-mail the
SBA's Customer Service Center at disastercustomerservice@sba.gov or call
(800)659-2955 for disaster loan information and application forms.

                       Eureka Times Standard (California)

                           October 24, 2013 Thursday

Drying times in Humboldt County: Drought effects echo through beginning of rainy
season

BYLINE: Catherine Wong/The Times-Standard

SECTION: BREAKING; News; Local

LENGTH: 712 words


With temperatures dropping and the fog rolling in, it may be hard to believe
Humboldt County is still in a drought.

"The effects of a drought, the lag is a full year," said Blake Alexandre, a
Humboldt County dairy farmer. "We will be suffering all winter and all spring
because of this summer."

Alexandre, who owns ranches in Ferndale, Eureka and Del Norte County, and a hay
farm in Modoc County, said he has 40 percent less feed going into this winter
than normal.

"Part of that is due to us having a drought year in 2012 too," he said. "When
the cattle were let back out to graze they were super hungry, so we had less
grass yield this year as a result."

The U.S. Department of Agriculture named Humboldt, Del Norte, Siskiyou, Trinity,
Shasta and Mendocino counties as primary natural disaster areas for severe to
exceptional drought levels in August. As of Tuesday, every county in California
was listed as a drought disaster area.

Alexandre said four of the wells on his property in Del Norte went dry for the
first time, and while he was expecting 6 to 7 tons of hay from the Modoc farm,
this year he received less than 5 tons. He said he will have to buy extra feed
this year just to keep the cattle fed.

"Hungry cattle aren't as healthy and they don't perform as well," he said. "They
produce less meat and less milk. There's just less to sell. All of our costs are
higher because we have to buy feed with less production."

USDA Farm Service Agency Humboldt County Executive Officer Katie Delbar said
there has been a 70 percent feed loss in Humboldt County this year. She said the
USDA designation allows affected farmers to apply for up to $500,000 in
emergency farm loans for losses directly caused by the drought.

Alexandre said he probably would not be applying for a USDA loan this year.

"I tried last year and was denied," he said. "I think we're just too big."

Delbar said the emergency loans are for ranchers or farmers less likely to
obtain traditional funding.

"Emergency loans are meant much more for beginning farms," she said. "If you are
able to get a bank loan, then that's what you should be doing."

Delbar said more than 100 Humboldt County farmers are part of the Noninsured
Crop Disaster Assistance Program. She said farmers who bought in to the program
will receive money from the government if they lose more than 50 percent of
their crops during a disaster.

"Those payments haven't been made yet," she said. "We're hoping those go out in
December or January."

Delbar said five disaster assistance programs authorized by the 2008 Farm Bill
have not been funded by Congress.

"I'm really hoping we see better weather in the winter and spring next year,"
she said. "But it's still going to be hard."

For the week of Oct. 15, Humboldt County was in a D-1, or moderate drought,
according to the U.S. drought monitor.

Humboldt County Agriculture Commissioner Jeff Dolf said the lack of rain is
concerning.

"We need to return to a more normal seasonal rainfall pattern for us to really
break this drought," Dolf said. "We thought we were getting a good start with
that initial rainfall we had, but unfortunately it hasn't continued."

National Weather Service meteorologist Scott Carroll said rainfall so far this
season -- which started July 1 -- has been 1.25 inches above normal, but overall
is still 10.5 inches below normal for the year.

Carroll said chances are nearly equal for there to be above or below normal
rainfall for the next three months, with the same nearly equal chances for the
weather to be above or below normal temperatures.

"It looks like we're still solidly in the dry season right now," he said.

On the web:

The latest U.S. drought monitor map is released each Thursday by the National
Drought Mitigation Center. For the latest updates, visitdroughtmonitor.unl.edu
and click on California.

Dried out in Humboldt

Rainfall: 10.5 inches below normal for year

Moderate drought: Designation in October

Feed loss: 70 percent

Farmers in disaster programs: 100

Information on disaster funds:

located at 5630 South Broadway St. in Eureka.

The phone number is 442-6058.

                               The New York Times

               February 25, 1985, Monday, Late City Final Edition

DOLE SAYS BIGGEST HELP TO FARMERS WOULD BE CUTTING BUDGET DEFICIT

BYLINE: By SETH S. KING

SECTION: Section A; Page 13, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 926 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24


Senator Bob Dole today told legislators from the Farm Belt that the best thing
the Government could do for farmers was to reduce the Federal budget deficit.

To do that, the Senate majority leader said, agriculture will have to absorb its
share of spending cuts.

More than 200 officials from 30 states gathered here this weekend to discuss the
growing farm recession in their areas. They plan a major lobbying campaign as
Congress debates emergency farm credit bills this week.

Speaking to these officials at a State of the American Farm Conference, Senator
Dole, a Kansas Republican, said, ''We are not going to be able to help every
farmer in every state with Federal programs, no matter how badly off they may
be.''

''The best thing we should do for your farmers in the long run,'' Mr. Dole said,
''is to bring down the deficit, get the budget into closer balance, and bring
down the interest rates that you say are killing your farmers.''

Promise to Hold Military

In answer to complaints from his audience that agriculture would take the
biggest budget cuts and increases in military spending would not be touched,
Senator Dole replied:

''That's not the way it's going to be. We're going to have a freeze-plus budget,
and defense is going to be included. We wouldn't be sitting down to talk to the
Russians today if we hadn't increased defense money. But we are now going to
hold those increases to somewhere between 2 and 4 percent next year.''

This would be a lower rate of increase than the 5.9 percent, adjusted for
inflation, that President Reagan called for in his 1986 Budget Message.

By a freeze-plus budget, Senator Dole meant that all appropriations would be
frozen at levels no higher than this year's, except where increases have been
committed in past budgets.

State Senator Richard G. Gannon, a Democrat from the wheat-growing area around
Goodland, Kan., agreed with Mr. Dole on the need for cuts in the 1986 budget.
''Yes, we have to get the deficit down and bring interest rates down and
agriculture will have to bear its share of this,'' he said. ''But if we don't
bring some sanity to those 1985 farm act proposals and don't strangle our
farmers with such big aid cuts, there won't be any agriculture left to worry
about.''

The legislators, many of whom are members of farm policy committees of the
National Conference of State Legislatures, will meet again Monday at the J. W.
Marriott Hotel to adopt farm policy resolutions for Congress and to hear
Agriculture Secretary John R. Block.

On Friday Mr. Block disclosed details of the Administration's proposed
''Agricultural Adjustment Act of 1985,'' which would gradually eliminate
subsidies to grain and cotton farmers and sharply reduce the amount of price
support loans these farmers could receive on their 1986 crops.

Farm Crises Every Year

Mr. Dole, who told his listeners that in each of the 25 years he had served in
Congress there had been either a farm problem or a farm crisis, gave no
indication of how much of Mr. Reagan's new farm program he would support.

''At this moment,'' Mr. Dole said, ''the best thing I can say about his
Agricultural Adjustment Act of 1985 is that it will at least focus us on where
we should be going with a new farm bill.''

Earlier, State Senator Charles Byrd of Minnesota said the farmers in his
district regarded the authors of the Administration's farm proposals, Mr. Block
and David A. Stockman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, ''in
common with Auschwitz.''

''My farmers are appalled,'' he told the other legislators, who applauded when
he added, ''I'm a Republican, but I don't know how much longer I'm going to stay
one.''

But they also applauded when Assemblyman Bob Anderson, also of Minnesota,
reminded Mr. Byrd that today's conference was nonpartisan and one purpose was to
show Congress that legislators of both parties wanted something done to help
their farmer constituents.

Focus on Emergency Credit

But the Farm Belt legislators appeared more immediately interested in emergency
credit for farmers either facing bankruptcy or needing money to plant their
spring crops than in the Administration's new farm program.

Farm Belt Democrats in the Senate, who had been delaying the confirmation vote
of Edwin Meese 3d as Attorney General in an effort to force the Administration
to liberalize farm loan guarantees, got a commitment from Mr. Dole last week
that this would be done. Mr. Dole also agreed that senators of both parties
could offer proposals this week on other emergency credit measures, including
advanced payments on price support loans farmers will get on 1985 crops.

''We're certainly on the right track on farm credit,'' Mr. Dole said today.
''But then we've always been. The President offered this same farm debt
restructuring plan last October, saying $650 million would be available for loan
guarantees. Now we're saying that any amount, a billion dollars, two billion,
whatever is needed, will be provided. There is no cap, no limit on this if the
bankers agree to reschedule the farm loans in trouble, using the guarantees
we've provided.''

The Administration also agreed to liberalize the standards the Farmers Home
Administration sets in endorsing the Government guarantees.

Senator Dole told the legislators that they could not expect anything more than
this on emergency farm credit.

''The country bankers are satisified with this expanded package, and they always
go after the best deal they can get,'' he said.

                            The Philadelphia Inquirer

                   JULY 13, 1999 Tuesday CNEW JERSEY EDITION

FOR FARMS HIT BY MAY STORM, THE WORST MAY BE YET TO COME

BYLINE: Erika Hobbs, INQUIRER SUBURBAN STAFF

SECTION: SOUTH JERSEY; Pg. B01

LENGTH: 1070 words


The quarter-size hail from a single storm in May cost Sal Parzanese $60,000.

At least.

The storm hacked away five acres of the Parzanese Bros. Produce Inc. cucumber
pickle crop, causing the Winslow Township farm to miss out on the early pickle
market.

"They go for about $30 a box," Parzanese said, "and I would have had about 2,000
to 3,000 boxes."

He was one of the lucky ones.

"Mine's not so bad," Parzanese said. "The other ones, especially the peach farms
, they got hit real hard." He has planted more cucumbers, asparagus and sweet
potatoes, which were also wiped out, and said he expected a normal harvest of
those crops this summer.

According to state reports, the May 24 thunderstorm ravaged more than 5,700
acres on 54 of the 1,785 farms in Atlantic, Camden and Gloucester Counties,
destroying a significant quantity of fruit orchards and vegetable crops.
Although the storm also hit Pennsylvania, the damage there was minimal,
agriculture agents said.

Many of the damaged fields have been replanted in time for late harvests.
However, farmers still face a potential financial nightmare. Federal farm aid
has nearly run out, and farmers fear that news of crop damage will steer
commercial buyers away from New Jersey.

"It's happened before," said Richard VanVranken, an agricultural agent with the
Rutgers Cooperative Extension of Atlantic County. "Word got out, and farmers
couldn't sell their [produce].

"But there is still a good quantity and good quality of crops still out there."

According to the National Weather Service in Mount Holly, 58-m.p.h. winds and
large hail ripped through the area that day. Winds of 40 m.p.h. will take down
power lines, said Bill Goodman, a meteorologist at the weather service.

According to a survey by the Rutgers Cooperative Extension of Atlantic County,
the storm flattened a path one mile wide and six miles long from Ancora through
Elm to Hammonton and caused scattered damage elsewhere. Nearly all of the 350
acres of peach orchards in Atlantic County were destroyed, and all 25 acres of
peas were wiped out.

Peach and apple orchards in all three counties were hardest hit. The hail caught
the budding fruit and smashed branches. If those buds live, they could mature
into pockmarked, ugly fruit that will not sell in stores.

In Atlantic County, other crops, including strawberries, peppers and squash,
were also devastated. Even fields with crops left standing had to be replanted
because flooding increased the risk of disease, the report said.

"There's no way to assess the monetary damage" immediately, said Lynn Tjeerdsma,
chief of emergency preparedness and programs at the U.S. Department of
Agriculture. But about 60 percent of the three counties' sweet-corn crop and
more than 40 percent of the strawberry crop were damaged, he said.

Jim Willmott, a Camden County Rutgers Cooperative Extension agricultural agent,
said at least three-quarters of the vegetable crops on Camden County's 200 full-
and part-time farms were damaged. Six of those farms are larger than 200 acres.
The rest are small, part-time farms.

Michelle Infante, an agent in Gloucester County, said the crops there -
including cucumbers, cantaloupe and squash - "look pretty good" and should
bounce back quickly.

"They were hit before they were very mature, and they are growing out of any
damage," she said.

Willmott said consumers were unlikely to be affected by the destruction because
most of the crops had recovered sufficiently to provide attractive produce at
low prices. The real cost of the storm's damage will not be revealed until the
fall, he said.

First, farmers spent unbudgeted money to replant the damaged fields. (Parzanese
estimated that it took an extra 16 hours and eight men to replant his pickle
crop by hand.) Now they may not have the financial safety net of a federal loan
to recoup the losses.

Further, VanVranken said, commercial brokers could avoid New Jersey farmers this
season, sinking farmers even further into debt.

New Jersey growers supply some summer fruit and vegetables to brokers who buy
produce for large grocery-store chains such as Acme and Giant in a region
extending from Canada to Florida and west to Mississippi, he said. Most of
summer produce, however, is sold to chains in the Philadelphia, New York and
Baltimore areas.

If buyers suspect a problem with the state's crops, no matter how minor, they
will bypass the entire state, VanVranken said.

Several years ago, a similar storm hit peach growers in South Jersey, he said.
Many orchards pulled through with unblemished fruit, but skittish buyers still
ignored the state.

"Hail did a good amount of damage in April. Then word got out, and they couldn't
sell their peaches in August," he said.

Farmers are so frightened that their crops will not be bought that at least a
half-dozen did not return repeated phone calls.

"They have been advised not to" by some agriculture agents, VanVranken said.

In June, Gov. Whitman asked the USDA to declare the region a natural-disaster
area, making farmers eligible for low-interest Department of Agriculture
emergency loans.

However, the Farm Service Agency, the USDA division that handles the loans, has
no more money to lend.

"Tremendous, widespread disasters across the county have made the loans more
necessary," said Chuck Ropp, a senior loan officer at the agency in Washington.
An unusual wave of disasters, from the Midwest flooding five years ago to the
recent Oklahoma tornadoes, has driven up the need for emergency assistance, he
said.

South Jersey qualified twice last year for emergency aid, and the May disaster
is the only pending emergency designation this year, said Steve Swieter, acting
state executive director for the Farm Service Agency.

Farmers who have sustained at least a 30 percent crop loss can apply for a 3
percent loan of up to $500,000 from the agency.

But the agency has depleted its $170 million fund for emergency loans as well as
an extra $92 million allocated by Congress in April. Ropp said the agency has
lent about $254 million this year.

Farmers should not give up hope, Ropp said. The agency can help them find
alternative loan sources or process a loan application, pending new funds. He
said the USDA was asking Congress for even more money this year and was trying
to shift money from other agency programs.

                               The New York Times

                May 28, 1981, Thursday, Late City Final Edition

Farm Loan Unit Raises Its Rates

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section D; Page 12, Column 4; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 153 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 27


The Farmers Home Administration said today that it was raising the interest
rates on most of its loans by one-quarter to one and three-quarters points,
effective Saturday.

''The higher rates were necessary because interest rates are increasing and it's
our intent to keep our rates as close as possible with the cost of money to the
U.S. Treasury,'' said Dwight Calhoun, the agency's acting administrator.

The agency's new rates will be as follows: 14 1/2 percent on farm operating
loans, 15 percent on emergency disaster loans, 14 3/4 percent on economic
emergency loans, 13 1/4 percent on single-family rural home loans and 13 1/4
percent on multiple-family housing loans.

Interest rates will remain at 7 percent for very-low-income farm production
loans and 5 percent for very-low-income farm real estate loans.

                           October 20, 2010 Wednesday

Flood damage assistance expanded

BYLINE: Sue Book, Sun Journal, New Bern, N.C.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 558 words


Oct. 20--Word of disaster assistance for more families and farmers in Eastern
North Carolina arrived Tuesday.

The major disaster declaration from the Federal Emergency Management Agency was
expanded to include Jones County and three other counties that suffered flood
damage from the remnants of Tropical Storm Nicole.

Storm victims in Jones, Pitt, Brunswick and Pender counties could be eligible
for federal low-interest loans or grants to help with repairs and the
replacement of some personal belongings.

"People need help cleaning, repairing and rebuilding their homes and lives,"
Gov. Bev Perdue said in announcing the expanded declaration. "This financial
assistance is a blessing for so many families at a very difficult time."

The U.S. Department of Agriculture's Farm Service Agency also announced Tuesday
that the Oct. 14 declaration of disaster from severe storm flooding and
straight-line winds will bring farmers in even more counties relief from crop
losses.

Counties in the primary disaster declaration -- including Craven, Onslow,
Beaufort, Bertie, Hertford and Tyrell -- are also primary counties in the Farm
Service Agency emergency loan program. But it adds another 13 counties,
including Jones, Pamlico, Carteret and Lenoir to the farm families eligible for
crop damage and loss emergency loans.

Others qualifying under the Consolidated Farm and Rural Development Act for
emergency designation M-1942 include Pitt, Washington, Duplin, Pender, Gates,
Hyde, Halifax, Martin and Northampton counties.

General flood victims can call 1-800-621-FEMA to begin the aid application
process that can be continued on the telephone, online at DisasterAssistance.gov
or by going to a FEMA Disaster Assistance Center. Craven County's center is at
411 Craven St., New Bern.

Perdue said details about disaster recovery centers for Jones, Pitt, Brunswick,
and Pender counties will be made available as soon as they are finalized.

FEMA officials said any designated disaster victim can use any FEMA Disaster
Assistance Center to continue the application process. Centers are now open in
Washington, Windsor, New Bern, Winton, Jacksonville and Columbia.

Farmers in eligible counties may apply for assistance for physical or production
loss by going to the Farm Service Agency at 304 Industrial Drive in Craven
Industrial Park outside New Bern and talking with Sue A. Smithwick. The office
is open from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. weekdays and the phone number is 252-637-3567.

Perdue had asked for an expanded declaration for eight additional counties but
federal officials denied the request for Camden, Martin, New Hanover and
Washington counties, explaining that those areas did not meet the minimum damage
threshold.

The governor has asked N.C. Emergency Management officials to work closely with
FEMA to submit an appeal for the non-declared counties.

                 Colusa County Sun-Herald (Colousa, California)

                            October 30, 2012 Tuesday

Disaster loans available for Colusa County farmers

BYLINE: Todd R. Hansen, Colusa County Sun-Herald, Calif.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 358 words


Oct. 30--Colusa County farmers impacted by the drought are now eligible for
emergency disaster loans through the US Department of Agriculture.

However, it is doubtful there will be many if any takers.

"The only crop that we have had impacted so far is the rangelands," said Denise
Nannen, with the Farm Service Agency is Colusa County.

And specifically, the unirrigated, native rangelands in the foothills are the
issue.

County Agriculture Commissioner Joe Domiano said that could have some impact on
cattle ranchers, but to qualify for the loan, they would have to show at least a
30 percent loss.

In this case, Domiano explained, it would likely be the result of having to pay
for more feed because the drought has reduced the natural grassland stock.

Colusa County did not apply for disaster county status.

It qualified because it is contiguous to Glenn County, which is one of nearly a
dozen California counties that qualified under emergency conditions in early
September.

Tehama County is another.

Shaleen Hogan, farm loan manager for the Farm Service Agency in Red Bluff, said
rangeland in western Glenn County is the primary issue there, too.

Not only is the concern losses because of drought alone, but because drought
caused conditions that were susceptible to the wildfires that hit the area.

Still, there have been no applications filed for loan relief, and Glenn County
officials, like their Colusa County counterparts, are not sure if they will get
any.

Colusa County experienced five wildfires this summer, though the largest -- the
29,000-acre Mill Fire -- was largely in the Mendocino National Forest and in an
area that would have little or no impact on crop losses.

The others, however, seared open grasslands in the foothills.

What impact that had is unknown, and county officials do not think it will
amount to much.

The application period is open through May 6, 2013. There are a number of other
qualifications, including the inability to obtain credit elsewhere.

                           Lowell Sun (Massachusetts)

                          September 21, 2016 Wednesday

USDA calls most of state 'natural disaster area'

BYLINE: By Colin A. Young, State House News Service

SECTION: TODAY'S HEADLINES

LENGTH: 735 words


BOSTON -- Eleven of the state's 14 counties have been deemed "primary
natural-disaster areas" by the United States Department of Agriculture due to
substantial crop losses that began with a February deep freeze and continued
though a summer marked by severe drought.

Barnstable, Berkshire, Bristol, Essex, Franklin, Hampden, Hampshire, Middlesex,
Norfolk, Plymouth and Worcester counties have been designated as primary
natural-disaster areas, the USDA said, "due to losses caused by frost and freeze
that occurred from February 14 through May 4, 2016."

Farmers in those counties are eligible for low-interest emergency loans from the
USDA's Farm Service Agency, the USDA said. Farmers have eight months to apply
for a loan to help cover part of their losses.

Farmers in Dukes, Nantucket and Suffolk counties --- as well as several counties
in Connecticut, Rhode Island, New Hampshire, New York and Vermont -- also
qualify for the loan program if their farms are in counties contiguous to the
primary disaster areas.

A deep freeze around Valentine's Day wiped out almost all of the state's peach
crop, farmers previously told the News Service, and the state Executive Office
of Energy and Environmental Affairs said Tuesday that other tree fruits were
affected as well.

One local farm hit by this year's meteorological extremes is Carlson Orchards in
Harvard, where the early-season freeze killed off a majority of its peach crop
and the summer drought limited the apple harvest to about 25 percent of what is
normally picked.

Co-owner Frank Carlson said he isn't sure if his farm will take advantage of any
of the new assistance programs.

"Nothing's going to be done until the harvest is over, and we can add everything
up," he said. "Some of these programs are good, but others aren't, so we'll just
have to wait and see."

On top of the deep freeze, Massachusetts farmers have been hit this summer with
an ongoing and widespread drought that has been blamed for contributing to wild
fires, an outbreak of gypsy moths, higher rates of ant infestation,
smaller-than-usual apples, loss of crops, a shortage of cattle feed and an
elevated population of mosquitoes able to carry West Nile virus.

The state earlier this month launched its own $1 million emergency loan fund to
help farmers who have struggled with the impacts of the drought.

"We appreciate the United States Department of Agriculture taking steps to
assist farms across the commonwealth," Gov. Charlie Baker said in a statement.
"I encourage farmers adversely impacted by this year's extreme weather
conditions to explore the USDA programs and the state's Emergency Drought Loan
Fund."

More than half of the state is experiencing an "extreme" drought, the
second-most intense level of dryness on the federal government's scale,
according to the U.S. Drought Monitor. The 52.13 percent of Massachusetts in an
extreme drought stretches from the Pioneer Valley to the Cape Cod Canal, and
encompasses all of Metro Boston and northeastern Massachusetts.

"This year's weather has been a great challenge to Massachusetts farmers, first
with the winter freeze and now with a severe drought," Energy and Environmental
Affairs Secretary Matthew Beaton said in a statement. "Despite that, our farmers
have done a remarkable job at getting high-quality, nutritious food to market,
and I urge Massachusetts residents to buy local to support our hardworking
farmers."

As of Aug. 19, when the application for a USDA disaster declaration was
submitted, Massachusetts farmers had lost just shy of $14 million worth of
crops, according to the USDA Farm Service Agency's Massachusetts office.

The same 11 Massachusetts counties are also eligible for the USDA's Livestock
Forage Disaster Program, which compensates some livestock ranchers who have
suffered "grazing losses on pasture land" due to the drought, the EEA said.

"Our livestock and dairy industry is a significant contributor to the state's
economy, contributing over $70 million dollars annually," Department of
Agricultural Resources Commissioner John Lebeaux said in a statement. "We
appreciate USDA implementing a program to address this specific sector."

Massachusetts farmers interested in applying for the USDA aid should contact
their local USDA Service Center for further information on eligibility
requirements and application procedures, the USDA said. More information is
available at http://disaster.fsa.usda.gov .

                Sentinel & Enterprise (Fitchburg, Massachusetts)

                          September 21, 2016 Wednesday

USDA: Most of state, including Middlesex and Worcester counties, 'natural
disaster area'

BYLINE: Sentinel & Enterprise

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 742 words


By Colin A. Young

State House News Service

have to wait and see."

On top of the deep freeze, Massachusetts farmers have been hit this summer with
an ongoing and widespread drought that has been blamed for contributing to wild
fires, an outbreak of gypsy moths, higher rates of ant infestation,
smaller-than-usual apples, loss of crops, a shortage of cattle feed and an
elevated population of mosquitoes able to carry West Nile virus.

The state earlier this month launched its own $1 million emergency loan fund to
help farmers who have struggled with the impacts of the drought.

"We appreciate the United States Department of Agriculture taking steps to
assist farms across the commonwealth," Gov. Charlie Baker said in a statement.
"I encourage farmers adversely impacted by this year's extreme weather
conditions to explore the USDA programs and the state's Emergency Drought Loan
Fund."

More than half of the state is experiencing an "extreme" drought, the
second-most intense level of dryness on the federal government's scale,
according to the U.S. Drought Monitor. The 52.13 percent of Massachusetts in an
extreme drought stretches from the Pioneer Valley to the Cape Cod Canal, and
encompasses all of Metro Boston and northeastern Massachusetts.

"This year's weather has been a great challenge to Massachusetts farmers, first
with the winter freeze and now with a severe drought," Energy and Environmental
Affairs Secretary Matthew Beaton said in a statement. "Despite that, our farmers
have done a remarkable job at getting high-quality, nutritious food to market,
and I urge Massachusetts residents to buy local to support our hardworking
farmers."

As of Aug. 19, when the application for a USDA disaster declaration was
submitted, Massachusetts farmers had lost just shy of $14 million worth of
crops, according to the USDA Farm Service Agency's Massachusetts office.

The same 11 Massachusetts counties are also eligible for the USDA's Livestock
Forage Disaster Program, which compensates some livestock ranchers who have
suffered "grazing losses on pasture land" due to the drought, the EEA said.

"Our livestock and dairy industry is a significant contributor to the state's
economy, contributing over $70 million dollars annually," Department of
Agricultural Resources Commissioner John Lebeaux said in a statement. "We
appreciate USDA implementing a program to address this specific sector."

Massachusetts farmers interested in applying for the USDA aid should contact
their local USDA Service Center for further information on eligibility
requirements and application procedures, the USDA said. More information is
available at http://disaster.fsa.usda.gov .

                               November 23, 2011

Crop loss relief available to most Maryland farmers

BYLINE: The Hancock News staff

LENGTH: 226  words


Maryland has received approval from U.S.

Agriculture Secretary Thomas Vilsack for a disaster designation for widespread
crop losses due to extreme weather conditions this year, which included
excessive heat, drought and damage resulting from Hurricane Irene and Tropical
Storm Lee.

"It is our hope that the designation will provide relief to the farmers who need
it and help them prepare for the next growing season," said Governor Martin
O'Malley.

From April through October, Maryland farmers experienced widespread crop losses
due to weather conditions, said State Agriculture Secretary Buddy Hance. Farmers
in the disaster designation areas experienced market value losses of more than
30%.

This designation allows farmers in Washington, Allegany, Frederick and most
other counties to be eligible to be considered for assistance from the U.S. Farm
Service Agency. Farmers must have purchased crop insurance on eligible crops to
quality for USDA disaster assistance programs.

The assistance includes Farm Service Agency emergency loans and the Supplemental
Revenue Assistance Payments Program. Farmers in eligible counties have eight
months to apply for emergency loan assistance.

The Farm Service Agency will consider each emergency loan application on its own
merits, taking into account the extent of production losses, security available
and repayment ability.

                       The Natchez Democrat (Mississippi)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           September 15, 2008 Monday

Deadline nears for disaster relief

BYLINE: Vershal Hogan, The Natchez Democrat, Miss.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 328 words


Sep. 15--VIDALIA -- Tuesday is the last day for local farmers to buy into the
federal disaster assistance programs.

Should the area in which they farm be declared a disaster, the buy-in will allow
farmers to be eligible for any 2008 federal disaster assistance programs
Catahoula Parish was declared a disaster area following Hurricane Gustav, and
though it is not a declared disaster area, Concordia Parish suffered significant
crop losses.

Because the 2008 farm bill passed after the sign up period ended for some
insurance, the buy-in is also for farmers who did not get crop insurance this
year. The administrative fee for the buy-in is $100 per commercial enterprise,
including pastures.

The buy-in is through the Farm Service Agency crop insurance program.

If the area is declared a disaster at some point in 2008, those who bought into
the program and experienced losses will be eligible for benefits under the
Supplemental Revenue Assistance Payments Program, the Livestock Forage Disaster
Program, the Tree Assistance Program and the Emergency Assistance Livestock,
Honeybees and Farm-Raised Fish Program.

Another way the farm service can help farmers is by providing emergency loans to
help them recover from a declared disaster.

To qualify for the loans, a farmer must have suffered a loss of at least 30
percent, Farm Loan Manager for Concordia Parish's FSA office Calvin Adams said
at a meeting with local farmers last Tuesday.

In Concordia Parish, the FSA office is located at 8331 U.S. 84, in Ferriday, and
can be reached at 318-757-4870.

To see more of the Natchez Democrat, or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.natchezdemocrat.com. Copyright (c) 2008, The Natchez Democrat, Miss.

tmsreprints@permissionsgroup.com, call 800-374-7985 or 847-635-6550, send a fax
to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave.,
Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

                     Marin Independent Journal (California)

                           August 20, 2008 Wednesday

Drought devastates county's pastures

BYLINE: By Rob Rogers

SECTION: MARIN; News

LENGTH: 447 words


No one had to tell George Grossi that drought has wreaked havoc on Marin's
farmers and ranchers this year.

"We have a couple of areas with very little pasture. Cattle could only stay
there a very short time, and then I had to feed them hay," the Novato rancher
said. "And I was fortunate because I had some lower pastures. Those people who
have had to buy a lot of hay may have had to cut cattle in order to get by."

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has declared Marin County a primary natural
disaster area due to the drought conditions over the 2007-08 winter and spring.
The declaration means farmers and ranchers are eligible for low-interest
emergency loans from the USDA's Farm Service Agency to help cover some of their
losses.

Marin supervisors declared an agricultural emergency in June, after the county's
driest spring since 1879. Agricultural Commissioner Stacy Carlsen estimated at
that time that county cattle ranchers had suffered a 70 percent loss of forage
as a result.

While no estimates were immediately available on the amount of damage caused by
the drought, milk made up 58 percent of the county's $67 million agricultural
output in 2007, while beef cattle amounted to $8 million.

Novato's Grossi said Marin's beef and dairy ranchers have been hit with a double
whammy - a lack of grass to feed their cows and skyrocketing costs for feed.

"The time when we really get grass growth are the late rains after the first of
March," Grossi said. "We could get all the rain in the world in January and
February and still have a poor grass season. This year, from the first of March
on, we had no rain. Some grass did grow on the flat ground, but on the hills, it
never got going."

Marin and Sonoma counties are among 37 California counties designated by the
USDA as drought disaster areas. Farmers and ranchers will have eight months to
apply for emergency loans or seek help from other programs.

In addition, small non-farm businesses in Marin can offset drought losses
through low-interest disaster loans of up to $2 million available from the U.S.
Small Business Administration.

Grossi said he had no idea how many farmers might take advantage of the
programs.

"It's all going to depend on what the programs look like," Grossi said. "Most
people definitely don't know what's going to be available."

Information on farm aid programs from the local Farm Service Agency is available
at 707-664-8593 or from www.fsa.usda.gov . Information for non-farm businesses
seeking disaster loans is available at 800-659-2955 or online at
www.sba.gov/services/disasterassistance .

Contact Rob Rogers via e-mail at rrogers@marinij.com

Read more West Marin stories at the IJ's West Marin section.

LOAD-DATE: August 21, 2008

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

normal.

                The Berkshire Eagle (Pittsfield, Massachusetts)

                          September 21, 2016 Wednesday

US Dept. of Agriculture: 11 counties   including Berkshire   officially 'natural
disaster areas'

BYLINE: By Colin A. Young State House News Service

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 642 words


BOSTON &GT;&GT; Eleven of the state's 14 counties have been deemed "primary
natural disaster areas" by the United States Department of Agriculture due to
substantial crop losses that began with a February deep freeze and continued
though a summer marked by severe drought.

Barnstable, Berkshire, Bristol, Essex, Franklin, Hampden, Hampshire, Middlesex,
Norfolk, Plymouth and Worcester counties were designated as primary natural
disaster areas, the USDA said, "due to losses caused by frost and freeze that
occurred from February 14 through May 4, 2016."

Farmers in those counties are eligible for low interest emergency loans from the
USDA's Farm Service Agency, the USDA said. Farmers have eight months to apply
for a loan to help cover part of their losses.

Farmers in Dukes, Nantucket and Suffolk counties -- as well as several counties
in Connecticut, Rhode Island, New Hampshire, New York and Vermont -- also
qualify for the loan program if their farms are in counties contiguous to the
primary disaster areas.

A deep freeze around Valentine's Day wiped out almost all of the state's peach
crop, farmers previously told the News Service, and the Executive Office of
Energy and Environmental Affairs said Tuesday that other tree fruits were
affected as well.

On top of the deep freeze, Massachusetts farmers have been hit this season with
an ongoing and widespread drought that's been blamed for contributing to wild
fires, an outbreak of gypsy moths, higher rates of ant infestation, smaller than
usual apples, loss of crops, a shortage of cattle feed, and an elevated
population of mosquitoes able to carry West Nile virus.

The state earlier this month launched its own $1 million emergency loan fund to
help farmers who have struggled with the impacts of the drought.

"We appreciate the United States Department of Agriculture taking steps to
assist farms across the Commonwealth," Gov. Charlie Baker said in a statement.
"I encourage farmers adversely impacted by this year's extreme weather
conditions to explore the USDA programs and the state's Emergency Drought Loan
Fund."

More than half of the state is experiencing an "extreme" drought, the
second-most intense level of dryness on the federal government's scale,
according to the U.S. Drought Monitor. The 52.13 percent of Massachusetts in an
extreme drought stretches from the Pioneer Valley to the Cape Cod Canal, and
encompasses all of Metro Boston and northeastern Massachusetts.

"This year's weather has been a great challenge to Massachusetts farmers; first
with the winter freeze and now with a severe drought," Energy and Environmental
Affairs Secretary Matthew Beaton said in a statement. "Despite that, our farmers
have done a remarkable job at getting high-quality, nutritious food to market,
and I urge Massachusetts residents to buy local to support our hardworking
farmers."

As of Aug. 19, when the application for a USDA disaster declaration was
submitted, Massachusetts farmers had lost just shy of $14 million worth of
crops, according to the USDA Farm Service Agency's Massachusetts office.

The same 11 Massachusetts counties are also eligible for the USDA's Livestock
Forage Disaster Program, which compensates some livestock ranchers who have
suffered "grazing losses on pasture land" due to the drought, EEA said.

"Our livestock and dairy industry is a significant contributor to the state's
economy, contributing over $70 million dollars annually," Department of
Agricultural Resources Commissioner John Lebeaux said in a statement. "We
appreciate USDA implementing a program to address this specific sector."

Massachusetts farmers interested in applying for the USDA aid should contact
their local USDA Service Center for further information on eligibility
requirements and application procedures, the USDA said. More information is
available at http://disaster.fsa.usda.gov .

                                August 30, 2012

Expanding Access to Credit in Rural America

BYLINE: The Glenville Democrat staff

LENGTH: 416  words


As drought continues across America, President Obama and I continue doing all we
can to help producers. In addition to the actions we've already taken, we will
continue to call on Congress to pass a Food, Farm and Jobs Bill that gives USDA
more tools to help, while providing more certainty for our producers.

Throughout this disaster, USDA has worked hard to offer emergency access to
credit for farmers and ranchers.

In the early days of the drought, USDA acted to lower the interest rate for FSA
Emergency Loans from 3.75 percent to 2.25 percent. This week, USDA announced
that we will modify emergency loans by allowing loans to be made earlier in the
season - helping livestock producers to offset increased feed costs, as well as
those who have liquidated herds.

In addition we've continued working with the Small Business Administration and
the National Credit Union Administration to further increase emergency lending
in drought-stricken areas.

But the importance of access to credit in rural America goes well beyond the
current drought. Under President Obama, USDA has made access to credit a
priority for producers, for rural businesses, and for families and we have
achieved a record amount of accomplishments.

Since 2009, USDA has made or guaranteed a record number of loans for farmers and
ranchers more than $1.8 billion in loans for nearly 130,000 producers.

USDA has made a record level of loans, along with grants, to help nearly 58,000
rural small businesses grow, creating or saving hundreds of thousands of jobs in
rural areas.

We've provided loans and loan guarantees for more than 520,000 families to buy
or refinance a home, to ensure that Americans who are working hard and playing
by the rules have a chance to achieve the dream of homeownership.

And USDA lending is helping to develop a strong biobased economy in America.
This August alone, USDA added two new loan guarantee efforts to help build
advanced biofuel plants in Nevada and North Carolina that will continue our work
to make America more energy secure, while bringing hundreds of new jobs to those
states.

We're proud of these results, but we can keep building on our success. We can
help more producers get a loan to buy or improve a farm. We can help small
business owners expand their operations. We can do more to grow the biobased
economy.

By giving folks in rural areas more tools to succeed, USDA will continue to
create good-paying jobs in rural America while helping strengthen our nation's
economy as a whole.

                         Cleburne Times-Review (Texas)

                     Distributed by Tribune Content Agency

                              July 31, 2015 Friday

County farmers have options for assistance

BYLINE: Jessica Pounds, Cleburne Times-Review, Texas

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 578 words


July 31--Johnson County farmers and ranchers impacted by the May 4 to June 19
storms, tornadoes, straight-line winds and flooding may be eligible to receive
assistance from several agencies.

Texas, according to the U.S. Department of Agriculture, leads the nation with
248,000 farms and ranches covering more than 130 million acres. The economic
impact of food and fiber grown in Texas amounts to more than $100 billion each
year.

According to the Federal Emergency Management Agency, many farmers and ranchers
still need grants to pay for temporary housing and minor home repairs, grants to
replace personal property and grants to pay for serious immediate needs not
covered by insurance.

Deputy State Coordinating Officer Duke Mazurek of the Texas Governor's Division
of Emergency Management said farmers and ranchers who sustained damage to their
primary residences should call FEMA at 800-621-3362.

"We understand the needs of rural Texans," Mazurek said."Farmers and ranchers
are a strong part of many communities. We want to make sure they're aware of the
help available to rebuild their operations and recover from the disaster."

In Johnson County, 184 families have registered for FEMA assistance, with more
than $284,000 awarded so far.

Johnson County Emergency Management Director Jamie Moore said his agency is
aware of many farms that had adverse effects from the storms and flooding.

"[There has been] everything from loss of livestock life to inability to harvest
crops in wet fields," Moore said. "Though many are insured -- which will assist
in their recovery -- application to FEMA is recommended as an option. And
because agriculture plays such a vital role in the U.S. economy, everyone has a
vested interest in seeing those affected in Johnson County getting back up on
their feet as quickly as possible."

The deadline to register with FEMA was extended from July 28 to Aug. 27.

FEMA Public Information Officer Nate Custer said the extension was given to the
entire state.

"As additional counties were added to the Individual Assistance declaration, the
original deadline of July 28 remained in place," Custer said. "But with that
giving survivors only a few weeks to register, the state requested, and FEMA
agreed, for the extension."

The U.S. Small Business Administration also offers several benefits to farmers
and ranchers to rebuild or repair their loss of damaged property including
low-interest loans and livestock or tree reimbursement.

USDA's Farm Service Agency provides emergency loans to help producers restore or
replace property, pay all or part of production costs associated with the
disaster year, pay essential family living expenses, reorganize the farming
operation and refinance certain debts, excluding real estate.

The maximum loan amount for an emergency loan is $500,000.

The Livestock Indemnity Program provides benefits to livestock producers for
livestock deaths in excess of normal mortality caused by adverse weather or by
attacks by animals reintroduced into the wild by the federal government.

The Tree Assistance Program provides financial assistance to qualifying
orchardists and nursery tree growers to replant or rehabilitate eligible trees,
bushes and vines damaged by natural disasters.

For applications for USDA benefits, visit www.fsa.usda.gov.

                      Chico Enterprise-Record (California)

                            October 28, 2012 Sunday

Farm Briefs for Oct. 28

BYLINE: Chico Enterprise-Record

SECTION: LOCAL

LENGTH: 418 words


Glenn/Colusa water projects funds

The deadline to sign up for water enhancement projects in the Colusa/Glenn
watershed is Nov. 16. The Natural Resources Conservation Service (NRCS) and
Colusa Glenn Subwatershed Program (CGSP) secured funding through the
Agricultural Water Enhancement Program for surface and groundwater projects to
enhance water quality and quantity within the area.

Property owners with irrigated land would be encouraged to use best management
practices to increase irrigation efficiency, decrease sediment runoff and
flooding and improve surface and groundwater quality.

For information, contact the Glenn NRCS, 132 N. Enright Ave., Suite B in
Willows, 934-4601 ext. 3.

Agribee gets national recognition

The Butte County Farm Bureau was recognized by the American Farm Bureau
Federation for its innovative program, the Agribee, and will be given an award
at the annual national farm bureau event in January in Nashville, a press
release from the California Farm Bureau Federation stated.

Butte is among 25 county groups in the nation to be recognized, and only one of
two counties in California.

The Agribee is a spelling bee with a special emphasis on the area's agriculture.
Students throughout the region participate, studying terms related to farming
and ranching. About 40 member volunteers help plan the spell-and-define
competitions at participating schools, where fourth- and fifth-graders vie for a
spot at the six-county regional finals. Farm Bureau members help judge the
contests.

Emergency loans for drought loss

Thirty-six counties, including Glenn and Butte, are eligible for emergency farm
loans for drought that occurred since Jan. 1 and is continuing.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture will offer the loans for losses of 30 percent
or more, where other lines of credit are not available, as well as other
requirements.

A FSA Service center includes the one in Willows, 132-A N. Enright Avenue,
934-4669.

Webinar for organic seed slated

The Organic Seed Alliance will hold an eOrganic webinar Nov. 16 at 10 a.m.

The tutorials include instructions on producing beets and chard, brassicas,
carrots, lettuce, onions and wet-seeded crops.

To
register:http://www.extension.org/pages/65533/using-the-eorganic-organic-seed-pr
oduction-tutorials-webinar .

Family Water Alliance dinner

The annual "Hot Cajun Night" dinner, auction and raffle for Family Water
Alliance takes place Nov. 17 beginning at 5:30 p.m. at the American Legion Hall
in Maxwell. Tickets are $25. For information call 438-2026.

                           October 13, 2012 Saturday

Aid programs available from farm officials

BYLINE: Daily Gazette, Sterling, Ill.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 804 words


Oct. 13--AMBOY -- The sign-up period for the U.S. Farm Service Agency's
2011-crop year Supplemental Revenue Assistance Payments program opens Oct. 22.

SURE authorizes assistance to farmers and ranchers who suffered crop losses
caused by natural disasters occurring through Sept. 30, 2011. The U.S.
Department of Agriculture's authority to operate the program ended on that date.
Production losses after Sept. 30, 2011, because of disasters are not eligible
for program coverage.

To be eligible for SURE, a farm or ranch must have:

n At least a 10 percent production loss on a crop of economic significance.

n A policy or plan of insurance under the Federal Crop Insurance Act or the
Noninsured Crop Disaster Assistance Program for all economically significant
crops.

n Been physically located in a county declared a primary disaster county or
contiguous county by the Secretary of Agriculture under a Secretarial Disaster
Designation.

The deadline for signing up is June 7. Visit www.fsa.usda.gov/sure or the Lee
County FSA office at 319 S. Mason Ave., Amboy, for more information.

Changes made to farm loans

AMBOY -- Recent modifications have been made to the U.S. Farm Service Agency's
Emergency Loan program to speed up calculation of grazing losses in pasture for
livestock operations.

Producers will no longer have to wait until the end of the production cycle to
obtain a loan. The change is applicable for applicants in "Fast Track"
designated counties, that suffered from a drought intensity value of at least D2
(Drought-Severe) for 8 or more consecutive weeks, or D3 (Drought-Extreme) or
higher at any time during the growing season according to the U.S. Drought
Monitor. Visit droughtmonitor.unl.edu for more information about drought
ratings.

Emergency Loan funds could be used if an operation liquidates livestock due to a
lack of available feed. Loan funds can be used to cover lost income from animals
sold and lost income from offspring.

Other uses include pasture losses; crops planted for grain and later chopped for
use as silage; loss of nursery plants; losses in contact livestock, if the loss
of income can directly be attributed to the disaster; lost milk production;
losses to perennial crops, such as Christmas trees, and fruit or nut bearing
trees; and equine losses for applicants whose primary income is received from
breeding, raising, and selling  horses.

Call John Prange in Morrison at 815-772-2124, or Dave Peterson in Oregon at
815-732-6127, for more information.

Keep good records

AMBOY -- Farm Service Agency staff are encouraging livestock producers affected
by natural disasters to keep thorough records of livestock and feed losses.

Important information to track includes:

n Documentation of the number and kind of livestock that have died, supplemented
if possible by photographs or video records of ownership and losses.

n Dates of death supported by birth recordings or purchase receipts.

n Costs of transporting livestock to safer grounds or to move animals to new
pastures.

n Feed purchases if supplies or grazing pastures are destroyed.

The department's authority to operate five disaster assistance programs
authorized by the 2008 Farm Bill expired Sept. 30, 2011. The programs are SURE;
the Livestock Indemnity Program; the Emergency Assistance for Livestock, Honey
Bees, and Farm-Raised Fish; the Livestock Forage Disaster Program; and the Tree
Assistance Program (TAP). Currently, production losses from disasters occurring
after Sept. 30, 2011, are not eligible for disaster program coverage.

Producers should call their county FSA office and dial ext. 2 for more
information. In Whiteside County call, 815-772-2124; Lee County, 815-857-3621;
Ogle County, 815-732-6127; Bureau County, 815- 875-8732; and Mount Carroll,
815-244-8732.

Risk information updated

AMBOY -- The U.S. Department of Agriculture's Risk Management Agency recently
released an information update for farmers considering planting cover crops this
fall.

Producers in Illinois, Indiana, Michigan or Ohio wanting to insure a crop
planted in spring 2013 following a cover crop must stop haying or grazing the
cover crop by May 10, and terminate all cover crop growth at least 7 days before
the final planting date for the spring crop to be planted. Suggested crops
include corn, sweet corn, popcorn, hybrid seed corn, processing pumpkins,
soybeans, processing beans and grain sorghum.

In areas where a double-cropping practice is insurable, producers may be able to
insure soybeans, processing beans and grain sorghum without meeting the
requirements above. However, additional rules and higher premium rates apply.
Producers should contact their insurance agent for more information.

Federal disaster aid available

BYLINE: The Wilson Daily Times, N.C.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 297 words


Mar. 27--On March 18, U.S. Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack declared a natural
disaster in North Carolina based on losses caused by excessive rain and flooding
that occurred from Nov. 1, 2009 through Dec. 31, 2009.

As a result, 13 counties were declared eligible for federal disaster assistance,
including Farm Service Agency emergency loans for eligible family farmers.

The primary disaster counties are Camden, Carteret, Craven, Currituck, Durham,
Granville, Greene, New Hanover, Onslow, Orange, Pasquotank, Pender and
Washington.

In addition to the 13 primary counties, 26 additional counties were named as
contiguous counties where eligible family farmers may qualify for FSA emergency
loan assistance in accordance with Section 321 (a) of the Consolidated Farm and
Rural Development Act.

Those counties are Alamance, Beaufort, Bertie, Bladen, Brunswick, Caswell,
Chatham, Columbus, Dare, Duplin, Franklin, Gates, Hyde, Jones, Lenoir, Martin,
Pamlico, Perquimans, Person, Pitt, Sampson, Tyrrell, Vance, Wake, Wayne and
Wilson.

Effective March 18, farmers in these counties may apply for emergency loan for
production losses.

Nov. 18 is the deadline for filing an application. The local office is located
at 1806 Goldsboro St., SW between the hours of 7 a.m. and 5 p.m. Any farmer who
suffered a production loss should contact the office for additional information.

July 04--All but two of Colorado's 64 counties were designated as drought
disaster areas Tuesday by U.S. Secretary of Agriculture Tom Vilsack.

All counties except Delta and San Juan qualify to receive federal assistance,
including Farm Service Agency emergency loans. Farmers in eligible counties have
eight months to apply for emergency loan assistance, according to a news release
from Gov. John Hickenlooper's Office.

Vilsack designated the counties as disaster areas because of the losses caused
by drought, excessive heat and high winds.

and nearly every other part of the state much needed relief," Hickenlooper said
in a news release.

The Farm Service Agency evaluates loan applications on its own merits,
accounting for the extent of production losses, security available and repayment
ability.
