Local crew member attends Noah's Ark Animal workshop National Convention

Palermo ­ Michele Silvas, a Palermo resident and crew member for Noah's Ark
Animal Workshop in Palermo, recently attended Noah's Ark's national Rainbow
Stars Convention held in July in Oakbrook, Illinois.

"The conference is a great opportunity to receive entertainment ideas, new
products and learn unique, new ways to make stuffed animal magic," said Silvas.
"The company makes the conference both exciting and educational."

The two-day conference brought together professionals from various industries
and crew members from across the country to shed light on new party ideas and
recently launched products. As attendees, crew members were eligible to be the
first in the company to launch a new workshop concept called Bella Bee Workshop.
Bella Bee is a traveling glamour girl's workshop that gives girls the trendy
glitter and shine products they love in an interactive party atmosphere, which
focuses on building confidence and character.

"Having learned valuable information and embraced new party ideas, I am excited
to serve the Palermo area as well as the greater Oroville area with more
expertise, enthusiasm and energy," said Silvas.

Noah's Ark Animal Workshop is a traveling Stuff-N-Fluff workshop that offers
independent crew members the chance to provide children of all ages a hands-on,
creative and stimulating experience. Noah's Ark allows children to stuff, name
and love the animal of their choice and personalize their new friend with
outfits, accessories and sound chips.

For more information, contact Michele Silvas, or visit:
www.noahsarkworkshop.com.

Butte County eligible for USDA Emergency Farm Loans

Pursuant to the Secretary of Agriculture's designation of an emergency in the
state of California on Sept. 7, 2006, 16 counties, including Butte, have been
named eligible for USDA emergency farm loans because of physical and production
losses based on damages and losses caused by record-setting heat wave which
occurred July 1, 2006, through July 31, 2006.

Farmers in the county have eight months to apply for the loans to help cover
part of the actual losses. To be eligible, farms must:

Have suffered at least 30 percent loss of normal production directly related to
the above-cited cause,

Be able to repay the loan and any other loans,

Be unable to obtain credit elsewhere,

have adequate security, and

have multi-peril crop insurance, if available.

All applicants must complete a certification of disaster losses, which reflects
the exact date and nature of the designated disaster and how it caused the loss
or damage. Crop insurance field reports may be a source for documenting losses
directly related to the cited cause.

The authorization from Farm Service Agency (FSA) to accept emergency loans under
this authorization that expires on May 7, 2007. Applications should be filed
with your FSA Service Center at: 2 Sutter Street, Suite C, Red Bluff, CA 96080.

Farmers in all fifty counties have eight months to apply for loans to help cover
part of their actual losses. To be eligible, they must:

Have suffered at least 30 percent loss of normal production directly related to
the above-cited cause,

Be able to repay the loan and any other loans,

Be unable to obtain credit elsewhere,

have adequate security, and

have multi-peril crop insurance, if available.

All applicants must complete the same certification of disaster losses. Crop
insurance field reports may be a source for documentation of losses directly
related to the cited cause. And, this authorization may also be sent to the same
FSA office as above.

                            November 7, 2011 Monday

Farm bills make sizable impacts

BYLINE: Mikkel Pates, Agweek Magazine

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 571 words


Nov. 07--By Mikkel Pates

Agweek Staff Writer

FARGO, N.D. -- Since 2008, the U.S. farm support program has kicked out a
half-billion to a billion dollars every year, depending largely on the size and
impact of weather disasters, which have become a regular fixture. That's
significant in that there are only about 34,000 farmers in the state.

In the past few years, the so-called "countercyclical" programs haven't been a
huge factor, except for some LDPs in durum wheat. Direct payments have continued
to go out, despite some exceptional income years -- a phenomenon that has become
increasingly difficult to justify.

Crop insurance has been the biggest growth area among farm programs. The reason
for the increased expenditure is two-fold: 1) crop insurance payments are not
limited by so-called "payment limitations" and 2) many crop insurance products
are scaled to the value of the crop, and crop values have been going up.

Most heavily used conservation programs are the Environmental Quality Incentive
Programs and the Conservation Reserve Program, which is becoming more targeted
at protecting highly erodible, at risk land. And then there are disaster
programs, triggered by natural disasters that seem to be coming more frequently.

Here are some of the numbers, according to USDA's Farm Service Agency and the
Risk Management Agencies, according to officials and website data. The actual
payment of amounts between the two agencies don't line up exactly for years
because FSA is on a fiscal year while RMA is on a calendar year:

FSA pay-outs

(Fiscal year)

- 2008: $609.3 million.

- 2009: $476.1 million.

- 2010: $950.2 million. This includes $293.6 million for a collection of
programs including SURE, Livestock Forage Payments, carry-over payments from the
2008 drought, and ELAP (Emergency Assistance for Livestock, Honeybees and Farm
-Raised Fish) and LIP (Livestock Indemnity Program) payments, as well as SURE
("Stimulus") enhancements.

It included $251.2 million for direct and counter-cyclical support payments.
There were $154.6 million in grain marketing loans, which usually are paid back.
It included $138 million in Loan Deficiency Payments, particularly in the durum
program. It also included $102.4 million for Conservation Reserve Program
payments, $855,000 for dairy loss payments. There also were $6.5 million in farm
storage loan programs and $1.1 million in Emergency Conservation Loan outlays.

- 2011: $659.2 million. This includes $160 million from disaster programs (SURE,
LFP, LIP and ELAP); $210 million in DCP; $120 million, marketing loans and LDPs;
$98 million in CRP; $31 million in 2009 ACRE payments; $31 .6 million in ACRE
programs (2009 crop year); $28.7 million in Crop Assistance Program, which was
pushed by Southern states for moisture losses not covered by regular crop
programs; and $8 million in farm facility loan programs.

RMA pay-outs

(Calendar year)

- 2008: $847 million, including prevent-plant coverage on 180,000 acres.

- 2009: $458 million, including prevent-plant coverage on 2 million acres.

- 2010: $443 million, with prevented planting on 1.7 million acres.

- 2011: $813 million and growing as of Oct. 31, with a record of 5.6 million
acres of prevent-plant in the state on a typical 21 million to 22 million-acre
normal planted crop acreage.

___ (c)2011 Agweek Magazine (Grand Forks, N.D.) Visit Agweek Magazine (Grand
Forks, N.D.) at www.agweek.com Distributed by MCT Information Services

                            December 13, 2009 Sunday

Drought disaster relief available

BYLINE: Joyce Lobeck, The Sun, Yuma, Ariz.

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 410 words


Dec. 13--The U.S. Department of Agriculture has designated 13 counties in
Arizona as primary natural disaster areas due to losses caused by drought Jan. 1
through Dec. 31, 2009.

The 13 counties are Apache, Greenlee, Pima, Cochise, Maricopa, Pinal, Coconino,
Mohave, Santa Cruz, Gila, Navajo, Yavapai and Graham.

Farm operators in La Paz and Yuma counties also qualify for natural disaster
assistance because their counties are contiguous.

"President Obama and I understand these conditions caused severe damage to the
area and serious harm to farms in Arizona and we want to help," said Agriculture
Secretary Tom Vilsack. "This action will provide help to hundreds of farmers who
suffered significant production losses to warm season grasses."

Farm operators in several counties in California, Colorado, Nevada, New Mexico
and Utah also qualify for natural disaster assistance.

These counties were designated natural disaster areas Dec. 3, making all
qualified farm operators there eligible for low-interest emergency loans from
USDA's Farm Service Agency (FSA), provided eligibility requirements are met.

Farmers in eligible counties have eight months from the date of the declaration
to apply for loans to help cover part of their actual losses. FSA will consider
each loan application on its own merits, taking into account the extent of
losses, security available and repayment ability.

FSA has a variety of programs in addition to the EM loan program to help
eligible farmers recover from adversity.

USDA has also made other programs available to assist farmers and ranchers,
including the Supplemental Revenue Assistance Program, which was approved as
part of the Food, Conservation and Energy Act of 2008; the Emergency
Conservation Program; Federal Crop Insurance; and the Noninsured Crop Disaster
Assistance Program.

Interested farmers may contact their local USDA service centers for more
information on eligibility requirements and application procedures for these and
other programs.

Additional information is also available online at http://disaster.fsa.
usda.gov.

LENGTH: 279  words

DATELINE: Washington


Texas and Southwestern Cattle Raisers Association has issued the following news

The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) has designated Hopkins County in Texas
as a primary natural disaster area due to damages and losses caused by a recent
drought. Farmers and ranchers in Delta, Franklin, Hunt, Rains and Wood counties
in Texas also qualify for natural disaster assistance because their counties are
contiguous.

All counties listed above were designated natural disaster areas on Nov. 26,
2014, making all qualified farm operators in the designated areas eligible for
low interest emergency (EM) loans from USDA's Farm Service Agency (FSA),
provided eligibility requirements are met. Farmers in eligible counties have
eight months from the date of the declaration to apply for loans to help cover
part of their actual losses. FSA will consider each loan application on its own
merits, taking into account the extent of losses, security available and
repayment ability. FSA has a variety of programs, in addition to the EM loan
program, to help eligible farmers recover from adversity.

Emergency Conservation Program, The Livestock Forage Disaster Program, the
Livestock Indemnity Program, theEmergency Assistance for Livestock, Honeybees,
and Farm-Raised Fish Program, and the Tree Assistance Program. Interested
farmers may contact their local USDA Service Centers for further information on

Drought assistance available to farmers

BYLINE: Statesville Record & Landmark, N.C.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 317 words


Nov. 13--Iredell County's proximity to five of the counties that were declared
natural disaster areas will give local farmers a chance to get some relief from
the U.S. Department of Agriculture.

The USDA designated 59 counties in North Carolina, including Davie, Mecklenburg,
Cabarrus, Wilkes and Yadkin, as primary natural disaster areas because of losses
caused by drought and extreme heat that occurred after Jan. 1, 2008.

Since Iredell County is next to an affected county, or in this case counties,
farmers are eligible for low-interest emergency loans from USDA's Farm Service
Agency, provided qualification requirements are met.

"This timely credit assistance program could benefit North Carolina farm
families incurring debt from drought and extreme heat," said Keith Weatherly,
USDA-Farm Service Agency state director.

In a new release, Gov. Mike Easley said he requested the disaster declaration
Oct. 3 because of the excessive losses for at least one major crop and
significant losses of corn, soybeans, hay and pasture and other forage crops.

Eligible farmers have eight months from the date of the declaration to apply for
loans to help cover part of their actual losses.

According to the USDA, the Farm Service Agency "will consider each loan
application on its own merits, taking into account the extent of losses,
security available and repayment ability.

FSA has a variety of programs, in addition to the emergency loan program to help
eligible farmers.

BRIEF: Farmers in 87 counties eligible for disaster loans

BYLINE: The Blade, Toledo, Ohio

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 144 words


Sept. 16--COLUMBUS -- Farmers in 87 of Ohio's 88 counties are eligible for
low-interest emergency loans from the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Farm
Service Agency as a result of severe weather -- floods, tornadoes, excessive
rain, and excessive heat -- that swept the state from February through July.

The USDA has designated 49 counties as primary agricultural natural disaster
areas. Farmers in 38 more counties are eligible because the counties are
contiguous to the primary areas, the USDA announced. Williams County is without
either designation.

Farmers have eight months from Sept. 7, when the USDA declared the emergency
areas, to apply for loans. More information is available at 71 Farm Service
Agency offices around the state.

                           September 6, 2014 Saturday

Schatz Announces USDA Designation of Hawai'i County as Natural Disaster Area

LENGTH: 299  words

DATELINE: Washington


Office of the Senator Brian Schatz, U.S Government has issued the following news
release:

Today, U.S. Senator Brian Schatz (D-Hawai'i) announced that the United States
Department of Agriculture (USDA) designated Hawai'i County as a primary natural
disaster area due to damages and losses caused by wind, rain, and flooding from
Tropical Storm Iselle. After a review of the Hawai'i County Loss Assessment
Reports, the USDA determined that there were sufficient agricultural production
losses to warrant a Secretarial natural disaster designation.

"Many farmers in Puna are still recovering after suffering devastating crop loss
due to Tropical Storm Iselle and they need our help," Senator Schatz said. "I
thank USDA Secretary Thomas Vilsack for reviewing the Loss Assessment Reports
and for issuing a Secretarial natural disaster designation for Hawai'i County.
Support from the USDA will help ensure that our farmers in Hawai'i County will
receive the assistance they need."

A Secretarial disaster designation makes farm operators in primary counties and
those counties contiguous to such primary counties eligible to be considered for
certain assistance from the Farm Service Agency (FSA), provided eligibility
requirements are met. This assistance includes FSA emergency loans. Farmers in
eligible counties have 8 months from the date of a Secretarial disaster
declaration to apply for emergency loans. FSA considers each emergency loan
application on its own merits, taking into account the extent of production
losses on the farm, and the security and repayment ability of the operator.  So
far, FSA has received over 100 inquiries for assistance from producers in
Hawai'i County.

Local farms eligible for emergency aid

SECTION: NATION; Pg. A2

LENGTH: 138 words


U.S. Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman has named three local Indiana counties
as eligible for emergency farm loans because of losses from heavy rain, flash
flooding, hail and high winds this spring.

Farmers in Indiana's Elkhart, La Porte and St. Joseph counties are eligible, the
government said.

Thirty-seven Michigan counties, including four in southwest Michigan, were named
primary disaster areas: Allegan, Berrien, Cass, Huron, Isabella, Jackson,
Lapeer, Lenawee, Macomb, Oakland, St. Clair, Tuscola, Washtenaw and Wayne.

Farmers in 23 adjoining Michigan counties also are eligible.

Qualified farm operators are eligible for low-interest emergency loans from the
USDA's Farm Service Agency. Farmers in eligible counties have until July 1 to
apply for the loans to help cover part of their actual losses.

Virginia: TWO VIRGINIA COUNTIES - BATH AND HIGHLAND - RECEIVE PRIMARY DISASTER
DECLARATIONS FOR DROUGHT IN 2014

LENGTH: 317  words

DATELINE: Richmond


Virginia Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services has issued the
following news release:

The Virginia Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services (VDACS) announced
today that Highland County received U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA)
designation as a primary disaster area due to drought that occurred from June 1
through October 31, 2014. Bath County received a similar designation due to
drought that occurred from August 22 through October 15, 2014. Alleghany,
Augusta and Rockbridge Counties were named contiguous disaster counties, meaning
they border a county named as a primary disaster area.

A federal Secretarial disaster designation makes farm operators in both primary
and contiguous counties eligible to be considered for assistance from the
federal Farm Service Agency (FSA), provided eligibility requirements are met.
This assistance includes FSA emergency loans. Local FSA offices can provide
affected farmers with further information.

Farmers in eligible counties have eight months from the date of a Secretarial
disaster declaration to apply for emergency loan assistance. FSA will consider
each emergency loan application on its own merits, taking into account the
extent of production losses, security available and repayment ability. Local FSA
offices can provide affected farmers with more information.

Sandra J. Adams, VDACS Commissioner, said, "I am grateful that the USDA has
declared these two counties as disaster areas eligible for federal assistance,
and that other localities have been designated as contiguous disaster areas. Any
assistance farmers can get will be appreciated."

immediate updates, follow us on Twitter@VaAgriculture or like us on

                               The New York Times

                 August 3, 1999, Tuesday, Late Edition - Final

Parched Eastern Farms Win A Promise of Federal Loans

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 4; National Desk

LENGTH: 990 words

DATELINE: FREDERICK, Md., Aug. 2


After the television reporters finished their stand-ups in the fields of stunted
corn and the orating politicians departed the shade of the front porch, the
Harshmans still had a drought on their hands and a farm crisis the family
described as the worst since the Great Depression.

"What a lot of . . . spin -- that's the right word, isn't it?" the family's
gray-haired matriarch, Janice Harshman, asked pleasantly as the clutch of
Federal and state officials drove away toward Washington in a dry cloud of dust.

Speaking to about 40 troubled farmers gathered here for a news conference on the
drought conditions that have bedeviled this region for three straight years,
Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman today declared West Virginia and parts of
Kentucky, Ohio, Maryland, Pennsylvania and Virginia a drought disaster area,
making low-interest Federal loans available for its farmers.

And President Clinton and Congressional Democrats, reacting to the drought's
surfacing in Washington as a pressing issue, began proposing a broader package
of emergency farm relief totaling $10.8 billion.

"Quietly, American farmers and ranchers are losing their businesses," Senator
Tom Harkin, Democrat of Iowa, warned in Washington, noting that net farm income
this year was 29 percent below the average of the last five years.

Here in Frederick, Mrs. Harshman's 41-year-old son, Vaughn, who played host to
Secretary Glickman and other public officials, gratefully accepted their words
in lieu of rain. Even so, he emphasized that the natural disaster of the
drought, though painful, was only compounding and underlining American farmers'
far more deeply rooted crisis: a world market glut and depressed prices.

"I sure don't need any more loans," Mr. Harshman said of the main immediate
remedy offered by Mr. Glickman, adding that the Government should show as much
alarm for the farmers' problems in world markets as it did today for the
drought.

"We need a fair market and fair playing field," he declared, and his sister,
Christie Brandenburg, agreed. "Loans won't do it," she said. "We need prices."

Down from the porch steps, other farmers said that while the general price
decline in a wide array of produce might be their biggest problem, the water
shortage was certainly an added burden.

"My pastures are nonexistent, just dried-up exercise yards for the livestock,"
said Glenn Eaves. He described already cutting into next winter's forage
supplies for his 5,000 head of livestock, and said the financial damages would
roll over well into next year, whether it rained soon or not.

If the drought news conference was sparking larger complaints about the general
state of the farm economy, Secretary Glickman could only agree as he toured
drought-ridden farmlands here and in West Virginia, where he accepted disaster
aid requests from state officials.

"We've had four years of worldwide record crop produce," he noted, standing in a
photo-op by a potted waist-high healthy soybean plant and a shin-high version
wilted by drought. "That's never happened before in human history. You have a
double whammy of low prices plus a natural disaster."

His hopes and prayers, the Secretary told the farmers, are for Congress to
allocate emergency assistance along the lines of the $6 billion emergency
appropriation, including direct grants, enacted last year when farmers in the
Southwest were struck by drought.

In the face of the complaints today, Secretary Glickman also said the 1996 farm
law that heralded an open world agricultural market in providing for a phaseout
of subsidies "needs mending" to protect American farmers. "If you live long
enough, you'll see the cycle of history come back and hit you," he declared.

Of the drought, Mr. Glickman said, "This thing will turn, I'm convinced of it."
He joked that a Federal meteorologist using a cell phone at the rear of the
crowd "was on the line with God."

Farmers in the audience here, far from banking on divine intervention, talked
yearningly of a past when Government policy was built less around free-market
vagaries and more around price supports to brace them through hard times. They
laughed out loud when one speaker talked of possibly freeing up forage from
Government conservation lands to help farmers.

"No way!" one farmer shouted. "That's all dried up!"

Drought-stricken counties in the East Coast farm belt, running up into central
New York State, have been submitting requests through their governors for
emergency agricultural assistance, Mr. Glickman said. While his immediate
options center mainly on low-interest loans, he said that in the face of the
drought, Congress would most likely consider a larger emergency package
including direct grants, like the $10.8 billion proposal being discussed in
Washington today. On Capitol Hill, there was no immediate estimate of such a
proposal's chances of enactment.

The $6 billion emergency aid package last year included grants to farmers for
crop and livestock damage from the drought as well as for lost income. "I don't
know what we're going to end up with," Mr. Glickman said of the current
Congress.

Maryland's Governor, Parris N. Glendening, who was one of the officials joining
Mr. Glickman here, promised farmers $3 million in state aid, and emphasized that
small and medium family farms were especially vulnerable to drought pressures
while large corporate farms were better able to survive hard times.

"This is about farmers fighting with their families for survival," the Governor
declared, warning that the alternative might be more farms plowed under for
housing subdivisions.

"That's right," Mrs. Harshman agreed after the politicians trailed off through
the family's parched fields. "The only option we're being left with is
subdivision," she declared darkly, as if she were talking of the plague of
spider mites that has swept across the soybean crop because of the drought.

The Flagler Tribune

Deal to Receive Emergency Loans

Applications for emergency crop and feed loans for 1939 are now being received
at the office of O.F. Alford, Bunnell, Fla., by H.Deal, field superintendent of
the Emergency Crop and Feed Loan Section of the Farm Credit Administration.

A picnic on the boardwalk adjacent to the municipal pier at Flagler Beach is on
the schedule for the Flagler Senior Citizens Club when it meets next Tuesday,
August 4th. The picnic will be at 12 o'clock noon with members bringing food and
beverage for a luncheon.

This will be the last of three monthly meetings scheduled by the Club for the
summer when so many members are away on vacation. The Club will resume its twice
monthly meetings in September.

Federal government offering drought relief emergency loans

BYLINE: Cheney Free Press staff

LENGTH: 220  words


SPOKANE -- The federal government automatically activated a disaster relief
program on May 28 for farmers and ranchers in Chelan, Lincoln and Walla Walla
counties affected by recent drough conditions.

According to a Farm Service Agency news release, the program was activated after
the three counties experienced D2 drought conditions for eight consecutive
weeks.

Due to their proximity to the affected counties, farmers and ranchers in 15
Washington counties, including Spokane, may also be eligible for this disaster
relief program which provides FSA emergency loans at 3.125 percent with payment
terms up to 40 years.

Farmers in eligible counties have eight months from the date of the designation
to apply for loans to help cover part of their actual losses. FSA will consider
each loan application on its own merits, taking into account the extent of the
losses, security available and repayment ability.

FSA has a wide variety of programs, in addition to the emergency loan program,
to help farmers recover from adversity. These programs include the Emergency
Conservation Program, Livestock Forage Disaster Program, Livestock Indemnity
Program, Emergency Assistance for Livestock, Honeybees and Farm-raised Fish
Program and the Tree Assistance Program.

Additional information is available at www.disaster.fsa.usda.gov.

                        The York Dispatch (Pennsylvania)

                           December 3, 2011 Saturday

Too much, too little rain? York farmers can apply for loans

BYLINE: CHRISTINA KAUFFMAN The York Dispatch

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 654 words


Two recent federal Department of Agriculture disaster declarations demonstrate
Mother Nature's bipolar treatment of York County this year.

The federal agency has made available emergency loan funds for farmers whose
crops were damaged from either too much or not enough rain.

York is one of three Pennsylvania counties named disaster areas because of
excessive rain and flooding associated with Hurricane Irene and Tropical Storm
Lee in August and September.

It's also one of 13 counties designated for relief because of drought and
excessive heat between June and September, according to the USDA.

It's abnormal for extreme opposite conditions to exist within the same county,
according to meteorologist Jason Krekeler from the National Weather Service in
State College.

He said it's common for summer thunderstorms to drench one area and ignore
another, even if the sites are within a couple of miles. But it's unusual for it
to happen so consistently.

Rainfall data show the disparity. He said York received 2.52 inches of rain on
July 25, just one day, and Hanover received "not a drop."

For the month of July, York had 5.72 inches of rain, compared with 1.88 inches
in Hanover, Krekeler said.

"That kind of extreme, that doesn't happen every day," he said. "But a half inch
here, two inches there, it'll add up. To the extent of the rainfall difference,
it's pretty impressive."

Help available: Farmers in the affected areas are eligible for low-interest
emergency loans from USDA's Farm Service Agency. They have about eight months to
apply for loans to help cover their losses.

Applications are considered by the extent of losses, security available and
repayment ability.

Several York County farmers have reported losing thousands of dollars because of
crop damage, mostly because of flooding, but none interviewed have said they
intend to apply for loans.

At York Township's Fitz Bros. Farm, owner Robert Fitz said crop insurance is a
requirement for some loans, and he doesn't carry it.

"The farm is tough enough. I can't afford to pay insurance premiums," he said.
"So I was told I'm not eligible."

At Raab Fruit Farm, also in York Township, farmer Jane Lehman said loans will be
helpful for those who qualify, but it has been her experience that the loans
mostly go to "huge corporations."

"Sometimes, as a family farm, you fall through the cracks," she said. "You're
too big to be small and too small to be big. Sometimes, the (required) yield is
so low nobody qualifies, and I'd like to see how many actually qualify."

She said farming has become harder and harder every year, and some people are
living off the equity on their farms.

"The past two years have been horrendous here," she said. "In the beginning of
2010 we started out with a freeze that took a lot of fruits. They froze in
bloom. Then we had severe drought. ... This year, we went into a really wet
spring and then another drought situation and then we went into the rains that
never stopped and then we went into the snowstorm on one of worst possible
weekends."

The weekend of Halloween is popular for buying and picking pumpkins, hayrides,
and other farm activities, she said.

She said apples that hadn't been picked were ruined, and trees were damaged from
the heavy snow. That's on top of the three fields of sweet corn lost to drought
earlier in the year, the loss of apples from hail in September, and other
weather-related damage, she said.

While a loan might sound like a good idea, Lehman said she isn't sure how a
family farmer would repay it.

"We're at the mercy of Mother Nature," she said. "We can do everything right and
in the blink of an eye, it's all destroyed."

Interested farmers may contact their local USDA Service Centers for further
information on eligibility requirements and application procedures at
http://disaster.fsa.usda.gov.

- Reach Christina Kauffman at 505-5436, ckauffman@yorkdispatch.com, or follow
her on Twitter at @dispatchbizwiz.

              The Times and Democrat (Orangeburg, South Carolina)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            October 13, 2013 Sunday

Federal ag services on hold, along with clients

BYLINE: Gene Zaleski, The Times and Democrat, Orangeburg, S.C.

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 672 words


Oct. 13--Local federally funded agricultural offices are closed as a result of
the government's partial shutdown, meaning farmers seeking funding and loan
assistance will have to wait.

Orangeburg's Henley Street Farm Service Agency office, which is a part of the
U.S. Department of Agriculture, closed Oct. 1 at the beginning of the shutdown.

The shutdown has become a "terrible inconvenience" for farmers needing to cash
checks and applying for loans, says state FSA Director Harry Ott.

"It is an unfortunate consequence as there are a lot of things during harvest
that farmers need to be taking advantage of," Ott said.

The federal shutdown stems from the inability of Congress to come to an
agreement that would allow passage of a continuing resolution to fund the
government. About 500,000 federal workers are still idle in the government
shutdown.

One the programs affected by the shutdown is the peanut loan program.

"Checks are made jointly to the farmer and to FSA until they (farmers) pay the
loans back," Ott said. "They can't do anything with the checks because we don't
have personnel there to sign the checks for farmers to put into the bank."

And then there are emergency disaster relief loans.

Earlier this year, the USDA declared the state a farm disaster area due to
over-abundant rainfall. The cotton and wheat crops locally saw up to a 35
percent crop loss. The FSA is the agency which considers disaster loan
applications.

Farmers have eight months to apply for the loans.

"If we miss this week, we still have time on all the emergency loans farmers may
need," Ott said.

Ott says the roughly 160 FSA employees in the state are also being hurt by the
shutdown. While employees may receive back pay, that does not suffice, he said.

"That really does not pay the light bill and the groceries they need to buy this
week. ... It puts a lot of stress on individuals and on their families," he
said.

The Orangeburg County FSA employs eight. In Bamberg and Calhoun counties, the
FSA employs three people each.

In addition to the FSA, other USDA offices in the Henley Street building
including the Natural Resources Conservation Service and Rural Development are
also closed.

Orangeburg County's NRCS employs three and Rural Development employs six.
Calhoun County has two employees with NRCS.

Rural Development programs are now on hold and no additional loans/grants,
including RD rural housing loans or guarantees, are being issued.

Due to the shutdown, enrollment in conservation programs such as the
Conservation Reserve Program, Wetlands Reserve Program, Grassland Reserve
Program and Healthy Forests Reserve Program have halted.

Orangeburg County Clemson Extension Agent Jonathan Croft said he has not heard
of any specific concerns about the impact of the government shutdown from
farmers.

"Most are going full tilt to get stuff harvested," Croft said.

He said there are some general concerns about the inability to process loans for
those farmers who have lost their cotton crop, although the failure to see a
farm bill passed is higher on the list of worries.

"Nothing has been done with the farm bill," he said.

At the Soil and Water Conservation District, employees are having to use their
personal phones and computers in order to continue conducting business. They are
employed by the county, but are housed in the NRCS offices. The staff cannot use
federal equipment, which includes phones, computers or copiers.

Glenda Lewis, district manager, said the temporary offices are housed with the
Clemson Cooperative Extension Service.

"We can't check emails ... but we are all working. It may have slowed us down,
but it has not shut us down all the way," Lewis said.

The Orangeburg County Clemson Extension Cooperative offices and Orangeburg
County Department of Public Works offices in the building remain open.

                        Savannah Morning News (Georgia)

                             June 28, 2011 Tuesday

Local counties declared federal drought disaster areas

BYLINE: Wayne Hodgin, Savannah Morning News, Ga.

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 390 words


June 28--Federal agricultural officials have declared a number of the state's
counties disaster areas because of the ongoing drought.

Georgia Gov. Nathan Deal received word Monday that U.S. Secretary of Agriculture
Tom Vilsack had approved his request sent earlier this month to declare 22
counties as a natural disaster areas.

Area counties affected include Bryan, Chatham and Effingham counties.

"With this designation, farmers and their businesses will qualify for
much-needed federal relief," Deal said in a released statement.

"It is my hope this aid will relieve some of the burden this drought has
caused," he added.

Vilsack also said that, in accordance with the Consolidated Farm and Rural
Development Act, he is naming the following areas as contiguous disaster
counties:

These counties will become eligible to apply for emergency loans and other
benefits provided by the Food, Conservation and Energy Act of 2008: Appling,
Atkinson, Bacon, Ben Hill, Brantley, Brooks, Bryan, Chatham, Coffee, Colquitt,
Cook, Dodge, Effingham, Irwin, Jeff Davis, Lanier, Lowndes, Pierce, Telfair,
Thomas, Wayne and Wheeler.

In accordance with the Consolidated Farm and Rural Development Act, Vilsack also
named the following areas as contiguous disaster counties: Berrien, Bleckley,
Bulloch, Camden, Charlton, Clinch, Echols, Evans, Glynn, Grady, Laurens,
Liberty, Long, McIntosh, Mitchell, Montgomery, Pulaski, Screven, Tattnall, Tift,
Toombs, Treutlen, Turner, Ware, Wilcox and Worth.

Like those in primary disaster counties, farmers in contiguous disaster counties
may be considered for assistance with the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Farm
Service Agency.

This includes FSA emergency loans and the Supplemental Revenue Assistance
Payments program. Farmers in eligible counties have eight months from the
secretarial disaster declaration to apply for emergency loan assistants.

MORE INFORMATION

Area farmers may contact the local Farm Service Agency office at 203 S. Laurel
St. in Springfield at 912-754-6664.

                                US Official News

                             July 19, 2014 Saturday

Klobuchar, Franken, Peterson, Walz Announce USDA Disaster Declaration for Rock
and Adjacent Counties, Allowing Them to Be Considered for Emergency Assistance

LENGTH: 439  words

DATELINE: Washington


Office of the House of Representative Tim Walz, U.S Government has issued the
following news release:

U.S. Senators Amy Klobuchar and Al Franken and U.S. Representatives Collin
Peterson and Tim Walz today announced that the U.S. Department of Agriculture
(USDA) has issued a disaster declaration for Rock County and the adjacent
counties of Murray, Nobles and Pipestone, allowing them to be considered for
emergency assistance. The USDA's Farm Service Agency (FSA) has designated Rock
County as a primary natural disaster area, making farmers and ranchers in the
county eligible to be considered for emergency loans to help recover and rebuild
from the extensive damage caused by heavy precipitation and flooding. Murray,
Nobles, and Pipestone Counties were designated as contiguous disaster areas and
producers in those counties will also be eligible for emergency credit.

"Weeks of torrential downpour and flooding have caused extensive damage to
communities in southern Minnesota and all across our state," Klobuchar said. "I
called for this critical disaster declaration that will allow impacted farmers
and ranchers to be considered for emergency loans, and I'll keep pushing to
ensure that our state has the resources we need to recover."

"When severe weather and flooding struck Minnesota last month, I saw firsthand
that our farmers, ranchers, and rural communities in the southwest were among
the hardest hit," Franken said. "I'm pleased to see USDA responding to our
request for a disaster declaration in these counties, and I'm going to continue
doing everything I can to help all the rural communities still trying to recover
from the storms."

"Severe weather has taken a toll on many Minnesota communities, with heavy
rains, flooding and hail devastating local farms and farmers' growing plans for
the season," Peterson said. "Unforeseen weather-related disasters are the reason
the farm bill's safety net is so important and this announcement will provide
some much-needed relief for Minnesota's farmers as they work to recover."

"I am very pleased that USDA promptly responded to our request for a disaster
declaration. This will speed up the process of providing emergency loans and
assistance to our farmers," Representative Walz said. "I toured flooded areas
and saw firsthand the devastation caused. It is exactly for these types of
situations that I fought so hard to include crop insurance and permanent
disaster assistance in the 2014 Farm Bill. As we move forward, I will continue
fighting for our rural, southern Minnesota agriculture values in Congress."

For further information please visit: http://walz.house.gov

                                    The Land

                           January 15, 2015 Thursday

More drought relief for farmers

SECTION: EARLY GENERAL NEWS; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 337 words


STATE and federal governments have chipped in with additional drought support
for farmers in NSW.

The NSW government will provide an additional $20 million under the emergency
water infrastructure rebates and the federal government dropped the interest
rate on its concessional loans schemes for drought-stricken farmers.

Rates for the Farm Finance Concessional Loans Scheme and the Drought
Concessional Loans Scheme will fall from 4.5 per cent to 4.34pc and from 4pc to
3.84pc, respectively, from February 1.

According to federal Agriculture Minister Barnaby Joyce, the new terms were good
news for farmers.

The late round of loans was announced in December.

"These schemes are designed to ensure viable farms can continue to be an
essential contributor to the national economy," Mr Joyce said.

NSW Primary Industries Minister Katrina Hodgkinson said the State government's
$20m boost included a number of key changes since the last scheme.

Ms Hodgkinson said the scheme had been reworked since the last round of funding.

Producers can now claim up to $20,000 and de-silting works in water storages
which has been approved under the new criteria.

"Eligibility will be assessed based on one-in-50-year rainfall deficiency or
greater, down to the farm level rather than the LGA (local government area)
level," Ms Hodgkinson said.

"Where producers cannot access groundwater to install infrastructure such as
pipelines, bores, tanks and troughs, they can now claim for de-silting works.

"These important changes will ensure assistance flows to those most in need,
regardless of which council area they live in or if they have access to ground
water."

The NSW government's Emergency Water Infrastructure Rebate will close on June 30
or when the $20m in funding is fully allocated.

Applicants must seek pre-approval of the NSW Rural Assistance Authority before
starting on-farm works.

                              The Bismarck Tribune

                             April 17, 2009 Friday

Farm emergency loans available

SECTION: DAKOTA WIRE; Pg. 1B-6B

LENGTH: 131 words


Farmers in Morton, Oliver and Burleigh counties who suffered physical and
production losses because of severe storms and flooding that occurred March 13
and afterward can apply for Farm Service Agency Emergency loans, farm loan
manager Todd Neurohr said.

The time allowed to file loan applications is eight months. For Morton, Oliver
and Burleigh farmers, this means the deadline for applications is Dec. 10.

Neurohr said farmers who suffered a qualifying loss (at least 30 percent from
normal) and are unable to get credit elsewhere, may apply for reduced interest
loans to cover up to 100 percent of their losses. The loans carry a 3.75 percent
interest rate.

Farmers who think they are eligible may apply for assistance at the FSA county
office at 2540 Overlook Lane, Mandan, N.D., 58554.

                                  The Monitor

                           August 17, 2005, Wednesday

USDA puts Hidalgo, Starr counties on list of agriculturally devastated areas

BYLINE: By Jennifer C. Smith

LENGTH: 668 words



ALAMO -- Phyllis Moore's cotton and grain crops have seen better days.

"This year has been real wacky," said the owner of the 600-acre Mid-Valley
Farms. "Prior to (Hurricane) Emily, we lost cotton because of the drought. It
was hot, dry and windy."

July's hurricane just compounded her crop woes.

"After that happened, everything went to pot," she said. "The color was off, the
grade was off, (and) the price went way down."

Moore's plight could be alleviated through low-interest emergency loans the U.S.
Department of Agriculture's Farm Service Agency now offers. The USDA designated
several Texas counties, including the contiguous jurisdictions of Hidalgo and
Starr, as agriculture disaster areas last week because of drought, high winds
and excessive temperatures they have suffered since March. The designation does
not include the damage Hurricane Emily inflicted.

"We've had just a couple of good years out of the last 10," said service center
farm loan manager Arnulfo Lerma. "Farmers were beginning to make headway and now
we've had these disasters that will set them back."

Farmers, ranchers and agricultural producers who lost 30 percent of a normal
year's yields should apply for the emergency loans, which carry a $ 500,000
limit per individual and a 3.34 percent annual interest rate. Other loans are
also available.

"They are available for refinancing, carry-over debt, or for purchasing new
equipment and, or, for annual operating expenses," Lerma said.

Applicants have until March 29, 2006, to seek the loans. At least 100 people
from Hidalgo and Starr counties are expected to apply, said Benny Cano, the USDA
Farm Service Agency district director.

The declaration is based on below normal average rainfalls since March, even
with Hurricane Emily. Although temperatures have remained average, the
combination of drought, wind and high temperatures stripped fragile cotton from
stalks or knocked crops over.

"Everybody has suffered at least a 50 percent production loss in all crops," he
said.

Damage assessments for all crops will be made after cotton season is finished in
September, said Brad Cowan, Hidalgo County agricultural extension agent for the
Texas Cooperative Extension. Grain sorghum and cotton are the crops that have
been hit the hardest by the rough weather. Pastures and range land have been
damaged as well.

Moore said she needs emergency loans to prepare for next season.

"You can't (deal) with the price of diesel, buy fertilizer, water, chemicals,
anything you might need, even preparing land for next year," she said. "We're
overextended on everything we have."

Agriculture disaster designations have been declared in Hidalgo County almost
every year since 1995 or 1996, Lerma said.

State and local agriculture officials did not have local financial damage
estimates, but the 10-year drought alone has cost the Rio Grande Valley $ 10
billion, according to Monitor archives.

The emergency loans have done little to help Donna vegetable farmer John Billman
though.

"It's geared toward big, subsidy growers," he said. "There's so much paperwork,
regulations."

This year's weather mostly spared his 100-acre farm of sweet corn, tomato,
squash and other crops. But he said he needed financial assistance three years
ago after heavy rainfall.

"It just wiped me out," he said. "I easily lost $ 12,000."

For more information on the loans, farmers should contact the USDA Service
Center in Edinburg at (956) 381-0916, or go to the Web site at
http://disaster.fsa.usda.gov.


Monitor staff writer Matt Whittaker contributed to this report.

                      Carlsbad Current-Argus (New Mexico)

                           January 15, 2009 Thursday

Local ag producers can apply for disaster assistance

BYLINE: By Stella Davis Current-Argus Staff Writer

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 397 words


CARLSBAD -- Eddy County farmers and ranchers affected by drought conditions are
now eligible for disaster assistance.

U.S. Sen. Jeff Bingaman, D-N.M., said Wednesday Eddy County has been declared
eligible for disaster assistance due to its proximity to Texas counties that
have been declared disaster areas due to drought.

As a result of the declaration, farmers and ranchers in Eddy County are now
eligible to be considered for low-interest emergency loans from the Farm Service
Agency, which is part of the U.S. Department of Agriculture.

Although farmers and ranchers in the county can apply for the emergency loan
program, they should be prepared for a lot of paper work and documentation, FSA
officials said.

FSA loan requirements are different from those of other lenders. Some of the
more significant differences include:

Borrowers must keep acceptable farmer records.

Borrowers must operate in accordance with a farm plan they develop and agree to
with local FSA staff.

Borrowers may be required to participate in a financial management training
program and obtain crop insurance.

There are also eligibility requirements for borrowers such as having an
acceptable credit history and the ability to repay the loan. They must have
suffered at least a 30 percent loss in crop production or a physical loss of
livestock, livestock products, real estate or chattel property.

Woods Houghton, Eddy County Extension Service agent, said some areas in Eddy
County have been hit harder by the drought than others.

"The areas contiguous to Texas primarily the areas in the south and east part of
the county have had more difficulty with the drought conditions" he said. "It's
(the emergency disaster loan program) something that a lot of people don't need,
or don't want to use it. But for those that do, it really helps."

Houghton said little winter moisture and unusually high winds for this time of
year could take a toll if the area does not receive rain soon.

"My major concern is that because of no winter moisture, there is a lot of dry
grass that is becoming a fire hazard. A wildfire could wipe out feed (for
livestock) in a matter of minutes," he explained. "We are a warm season
grassland area."

He said in Eddy County, crops planted in the fall could struggle to come up in
the spring.

"Plants that come up with no moisture make it hard on the stands when starting
in the spring," he added.

                   Mississippi Business Journal (Jackson, MS)

                               November 18, 2009

USDA declares virtually entire state of Mississippi a disaster

BYLINE: Wally Northway

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 399  words


The U.S. Department of Agriculture has designated 79 counties in Mississippi as
primary natural disaster areas due to losses caused by the combined effects of
severe spring and fall flooding and summer drought, that occurred March 1, 2009,
and continuing.

Farm operators in the other three counties - Kemper, Neshoba and Newton - also
qualify for natural disaster assistance because their counties are contiguous.

All counties and parishes listed above were designated natural disaster areas
Nov. 13, 2009, making all qualified farm operators in the designated areas
eligible for low interest emergency (EM) loans from USDA's Farm Service Agency
(FSA), provided eligibility requirements are met. Farmers in eligible counties
have eight months from the date of the declaration to apply for loans to help
cover part of their actual losses. FSA will consider each loan application on
its own merits, taking into account the extent of losses, security available and
repayment ability. FSA has variety of programs, in addition to the EM loan
program, to help eligible farmers recover from adversity.

USDA has also made other programs available to assist farmers and ranchers,
including the Supplemental Revenue Assistance Program (SURE), which was approved
as part of the Food, Conservation, and Energy Act of 2008; the Emergency
Conservation Program; Federal Crop Insurance; and the Noninsured Crop Disaster
Assistance Program. Interested farmers may contact their local USDA Service
Centers for further information on eligibility requirements and application
procedures for these and other programs.

Additional information is also available online at disaster.fsa.usda.gov.

According to the latest figures, this year Mississippi farmers experienced
losses totaling $473 million, or 30 percent of the crop's value. The Mississippi
Department of Agriculture and Commerce reported sweet potato producers saw a
63.6 percent crop loss, tops in loss percentage. Soybean growers took the
biggest dollar loss - $307 million (44 percent loss).

Perhaps the cruelest blow was dealt to Mississippi's already-struggling cotton
industry. Rising input costs had already dethroned cotton as king, but this
year's disaster is dealing a double blow. Not only are cotton farmers facing a
48.1 percent loss, the important cottonseed crop has seen a 46 percent loss. All
total, cotton growers are out more than $100 million.

                     Valley Morning Star (Harlingen, Texas)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           December 27, 2008 Saturday

Valley farmers affected by Dolly could receive disaster loan

BYLINE: Edwina P. Garza, Valley Morning Star, Harlingen, Texas

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 314 words


Dec. 27--SAN BENITO -- Farmers whose crop was destroyed by heavy rainfall
throughout the week after Hurricane Dolly hit are eligible for Farm Service
Agency disaster emergency loans, FSA officials said.

Rainfall from the July 23 hurricane was close to 10 inches in a number of areas,
according to previous reports.

The loans are for eligible farmers in Cameron, Willacy, Hidalgo and Starr
counties who lost at least 30 percent of their crop production from rainfall
from July 23 to July 30.

It's unclear how many acres across the Rio Grande Valley the hurricane may have
affected. Local FSA officials were unavailable for comment on Friday.

In previous reports, estimated losses from the Category 2 hurricane ranged up to
more than $20 million.

The Rio Grande Valley was declared eligible for the loans in late November,
officials said.

FSA officials said crop insurance money would be taken into consideration when
determining eligibility for loans.

The deadline to apply for the emergency loan is July 27, 2009. FSA Farm Loan
Manager Arnulfo E. Lerma from the Edinburg FSA office recommends that
applications be filed early to avoid delays.

"If the applications come in early, we can avoid backlogs and speed up the
process," Lerma said in a news release.

FYI

For more information, call the local FSA offices. In Cameron County, call
956-399-1311; in Willacy County, call 956-689-2437; in Hidalgo County, call
956-381-0916; in Starr County, call 956-487-2511.

Starting at 6 p.m., the event will be hosted by Jan Duke, Re/Max Gold agent, and
Mike Baker, Metro Gold Financial loan officer.

For reservations, call 674-4895 or 790-0295. Seats limited.

Y-S Farm Bureau dinner March 1

The Yuba-Sutter Farm Bureau's annual meeting and fundraiser dinner is slated
March 1 at the Bonanza Inn, 1001 Clark Ave. in Yuba City.

The event will begin at 6 p.m. with no-host cocktails, followed by dinner at 7
p.m.

Events include keynote speaker Charles Hoppin, the Distinguished Service Award,
the installation of new officers and silent and live auctions.

Tickets are $50 per person or $90 per couple. For reservations, due by Feb. 19,
contact the Farm Bureau at 475 N. Palora Ave., Suite A, Yuba City.

Great Harvest is in Top 500

Great Harvest Franchising Inc. was named to Entrepreneur magazine's Top 500
Franchises in its 29th annual ranking list published in the January 2008 issue.

A local franchise, owned by Jennifer and Terry Moe, is located at 1500 Butte
House Road, Yuba City.

Great Harvest was ranked 256 and has made the list six years in a row. The
company was founded in 1976 in Great Falls, Mont., and now has more than 210
bakeries throughout the nation.

Emergency loans offered to farms

Farmers in three Mid-Valley counties are among those eligible for emergency loan
funds from the U.S. Department of Agriculture.

The counties are near counties designated as primary areas eligible for farm
loans due to physical and production losses based on damages and losses caused
by drought conditions.

Colusa County is eligible for damage that occurred on Jan. 1 through Aug. 31,
2007. Yuba and Butte counties are eligible for damage between Jan. 1, 2007, and
onward.

Contact the Tehama Farm Service Agency at 2 Sutter St., Suite C, Red Bluff, CA
96080; or call 527-3013.

                     News-Journal (Daytona Beach, Florida)

                            February 2, 2010 Tuesday
                               N-j Final Edition

$75 million in crop damage spurs disaster declaration

BYLINE: BOB KOSLOWBUSINESS WRITER, BOB KOSLOW - BUSINESS WRITER

SECTION: SECTION A; Pg. 1A

LENGTH: 554  words

DATELINE: DAYTONA BEACH


DAYTONA BEACH -- Volusia County farmers suffered more than $75 million in crop
damage, especially cut foliage, as a result of the hard freeze in January.

Flagler County's damage was much less.

To help those hit hardest by one of the longest cold spells in recent state
memory, U.S. Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack declared a disaster at the behest
of Gov. Charlie Crist and members of Congress.

The declaration, which covers 60 Florida counties including Volusia and Flagler,
may enable farmers and ranchers to secure federally issued or guaranteed
low-interest loans and grant assistance to recover from the cold damage.

The USDA's Farm Service Agency will administer the programs.

The No. 1 thing we ask is that farmers work with their local Farm Service Agency
offices for personal services and find out what is available to them," said
Andre Kok, a Farm Service Agency spokesman in Washington, D.C.

The declaration opens the door for emergency loans of up to $500,000 with a 3.75
percent interest rate and access to the Supplemental Revenue Assistance Payments
Program, Kok said.

The Farm Service Agency could not provide county crop-damage assessments in time
for this report.

However, U.S. Rep. Suzanne Kosmas, D-New Smyrna Beach, said that the cut-foliage
industry in Volusia sustained about a 60 percent loss of ferns with an estimated
sales value of $40 million -- just at the start of its peak Valentine's Day
cutting season.

Other damage estimates in Volusia included a $35 million loss to nurseries,
$850,000 to citrus fruit and trees and $45,000 damage to winter vegetables.

A lot of these businesses were already being hit by a weak economy, which
affects much of their products, particularly if it is related to housing or
landscaping," she said.

The cabbage crop in Flagler County "came through OK," said Mark Warren, the
county's agricultural extension agent. "We are counting our blessings that we
came though as well as we have."

There are some fungal issues with the cabbage's outer freeze- damaged leaves,
but that should not be an issue with cabbage quality, Warren said.

The two counties became eligible for the federal programs by sustaining at least
30 percent overall crop damage during the freezes, Kok said.

Emergency loans can cover crop loss, real-estate damage, essential family living
expenses and farm operations.

Farmers must have at least a 30 percent crop loss to qualify as well as be
landowners or operators in the designated counties, be an established farm
operator, have acceptable credit history, be eligible for a commercial loan and
have loan collateral.

The loans have one- to seven-year repayment periods and 30 years for real-estate
loans.

The disaster declaration is good news for Eric Hagstrom, who's Albin Hagstrom &
Son fernery in Pierson sustained about 60 percent damage to the fern crop,
nearly all the young and tender ferns. But he is cautious about the federal
help.

We are still going back and forth on the programs and the rules that go with
them. In the past, the programs have meant well, but no one would qualify,"
Hagstrom said.

Farm Disaster Aid

The USDA's Farm Service Agency has service centers in the region:

DELAND: 101 Heavensgate Road, 386-985-4037

EAST PALATKA: 111 Yelvington Road, 386-328-5051.

OCALA: 2441 NE Third St., Suite 204, 352-732-7534

ONLINE: disaster.fsa.usda.gov

LOAD-DATE: February 3, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

million. News-Journal/ PETER BAUERPhoto 2: Icicles hang from a tangerine tree
along State Road 11 near DeLeon Springs on a January morning after overnight
temps dipped into the mid-20s. News-Journal file/ PETER BAUER

                            December 28, 2014 Sunday

Washington: USDA Designates St. Francis County in Arkansas as a Primary Natural
Disaster Area

LENGTH: 387  words

DATELINE: Washington


US Department of Agriculture, The Government of USA has issued the following
news release:

The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) has designated St. Francis County in
Arkansas as a primary natural disaster area due to damages and losses caused by
severe hail that occurred on Oct. 2, 2014.


"Our hearts go out to those Arkansas farmers and ranchers affected by recent
natural disasters," said Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack. "President Obama and
I are committed to ensuring that agriculture remains a bright spot in our
nation's economy by sustaining the successes of America's farmers, ranchers, and
rural communities through these difficult times. We're also telling Arkansas
producers that USDA stands with you and your communities when severe weather and
natural disasters threaten to disrupt your livelihood."


Farmers and ranchers in Crittenden, Cross, Lee, Monroe and Woodruff counties in
Arkansas also qualify for natural disaster assistance because their counties are
contiguous.


All counties listed above were designated natural disaster areas on Dec. 24,
2014, making all qualified farm operators in the designated areas eligible for
low interest emergency (EM) loans from USDA's Farm Service Agency (FSA),
provided eligibility requirements are met. Farmers in eligible counties have
eight months from the date of the declaration to apply for loans to help cover
part of their actual losses. FSA will consider each loan application on its own
merits, taking into account the extent of losses, security available and
repayment ability. FSA has a variety of programs, in addition to the EM loan
program, to help eligible farmers recover from adversity.


Additional programs available to assist farmers and ranchers include the
Emergency Conservation Program, The Livestock Forage Disaster Program, the
Livestock Indemnity Program, the Emergency Assistance for Livestock, Honeybees,
and Farm-Raised Fish Program, and the Tree Assistance Program. Interested
farmers may contact their local USDA Service Centers for further information on
eligibility requirements and application procedures for these and other
programs. Additional information is also available online at
http://disaster.fsa.usda.gov.

                      Chico Enterprise-Record (California)

                           February 18, 2006 Saturday

Farmers from north state eligible for emergency loans

BYLINE: E-R Staff

SECTION: LOCAL

LENGTH: 182 words


Butte, Glenn, Colusa and Tehama County growers are eligible for federal
emergency farm loans if they suffered losses caused by severe storms, flooding,
mudslides or landslides between Dec. 17 and Jan. 3.

President Bush declared an emergency in 29 California counties on Feb. 3, making
them eligible for the aid. Farmers in 16 adjacent counties are also eligible.

Farmers in all 45 counties have eight months to apply for the loans to help
cover part of their actual losses.

To be eligible, they must:

-- Have suffered at least a 30 percent loss directly related to the weather,

-- Be able to repay the loan and any other loans,

-- Be unable to obtain credit elsewhere,

-- Have adequate security, and

-- Have multi-peril crop insurance, if available.

All applicants must complete a certification of disaster losses. Crop insurance
field reports may be a source for documenting losses directly related to the
cited cause.

Applications should be filed with the Farm Service Agency service center at
132-A N. Enright Ave., Willows, CA 95988, or call 934-4669, ext. 2.

                       Telegram & Gazette (Massachusetts)

                     March 28, 2002, Thursday ALL EDITIONS

The Market; Local

SECTION: BUSINESS; THE MARKET; LOCAL; Pg. E1

LENGTH: 325 words

DATELINE: WORCESTER



The Market

Index rising

- The T&G/Bloomberg Central Massachusetts Index rose 0.75 yesterday to 111.39
points as nearly 28.9 million shares traded.

Twelve stocks rose, 14 fell and five closed unchanged.

Concord Communications Inc. of Marlboro led advancers, rising $1.02 to $20.07.
Decliners were led by Waters Corp. of Milford, which fell 60 cents to $27.89.

Local

Emergency loans

Worcester County is eligible for U.S. Department of Agriculture emergency farm
loans because of losses caused by excessive rainfall, lack of sunshine and cold
weather in 2000.

Farmers have eight months from March 22 -- the date the county was named among
primary disaster areas -- to apply for the loans. They should contact the Farm
Service Agency office in Holden.

William G. Graham Jr., Farm Service Agency county executive director for
Worcester County, said the 3.75 percent rate loans can be used to refinance debt
and make capital improvements. To be eligible, farmers must have been turned
away by their traditional lender, he said.

Conover creates

SOUTHBORO -- Conover & Co. Communications, a marketing communications and public
relations firm, has created a new division to service the life sciences and
medical products industries. Allison Jones Hallacy, a medical products marketing
executive, will manage the division.

UMass index up

The University of Massachusetts Benchmarks Economic Indexes both rose in
February, showing signs of growth.

The current economic index for Massachusetts in February was 127.7, up 0.4
percent from January and down 1.4 percent from February 2001. The leading
economic index, a forecast of growth in the current index during the next six
months, was up 1.8 percent, UMass said.

''While the recession has been mild, it has been deeper and longer in
Massachusetts than the country as whole,'' Benchmarks said. ''Nevertheless, it
appears the economy is beginning to turn around.''

                              The Bismarck Tribune

                             March 26, 1999 Friday

LENGTH: 353 words


WASHINGTON (AP) -- With a two-week congressional recess set to begin this
weekend, farm state Democrats began an urgent push Thursday for passage of $153
million in emergency money for farm loans. The money is part of a $1.3 billion
supplemental bill that also includes aid for Central America. That measure is
held up because lawmakers are at odds over some cuts Republicans have proposed
to offset the spending.

President Clinton has promised to veto that measure, and lawmakers are unsure if
a compromise can be hammered out before the Easter holiday recess begins. John
Czwartacki, a spokesman for Senate Majority Leader Trent Lott, R-Miss., said it
was unlikely the supplemental would be passed by today. Instead, it will be
completed after the recess, he said. With the clock ticking down, Democratic
congessional aides said late Thursday that Clinton was reviewing whether he
could give the Agricultre Dpartment the authority to reallocate funds within its
budget to cover the emergency farm loans without congressional approval. ""We're
getting some indictions now the White House . . . may have a solution that can
cover money within the department,'' said Mark Halverson, the Senate Agriculture
Committee's Democratic counsel. Democrtic senators contended Thursday that
farmers can't wait any longer. ""We've got to act now,'' said Sen. Tom Harkin of
Iowa, the Agriculture Committee's top Democrat. Added Sen. Byron Dorgan, D-N.D.,
""We are just weeks away from spring planting. We face a very urgent
situation.'' The money would be used for direct loans or loan guarantees for an
estimated 10,000 producers who can't get credit from private sources. The
Agriculture Department has said a year of extremely low prices has led to the
problem. Dorgan and other Democrats also pushed an amendment Thursday that would
lift marketing loan rate and create a price support for farmers. The proposal,
which would be attached to the fiscal year 2000 budget resolution, has been
pushed by Democrats since the 1996 farm law, which began phasing out subsidies
for farmers. Attempts to pass a similar measure failed last year.

                                 March 25, 2015

County Dart of recent disaster declaration

BYLINE: The Lake Metigoshe Mirror staff

LENGTH: 433  words


The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) has designated 25 counties in North
Dakota as a primary natural disaster area due to damages and losses caused by
the combined effects of frost, colder than averages winter, cooler than normal
spring temperatures, excessive rainfall, ground saturation, frost, freeze,
severe thunderstorms, hail, high winds, drought, weather-related insects,
diseases and sprout damage that occurred from Jan. 1. 2014. and continues. Those
counties include Bottineau, Renville and McHenry.

"Our hearts go out to those North Dakota farmers and ranchers affected by recent
natural disasters," said Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack. "President Obama and
I are committed to ensuring that agriculture remains a bright spot in our
nation's economy by sustaining the successes of America's farmers, ranchers, and
rural communities through these difficult times. We're also telling North Dakota
producers that USDA stands with you and your communities when severe weather and
natural disasters threaten to disrupt your livelihood."

Farmers and ranchers in other counties in North Dakota also qualify for natural
disaster assistance because their counties are contiguous. Those counties are
include Rolette, Towner and Pierce.

All counties listed above were designated natural disaster areas on March 18.
2015, making all qualified farm operators in the designated areas eligible for
low interest emergency (EM) loans from USDA's Farm Service Agency (FSA).
provided eligibility requirements are met. Farmers in eligible counties have
eight months from the date of the declaration to apply for loans to help cover
part of their actual losses. FSA will consider each loan application on its own
merits, taking into account the extent of losses, security available and
repayment ability. FSA has a variety of programs, in addition to the EM loan
program, to help eligible farmers recover from adversity.

Additional programs available to assist farmers and ranchers include the
Emergency Conservation Program. The Livestock Forage Disaster Program, the
Livestock Indemnity Program, the Emergency Assistance for Livestock, Honeybees,
and Farm-Raised Fish Program, and the Tree Assistance Program. Interested
farmers may contact their local USDA Service Centers for further information on
eligibility requirements and application procedures for these and other
programs. Additional information is also available online at
http://disaster.fsa.usda.gov.

Farmers in eligible counties have eight months from the date of the declaration
to apply for loans to help cover part of their actual losses.

                                January 19, 2012

County put on primary disaster list

BYLINE: East Bernard Express staff

LENGTH: 476  words


The United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) on Jan. 5 designated 40
counties in Texas as primary natural disaster areas due to losses caused by
drought, excessive heat, high winds and wildfires that occurred during the
period of Jan. 1, 2011, and continues.

Wharton County is included in that list, as well as neighboring Matagorda
County.

"Texas farmers have experienced severe drought conditions over a long period of
time, which has caused major losses to a wide variety of crops such as forage
crops, pasture, corn, oats and wheat," said Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack.
"President Obama and I are committed to using the resources at our disposal to
reduce the impact of these disasters on Texas producers and help to get those
affected back on their feet."

Farmers and ranchers in Fort Bend and Jackson counties, as well as many other
counties, also qualify for natural disaster assistance because their counties
are contiguous.

Wharton was among the counties fisted as designated natural disaster areas on
Jan. 3, making all qualified farm operators in the designated areas eligible for
low interest emergency (EM) loans from USDA's Farm Service Agency (FSA),
provided eligibility requirements are met.

Farmers in eligible counties have eight months from the date of the declaration
to apply for loans to help cover part of their actual losses. FSA will consider
each loan application on its own merits, taking into account the extent of
losses, security available and repayment ability. FSA has a variety of programs,
in addition to the EM loan program, to help eligible farmers recover from
adversity.

USDA also has made other programs available to assist farmers and ranchers,
including the Supplemental Revenue Assistance Program (SURE), which was approved
as part of the Food, Conservation, and Energy Act of 2008; the Emergency
Conservation Program; Federal Crop Insurance; and the Noninsured Crop Disaster
Assistance Program. Interested farmers may contact their local USDA Service
Centers for further information on eligibility requirements and application
procedures for these and other programs. Additional information is also
available online at http://disaster. fsa.usda.gov.

Vilsack also reminds producers that the department's authority to operate the
five disaster assistance programs authorized by the 2008 farm bill expired on
Sept. 30, 2011. This includes SURE; the Livestock Indemnity Program (LIP); the
Emergency Assistance for

Livestock, Honey Bees, and Farm-Raised Fish (ELAP); the Livestock Forage
Disaster Program (LFP); and the Tree Assistance Program (TAP).

Production losses in the designated counties are covered because the event
triggering the loss occurred prior to the expiration of these programs; however,
production losses due to disasters occurring after Sept. 30, 2011, are not
eligible for disaster program coverage.

             The Press of Atlantic City (Pleasantville New Jersey)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                          November 13, 2013 Wednesday

USDA issues disaster declaration for South Jersey farms, citing excessive summer
rains

BYLINE: Anjalee Khemlani and Steven Lemongello, The Press of Atlantic City,
Pleasantville, N.J.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 549 words


Nov. 13--The U.S. Department of Agriculture approved a disaster declaration for
some southern New Jersey counties where flooding, high winds and hail affected
farmers' crops during the summer.

Agricultural production was negatively affected due to excessive weather in
Atlantic, Burlington, Camden, Cape May, Cumberland, Gloucester, Ocean and Salem
counties.

Farmers in those counties are eligible for low-interest emergency loans from
USDA's Farm Service Agency and have eight months to apply for loans to help
cover part of their actual losses, according to the USDA. The FSA "will consider
each loan application on its own merits," the USDA said, taking into account the
extent of losses, security available and repayment ability.

"Our hearts go out to those New Jersey farmers and ranchers affected by recent
natural disasters," Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack said in a statement.
"President Obama and I are committed to ensuring that agriculture remains a
bright spot in our nation's economy by sustaining the successes of America's
farmers, ranchers and rural communities through these difficult times. We're
also telling New Jersey producers that USDA stands with you and your communities
when severe weather and natural disasters threaten to disrupt your livelihood."

Charles Muzzarelli, owner of Muzzarelli Farms in Buena Vista Township, said his
farm, which grows tomatoes, sweet potatoes, blueberries and other produce, was
affected by the increased rainfall this summer.

"Any help we get is beneficial," Muzzarelli said. "The yields were down, our
production was affected. It was just a lot harder to get work done because of
the weather conditions."

While this summer's rain total in June, July and August, as recorded at the
Atlantic City International Airport in Egg Harbor Township, came to 13.9 inches,
about 3 inches more than average, much of that fell in June alone -- with 9.55
inches of rain recorded in June at the Atlantic City Marina.

"The sheer amount of rain, flooding and extreme weather that South Jersey
experienced this past summer was far beyond what our farms and crops could
handle," said U.S. Rep. Frank LoBiondo in a statement Wednesday.

"With this declaration, farm operators will have access to emergency loans
through the Farm Service Agency to recoup their losses and rebuild their
operations. I appreciate Gov. Chris Christie's efforts to ensure the
critically-important agricultural sector of our state -- and the backbone of
South Jersey -- was not forgotten," said LoBiondo, R-2nd.

The official letter to Christie states the damaging weather lasted from May
through September, and does not name Monmouth and Mercer counties, which also
suffered damage.

Many of the same counties, including Atlantic, Cape May, Cumberland and Ocean,
received a similar disaster declaration in February due to the effects of
Hurricane Sandy and a November 2012 northeaster.

                            Newton Daily News, Iowa
