                            August 2, 2012 Thursday

Jasper County, 41 others named federal disaster areas

BYLINE: Bob Eschliman,, Newton Daily News, Iowa

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 496 words


Aug. 02--Gov. Terry Branstad announced Wednesday he had received a letter from
U.S. Secretary of Agriculture Tom Vilsack designating 42 counties in Iowa,
including Jasper County, as "primary disaster areas."

"In response to my letter, the lieutenant governor and I would like to thank
Secretary Vilsack for the USDA's recent drought declaration of several Iowa
counties," Branstad said of the declaration. "This drought has had a significant
impact on Iowa agriculture and the farmers who work hard every day to feed a
growing world population. This disaster designation will provide affected Iowans
with additional resources during these difficult times."

Other Iowa politicians, including Lt. Gov. Kim Reynolds, also responded to the
declaration.

"One thing that I know for certain is that Iowa farmers have the tenacity,
resilience, resolve and fortitude to withstand these challenging times," she
said. "The governor and I stand with all Iowans as we work together to respond
swiftly to these drought conditions."

"The ongoing drought continues to inflict hardship on farmers in Iowa and across
the Midwest," U.S. Sen. Tom Harkin, a senior member and former chairman of the
Senate Agriculture, Nutrition and Forestry Committee, said. "I welcome today's
actions and thank Secretary Vilsack for responding to our severe drought
problems in Iowa."

The primary disaster declaration includes all seven contiguous counties to
Jasper County: Mahaska, Marion, Marshall, Polk, Poweshiek, Story and Tama.

"These counties have suffered from a drought intensity value of at least D2
(Drought-Severe) for eight or more consecutive weeks, or D3 (Drought-Extreme) or
higher at any time during the growing season according to the U.S. Drought
Monitor," Vilsack wrote to Branstad.

A secretarial disaster declaration makes farm operators in primary disaster
counties eligible to be considered for assistance from the Farm Service Agency,
provided other eligibility requirements are met. Assistance includes FSA
emergency loans, which eligible farmers would have until the end of March of
2013 to apply for emergency loan assistance.

"It may be a little early in the game to think about applying for loans now,
since those emergency loans are based on production losses," Jasper County FSA
Farm Loans Program Manager Jon Northrup said. "They will have to go through the
harvest and measure their yield, which we will then compare to a normal year to
establish their loss. The declaration is certainly good to have, but farmers
really can't apply yet until after the harvest."

Northrup added current crops appear to be several weeks to a month ahead of
schedule due to this year's weather conditions. That will likely mean an early
harvest.

bschliman@newtondailynews.com

                              The Washington Post

                    February 3, 1984, Friday, Final Edition

Agency Chief 'Proud' of Performance;
USDA Aides Blasted on Farm Loan Policy

BYLINE: By Ward Sinclair, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: First Section; A9

LENGTH: 535 words


A bipartisan parade of congressmen, reflecting farmer complaints about
difficulties in getting federal disaster and emergency loans, blistered
administration officials at a hearing yesterday, but seemed to make little
impression.

The farm-state legislators were critical of the administration's handling of
disaster loans, related to last summer's drought, and a $600 million economic
emergency loan program that was reinstated under a federal court order in
December.

But Farmers Home Administration (FmHA) chief Charles W. Shuman said he was
"proud" of his agency's performance, contending that loan applications are being
handled promptly and generally favorably. And his boss, Under Secretary of
Agriculture Frank W. Naylor Jr., assured a House Agriculture subcommittee that
all the credit the farmers need is available.

Shuman said that, through mid-January, FmHA had received 23,849 disaster loan
applications, with 3,740 approved, 2,879 rejected or withdrawn and the rest
pending. He said that 4,800 economic emergency loan requests had been received,
with about 60 percent approved.

His statistics were received skeptically, and Naylor provoked further
displeasure by refusing to concede that the president's Office of Management and
Budget had ordered the Agriculture Department to limit to $50 million the direct
loans that could be made to farmers under the court-ordered reinstatement.

The FmHA stopped accepting applications in mid-January, when the $50 million ran
out. The remaining $550 million, at OMB direction, is being held back for use as
guarantees for higher-interest loans that farmers would have to seek from
commercial lenders.

Members of the conservation, credit and rural development subcommittee, plus
other congressional witnesses, complained that the policy effectively had
stopping lending activity to farmers. Contrary to Naylor's assertions, they said
rural banks were refusing to take part in the guarantee program.

Despite its seriousness, the day-long assault on the administration's
performance carried clear election-year overtones. USDA officials in the
audience alternately winced, smiled, smirked and winked at each other as one
Democrat and Republican after another threw rhetorical punches at them.

The administration's only defender, Rep. Joe Skeen (R-N.M.), scolded his
subcommittee colleagues. "I hope we do something that helps farmers and not
politicians," he said.

At one point, Rep. Tom Harkin (D-Iowa), a candidate for the U.S. Senate, said
that the FmHA's performance had been so callous and hard-hearted that if he were
attorney general he would be seeking contempt-of-court citations against USDA
officials.

"In my nine years in Congress, I have never seen anything so badly administered
as the disaster and economic emergency loan programs," Harkin said. "The court
ordered them to implement the emergency program and they have shown clear
contempt of the court."

Subcommittee Chairman Ed Jones (D-Tenn.) and Sen. Walter D. Huddleston (D-Ky.),
among others, have written to U.S. District Court Judge Thomas Flannery to draw
his attention to the OMB order that restricted FmHA from giving out more than
$50 million in direct loans.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                       Copyright 1984 The Washington Post


                             273 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                              The Washington Post

                    November 28, 1999, Sunday, Final Edition

Farmers Taking Wait-and-See Approach to Drought

Graeme Zielinski, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: LOUDOUN EXTRA; Pg. V01

LENGTH: 790 words



Local agriculture experts and others in the farm industry say the drought that
was interrupted by late-summer rains is showing signs of picking up where it
left off.

At Dulles International Airport, total annual rainfall averages 40.24 inches,
according to the National Weather Service. Through Tuesday, 40.06 inches had
fallen--but that included 9.32 inches in September, more than three times the
normal amount for that month, and only .84 inches in November, almost 2 1/2
inches less than normal.

Donald Davis, state director of the U.S. Department of Agriculture Farm Service
Administration Office, said that, in large part because of September's rain,
there was no rush by farmers to enroll in some of the emergency programs his
office administers. But he predicted that the numbers would increase during the
winter.

"We anticipated a high participation rate in our emergency programs. We haven't
seen that yet," Davis said. "But we're gearing up for a pretty good amount. Our
loan-making season is just getting started."

With 40 counties in the state declared drought-emergency areas during the
summer, including Loudoun, Fauquier, Fairfax and Prince William, farmers are
eligible for various kinds of assistance, including low-interest loans and
direct cash assistance.

About $ 20.9 million in cash assistance has been given to 14,372 Virginia
farmers from an emergency congressional appropriation in August that took into
account the drought's damage to crops. But only 41 farmers statewide have
applied for emergency loans, totaling only about $ 3.5 million.

More money was lent this year than in 1998--also a drought year--but Davis said
the figure still was less than expected. And although preliminary figures aren't
available, many agriculture officials and farmers said the 1999 harvest was
generally better than expected.

"The drought conditions in our area appear to be less severe than we
anticipated, and I think crop yields turned out better than people anticipated,"
said Louis Hitt, Warrenton branch manager for Blue Ridge Farm Credit.

Hitt, who farms in northern Fauquier County, said he didn't see requests for
loan extensions, or requests for refinancing, in the numbers he expected in the
beginning of the year. "We might have seen some farmers taking some
intermediate-term debt or refinancing, but we didn't," Hitt said. "Again, I
think our overall farm economy is in fairly decent shape."

The notable exception has been hay farmers. According to estimates from the
local field offices of the Farm Service Administration, Northern Virginia's hay
yield dropped 75 percent. The skimpy hay crop coupled with dry pastures meant a
difficult year for those who raise sheep, beef and dairy cattle and horses.
Those who could not find alternative sources of water or afford to feed their
animals grain have been forced to cull their herds.

In Loudoun County, the estimated number of livestock sold for slaughter was 25
percent higher than usual, and in Fauquier County that number was 30 percent,
according to USDA figures.

Traude Smith, an accountant for the Fauquier Livestock Exchange in Marshall,
where some of those sales took place, said the September rains, which refilled
streams and wells, have contributed to a wait-and-see attitude by farmers.

"There are not as many complaints from the farmers anymore," Smith said. "The
big sell-off was in August, which was unusual. We had the rains, and what I see
now is fairly steady numbers for the fall. People are holding on to their cattle
for a little while."

Even with fewer animals to feed, demand for hay and grain is high, as is the
price of hay, which is hard to come by, some farmers said.

Dan Marvin, manager of Four Seasons Small Farm Services Inc. in Purcellville,
said he had sold all of his hay by July. Typically, he said, he would have about
one-third of his yearly supply available now. But he said some late-season hay
"was spoken for even before we made it."

Hay that normally would sell for $ 3 to $ 3.25 a bale is selling for $ 4.50 a
bale, Marvin said.

Andrew Gerachis, Virginia Tech extension horticulture agent for Loudoun County,
said the full effects of this year's drought have yet to be seen. But next
year's crop of fruits and vegetables will be affected, he said. "The drought has
reduced the number of buds that were set for next year's growth," he said. "All
of those plants will be slightly less vigorous and possibly less fruitful."

Gerachis said that with the financial crunch caused by the drought, farmers may
not have the funds available to make the necessary improvements for next year.

"Most people are just sitting on their hands to kind of wait until spring," he
said.

                               The New York Times

                May 30, 1981, Saturday, Late City Final Edition

U.S. Tightens Farm Disaster Aid

BYLINE: UPI

SECTION: Section 2; Page 35, Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 232 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 29


The Agriculture Department announced changes in regulations today to tighten
administration of its emergency lending to farmers who suffer damage from
natural disasters.

Effective immediately, the rules are intended to stop recipients from misusing
loans to expand their farming operations, the department said. Farmers are
eligible for disaster loans after their farms are hit by flood, drought or other
natural disasters.

Dwight O. Calhoun, acting administrator of the Farmers Home Administration,
which administers the loans, said the changes would ''help to preserve the
integrity of the emergency loan program.''

The program was never intended to compete with commercial lenders, he said, and
it should be targeted at farmers who truly need Federal help after disasters.

''In the recent past, F.H.A. emergency loans have been used to expand farming
operations,'' he said. ''Emergency loans often completely replace commercial
financing by offering loans for purposes and on terms with which commercial
lenders cannot compete.''

Mr. Calhoun did not estimate how much money the tightening might save.  Congress
put a ceiling on disaster loans, starting at $2 million, to be phased down to
$500,000 by the fiscal year 1983.

                                US Official News

                            November 6, 2015 Friday

Virginia: EIGHT LOCALITIES IN VIRGINIA RECEIVE DISASTER DECLARATIONS FROM THE
U.S. DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE

LENGTH: 269  words

DATELINE: Lahore



    Richmond: Virginia Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services has
issued the following news release:



 The Virginia Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services announced that
eight localities in Virginia along the North Carolina line are eligible for
disaster assistance from the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA). These
include Brunswick, Greensville, Halifax, Mecklenburg, Pittsylvania and
Southampton Counties and the Cities of Danville and Suffolk, localities that are
contiguous to North Carolina.





 On October 22, 2015, the State Executive Director of the North Carolina Farm
Service Agency (FSA) requested a primary county disaster designation for 11
North Carolina counties, due to losses caused by excessive rain and flooding
that occurred from September 22 through October 4, 2015.



 A USDA Secretarial disaster designation makes farm operators in primary
counties and those counties contiguous to such primary counties eligible to be
considered for certain assistance from the Farm Service Agency as long as
eligibility requirements are met. This assistance includes FSA emergency loans.



 Farmers in eligible counties have eight months from the date of a Secretarial
disaster declaration to apply for emergency loans. FSA considers each emergency
loan application on its own merits, taking into account the extent of production
losses on the farm, and the security and repayment ability of the operator.



 Local FSA offices can provide affected farmers with further information.

                                US Official News

                            March 15, 2017 Wednesday

Missouri: State Treasurer Eric Schmitt Announces Extension of Emergency Loan
Program to Carroll County

LENGTH: 257  words

DATELINE: New York



 Jefferson: The  State of Treasurer Clint Zweifel, Missouri has issued the
following news release:



 Missouri State Treasurer Eric Schmitt and State Representative Joe Don McGaugh
today announced the extension of an emergency loan program to Carroll County
small businesses and farms impacted by this week's storms.





 The Harmed-area Emergency Loan Priority system, or HELP, authorizes 24-hour
approval of low-interest loans for small businesses and farms. HELP is
administered through the Missouri Linked Deposit Program. Perry County and Oak
Grove were previously identified as active jurisdictions for the system.



 "We stand side-by-side with the farmers and small business owners who were
devastated by this week's storms," said Schmitt. "By extending the HELP system
to cover Carroll County we are laying the groundwork for those impacted to
return to regular operation in less time and at a lower cost than they otherwise
would be able to."



 "Small, family-owned businesses are the bedrock of Carroll County," said
McGaugh."I appreciate the quick work of Treasurer Schmitt to get the HELP system
activated for our community so we can begin the rebuilding process."



 The Missouri Linked Deposit Program is managed by State Treasurer Eric Schmitt.
Missouri-based small businesses with up to 99 employees are eligible to receive
a loan through the Missouri Linked Deposit Program based on lender underwriting
standards.

                              The American Banker

White House to Unveil Farm Relief Package; May Offer Emergency Fund Up to $3
Billion

                           February 22, 1985, Friday

By BARTLETT NAYLOR

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


Programs designed to relieve the farm credit crunch are speeding their way
through Congress, with the White House expected to unveil its own package - the
second in two weeks - today.

The Reagan administration's first package was snubbed by Congress and trade
groups, who called it ineffective.

Details of the Reagan plan were worked out Thursday as farm state senators
applied direct pressure on the austerity-minded White House: It was the second
day of a filibuster in the Senate on the confirmation of Edwin Meese 3d as
attorney general.

Tentative agreement was reached late Thursday on a plan that would satisfy farm
state senators conducting the filibuster.  Sen. James Exon, D-Neb., said the
agreement was subject to approval by Democrats and a letter confirming the
agreement from President Reagan and Agriculture Secretary John Block.

The President's advisers were bargaining for an ''administrative'' solution,
according to a source close to the Senate-White House negotiations on a new farm
plan. The source said the administration is willing to offer a special emergency
fund of up to $3 billion in federal guarantees for farm loans. The source said
the Department of Agriculture is prepared to hire as many as 1,000 people to
process loans in time for the planting season.

The $3 billion in guarantees would be an off-budget item since no actual
appropriations would be needed, according to Senate staffers close to the
negotiations.

But in addition, the White House insists that banks forgive a fraction of the
principal and interest obligation in exchange for new federal loan guarantees, a
proposal made two weeks ago. Bankers must ''take a hit,'' White House
negotiators say, according to a source.

Specifically, bankers must forgive 10% of the principal and/or interest on a
farm loan in exchange for a federal guarantee covering 90% of the loan in case
of default.

It is this clause, first announced by the administration last August, that
upsets farm bankers. ''Forgiveness is a serious flaw in the program,'' said
Kenneth Guenther, executive director of the Independent Bankers Association of
America. The association represents mostly smaller banks.

The administration has also advised key Senate Republicans that it will not work
with a House-authored bill, a source said.

Meanwhile, already making its way through the Democrat-controlled House is a $1
billion authorization measure for the federal guarantee pool. The money would be
used to insure bank lenders against loan losses. Farm income this year will be
only about $2 billion more than the debt service on the $210 billion in
outstanding loans, according to economists at the University of Iowa.

The initiative passed the 57-member House Appropriations Committee without
dissent along with several other measures in less than an hour Thursday. It is
scheduled for a full floor vote next Thursday.

The $1 billion in supplemental guarantees is about a 150% increase over the
current $650 million in credit guarantees authorized in the present Reagan
budget.

Debate on the farm crisis continues in Washington with intensity and breadth
unusual for a single issue. On Thursday alone, three House committees addressed
the issue - in addition to action taken by the Appropriations Committee. The
Agriculture Committee reviewed budget proposals for the Agriculture Department,
questioning Secretary John Block on what some committee members charged was the
Reagan administration's abandonment of America's farmers; the credit and rural
development subcommittee was slated to draft emergency farm credit legislation;
and another agriculture subcommittee held hearings on the Farm Credit
Administration.

House Banking Committee Chairman Fernand J. St Germain, D-R.I., indicated he
planned to schedule hearings on the farm credit crisis ''in the very near
future.'' In a Feb. 11 letter responding to Republican members of his committee,
Mr. St Germain said he was ''aware of this situation and have already directed
staff to make recommendations to me concerning the way in which we can
proceed.''

The Republicans who addressed Mr. St Germain on the issue in that Feb. 7 letter
were Rep. Chalmers P. Wylie of Ohio, the minority leader on the committee, Jim
Leach of Iowa, Norman D. Shumway of California, and Doug Bereuter of Nebraska,
all with large farm constituents.

No hearings have yet been scheduled, though, before the committee.

These farm initiatives represent the first test of the Reagan administration's
pledge to reduce the budget deficit, cutting federal subsidies from nearly all
sectors of the economy except the defense industry.

Budget director David Stockman, who was hospitalized early Thursday morning for
fatigue, has been outspoken in urging cuts in farm programs.

Even Agriculture Secretary Block warned antagonistic senators on the Senate
Budget Committee earlier in the week that the Reagan administration's present
plan is ''enough'' for the beleaguered farm sector.

To date, the most ambitious plan for helping farm creditors comes from the
independent bankers group. The Washington-based lobby has called for additional
federal loan guarantees of $3 billion, triple the amount being considered in the
House.

The American Bankers Association is largely supportive of current administration
efforts.

Sen. Mark Andrews, R-N.D. has also suggested a $3 billion addition to federal
credit guarantees.

Sen. David Boren, D-Okla., who helped organize the filibuster of the Meese
confirmation, has declined to detail how large the guarantee authority must be
or mention other measures.

SECTION: THE FARM CRISIS; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 935 words

                             282 of 1000 DOCUMENTS



                              The Washington Post

                           October 31, 2002 Thursday
                                 Final Edition

Few Takers Likely For Loans;
Federal Drought Aid Seen as 'Last-Ditch' Effort

BYLINE: Abhi Raghunathan, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: VIRGINIA EXTRA; Pg. T11

LENGTH: 540 words


Farmers in Loudoun and Fauquier counties who suffered during this summer's
drought may soon get a little help: The Agriculture Department says they can
apply for low-interest loans from the federal government.

But officials say few farmers suffered losses great enough to qualify, and those
who did may not want to take on more debt.

"We're grateful for what we can get," said Keith Dickinson, Fauquier's
agricultural extension agent. "But some farmers may decide that they're in the
stage where they can't do this anymore. . . . They may just decide to sell their
farm."

Last week, Virginia Agriculture Secretary Ann M. Veneman designated 96 Virginia
jurisdictions as agriculture disaster areas. Fifty-seven, including Loudoun and
Fauquier, are eligible for the emergency farm loans. Thirty-nine, including
Prince William County, are considered "primary" agriculture disaster areas and
can also qualify for grants from the livestock compensation program, which is
intended to help make up costs from lost pasture and other sources of animal
feed.

Farmers and ranchers who apply for the federal loans must show they have
suffered at least a 30 percent loss in a single farming or ranching enterprise,
according to Agriculture Department regulations. They also must have been unable
to receive credit from commercial sources. Dickinson called the loans a
"last-ditch" effort to save a farm.

The emergency loans have a fixed 3.75 percent interest rate. The maximum loan
available is $ 500,000, and most must be repaid in one to seven years.

Dickinson said this summer was "very stressful" in Fauquier and severly hurt a
few pockets of farmers. Gary Hornbaker, Loudoun's agricultural extension agent,
said his county was not as hard hit. "We had drought conditions, but we had rain
when we needed to make our crops," he said.

In fact, Loudoun and Fauquier were put on the list not because drought
conditions were that bad but because the counties bordered such places as Prince
William that suffered more, officials said.

"There won't be much -- if any -- participation," Hornbaker said. "Farmers are
cautious about borrowing more money."

For farmers who suffered losses, he said, "to borrow money compounds their
losses."

Jeanette Smith, executive director of the Farm Service Agency in Loudoun, which
helps distribute the loans to farmers, said there was a low turnout the last
time Loudoun was declared an agriculture disaster area. In 1999, "maybe five
people" applied for the loans, she said.

Still, she said she was grateful that farmers have the opportunity to apply for
the loans. "If you help one producer, you've done something for somebody," she
said.

The designation of Loudoun and Fauquier came only after Virginia Gov. Mark R.
Warner (D) sent a letter to Veneman two weeks ago.

"Farmers in this agricultural sector have been hit hard by drought conditions in
2001 and 2002," he wrote. He also asked her to open up the livestock
compensation program to more Virginia counties.

"If the letter helped things along, then that's great," said Ellen Qualls, a
press secretary for Warner. "The sooner, the better."

Farmers who are interested in applying for the loans should contact their local
farm service agency office.

LOAD-DATE: October 31, 2002

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              The Bismarck Tribune

                             July 27, 1993 Tuesday

BYLINE: Kristine Donatelle

LENGTH: 553 words


The White House on Monday issued a presidential disaster declaration for 17
counties in North Dakota, enabling businesses, farmers and homeowners assaulted
by heavy rains to qualify for aid. The declaration opens the full range of
federal disaster programs to North Dakotans who have suffered rain and flood
damage, said Sen. Kent Conrad, D-N.D. The counties are Barnes, Burleigh, Cass,
Dickey, Emmons, Grant, Hettinger, Kidder, LaMoure, Logan, McIntosh, Morton,
Ransom, Richland, Sargent, Sioux and Stutsman.

""Help is on the way,'' said Conrad, who toured flood-ravaged communities in
eastern North Dakota over the weekend. ""The damages are already high in North
Dakota, and if the weather forecasters are right, we're going to need even more
help.'' The declaration makes North Dakota the ninth state in the flooded
Midwest to be designated for federal disaster relief. Gov. Ed Schafer made the
disaster request for the counties Friday, saying flooding has inflicted $406
million in damage to private and public property, businesses and agriculture in
North Dakota. Damage in Burleigh and Morton counties exceed $2 million,
according to official estimates. ""I am pleased to see that President Clinton,
who promised fast action during my meeting with him in St. Louis, came through
on his commitment,'' Schafer said. The Federal Emergency Management Agency is
spearheading an effort by local, state and federal teams to assess the damage.
FEMA representative Brett Hansard said 11 additional counties will be undergoing
assessment this week. They are McLean, Mercer, Oliver, Sheridan, Wells, Benson,
Ramsey, Grand Forks, Griggs, Steele and Traill. Schafer said, ""We are
monitoring the situation closely at the state level given the heavy rainfall
over the weekend, and we will be moving quickly to add counties to the list as
needed.'' A $3 billion disaster aid package for farms hit by the flooding is
moving through Congress, with a hearing in the House Appropriations Committee
scheduled this week. The level of relief remains fluid. Schafer said disaster
application centers will be set up in Jamestown, Valley City, Fargo and Bismarck
with a coordinating field office to be established somewhere in the
Morton-Mercer-Oliver area. Exact locations will be announced today.
Registrations are being taken on the disaster toll free line at 1-800-462-9029,
which is operating 8 a.m. to 7 p.m. seven days a week. Conrad says disaster
relief programs that will be made available to North Dakotans include: Through
FEMA Ä Help for people including temporary housing, home repairs and emergency
grants, as well as aid to government entities including technical assistance and
financial aid to repair highways and public facilities. Through the Farmers Home
Administration Ä Low-interest emergency loans to family farms which suffer
property losses or crop damage above 30 percent. Through the Small Business
Administration Ä SBA will provide three types of low-interest disaster loans
with payback periods up to 30 years, and no payments due until five months after
the loan is distributed. Loan categories include losses suffered by residential
property owners and renters, damage to property suffered by businesses, and
economic injury loans to provide working capital for losses sustained as a
result of the disaster.

LENGTH: 540  words

DATELINE: Salt Lake City


Department of Agriculture Farm Service Agency, The State of Utah has issued the
following news release:

Department of Agriculture (USDA) has designated 21 counties in Mississippi as
primary natural disaster areas due to damages and losses caused by a freeze that
occurred March 25-29, 2013.


The counties are:


Clarke

Harrison

Marion

Covington

Perry

Stone

"Our hearts go out to those Mississippi farmers and ranchers affected by recent
natural disasters," said Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack. "President Obama and
I are committed to ensuring that agriculture remains a bright spot in our
nation's economy by sustaining the successes of America's farmers, ranchers and
rural communities through these difficult times. We're also telling Mississippi
producers that USDA stands with you and your communities when severe weather and
natural disasters threaten to disrupt your livelihood."

Washington


Louisiana

All counties listed above were designated natural disaster areas July 31, 2013,
making all qualified farm operators in the designated areas eligible for low
interest emergency (EM) loans from USDA's Farm Service Agency (FSA), provided
eligibility requirements are met. Farmers in eligible counties have eight months
from the date of the declaration to apply for loans to help cover part of their
actual losses. FSA will consider each loan application on its own merits, taking
into account the extent of losses, security available and repayment ability. FSA
has a variety of programs, in addition to the EM loan program, to help eligible
farmers recover from adversity.


Additional programs available to assist farmers and ranchers include the
Emergency Conservation Program, Federal Crop Insurance, and the Noninsured Crop
Disaster Assistance Program. Interested farmers may contact their local USDA
Service Centers for further information on eligibility requirements and
application procedures for these and other programs. Additional information is
also available online at http://disaster.fsa.usda.gov


Secretary Vilsack also reminds producers that Congress has not funded the five
disaster assistance programs authorized by the 2008 Farm Bill. These are SURE;
the Livestock Indemnity Program (LIP); the Emergency Assistance for Livestock,
Honey Bees, and Farm-Raised Fish (ELAP); the Livestock Forage Disaster Program
(LFP); and the Tree Assistance Program (TAP). Production losses due to disasters
occurring after Sept. 30, 2011, are not eligible for disaster program coverage.

For further information please visit: http://www.fsa.usda.gov/

TEXAS MAN PLEADS NOT GUILTY IN FATAL SHOOTINGS

GRAND ISLAND - A Texas man accused of fatally shooting two Grand Island men has
pleaded not guilty to charges in the March incident.

Marco E. Torres Jr., 32, of Pasadena, entered the plea Tuesday in Hall County
District Court.

Authorities have said Torres shot and killed Edward Hall, 60, and Timothy
Donohue, 48, during the first weekend in March. Torres also was charged with
kidnapping another man, Bill Packer.

Torres was charged with two counts of first-degree murder and weapons charges,
two counts of robbery and one count of kidnapping.

Hall County Attorney Mark Young has said Torres fled to Texas after the
shootings and burned Hall's car in a remote area.

He was arrested March 26 in Houston.

District Judge James Livingston scheduled trials for November.

FARMERS IN 3 COUNTIES NOW ELIGIBLE FOR LOANS

Family farmers in three southeast Nebraska counties may apply for low-interest
emergency loans to help them recover from weather-related losses suffered May
5-18.

Brian Wolford, Nebraska executive director of the federal Farm Service Agency,
said in a news release Tuesday that the counties are Otoe, Nemaha and
Richardson.

They became eligible for federal assistance because they are contiguous to one
or more of the 17 Missouri counties covered in a presidential major disaster
declaration Monday.

Last week, eight counties were approved for the emergency loan program because
they are contiguous to one or more of the nine Kansas counties that were
declared a "presidential major disaster" June 1.

In addition, farmers in 13 Nebraska counties have been approved for the loan
program for weather-related losses sustained Feb. 21 through May 22. Wolford
said 39 more counties contiguous to those 13 were approved for the loan program
as well.

Applicants must be family farm operators. Loans can be used to buy feed, seed,
fertilizer, livestock or refinance certain debts and to repair or replace
damaged property.

Farmers may apply through their local Farm Service Agency offices.

UNO STUDENT NAMED MISS NEBRASKA 2007

A student at the University of Nebraska at Omaha has been crowned 2007 Miss
Nebraska.

Ashley Bauer, competing as Miss Douglas County, was crowned Saturday in North
Platte.

Bauer is a mentor for the TeamMates Mentoring Program and selected TeamMates: A
Partnership for Youth as her platform.

Bauer is majoring in bioinformatics and is a Walter Scott Scholar. In addition
to the title of Miss Nebraska, Bauer won the Miss Scholar Award and the Miss
Community Service Award for her work with the TeamMates Mentoring Program.

Bauer has volunteered as a TeamMates Mentor in the Omaha Public Schools for the
past two years.

Runners-up at the pageant included first runner-up, Brittany Jeffers, Ogallala,
senior, University of Nebraska-Lincoln; second runner-up,Rachel Seidel,
Crawford, senior, Nebraska Wesleyan; and third runner-up, Kerry ter Kuille,
Omaha, junior, UNL.

Bauer will represent Nebraska at the Miss America 2008 Scholarship Pageant.

POLICE ARREST SECOND MAN IN ARMED ROBBERY

OMAHA - Police have arrested a second man suspected of an armed robbery broken
up by an off-duty police officer who chased one suspect and shot him.

An Omaha police news release said Wesley Kitt, 22, of Omaha was arrested on a
warrant early Wednesday without incident.

He was booked into jail on suspicion of two counts of robbery, two counts of
using a weapon to commit a felony, two counts of second-degree assault and one
count of attempted felony assault on an officer.

According to an Omaha police account, early Saturday, the officer, who was in
uniform as he worked security at an apartment complex, saw a man and woman being
held up by two armed robbers.

The robbers fled in different directions, and the officer chased one. That
robber turned and raised a gun toward the officer, who fired several times.

The officer, Kevin Vodicka, was placed on administrative leave pending further
investigation.

A gunshot victim was later reported at an Omaha hospital, and he was taken after
treatment to police headquarters.

That man, Joshua Harrington, 22, also of Omaha, was arrested on two counts of
robbery, two counts of using a weapon to commit a felony and one count of
attempted felony assault on an officer.

One of the robbery victims was taken to a hospital for treatment of injuries
that were not life-threatening.

                      The Atlanta Journal and Constitution

                             April 1, 1994, Friday

Storm aid programs gear up Federal, state agencies will help North Georgia
residents

BYLINE: By Shelley Emling STAFF WRITER

SECTION: STATE NEWS; Section B; Page 4

LENGTH: 269 words


Now that President Clinton has signed a declaration making six North Georgia
counties disaster areas, here's what federal and state agencies will do to help
those affected by Sunday's tornadoes, which killed 19 people and destroyed
hundreds of homes and businesses.

A disaster field office will be opened in North Georgia within a few days to
coordinate the distribution of aid.

At least three or four federal Disaster Assistance Centers will be established
in affected areas this weekend, said Miller spokesman Rick Dent. Residents will
be able to go to these centers to apply for financial assistance, as well as
receive a wide range of help, from tax advice to psychological counseling.

Through the Federal Emergency Management Agency, working with the Georgia
Emergency Management Agency, governments also will be able to receive help to
pay cleanup costs. Residents will be able to apply for assistance such as
low-interest business loans through programs that include:

A broad grant program for low-income individuals who would not be eligible for
loans. Money would be available in about 10 days.

A low-interest loan program for individuals who have suffered damages either to
their homes or businesses.

A housing-assistance program to provide grants to people whose homes have been
made uninhabitable. Money for repairs and to obtain housing in the interim would
be provided.

An unemployment-assistance program to provide benefits to people who are out of
work as a result of the disaster. It covers people who would not otherwise be
eligible for unemployment benefits, such as farm workers.

                        The Patriot Ledger (Quincy, MA)

                             June 28, 2005 Tuesday
                                  City Edition

Shellfish farmers to get assist;
Feds approve loans for hard-hit counties

BYLINE: Jon Chesto

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 463 words


The Patriot Ledger Shellfish farmers in Massachusetts can apply for low-interest
loans to help recover from red tide-induced losses now that federal officials
have designated three coastal counties as agricultural disaster areas.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture's Farm Service Agency said yesterday that it
declared Plymouth, Barnstable and Essex counties eligible for subsidized loans.
Contiguous counties to the designated areas, such as Norfolk and Bristol
counties, are also eligible for the farm aid.

The disclosure is welcome news for the state's roughly 300 shellfish farmers,
also known as aquaculturists. They learned last week that they would not be
eligible for Small Business Assistance loans available to most of the state's
1,700-plus shellfishermen.

The local shellfish industry has been struggling since a red tide algae bloom
that shut down most of the state's shellfish areas hit in May. The algae can
render shellfish, such as clams and oysters, unsafe to eat.

Shellfishermen had hoped that the Federal Emergency Management Agency would open
the door to unemployment checks. However, FEMA denied that request last week,
leaving the shellfishermen to turn to low-interest loans for help. A spokesman
for Gov. Mitt Romney said last week that the state will appeal the FEMA
decision.

Meanwhile, the offices of U.S. Sens. John F. Kerry and Edward M. Kennedy
yesterday touted the passage in the U.S. Senate of a bill that the two
Massachusetts Democrats co-sponsored that would, if it becomes law, give
shellfish farmers access to SBA loans. For now, they can at least look to the
USDA for similar loans. The farming assistance that was disclosed yesterday will
give shellfish growers access to loans with interest rates of 3.75 percent for
up to 7 years, said Carrie Novak, farm loan chief at the Farm Service Agency's
Amherst office. Shellfish farmers can borrow up to $500,000, depending on their
losses.

"This is terrific news," U.S. Rep. William D. Delahunt, a Quincy Democrat, said
in a press release. "With a little more help from Mother Nature, and continued
pressure for a FEMA disaster declaration, let's hope to get through this crisis
without too much more hardship."

State Sen. Robert Hedlund, a Weymouth Republican, said he would like to support
some state assistance for the industry. Possible funding sources include two
supplemental budget bills that could come before the Legislature after the
fiscal year ends on Thursday.

"I'm not looking necessarily at handouts," Hedlund said. "But I want to see us
be in a position to keep that industry viable."

Shellfish growers in southeastern Massachusetts can find out more information or
apply for the low interest loans at the USDA service center in West Wareham. Jon
Chesto may be reached at jchesto@ledger.com.

                       The Oklahoman (Oklahoma City, OK)

                           September 8, 2007 Saturday
                                  City Edition

Capitol: USDA grants governor's request for funds, while money from 'big
tobacco' and state coffers goes to help Oklahoman's health;
Farmers can ask for federal loans

BYLINE: Michael McNutt, Capitol Bureau

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 10A

LENGTH: 431 words


Oklahoma's farmers and ranchers who had to deal this year with high winds,
tornadoes, ice storms, floods and late freezes are eligible for low-interest
emergency loans from the federal government.

It's the second time in as many years agriculture producers in each of the
state's 77 counties may apply for the disaster loans.

U.S. Agriculture Secretary Mike Johanns on Friday declared 75 counties to be
disaster areas, making farmers and ranchers eligible for U.S. Agriculture
Department assistance.

The two counties not included in the disaster declaration - Pontotoc and
Pushmataha - are considered contiguous counties. Farmers and ranchers in those
counties also are eligible for federal low-interest emergency loans.

"This designation will not solve every problem that confronts Oklahoma farmers
and ranchers, but it is a step in the right direction," said Gov. Brad Henry.

"Oklahoma has seen some remarkable weather this year, and that has taken a toll
on Oklahoma's individual agricultural producers and an industry that is vital to
our state."

Unusual to repeat  Last year, Johanns approved a natural disaster designation
for all 77 Oklahoma counties because of drought, extreme heat and high winds in
2005 and 2006.

The back-to-back statewide disaster declarations are unusual, said Rod Wanger,
program specialist for the U.S. Agriculture Department's Farm Service Agency in
Stillwater.

"You usually don't have a disaster that affects the whole state," he said.
"Unfortunately drought did last year, and unfortunately this year everybody was
affected by freeze or all the perils we put in that (disaster request). We kind
of gathered up all the perils that happened in the state at that time, and by
the time we gathered all those up it pretty well had affected the whole state."

Disaster assistance  Friday's action is in response to a letter sent July 11
from Henry seeking assistance because of the various extreme weather conditions
since Jan. 1.

The request was made about a month before the remnants of Tropical Storm Erin
dumped as much as 10 inches in some parts of the state, resulting in flooding in
several cities and towns.

The federal disaster declaration will include damage caused by those floods and
heavy rains as well as severe weather that still may develop, Wanger said. The
declaration makes farmers and ranchers eligible for low-interest loans "and
that's about it," he said.

The emergency loans are capped at $500,000 per producer and have an interest
rate of 3.75 percent, said Phil Estes, farm loan program chief for the Farm
Service Agency in Stillwater.

ENERGY;
Repairs set for Texas power station

BYLINE: Staff Reports

SECTION: BUSINESS; OKLAHOMA BRIEFS; Pg. 4B

LENGTH: 397 words


American Electric Power Co. Inc. said Monday it will shut its 690-megawatt
Oklaunion coal fired power station in Texas on Friday to repair the main boiler
feed pump.

The power plant is operated by AEP's Tulsa-based subsidiary Public Service Co.
of Oklahoma and supplies electricity to PSO and the Oklahoma Municipal Power
Authority, as well as three Texas utilities.

The plant is expected to remain closed until Feb. 8.

Restaurant operators sued for closing shop

Noodles Development LP, the Arizona franchisor of Nothing But Noodles, has filed
a lawsuit against Oklahoma's B&B Foods Inc., operator of the Nothing But Noodles
location at 2410 W Memorial Road and the former location at 208 Johnny Bench
Drive in Bricktown.

Noodles Development contends B&B is in breach of a franchise agreement because
the Oklahoma company closed its Bricktown franchise without permission from the
franchisor.

The lawsuit states B&B entered a 10-year franchise agreement with Noodles
Development to open two Nothing But Noodles locations and pay the franchisor a
continuing royalty fee of 6 percent and advertising fees for the term of the
agreement.

B&B Foods Inc., owned by Nic and Brandon Bittle, closed the Bricktown location
at the beginning of the year.

The company plans to turn the location into a Mexican restaurant, Rio Del Fuego
Mexican Grill, scheduled to open in February.

Nomination deadline nears for state award

The Oklahoma Department of Agriculture is accepting nominations for the
Governor's Outstanding Achievement Award in Agriculture.

The person selected will become the 2006 inductee into the Oklahoma Agriculture
Hall of Fame.

Anyone who derives the bulk of income from agriculture or who retired from an
agriculture enterprise is eligible.

Nomination deadline is March 15.

For more information or for a nomination form, visit www.oda.state.ok.us.

Emergency loans available for farmers

Oklahoma farmers affected by the recent wildfires may be able to apply for
emergency loan assistance from the Farm Service Agency.

Farm operators in Canadian, Cotton, Garvin, Hughes, Lincoln, Logan, Mayes,
Okfuskee, Oklahoma, Pottawatomie, Seminole and Stephens counties are also
eligible for low-interest emergency loans.

Emergency loan funds can be used for repairs or to purchase seed, fertilizer and
fuel.

For more information, contact your local Farm Service Agency at
www.fsa.usda.gov.

                             Northern Daily Leader

                              July 4, 2014 Friday

Minister for Primary Industries and assistant Minister

SECTION: OTHER TOWNS; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 594 words


Minister for Primary Industries and assistant Minister for Tourism and Major
Events Katrina Hodgkinson writes with an update on the NSW government's
commitment to helping drought-affected farmers.

There is no question the farming communities of rural and regional NSW are
resilient and stoic in the face of adverse conditions be they seasonal or market
driven.

However, the devastating seasonal conditions of the past two years have
stretched that resilience and stoicism to its limits in some regions.

I have visited much of drought-stricken NSW, including some parts where farmers
are experiencing the longest period of rainfall deficiency on record.

The NSW Liberal and National government has allocated more than $30 million to
temporary emergency assistance measures since November, 2013, to support our
drought-affected primary producers and regional communities.

For the first time, these emergency assistance measures included a waiver of
Local Land Services rates, from January 1, 2014 to June 30, 2014.

Unfortunately, due to the increased demand on the emergency drought support
package, this waiver was reduced from 12 months to six months, to ensure more
targeted relief measures could be delivered to those farmers in greatest need.

Another issue we faced was that a number of primary producers outlaid capital to
install crucial water infrastructure, but did not lodge an application prior to
the popular $21 million Emergency Water Infrastructure Rebate becoming fully
subscribed.

To address this problem, the NSW government has committed further money to fund
its contribution to the program for all applications received prior to today,
for work completed on or before June 30, 2014.

On July 1 this year the new national drought program commenced, which sees the
NSW government's role shift towards helping primary producers prepare for
drought and administering a number of Commonwealth government assistance
measures.

The NSW government's temporary emergency assistance measures concluded on June
30, ahead of the commencement of the new national drought program.

Looking to the future, we have allocated more funding to the Rural Support
Worker program and the Farm Innovation Fund, which provides primary producers
with long-term loans at concessional interest rates for on-farm drought
preparedness activities.

The NSW Liberal and National government has boosted staff numbers at the Rural
Assistance Authority (RAA), to ensure timely administration of the large amount
of applications received for emergency assistance measures.

The RAA and Local Land Services administer a number of Australian government
programs, including the $100 million Drought Concessional Loans Scheme, the Farm
Finance Concessional Loans Scheme and pest management programs.

The NSW Department of Primary Industries continually invests in, and
facilitates, the latest research and development into programs which support
drought preparedness, like drought- tolerant cereal and pasture varieties.

The NSW government also produces the monthly Seasonal Conditions Report a
valuable resource to assist primary producers to manage seasonal conditions.

I recognise that these measures only go so far in helping those primary
producers deal with drought, which is insidious in nature and has an ability to
pervade almost all aspects of life in our rural and regional communities.

The NSW government has established the independent and expert Regional
Assistance Advisory Committee, which will continue to provide ongoing advice and
recommendations on seasonal conditions and support programs.

                              The Washington Post

                              June 2, 2002 Sunday
                                 Final Edition

Disaster Relief Small Help to Farmers;
Stricken by Tornado, Struggling With Debt, Some Can't Afford New Loans

BYLINE: Michael Amon, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: METRO; Pg. C05

LENGTH: 1064 words


When a federal disaster area was declared after a tornado devastated much of
Southern Maryland, George Abell's spirits rose. The April 28 twister caused
about $ 250,000 in damage to his farm in western Charles County, and he would
need cash to rebuild.

But lately, reality has sunk in. Instead of providing the direct cash grants
that some homeowners have received, federal agencies could offer Abell and other
farmers only low-interest loans. And while most aid being offered to all
categories of property owners is in the form of loans, taking on new debt can
present special problems for farmers.

"That was a big disappointment," Abell, 54, said. "Paying it back, even at low
interest, is hard to do in the farming industry today."

Many Southern Maryland farmers feel left out of the federal assistance packages
that have flooded the region since the tornado blew through, causing five
deaths, destroying downtown La Plata and causing more than $ 120 million in
damage in Charles and Calvert counties and in Dorchester County on the Eastern
Shore.

For some, federal government aid has been adequate. The Federal Emergency
Management Agency has doled out $ 150,000 in grants to homeowners and renters.
The U.S. Department of Labor on Thursday authorized a grant of $ 2.2 million for
workers whose jobs were lost in the rubble of flattened businesses. FEMA has
given Charles County a $ 100,000 grant to help victims sort through mental
health issues, and the counties will be reimbursed for responding to the
twister.

But for farmers, promises of government help have largely not materialized.

No one has applied for the emergency low-interest loans offered through the U.S.
Department of Agriculture, though they have been available for a month.

Most farmers already have enough loan payments for equipment -- such as
combines, which can cost hundreds of thousands of dollars -- and buildings,
agriculture officials say. And many farmers are too old to want more debt. The
average Maryland farmer is older than 55, according to the Maryland Department
of Agriculture.

The debt "would be on top of what they already owe," said Pat Wathen, president
of the Charles County Farm Bureau, a private nonprofit advocacy group for
farmers. "And a lot of them wouldn't live long enough to pay it off."

Some federal cash assistance is available. On Thursday, USDA authorized $
180,000 in cost-share grants to help farmers clear debris and rebuild fences.
Charles County's division of the Farm Service Agency had requested $ 600,000.

But many farmers have already removed and burned most of their debris on their
own or with the help of volunteers. And the grant money cannot be used to
rebuild barns or sheds or buy new equipment.

In addition, the USDA money is only partial reimbursement. Farmers say they
cannot afford to pay substantial sums up front for debris removal and fences.

"I wish there was some sort of magic wand to wave to make things better," said
Steve Connelly, executive director of USDA's Maryland Farm Service Agency.
"We're limited in what's available."

Among farmers' compounding worries is insurance money, which has been slow in
coming. Some are still waiting for estimates. Others who took the state tobacco
buyout two years ago and agreed to stop growing the crop had reduced or
terminated the insurance on their tobacco barns, though they still used the
barns to store equipment or crops.

Maryland and county officials say they are trying to fill in with funding where
the federal assistance falls short.

One member of a Maryland task force appointed to help determine how $ 3.1
million in state tornado aid will be distributed has visited every farm damaged.
Tomorrow night in Hughesville, Maryland Agriculture Secretary Hagner R. Mister
-- himself a Calvert County farmer -- and other state and county officials will
talk to farmers about state money.

"This is a very high priority," said Mister, who knows several of the farmers
whose farms were damaged.

But some farmers are weary of officials talking about help. Carl and Olga
Walter, whose picturesque Hughesville farm lost 13 barns, seven grain bins,
three equipment sheds, a house and a trailer, have spoken to several officials
about their losses.

State officials and delegates have dropped by the Walter farm, which is run by
their nephew Steven Walter. Charles County commissioners have made phone calls
to state agencies on their behalf. U.S. Rep. Steny H. Hoyer (D-Md.) held Olga
Walter in his arms as she cried in front of television cameras.

But for all the attention paid to the Walters, no one has been able to deliver
the cash assistance they say they need to rebuild. They are both in their
mid-seventies and do not want loans.

"We've talked to a lot of people, but every time we go to get some actual help,
they say no," Olga Walter said.

Sitting on hilly lowland east of Hughesville, the farm where the Walter family
has lived for four generations over more than 80 years is the epitome of old
Southern Maryland. Tobacco was once grown on the Walters' 500 acres and taken to
the auction house in Hughesville.

Two years ago, the Walters took the Maryland tobacco buyout and now grow wheat
and tomatoes instead. The tornado helped usher out other vestiges of the past,
knocking down all the old tobacco barns.

The twister lifted grain bins off their foundations; the mangled metal of the
remains is strewn throughout a nearby woods. In a cruel reminder of a tornado's
caprice, a nearby queue of broken-down cars and a pile of junk next to them were
untouched.

The twister damaged hundreds of the Walters' irrigation pipes, which cost $ 150
each. It also uprooted countless trees, a serious blow for many farmers with
forestland because many logging companies will not pay premium prices for
damaged wood.

"That would be a source of revenue for them. That would probably be a part of
many farmers' retirement," Wathen said.

The Walters have started rebuilding as much as they can without government help.
Amish men from St. Mary's County gave free labor to help them build a hay shed,
but materials cost $ 15,000.

They and their nephew have started asking contractors about building new grain
bins, which cost $ 22,000 each. But they are waiting to see whether any disaster
aid becomes available.

"Things need to be decided," Steve Walter said. "We're just waiting."

USDA Designates Niobrara County as Primary Natural Disaster Area

BYLINE: Weston County Gazette staff

LENGTH: 473  words


The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) has designated Niobrara County in
Wyoming as a primary natural disaster area due to damages and losses caused by
severe flooding and hail that occurred on June 3, 2015, and continues.

"Our hearts go out to those Wyoming farmers and ranchers affected by recent
natural disasters," said Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack. "President Obama and
I are committed to ensuring that agriculture remains a bright spot in our
nation's economy by sustaining the successes of America's farmers, ranchers, and
rural communities through these difficult times. We're also telling Wyoming
producers that USDA stands with you and your communities when severe weather and
natural disasters threaten to disrupt your livelihood."

Farmers and ranchers in Converse, Goshen, Platte and Weston counties in Wyoming
also qualify for natural disaster assistance because their counties are
contiguous.

Farmers and ranchers in the following counties in Nebraska and South Dakota also
qualify for natural disaster assistance because their counties are contiguous.
Those counties are: Sioux County in Nebraska, Custer and Fall River Counties in
South Dakota.

All counties listed above were designated natural disaster areas on June 24,
2015, making all qualified farm operators in the designated areas eligible for
low interest emergency (EM) loans from USDA's Farm Service Agency (FSA),
provided eligibility requirements are met. Farmers in eligible counties have
eight months from the date of the declaration to apply for loans to help cover
part of their actual losses. FSA will consider each loan application on its own
merits, taking into account the extent of losses, security available and
repayment ability. FSA has a variety of programs, in addition to the EM loan
program, to help eligible farmers recover from adversity.

Additional programs available to assist farmers and ranchers include the
Emergency Conservation Program, The Livestock Forage Disaster Program, the
Livestock Indemnity Program, the Emergency Assistance for Livestock, Honeybees,
and Farm-Raised Fish Program, and the Tree Assistance Program. Interested
farmers may contact their local USDA Service Centers for further information on
eligibility requirements and application procedures for these and other
programs. Additional information is also available online at http://disaster.
fsa.usda.gov.

FSA news releases are available on FSA's website at www.fsa.usda.gov via the
"Newsroom" link. USDA is an equal opportunity provider and employer. To file a
complaint of discrimination, write: USDA, Office of the Assistant Secretary for
Civil Rights, Office of Adjudication, 1400 Independence Ave., SW, Washington, DC
20250-9410 or call (866) 632-9992 (Toll-free Customer Service), (800) 877-8339
(Local or Federal relay), (866) 377-8642 (Relay voice users).

Agriculture Briefs

BYLINE: Telegraph Herald Staff

SECTION: Pg. d4

LENGTH: 354 words


Farmers can apply for emergency loans

Emergency loans are available to farmers in three Wisconsin counties and 13 Iowa
counties that might have suffered significant damage because of severe storms
that occurred in early April.

Eligible Iowa counties include Dubuque, Clayton and Jackson counties. The
Wisconsin counties eligible for emergency loans are Crawford, Grant and Vernon.

Emergency loans, at an interest rate of 3.75 percent, may be made to any family
farmer with qualifying losses in the affected counties. Approval is limited to
applicants who suffered severe physical losses caused by storms that occurred on
April 8, and who are unable to obtain credit elsewhere.

Loan applications will be accepted through Jan. 2. Interested farmers in the
designated counties should contact Farm Service Agency personnel at their local
USDA Service Center for more information and application forms.

Dairy breakfast planned

LANCASTER, Wis. - The Grant County Dairy Breakfast will be June 10 at the Grant
County Fairgrounds.

An all-you-can-eat breakfast featuring pancakes and ham and a host of dairy
items will be served from 7 a.m. until noon.

Tickets are $$ @3 for adults, $$ @1 for children age 6 to 12, and children
younger than 6 are admitted free.

Sky divers are scheduled at 9 and 11 a.m. There also will be a petting zoo, 4-H
Club singing demonstrations, machinery and antique machinery display, fire
department and rescue squad display, and free child safety seat inspections.

The WGLR Farm Family of the Year will be presented. The breakfast will feature
the John Schurman Memorial Cheese Challenge Contest and other attractions and
exhibits.

2 receive scholarships

LANCASTER, Wis. - Sheena Allbee and Cari Ehlen, both of Potosi, are the 2001
recipients of Kelly Meier Memorial Scholarships.

The awards recognize 4-H members seeking further education through the 4-H Horse
and Pony Project.

The recipients will use the scholarships toward registration fees at the Dubuque
County Trailblazers 4-H Horse and Pony Camp June 17-23 at the Dubuque County
Fairgrounds.

Seven MN counties designated Primary Natural Disaster areas

BYLINE: The Ortonville Independent staff

LENGTH: 534  words


The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) has designated seven counties in
Minnesota as primary natural disaster areas due to losses caused by the combined
effects of excessive rain, excessive heat, high winds, tornadoes and an early
fall frost that occurred during the period of April 1, 2011, through Sept. 15,
2011. Those counties are: Clay, Meeker, Pope, Yellow Medicine, Le Sueur, Norman
and Waseca.

"Minnesota has experienced multiple disaster conditions this year," said
Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack. "President Obama and I are pleased to
announce that Minnesota producers will soon see some very much needed federal
disaster assistance for its agricultural industry."

Farmers and ranchers in the following Minnesota counties also qualify for
natural disaster assistance because their counties are contiguous. Those
counties are: Becker, Kandiyohi, Otter Tail, Stearns, Blue Earth, Lac Qui Parle,
Polk, Steele, Chippewa, Lincoln, Redwood, Stevens, Douglas, Lyon, Renville,
Swift, Faribault, McLeod, Rice, Wilkin, Freeborn, Mahnomen, Scott, Wrigh, Grant,
Nicollet and Sibley.

Farmers and ranchers in Cass, Richland and Traill counties in North Dakota, and
Deuel County in South Dakota also qualify for natural disaster assistance
because their counties are contiguous.

All counties listed above were designated natural disaster areas Dec. 13, 2011,
making all qualified farm operators in the designated areas eligible for low
interest emergency (EM) loans from USDA's Farm Service Agency (FSA), provided
eligibility requirements are met. Farmers in eligible counties have eight months
from the date of the declaration to apply for loans to help cover part of their
actual losses. FSA will consider each loan application on its own merits, taking
into account the extent of losses, security available and repayment ability. FSA
has a variety of programs, in addition to the EM loan program, to help eligible
farmers recover from adversity.

USDA also has made other programs available to assist farmers and ranchers,
including the Supplemental Revenue Assistance Program (SURE), which was approved
as part of the Food, Conservation, and Energy Act of 2008; the Emergency
Conservation

Program; Federal Crop Insurance; and the Noriinsured Crop Disaster Assistance
Program. Interested farmers may contact their local USDA Service Centers for
further information on eligibility requirements and application procedures for
these and other programs. Additional information is also available online at
http://disaster.fsa.usda.gov.

Secretary Vilsack also reminds producers that the department's authority to
operate the five disaster assistance programs authorized by the 2008 Farm Bill
expired on Sept. 30, 2011. This includes SURE; the Livestock Indemnity Program
(LIP); the Emergency Assistance for Livestock, Honey Bees, and Farm-Raised Fish
(ELAP); the Livestock Forage Disaster Program (LFP); and the Tree Assistance
Program (TAP). Production losses in the counties listed above are covered
because the event triggering the loss occurred prior to the expiration of these
programs; however, production losses due to disasters occurring after Sept. 30,
2011, are not eligible for disaster program coverage.

                                US Official News

                             July 15, 2014 Tuesday

Washington: Farmers and Gardeners: Prepare Now to Weather the Whims of Mother
Nature

LENGTH: 737  words

DATELINE: Washington


Federal Emergency Management Agency has issued the following news release:

New Jersey comes by its nickname, "The Garden State," honestly, as the
agricultural industry brings more than $987 million into the state's economy.
The state is among the top ten producers of cranberries, peaches, spinach, bell
peppers, blueberries, cucumbers, squash and tomatoes in the United States,
according to the New Jersey Farm Service Agency.

Commercial farms and home gardens alike present similar challenges when natural
disasters are a threat. The flat, open land that crops grow in and animals graze
on has few natural defenses against flooding, and any tall buildings on
farmland, such as barns and silos, can be vulnerable to lightning strikes.

While the average home garden doesn't have the same scope of a large farm,
owners of both can use similar methods to protect their crops, livestock and
property from the impact of a natural disaster.

Take a full inventory of everything: livestock, equipment, pesticides,
fertilizers, other chemicals and fuel. Animals should be tagged so they can be
returned if they get lost or hurt during an incident. Have sandbags and plastic
sheeting on hand to cover and protect crops and garden plots in case of
flooding. Use wire and rope to secure objects, and lumber and plywood to protect
windows. Put a fire extinguisher in every building and vehicle on your property.

Choose a safe, flood-proof location to store extra fuel for tractors and
vehicles, food and water for livestock, and a gas-powered generator in case of
power failure. Make sure that electrical power to flood-prone machines and
structures can be easily turned off. Have hand tools accessible to assist in
preparation and recovery.

If you are in a particularly flood-prone area, figure out escape routes for
livestock to get to higher ground. Also, keep them out of barns that may flood,
as their natural instinct is to seek shelter in a barn during an emergency.

In the aftermath of a disaster, report leaks of any hazardous materials
(pesticides, fuel, fertilizer and other chemicals) to authorities. Check your
utilities for signs of damage, and contact your utility company before turning
anything back on. Spray surviving livestock with insect repellent to protect
against mosquitoes, and have all animals checked for infectious diseases such as
pneumonia or foot rot.

Test the soil, especially in smaller gardens and flower beds. It is recommended
that flooded areas not be planted again for at least 30 to 60 days. Before
replanting, make sure the soil is dry and has been reworked. Salt water can get
washed up by waves and storm surge and get into the soil and on plants and
trees, causing leaves to brown and damaging roots and buds. The damage salt
spray can do to plants can last for several years.

Dispose of any leafy green vegetables and any other crops with edible parts that
were touched by flood water. Affected root vegetables can be sanitized for
consumption by rinsing them and soaking them in a bleach/water solution.

Once a disaster happens, the Farm Service Agency offers loans to farm owners to
cover repairs/replacements and working capital. Contact the local Disaster
Recovery Center after an incident for information, or visit a local FSA office.
Farmers can also contact the Department of Agriculture's Extension Service for
more information and materials on how they can protect themselves from
disasters.

The FSA has several financial programs to help farmers in the event of a
disaster.

The Emergency Conservation Program provides emergency funding for farmers and
ranchers to rehabilitate farmland damaged by wind erosion, floods, or other
disasters.

The Emergency Haying and Grazing Assistance Program coordinates emergency hay
placement and grazing of certain Conservation Reserve Program acreage in areas
suffering from weather-related disasters at the discretion of either the state
or national FSA.

The Noninsured Crop Disaster Assistance Program covers non-insurable crop losses
caused by low yields, inventory loss or inability to plant crops due to a
disaster.

The Emergency Loan Assistance Program provides emergency loans to help livestock
producers recover from production and physical losses due to drought, floods,
other natural disasters, or quarantine. Contact your local Farm Service Agency
for more information about these programs.

For further information please visit: http://www.fema.gov/

                                The Denver Post

                        May 31, 2002 Friday 1ST EDITION

Disaster area covers state Farmers in all counties now eligible for federal
loans because of drought

BYLINE: By Mike Soraghan , and Steve Raabe, Denver Post Staff Writers,

SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. A-01

LENGTH: 1112 words


WASHINGTON - Every last parched bit of Colorado real estate  has now officially
been declared a federal agricultural disaster  area because of the worst drought
in decades.

Agriculture Secretary Ann Veneman added 60 Colorado counties  Thursday to the
four already designated. That will make farmers in  all of Colorado's 64
counties eligible for low-interest loans of  up to $ 500,000.

According to the U.S. Farm Service Agency, it's the first  time since 1977 that
all of Colorado has been declared a drought  disaster area.

Colorado's winter wheat crop has been especially hard hit,  with estimates of
losses greater than $ 80 million.

Farm experts view winter wheat as an important early  indicator of drought
impact because the crop is harvested in July,  months before fall-harvest crops.
Colorado is the nation's  fifth-largest producer of winter wheat.

'The wheat crop is in pretty bad shape,' said Wiggins farmer  Joe Westhoff. 'I'm
almost 55 years old, and I can't ever remember  a crop this small.'

Some Colorado farms enjoyed a good rain last week that  salvaged a bit of their
crop. Others received almost no moisture  and have begun plowing under hundreds
of thousands of acres of  wheat.

'Out here, it's dry in a good year,' said Colorado  Agriculture Commissioner Don
Ament. 'When you end up with a lousy  snowpack, it all comes to roost. I'm
telling you flat out there  are going to be some guys who are not going to be in
this business  next year.'

Four counties in eastern Colorado - Kit Carson, Lincoln,  Phillips and Yuma -
were declared drought disaster areas on May 2.  Of the 60 declared Thursday, 44
are 'primary' disaster areas,  while 16 received the designation because they
border primary  disaster counties. Among those are Denver County, which borders
  primary disaster areas in Adams and Jefferson counties.       'Farmers and
ranchers in Colorado are suffering from extreme  drought conditions, and we are
examining every available program  to assist during these difficult times,'
Veneman said. 'This  emergency assistance should provide some relief from these
  devastating losses.'

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has declared disasters in  10 other states,
including all of Arizona, 66 of Texas' 254  counties, seven counties in Kansas,
13 in South Dakota and four in  Idaho.

The interest rate on the disaster loans is 3.75 percent,  which could allow a
farmer who has lost a crop to plant another  one for the summer, said Lewis
Frank, a Logan County farmer and  state director of the Farm Service Agency.

The disaster designation also allow ranchers to avoid large  capital gains tax
payments if they have to sell off all their  cattle.

Officials said they can't predict how many of Colorado's  30,000 farms and
ranches will be eligible for disaster loans  because total financial losses
won't be known for several months.

Wheat farmer Westhoff said drought losses are compounded by  low market prices
for crops.

'We've got a poor crop, and the dang stuff isn't worth  anything, anyway,' he
said.

Westhoff said he's not sure whether he'll apply for loans.

'When farmers are having trouble paying off their existing  loans, do they
really want to assume more debt?' he said.

Ament stressed that although the aid may help struggling  farmers, many farmers
will still decide selling out is better.  Loans must be paid back. Other
emergency programs allow cattle to  graze on land set aside for conservation,
but the land usually  doesn't have fences to keep cattle in or stock ponds for
them to  drink from.

'I'm sensitive to people saying, 'The government's bailed  them out. The
problem's over,'' Ament said. 'If you're sitting out  there with two days of
feed left, and I say you can have some  low-interest loans, but there's a lot of
ifs, you'd look at it and  say, 'Hell with it. I'm going to the sale barn.''

But if Congress were to pass an aid package for  drought-afflicted farmers, the
aid would most likely be directed  to the counties that have been designated.
Drought aid was  stripped out of this year's farm bill before it was passed. But

  the $ 2 billion package was reintroduced as a separate bill in the  Senate.

Gov. Bill Owens had requested the aid, and lawmakers  such as U.S. Sen. Wayne
Allard of Loveland U.S. Rep. Scott McInnis  of Grand Junction pressed Veneman to
grant the aid. McInnis wrote  to the Internal Revenue Service on Thursday asking
the agency to  confirm that farmers in disaster areas who sell off their
livestock don't have to pay capital gains tax.

Veneman also announced Thursday that farmers and ranchers in  an additional 10
Colorado counties will be able to grow crops or  graze cattle on land they'd set
aside for conservation, said Sean  Conway, a spokesman for Allard. But they will
have to pay a fee to  use it.

The 10 new counties, which bring the total for the emergency  grazing program to
26, are Adams, Boulder, Crowley, El Paso,  Lincoln, Logan, Morgan, Otero, Routt
and Washington counties.

The idea, Conway said, is to prevent the massive sell-off of  livestock that has
been occurring in southeastern counties.

'Last week, the governor and I went to a sale barn in La  Junta,' Ament said.
'I'm telling you, you couldn't have squeezed  another critter in there.'

Who qualifies

Emergency loans may be made to farmers and ranchers who:

Own or operate land located in a county declared by the  president or designated
by the secretary of agriculture as a  disaster area. (For physical losses only,
the FSA administrator  may authorize emergency loan assistance.)

Are established family farm operators and have sufficient  farming or ranching
experience.

Are citizens or permanent residents of the United States.

Have suffered at least 30-percent loss in crop production or a  physical loss to
livestock, livestock products or real estate.

Have an acceptable credit history.

Can provide collateral to secure the loan.

Have repayment ability.

Producers can borrow up to 100 percent of actual production or  physical losses,
to a maximum of $ 500,000. Loans for crop,  livestock, and non-real-estate
losses must normally be repaid in  one to seven years. In special circumstances,
terms of up to 20  years may be authorized. Loans for physical losses to real
estate  are normally repaid within 30 years. In certain circumstances,
repayment may be extended to 40 years. The current annual interest  rate for
such loans is 3.75 percent.
