                  Herald-Journal (Spartanburg, South Carolina)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           August 28, 2013 Wednesday

Spartanburg, Cherokee and Union counties declared federal disaster areas due to
heavy rains

BYLINE: Lynne P. Shackleford, Herald-Journal, Spartanburg, S.C.

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 709 words


Aug. 28--Upstate farms devastated by excessive rainfall this year could qualify
for federal low-cost emergency loans to provide some relief.

The U.S. Secretary of Agriculture announced farmers in 36 South Carolina
counties -- including Spartanburg, Cherokee and Union counties -- could qualify
for the emergency loans to help farmers into next season.

Andy Rollins is a Clemson Extension service agent in Spartanburg who specializes
in commercial fruit and vegetables. He said excessive rains have damaged every
crop in almost each local farm he works with. Older farmers don't remember
another season where rains have caused as much damage, Rollins said.

Peaches are the highest valued crop in Spartanburg County and peach farmers face
the greatest financial losses from the rains, Rollins said.

Many peach trees have been lost to the damage, which affects this year's profits
and profits in subsequent years. If a peach tree is lost, it can be replaced,
but it takes three to five years before the tree can bear fruit in order for a
farmer to begin making up for lost profit, Rollins said.

Chesnee peach farmer Geary Jolley agreed with Rollins' assessment.

"The problem with these excessive rains we've had is that it kills the trees and
you lose production for four to five years before you have any peaches from a
new tree," Jolley said.

Investment and labor costs are higher for peach farmers, although farmers who
harvest vegetable and other fruits also suffered damage and financial losses,
Rollins said.

Trees need to breathe and with recurring, heavy rains, trees can't get the air
they need. Rollins said there have been multiple issues with peaches rotting,
but brown rot damage is extensive and affects the entire tree. Another problem
is protection products farmers use on the trees are washed away by heavy rain.

Farmers have reported damage, although the extent varies according to location.

"It's safe to say, though, that this area has already seen twice as much
rainfall already this year than was reported in all of last year," he said.

Jolley, president of Geary Jolley Farms in Chesnee, said this year has been
"tough."

Jolley said any assistance the federal government provides can help some
farmers, but a stipulation of past emergency loans has been for the farmer to
exhaust all other financial assistance options.

"Most farmers are in debt of some kind, but unless you're up to your eyeballs in
debt, these type of loans aren't all that useful," Jolley said. "If you can
borrow money somewhere else, they want you to do that first."

Rollins said farmers of vegetables and fruits such as strawberries and
blackberries also have had a hard time this season. Local strawberry farmers
reported a fourth to half of their normal crop was lost. A Pickens strawberry
farmer had his entire crop wiped out, Rollins said.

"It messed up the strawberries pretty badly and it ended the blackberry season
sooner," Rollins said. "There are still some good crops out there and not every
farmer suffered really extensive damage, but it's been a trying time for them."

Billy Ledford, who co-owns Beechwood Farms with his sister in northern
Greenville County, sells vegetables such as sweet corn, squash, tomatoes, okra
and strawberries at his roadside market and on Saturdays at the Hub City Farmers
Market in Spartanburg.

Ledford said about five to seven acres on his farm have been flooded.

"It's sadly discouraging when you have rain like we've had rain this year,"
Ledford said.

Ledford is hopeful the low-interest loans could help pay for fertilizer and seed
from this year's crop and help with operating costs for next year.

"If you have a four to six percent loan and can possibly take it down to a 1.25
percent loan, that's worth looking into," Ledford said. "It's not all bad news
this way, but any help is better than no help."

Rollins said that despite the rainfall, peach farmers are confident the last
three weeks of the season will yield good peaches.

"The tail end of the season looks real promising so I would urge people to keep
buying produce and to buy local," Rollins said.

                           Bangor Daily News (Maine)

                             March 19, 2004 Friday
                                  All Editions

4 Maine counties approved for;
Disaster-area loans

SECTION: Pg. B7

LENGTH: 194 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


The U.S. Department of Agriculture has approved four Maine counties to be
declared primary natural disaster areas, making farmers in Aroostook, Franklin,
Oxford and Penobscot counties eligible for low-interest emergency loans from the
Farm Service Agency.

The disaster declaration is based on submitted damage assessment reports
provided by each county detailing the excessive rain that occurred in the summer
and fall of 2003, which contributed to losses in agricultural products within
the regions.

Additionally, the following Maine counties were declared contiguous disaster
areas, making them also eligible to be considered for the low-interest emergency
loans from FSA: Androscoggin, Cumberland, Hancock, Kennebec, Piscataquis,
Somerset, Waldo, Washington and York counties.

"The excessive rain season and detrimental winter experienced in 2003 devastated
the viability of the agricultural products that farm operators rely on for their
livelihood," said U.S. Sen. Olympia Snowe in announcing the declaration. "The
financial assistance these low-interest loans provide serves as a vital tool for
preventing further economic hardship caused by unpredictable weather."

USDA Designates 4 Counties in Arizona as Primary Natural Disaster Areas with
Assistance to Producers in New Mexico

LENGTH: 495  words

DATELINE: New York



 Phoenix: Department of Agriculture, The State of Arizona has issued the
following news release:



 The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) has designated Cochise, Graham, Pima,
and Santa Cruz counties in Arizona as primary natural disaster areas due to
damages and losses caused by a recent drought.





 "Our hearts go out to those Arizona farmers and ranchers affected by recent
natural disasters," said Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack. "President Obama and
I are committed to ensuring that agriculture remains a bright spot in our
nation's economy by sustaining the successes of America's farmers, ranchers, and
rural communities through these difficult times. We're also telling Arizona
producers that USDA stands with you and your communities when severe weather and
natural disasters threaten to disrupt your livelihood."



 Farmers and ranchers in Apache, Gila, Greenlee, Maricopa, Navajo, Pinal, and
Yuma counties in Arizona also qualify for natural disaster assistance because
their counties are contiguous.



 Farmers and ranchers in Hidalgo County in New Mexico also qualify for natural
disaster assistance because their counties are contiguous.



 All counties listed above were designated natural disaster areas on Aug. 10,
2016, making all qualified farm operators in the designated areas eligible for
low interest emergency (EM) loans from USDA's Farm Service Agency (FSA),
provided eligibility requirements are met. Farmers in eligible counties have
eight months from the date of the declaration to apply for loans to help cover
part of their actual losses. FSA will consider each loan application on its own
merits, taking into account the extent of losses, security available and
repayment ability. FSA has a variety of programs, in addition to the EM loan
program, to help eligible farmers recover from adversity.



 Other FSA programs that can provide assistance, but do not require a disaster
declaration, include the Emergency Conservation Program; Livestock Forage
Disaster Program; Livestock Indemnity Program; Emergency Assistance for
Livestock, Honeybees, and Farm-Raised Fish Program; and the Tree Assistance
Program. Interested farmers may contact their local USDA Service Centers for
further information on eligibility requirements and application procedures for
these and other programs. Additional information is also available online at
http://disaster.fsa.usda.gov.



 FSA news releases are available on FSA's website at www.fsa.usda.gov via the
"Newsroom" link.

                            The Blade (Toledo, Ohio)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             July 26, 2012 Thursday

Kasich seeks federal aid for Ohio farmers

BYLINE: Jim Provance, The Blade, Toledo, Ohio

SECTION: FOOD NEWS

LENGTH: 1069 words


July 26--COLUMBUS -- Immersed in Ohio's annual celebration of all things
agriculture, Gov. John Kasich on Wednesday urged the federal government to
declare an emergency for drought-stricken farmers to make them eligible for
low-interest loans and other help.

He also ordered the state to make highway rights-of-way available for
neighboring farmers to cut hay for livestock feed, if that can be done safely.

"There are a number of things that we can do in this state that are all related
to this," Mr. Kasich said after getting a tour on the opening day of the Ohio
State Fair.

"There's going to be a lot of loss, and it's tragic," he said. "These farmers
scrape by, sometimes year to year, and this year could knock them out. That's
the problem."

So far, just five Ohio counties, all in the northwest, are deemed to be in a
drought emergency by the U.S. Department of Agriculture. But Fulton, Williams,
Defiance, Paulding, and Van Wert have that designation because they abut
counties in Michigan or Indiana that have been formally declared. That could
also make farmers in those counties eligible for low-interest loans.

"We've got another 83 counties in the state that have been pretty hard-hit, but
do not yet qualify to seek that assistance," said Erica Pitchford, spokesman for
the Ohio Department of Agriculture.

The chief form of assistance that would be available, low-interest federal
loans, recently saw the annual interest rate slashed from 3.75 percent to 2.25
percent. In prior years, farmers in designated counties might have been eligible
for cash assistance from the federal government to help compensate for crop
losses not covered by insurance, but that help expired with the last federal
farm bill in 2011. Congress has yet to pass a successor.

The loan fund is fueled by Congress, but the loan repayments flow directly back
into the U.S. Treasury so it is designed not to add to the federal budget
deficit, the size of which has been often criticized by the Republican governor.

"These are loans," said Kasich spokesman Rob Nichols. "The government is repaid
the money."

Three weeks ago, U.S. Secretary of Agriculture Tom Vilsack moved to streamline
the emergency declaration process, which typically would involve multiple
government agencies in determining whether a county qualified.

Mr. Kasich also urged the federal government to temporarily defer payments on
prior federal loans and to waive restrictions on the cutting of hay for
livestock from acreage owned by farmers that has been set aside for
conservation. The federal government has already expressed a willingness to do
the latter.

"We're down that path now, but I can see why the governor wanted to make sure we
did not leave any stone unturned," said Steve Mauer, Ohio director for the
federal Farm Service Agency. "What the secretary did the other day with the
conservation preserve program is to open the land for haying and grazing in the
state. He simplified the process, and the governor, I think, is asking us to
keep doing that kind of stuff. We're doing everything we can."

The Ohio Department of Agriculture will be required under Mr. Kasich's order to
educate farmers on ways they can mitigate drought damage and to hold a series of
regional hearings to discuss forage management, water availability, heat stress,
and mitigation.

Defiance County farmer Leo Shininger said federal assistance might help some
farmers, but what the region really needs is something no agency can give them
-- more rain.

Though he said some farmers may be helped by low-interest federal loans, he
worries others might use the assistance to expand their farms instead.

"It's a fine line when you're helping people, what they do with the money," Mr.
Shininger said. "Are they going to pay the bills with it, or are they going to
buy some new ground?"

Mr. Shininger, who also is a member of the Defiance County Board of Trustees for
the Ohio Farm Bureau, estimated that about 80 percent of the county's corn acres
were insured, but only about half of farmers had insurance. Generally, farmers
with smaller operations are less likely to get insurance, he said.

"The guys that have crop insurance will be fine. The guys that don't have
insurance, well, they made a mistake. What do you do with people that made a
mistake? There's some people who had been [buying insurance] for years and
decided this year they won't have it. It's a bad year to decide that," he said.

In spite of this year's drought, Mr. Shininger said the last few years have been
very good ones for him and many other area crop farmers, and he is already
looking toward future crops.

"A long time ago I just wrote off the year, and I sleep better at night," he
said. "You think about next year. You think about survival next year."

David Daniels, Ohio agricultural director, said the state hasn't seen an
agricultural drought like this since 1988. While Toledo's rainfall for 2012 was
just 2.18 inches below normal as of Wednesday afternoon, some areas' rainfall
has fallen nine inches short this year.

But while topsoil conditions are dry, he stressed that water tables have not
fallen enough that a drought-emergency declaration for the general public is
necessary.

"A lot of people have not lived through this type of a dry spell before, so one
of the things we want to do is bring together all of our partners so that we can
put together some informational meetings about where you can find hay, how you
go about culling your herd if you need to, that sort of thing," Mr. Daniels
said.

Unlike a disaster declaration, there is no state equivalent of a federal
agricultural drought emergency that would free up state money.

The drought comes as the state continues to work to recover from the recession.
Mr. Kasich said his administration has not tried to quantify what impact a
drought affecting the state's $105 billion food and agricultural industry could
have on the state's broader economy.

"Clearly, with agriculture being important, it's going to have an impact," he
said. "You're going to have higher prices, which will impact consumers, whether
it's dairy, whether it's beef.... But in terms of a macro impact, we haven't
made an estimate."

Staff writer Tyrel Linkhorn contributed to this report.

Contact Jim Provance at: jprovance@theblade.com or 614-221-0496.

                                 The Area News

                              July 7, 2014 Monday

Minister for Primary Industries Katrina Hodgkinson

SECTION: EDITOP; Pg. 7

LENGTH: 633 words


Minister for Primary Industries Katrina Hodgkinson is concerned about
drought-stricken farmers.

There is no question the farming communities of rural and regional NSW are
resilient and stoic in the face of adverse conditions be they seasonal or market
driven.

However, the devastating seasonal conditions of the last two years have
stretched that resilience and stoicism to its limits in some regions.

I have visited much of drought-stricken NSW, including some parts where farmers
are experiencing the longest period of rainfall deficiency on record.

The NSW Liberals and Nationals government has allocated more than $30 million to
temporary emergency assistance measures since November 2013, to support our
drought-affected primary producers and regional communities.

For the first time, these emergency assistance measures included a waiver of
Local Land Services rates, from January 1, 2014 to June 30, 2014.

Unfortunately, due to the increased demand on the emergency drought support
package, this waiver was reduced from 12 months to six months, to ensure more
targeted relief measures could be delivered to those farmers in greatest need.

Another issue we faced was that a number of primary producers outlaid capital to
install crucial water infrastructure, but did not lodge an application prior to
the popular $21 million Emergency Water Infrastructure Rebate becoming fully
subscribed.

To address this problem, the NSW government has committed further money to fund
its contribution to the program for all applications received prior to July 4,
2014, for work completed on or before June 30, 2014.

On July 1 this year the new national drought program commenced, which sees the
NSW Government's role shift towards helping primary producers prepare for
drought and administering a number of assistance measures.

For information on NSW Government support, and advice on how to best manage
seasonal conditions, visit the Local Land Services, www.lls.nsw.gov.au; the RAA,
www.raa.nsw. gov.au; and the DPI, www.dpi.nsw.gov.au/agriculture/emergency
/drought.

The NSW Government's temporary emergency assistance measures concluded on 30
June 2014, ahead of the commencement of the new national drought program.

Looking to the future, we have allocated more funding to the Rural Support
Worker program and the Farm Innovation Fund, which provides primary producers
with long-term loans at concessional interest rates for on-farm drought
preparedness activities.

The NSW Liberals & Nationals Government has boosted staff numbers at the Rural
Assistance Authority (RAA), to ensure timely administration of the large amount
of applications received for emergency assistance measures.

The RAA and Local Land Services administer a number of Australian Government
programs, including the $100 million Drought Concessional Loans Scheme, the Farm

Finance Concessional Loans Scheme and pest management programs.

The NSW Department of Primary Industries (DPI) continually invests in and
facilitates the latest research and development into programs which support
drought preparedness, like drought-tolerant cereal and pasture varieties.

The NSW Government also produces the monthly Seasonal Conditions Report - a
valuable resource to assist primary producers to manage seasonal conditions.

I recognise that these measures only go so far in helping those primary
producers deal with drought, which is insidious in nature and has an ability to
pervade almost all aspects of life in our rural and regional communities.

The NSW Government has established the independent and expert Regional
Assistance Advisory Committee, which will continue to provide ongoing advice and
recommendations on seasonal conditions and support programs.

Katrina Hodgkinson MP

Minister for Primary Industries

Assistant Minister for Tourism and Major Events

                         Cleburne Times-Review (Texas)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           January 18, 2012 Wednesday

More aid rolls in for Johnson County farmers

BYLINE: John Harden, Cleburne Times-Review, Texas

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 464 words


Jan. 18--The federal government announced it is making low-interest loans
available to help farmers with agricultural recovery efforts in Johnson County
and several other Texas counties.

On Jan. 3, the U.S. Department of Agriculture named Johnson County and 39 other
Texas counties as primary disaster areas because of the drought and related
factors, such as last year's devastating wildfires.

People who live in those counties may be eligible for low-interest emergency
loans of up to $500,000 from the USDA's Farm Service Agency.

Other counties include Austin, Bell, Bosque, Brazoria, Burnet, Cochran, Fort
Bend, Freestone, Garza, Hockley, Jack, Lee, Limestone, Lubbock, Lynn, McLennan,
Milam, Nolan, Parker, Robertson, Scurry and Taylor.

People in these counties and 23 others neighboring them in the basin can apply
for loans.

The drought has been hard on countless farmers across Texas. Farmers and
ranchers depend on regular rainfall to sustain their livelihood, HayBarn.com
owner Hank Neal said.

Haybarn.com, a site devoted to helping farmers nationwide find hay during
droughts, is one site seeing an increase in web traffic from desperate Texas
farmers using ads to find hay and other farming assistance.

"I'm continuing to see some really sad emails from farmers who can't afford to
feed their herds," Neal said. "Hopefully this loan will help provide some
relief."

AgriLife Extension Service economists estimate Texas has already lost about $6
billion in revenue caused by the drought.

The loans can be used to replace or restore essential property, pay production
costs from the disaster year, pay essential family living expenses, reorganize
the farming operation and refinance certain debts, according to the USDA.

To be eligible for the loan, farmers and ranchers must be established family
farm operators who suffered at least a 30 percent loss to their crop production
or livestock and have an acceptable credit history, among other factors.

The low-interest loan offer for these counties expires in eight months,
according to the USDA.

"Texas farmers have experienced severe drought conditions over a long period of
time, which has caused major losses to a wide variety of crops such as forage
crops, pasture, corn, oats and wheat," Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack said in
a press release. "[We are] committed to using the resources at our disposal to
reduce the impact of these disasters on Texas producers and help to get those
affected back on their feet."

To learn about the emergency loan requirements or the emergency declaration and
other types of agricultural assistance, visit www.fsa.usda.gov.

              The Times and Democrat (Orangeburg, South Carolina)

                          September 19, 2013 Thursday

Orangeburg County farmers can get loans for June tornado damage

BYLINE: The Times and Democrat, Orangeburg, S.C.

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 381 words


Sept. 19--A June tornado has led the U.S. Department of Agriculture to make
farmers in Orangeburg and four other counties with damage from the storm
eligible for USDA disaster assistance, announced Deborah DeLorme, county
executive director of the Farm Service Agency.

The disaster designation is a result of losses caused by a tornado that occurred
on June 4. The decision makes all qualified farm operators in the designated
areas eligible for low-interest emergency loans from FSA.

The disaster areas were designated on Sept 11. Farmers have eight months from
the date of the declaration to apply for loans to help cover part of their
actual losses.

In addition to Orangeburg, the designated counties are Berkeley, Charleston,
Colleton and Dorchester.

According to T&D reporting of the storm, the National Weather Service stated
that the tornado downed trees and snapped power lines near Interstate 26 in the
Bowman area.

The storm moved along the interstate and its path seemed to cross Ebenezer Road,
Duncan Chapel Road, Landsdown Road, Arista Road and Winter Creek Road.

A chicken house on Arista Road completely collapsed in the storm and others
sustained roof damage.

Downed trees also caused traffic to back up several miles near the Interstate 95
interchange.

The tornado arrived as eastern Orangeburg County was under a severe thunderstorm
warning. The storm eventually moved into Dorchester and Berkeley counties.

FSA states that it will consider each loan application on its own merits, taking
into account the extent of losses, security available and repayment ability. FSA
has a variety of programs, in addition to the emergency loan program, to help
eligible farmers recover from adversity.

USDA has also made other programs available to assist farmers and ranchers,
including the Emergency Conservation Program, Federal Crop Insurance and the
Noninsured Crop Disaster Assistance Program.

Interested farmers may contact USDA Service Centers for further information on
eligibility requirements and application procedures for these and other
programs. Additional information is also available online at:
disaster.fsa.usda.gov.

USDA disaster loans open to state farmers

SECTION: Pg. A5

LENGTH: 351 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


The U.S. Department of Agriculture has designated Aroostook, Hancock, Penobscot,
Piscataquis, and Somerset Counties in Maine as primary natural disaster areas in
three separate disaster designations. The designation means farmers and ranchers
are eligible for low-interest loans.

Aroostook County received a disaster designation for drought that occurred
between Aug. 1 and Sept. 15, 2009. Somerset County received a designation for
heavy rains, flash flooding and high winds that occurred starting June 1, 2009.
Hancock, Penobscot and Piscataquis counties received a designation for heavy
rains and subsequent drought from June 9 through Aug. 30, 2009.

Farmers and ranchers in the following counties in Maine also qualify for natural
disaster assistance because their counties are contiguous: Franklin, Kennebec,
Knox, Waldo, Washington.

All counties listed above were designated natural disaster areas Jan. 4, 2010,
making all qualified farm and ranch operators in the designated areas eligible
for low-interest emergency loans from USDA's Farm Service Agency, provided
eligibility requirements are met.

Farmers in eligible counties have eight months from the date of the declaration
to apply for loans to help cover part of their actual losses. The farm agency
will consider each loan application on its own merits, taking into account the
extent of losses, security available and repayment ability.

The agency has a variety of programs, in addition to the EM loan program, to
help eligible farmers and ranchers recover from adversity.

USDA has also made other programs available to assist farmers and ranchers,
including the Supplemental Revenue Assistance Program, which was approved as
part of the Food, Conservation and Energy Act of 2008; the Emergency
Conservation Program; Federal Crop Insurance; and the Noninsured Crop Disaster
Assistance Program.

Interested producers may contact their local USDA Service Centers for further
information on eligibility requirements and application procedures for these and
other programs. Additional information is also available online at
http://disaster.fsa.usda.gov.

                             National Mortgage News

                                 June 14, 1999

Demand for USDA Loans Climbs Sharply

LENGTH: 234 words

Washington-Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman said that demand for U.S.
Department of Agriculture guaranteed and direct farm loans has increased 65%
this year from last year's level.

Mr. Glickman said natural disasters and a weak agricultural economy have fueled
demand for government-backed farm loans. Many farmers and ranchers are seeking
USDA loans to restructure existing debt.

As a result, the USDA has a backlog of 12,000 applications for direct and
guaranteed farm operating, farm ownership and emergency loans. The funds for all
of these programs are out of money or nearly out, he said.

Mr. Glickman chided Congress for not acting quickly on a request for more
lending authority, saying that for each day that Congress fails to act, 150
farmers are unable to get financing they need to stay in business.

President Clinton requested $ 152 million in emergency supplement funding for
farm credit and staffing needs in February.

"I can't say it more clearly: this is a crisis that deepens with every day of
delay. The time to act is now," he said.

In late May, both the House and the Senate passed a supplemental appropriations
bill that includes additional funding for the USDA's guaranteed loan programs.
The legislation enjoyed support from the American Bankers Association.
Currently, the USDA guarantees credit made to some 48,000 farmers and ranchers.

                                    The Land

                             June 25, 2015 Thursday

Pollies still preparing as drought drags on

BYLINE: MIKE FOLEY

SECTION: EARLY GENERAL NEWS; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 451 words


AS DROUGHT drags on in Far North West NSW, the government continues to fund
preparedness measures for farmers.

Primary Industries Minster Niall Blair announced $63 million would be invested
across five years in drought assistance, with $50m set aside for low- interest
Farm Innovation Fund loans.

A further $9m was allocated to training farmers to better prepare for drought,
which would include the Rural Financial Counsellors service to help them apply
for loans.

Also, $1.25m was committed to building the network of weather stations across
the state for improved weather forecasting.

NSW Farmers president Fiona Simson said funding for practical drought assistance
is needed immediately.

Drought-hit northern NSW was a "disaster situation" with many producers copping
their fourth year in a row with less than average rainfall, she said.

"It is disappointing there is no in-drought support," she said.

"We will continue to talk with government about this issue.

"It is absolutely critical the government stands beside people in North West
NSW.

"These people pay taxes and contribute to the state in good times.

"It is an integral part of the economy."

The Emergency Water Infra-structure Rebate scheme (EWIR) is set to expire on
June 30, but little on-farm assistance was announced to replace it.

However, the budget allocates $1m towards fodder and transport subsidies.

Mr Blair said the government was working with the Common-wealth on its drought
support measures, the Drought Recovery Concessional Loans and Drought
Concessional Loans schemes.

"I am in constant discussions with the Commonwealth government regarding drought
assistance measures, to ensure they continue to be made available to those
farmers most in need," Mr Blair said.

The emergency water scheme provides rebates for water works to de-silt dams and
install emergency on-farm water infrastructure, such as pipelines, bores, tanks
and troughs for farmers experiencing a greater than one-in-50-year drought.

The Land reported last month the scheme was undersubscribed as the end of
financial year 2014-15 approaches, with farmers questioning the funding criteria
set by the federal government, which relies on a weather analysis system that
categorises some North Coast towns in a 50-year drought, but excludes parched
areas of the Far North West ("Rebate scheme fires up farmers", May 28 p5).

Opposition primary industries spokesman Mick Veitch had "real concerns" about
the budget's allocation for drought.

"There's no new funding in the budget for drought and nothing for farmers who
are currently in a drought," he said.

"I want to know how the government is going to make it simpler for farmers who
are in drought to apply for this funding."

MIKE FOLEY

                       Charleston Gazette (West Virginia)

                            August 31, 2007, Friday

USDA designates counties as natural disaster areas

SECTION: METRO EAST; Pg. P3

LENGTH: 205 words


According to the United States Department of Agriculture's Farm Service Agency
in West Virginia, 42 counties in the state have been declared primary natural
disaster areas because of losses caused by continuing drought that began May 15.

Local counties falling under the designation include Kanawha, Putnam, Mason and
Fayette counties.

All counties listed were designated natural disaster areas on Aug. 9, making all
qualified farm operators in the designated areas eligible for EM loans, provided
eligibility requirements are met.

Farmers in eligible counties have eight months from the date of the declaration
to apply for the loans to help cover part of their actual losses.

FSA will consider each loan application on its own merits, taking into account
the extent of losses, security available and repayment ability. FSA has a
variety of programs available, in addition to the emergency loan program, to
help eligible farmers recover from adversity.

USDA has also made other programs available to assist farmers and ranchers,
including the Emergency Conservation Program, Federal Crop Insurance and the
Noninsured Crop Disaster Assistance Program.

Interested farmers can contact their local USDA Service Centers for further
information.

                                August 29, 2012

Disaster declaration to expire March 2013

BYLINE: The Portola Reporter staff

LENGTH: 328  words


Pursuant to the secretary of agriculture's designation of an emergency for 19
California counties July 12, 2012, the counties listed below have been named
eligible for USDA emergency farm loans because of physical and production losses
based on damages and losses caused by drought, which occurred Feb. 21 through
May 14,2012:

Butte, Calaveras, Fresno, Inyo, Kern, Lassen, Madera, Mariposa, Modoc, Mono,
Plumas, Riverside, San Bernardino, Shasta, Sierra, Siskiyou, Tehama, Tulare and
Tuolumne.

In addition, the following contiguous counties are eligible:

California: Alpine, Amador, Colusa, Del Norte, Glenn, Humboldt, Imperial, Kings,
Los Angeles, Mendocino, Merced, Monterey, Nevada, Orange, San Benito, San Diego,
San Joaquin, San Luis Obispo, Santa Barbara, Stanislaus, Sutter, Trinity,
Ventura and Yuba.

Oregon: Jackson, Josephine, Klamath and Lake.

Nevada: Clark, Douglas, Esmeralda, Lyon, Nye and Washoe.

Arizona: La Paz.

Farmers in all counties have eight months to apply for the loans to help cover
part of their actual losses. Some of the eligibility requirements are listed
below:

Have suffered at least a 30 percent loss of normal production directly related
to above-cited cause.

Be able to repay the loan and any other loans.

Be unable to obtain credit elsewhere.

Have adequate security.

Have multi-peril crop insurance, if available.

Meet other eligibility criteria.

All applicants must complete a certification of disaster losses, which reflects
the exact date(s) and nature of the designated disaster and how it caused the
loss or damage. Crop insurance field reports may be a source for documenting
losses directly related to the cited cause.

The authorization for Farm Service Agency (FSA) to accept emergency loan
applications under this authorization expires March 12, 2013. Applications
should be filed with the FSA Service Center at 215 Executive Court, Suite C,
Yreka, CA 96097 or the Shasta County FSA office at 3644 Avtech Parkway, Suite

D, Redding, CA 96002.

                               The New York Times

             September 10, 1986, Wednesday, Late City Final Edition

WASHINGTON TALK: FARMERS HOME ADMINISTRATION;
TRYING TO COLLECT IN HARD TIMES

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section B; Page 6, Column 4; National Desk

LENGTH: 1138 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9


For most of its 51 years, the Farmers Home Administration has existed deep in
the bowels of the Agriculture Department's enormous building near the Washington
Monument, quietly lending farmers down on their luck just enough to stay in
business. In county offices around the country, the agency's supervisors saw as
their primary mission preservation of the small American family farm, even if
some loans went bad and some others were paid off too slowly.

Lately, however, the Reagan Administration has seen things somewhat differently.
The agency's 275,000 farm borrowers now owe the Government $30 billion and the
Administration has been trying to collect by mailing foreclosure notices, hiring
debt collection people, filing civil suits and indicting farmers who have sold
crops or livestock that belonged to the Government.

The effort has been met by resistance in Congress, outrage in the fields and
vituperation in newspapers in the Middle West. Last week, after some outcry, the
Administrator of the agency said that the policy was being reviewed. $64.6
Million Debt Administration officials and other critics contend that the
agency's woes are to a large extent a result of its own extravagant and reckless
loan practices in the late 1970's and 1980's.

In California, for example, Tex-Cal Land Management Inc., a 7,000-acre grape and
almond farm near Delano, was lent $12 million in 1979, was granted several other
huge loans in 1980 and 1981, and now owes the Government $64.6 million. Interest
on the debt is mounting at a rate of $12,790.74 daily.

Vance L. Clark, Administrator of the agency since late last year, is the first
to admit that the agency's ability to manage its loan portfolio ''sometimes left
a lot to be desired.''

Mr. Clark, however, puts part of the onus on Congress, which passed a number of
new programs in the mid-1970's that suddenly put billions of dollars into the
agency's coffers. All over the country, he said, the agency's county supervisors
regularly authorized disaster, emergency and other farm loans of more than $1
million. No lending institution in America had a more liberal policy. Yet, after
five years of decline in agriculture, the agency is now faced with collecting
the debt, a mission that has put Mr. Clark and his agency in a delicate
position.

'We Have Responsibility'

''We're talking about a sacred group in America,'' he said. ''Anytime you do
anything that is perceived to jeopardize their way of life, you better be
prepared to duck a few rocks. But we are owed a lot of money and we have the
responsibility to try and collect it.''

Some authorities on agricultural law, however, contend that the agency's
debt-collecting strategy represents an abrupt shift in policy that may be
illegal. ''Their original statute does not provide them with this kind of
authority without the prior approval of Congress,'' said John Arens, a lawyer in
Fayetteville, Ark,. who specializes in cases involving the agency.

The agency has been sued 55 times since 1981 by farmers saying its loan
-collecting and foreclosure practices were unconstitutional. The agency lost 37
times, including a landmark case in North Dakota two years ago that prompted the
agency to write new foreclosure regulations. Mr. Clark says it now has the
authority to collect its debt without Congressional approval.

Warning Notices Used

Legislators, too, are concerned about stepped-up efforts to pursue delinquent
loans. Last winter Congressmen from both parties criticized a program that
involved mailing 65,000 notices warning farmers who owed a total of $6 billion
that unless they got current on their payments the Government was prepared to
foreclose on their farms.

Today, a group of Senators attacked the program to hire a collection agency to
pursue 6,500 delinquent borrowers who owe $630 million. The Senate Agricultural
Appropriations Subcommittee unanimously approved a measure that would prevent
the Department of Agriculture from using any of its money to employ collection
agencies.

''Farmers Home is doing a very poor job in dealing with this problem,'' said
Senator Thad Cochran, a Republican from Mississippi, who is the subcommittee's
chairman. ''A great deal of insensitivity is being shown. Adopting this
amendment will send a message that I think will result in a change of policy.''

The Farmers Home Administration began life in 1935 as the Resettlement
Administration, which became the Farm Security Administration in 1937, and took
its current name under a new Congressional act in 1946.

Once Before a Target

Only once before, in the years after World War II, when it was accused of aiding
Communism by sponsoring experimental communal farms in several states, has the
lending agency attracted the kind of animosity that is directed at its leaders
now.

Experts date the agency's current problems to the late 1970's, when Congress
approved programs providing farmers with loans to recover from poor weather or
economic emergencies, such as an unexpected crop failure. The agency, which had
prided itself on careful review of the portfolios of farmers most in need, was
suddenly flush. In 1977, the agency lent farmers $2.4 billion. By 1981, it was
lending farmers $8.1 billion.

Agency administrators now acknowledge that the practices became sloppy. Critics
say agency loan decisions were simply unfair. In Maricopa County in Arizona, for
example, it approved a $3.8 million loan to a business executive who was not a
farmer and also approved a $581,000 loan to a person who was serving time in a
Federal prison for bank fraud.

But the supervisor turned down an application for emergency loans submitted by a
profitable farmer, Paul Carroll, whose ranch had been devastated the summer
before by a storm. Mr. Carroll has sued the agency, which does not dispute the
facts in the case. The case will be heard in Phoenix in the fall.

Fears on Collection

In 1982, the emergency loan program under which most of the big loans were made
was discontinued. Nevertheless, thousands of bankrupt farmers have loans of $1
million or more each, and Congressional economists who have studied the books
worry that as much as $12 billion of the $30 billion may never be paid back.

It is those farmers that have become the target for the collection efforts.
''We've got a lot of people out there that are thumbing their noses at us,''
said Mr. Clark. ''These are taxpayer dollars we're talking about, and the
taxpayers expect us to do something about it.''

Still, other authorities point out that the very purpose of the lending agency
has been to provide funds for the most economically pressed farmers.''These are
the poorest of the poor,'' said Senator Tom Harkin, a Democrat of Iowa. ''Trying
to collect from them is like drawing blood from a turnip.''

                 The Yorkville Enquirer (York, South Carolina)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             July 12, 2007 Thursday

Farmers find relief from freeze

BYLINE: Adam Macinnis, Enquirer-Herald, York, S.C.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 683 words


Jul. 12--Arthur Black's family has been growing peaches in York since 1923. In
all those years, he can remember few as poor for business as this year.

A late freeze in April that devastated orchards across the upstate destroyed 100
percent of his peach crop. He's still feeling the effects of that today.

Customers once drawn to buy the fresh tree fruit aren't coming. That, in turn,
affects the sales of other crops such as tomatoes, watermelon and cantaloupe at
his roadside store.

"When you don't have the tree fruit, people don't come here and the rest of the
stuff doesn't sell like it ought to," Black said.

Relief could soon come for farmers like Black.

The United States Department of Agriculture has decided to offer emergency,
low-interest loans to farmers affected by the April freeze, U.S. Rep. John
Spratt, a York native, said in a press release. Some farmers also may be
eligible for direct payments.

"Hopefully this disaster assistance provided by Congress will help lessen the
blow that farmers have experienced this growing season," Spratt said in the
release.

The low-interest emergency loans are available to all eligible farmers in the
5th District. Farmers have eight months from the date of the declaration to
apply for the loans to help them cover part of their losses, according to the
USDA Farm Service Agency in York County. The agency will consider loan
applications individually, taking into account the extent of the losses,
security available and repayment ability.

To be eligible for the direct payments, farmers must have planted or planned to
plant, the crop before Feb. 27, 2007, and have lost 35 percent of their crop.
Only producers with crop insurance or those who signed up for the Non-Insured
Assistance Program are eligible for the direct payment assistance. Payment will
be 50 percent of the established crop insurance price.

Black said he plans to apply for the aid. This kind of support is good for
everybody, even non-farmers, he said.

"What a lot of people don't understand is that the American public is used to
buying cheap food," Black said. "If you don't keep the agricultural sector
afloat then you really hurt the whole nation."

While many farmers have crop insurance, it only does so much, said Andy Rollins,
the upstate fruit and vegetable agent for Clemson Extension Services.

"A lot of people are under the misconception that crop insurance pays for
(farmers') yield and their potential profits, and it never does," he said. "It's
important and we have to have it, but our farms still lose a lot of money. I
don't think most people can fathom the hundreds of thousands of dollars these
farms will lose this year."

Jimmy Bryant of Bryants Peaches in York lost both his peach and plum crops to
the freeze. Like Black, he said business is slower this year.

"Peaches are our main draw," he said, explaining without them the other
vegetable and fruit sales suffer.

Bryant is using his insurance to help cover the loss. He doesn't plan on
applying for a loan or grant.

"I don't see the need of it for me at this point," he said.

Many farmers may be leery of loans.

Rollins said most farmers already depend on loans to operate and the idea of
additional debt doesn't appeal to them.

"There's no farm that's operating on a completely cash basis," he said. "I don't
think the average person understands the amount of stress there is on the
average farm in terms of paying those debts off."

The best way for people to help farmers is to shop at their stands, Rollins
said.

"They're not the prettiest peaches we've had, and we don't have the quantity
we've had in the past," he said. "But we do have some local peaches, and people
need to go buy them."

S.C. Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For reprints, email

BRIEF: Erie disaster designation to aid Crawford, Warren counties

BYLINE: Erie Times-News, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 228 words


Nov. 16--The U.S. Department of Agriculture has designated Erie County as a
natural disaster area due to excessive rain from May 1 through June 28.

That qualifies Crawford and Warren counties for federal natural disaster
assistance, according to U.S. Rep. Glenn Thompson, R-5th Dist.

Producers in both primary and contiguous counties are eligible to be considered
for Farm Service Agency, emergency loans, and the Supplemental Revenue
Assistance Program.

The Supplemental Revenue Assistance Program was approved as part of the Food,
Conservation and Energy Act of 2008, and was implemented on Jan. 4, 2010.

Food, Conservation and Energy Act officials will consider each emergency loan
application by evaluating the extent of losses, security available and repayment
ability.

Applicants in eligible counties have eight months from the date of the
declaration to apply for loans to help cover part of their actual losses. Local
Food, Conservation and Energy Act offices can provide affected individuals with
additional information.

For information, contact the Crawford Farm Service Agency, 14699 N. Main St., in
Meadville, at (814) 336-2127, Ext. 2, or the Warren Farm Service Agency, 265
Holiday Inn Road, in Clarion, at (814) 226-8160.

                               September 2, 2011

County Eligible for Emergency Loans

BYLINE: The Western Star staff

LENGTH: 329  words


The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) has designated four counties in Kansas
as primary natural disaster areas due to losses caused by drought, excessive
heat and high winds that began Jan. 1, 2011, and continue.

While Comanche County is not one of the four named counties, Comacnhe County
farmers also qualify since Comanche is listed as one of the "contiguous
counties."

"Kansas producers can continue to count on USDA to provide emergency assistance
during difficult times, "said Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack.

"America's farmers and rural communities are vitally important to our nation's
economy, producing the food, feed, fiber and fuel that continue to help us grow
and out-compete the rest of the world, the agriculture secretary said.

"President Obama and I are committed to use the resources at our disposal to
reduce the impact of this disaster on Kansas producers and help to get those
affected back on their feet, "he said.

The four counties named are: Kiowa, Marion, McPherson, and Pratt Counties.

Farmers and ranchers in the another 16 contiguous counties in Kansas also
qualify for natural disaster assistance because their counties are contiguous.
They include Comanche, Barber, Ford, Reno, Butler, Dickinson, Harvey, Rice,
Chase, Edwards, Kingman, Saline, Clark, Ellsworth, Morris, and Stafford
Counties.

All counties listed were designated natural disaster areas Aug. 25, making all
qualified farm operators in the designated areas eligible for low interest
emergency (EM) loans from USDA's Farm Service Agency (FSA), provided eligibility
requirements are met.

Farmers in eligible counties have eight months from the date of the declaration
to apply for loans to help cover part of their actual losses.

FSA will consider each loan application on its own merits, taking into account
the extent of losses, security available and repayment ability.

FSA has a variety of programs, in addition to the EM loan program, to help
eligible farmers recover from adversity.

USDA: Drought is a disaster

BYLINE: The Times and Democrat, Orangeburg, S.C.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 280 words


Aug. 19--T&D Region counties are included among those designated as "primary
natural disaster areas" by the U.S. Department of Agriculture because of the
drought and excessive heat that began April 1.

"South Carolina producers can continue to count on USDA to provide emergency
assistance during difficult times," Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack said.

The department named 37 South Carolina counties primary natural disaster areas,
including Allendale, Bamberg, Barnwell, Calhoun, Colleton, Dorchester, Lexington
and Orangeburg counties. Farmers in other counties may also qualify for natural
disaster assistance.

All qualified farm operators in the designated areas are eligible for
low-interest emergency loans from USDA's Farm Service Agency. Farmers in
eligible counties have eight months to apply for loans to help cover part of
their actual losses.

FSA will consider each loan application on its own merits, taking into account
the extent of losses, security available and repayment ability. FSA has a
variety of programs in addition to the loan program to help eligible farmers
recover from adversity.

Interested farmers may contact their local USDA Service Centers for further
information on eligibility requirements and application procedures.

Additional information is also available online at http://disaster.fsa.usda.gov.

                              The Bismarck Tribune

                              May 14, 1999 Friday

LENGTH: 412 words


WASHINGTON (AP) -- Farm state Democrats criticized Republicans on Thursday for
rejecting $5.3 billion in emergency aid for farmers and pledged to continue to
push the issue. Sen. Tom Harkin, D-Iowa, and Sen.

Byron Dorgan, D-N.D., tried to get the money included in a supplemental spending
bill being worked out by budget negotiators. But when put to a vote late
Wednesday night, the farm aid proposal, which started as a $4.3 billion deal but
increased as lawmakers added riders, got a 14-14 tie vote. One Republican, Sen.
Conrad Burns, R-Mont., voted with all the Democrats in favor of the package.
Instead, the committee agreed to $566 million for farmers, which includes money
to replenish the shrinking coffers that supply farm loans. The proposal will
still have to get past both floors of Congress. Democrats say the money isn't
nearly enough, particularly when budget planners agreed to $11.6 billion for the
air assault on Yugoslavia and to boost defense spending. President Clinton had
only requested $6 billion. Congress is telling farmers ""you better get down and
paint your tractors in camouflage,'' said Sen. Dick Durbin, D-Ill. ""What does
it take to get the attention of the Republican leadership around here?'' ""For
them, on defense, the sky is the limit,'' said Dorgan. Republicans said the
agreement helped farmers. ""The Democrats are grandstanding,'' said Sen. Thad
Cochran, R-Miss., chairman of the Agriculture Committee's appropriations panel,
adding that the GOP leaders are open to passing more money later this year if
the administration requests it. ""We gave the administration everything they
asked for and more.'' Selma Sierra, spokeswoman for Rep. Joe Skeen, R-N.M., said
Clinton's request to replenish the farm loan funds was $152 million, so
Republicans increased it fivefold. ""If they think we don't care about farmers,
then Democrats must be heartless,'' Sierra said. Congress last year passed a $6
billion emergency package for farmers as prices plummeted. With low prices
expected to continue much of this year, many lawmakers have pushed for early
emergency funds to ease the pain. The farm money includes the money for loans as
well as $20 million in farmworker aid; $70 million in livestock assistance and
$145 million to help pork producers, who have been suffering from their lowest
prices in 40 years. One more Republican vote ""would have made all the
difference in the world,'' Harkin said. ""We helped everybody but farmers.''

                    The Herald Bulletin (Anderson, Indiana)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             January 4, 2008 Friday

Aid available for drought-stricken Indiana counties

BYLINE: Steve Dick, The Herald Bulletin, Anderson, Ind.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 475 words


Jan. 4--Madison is one of 74 Indiana counties that have been declared primary
disaster areas because of losses caused by extended drought conditions from June
5 to Nov. 7, 2007, according to a press release from the Farm Service Agency of
the U.S. Department of Agriculture.

Farmers in the stricken counties will be eligible for low-interest emergency
loans from the USDA.

The availability and price of hay has been the primary concern, according to
Jane Haste, program technician at the USDA office in Anderson. John Orick,
extension educator at the Madison County Extension Office, agreed.

"The drought has really affected livestock producers," said Orick. "It's slowed
down hay production. Hay is scarce, and prices are higher than normal. People
are going long distances to get hay."

But Orick said counties on the eastern side of Indiana have been particularly
hard hit.

"The yields are just awful in that area for everything," said Orick, "which
would include corn and soybeans."

Farmers in the eligible counties have eight months from the time of the
declaration to apply for loans to help cover part of their actual losses,
according to the press release. Farm Service Agency will consider each loan
application on its own merits, taking into account the extent of losses,
security available and repayment ability.

FSA has a variety of programs, in addition to the loans, to help eligible
farmers recover from adversity, according to the press release.

"It was a really bad drought," said Orick. He said farmers are hoping that the
winter will recharge the soil with moisture. If that happens, the 2007 drought
shouldn't affect crops in 2008.

------

Seeking USDA loans

According to Jane Haste of the Madison County U.S. Department of Agriculture
office, all Madison County farmers seeking low-interest emergency government
loans for help with drought losses will have to apply at the Grant County
regional USDA office. It can be contacted at (765) 668-8983. The Madison County
office of the USDA can be reached at (765) 644-4249.

Counties affected

Of Indiana's 92 counties, 74 are eligible for low-interest emergency loans due
to drought losses. Local counties included in the disaster declaration:
Delaware, Grant, Hamilton, Hancock, Henry and Tipton.

In addition, counties in Ohio, Illinois, Kentucky and Michigan that are
contiguous with affected Indiana counties are eligible.

The disaster declaration was made Dec. 27.

                            Queensland Country Life

                           January 16, 2014 Thursday

Drought Relief Assistance Scheme (DRAS) to assist producers

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 9

LENGTH: 292 words


Drought Relief Assistance Scheme (DRAS) to assist producers in drought declared
areas, including subsidies on freight for fodder and water.

DRAS includes:

l Freight subsidies of up to 50 percent for the movement of fodder and water for
livestock in drought declared areas or on properties with an Individual
Droughted Property declaration.

l Emergency water infrastructure rebate, which provides up to 50pc of the cost
of the purchase and installation of water infrastructure for emergency animal
welfare needs. The Federal Government is also providing $7 million to top up
emergency water infrastructure rebate under DRAS by providing a further rebate
of 25pc, up to a maximum of $20,000.

l The maximum amount claimable under DRAS is $20,000 each financial year or
$30,000 on completion of a Drought Management Plan approved by the Local Drought
Committee.

l A freeze on land rent increases for this financial year.

l More than 40 mental health workshops, the first of which began in November in
Charleville.

Rural Financial Counselling Service (RFCS) in the state's south-west.

through the Farm Finance Concessional Loan Scheme. The Federal Government has
recently announced an additional $20 million in funding for Farm Finance
Concessional loans on top of the current $30 million originally allocated for
2013-14. The loans are administered by QRAA, with a second application round
just opened.

                          Australian Financial Review

                           February 27, 2014 Thursday
                                 First Edition

Drought plan has politics at centre: experts

BYLINE: Joanna Mather, Fleur Anderson and Lucille Keen

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 713 words


A $320 million drought assistance package offering farmers low-interest loans is
based on politics, not economics, experts say.

Professor Linda Botterill, a drought policy specialist with the University of
Canberra, said it was too politically risky for Prime Minister Tony Abbott to
refuse to support struggling farmers because Australians have a "deep seated
cultural sympathy" for agriculturalists.

She said the Prime Minister was deliberately using the term "disaster" when
talking about drought in a bid to distance farmers from factory workers as
candidates for government support.

"The government wants to differentiate support for farmers from the support it
is denying other businesses - SPC Ardmona and the car industry," Professor
Botterill said.

The package includes Interim Farm Household Assistance, which will allow family
households with farm assets of up to $2.5 million to apply for a fortnightly
payment equivalent to the Newstart Allowance, which has a base rate of $35 a day
for a single person.

A drought concessional loan scheme will offer up to $280 million in loans to
eligible farmers for debt restructuring, operating expenses and drought recovery
activities. The loans will come with a 4 per cent fixed interest rate over five
years and will be run in co-operation with banks and state-based rural finance
authorities.

There will be extra funding for water-related infrastructure rebates for farmers
in Queensland and NSW and up to $10.7 million to provide social support, such as
mental health services, to farmers. A further $10 million will help manage pests
in drought-affected areas.'They are not multiple-billion dollar organisations'

More than 70 per cent of Queensland and half of NSW are in drought with a dry
autumn forecast.

Mr Abbott defended the package after the government knocked back support for
manufacturers such as SPC Ardmona and Holden.

"This is akin to a natural disaster and state and federal governments have
always stood behind people wherever they are hit by natural disaster," he said.

Associate professor John Spoehr, who is the head of a workplace research centre
at the University of Adelaide, said there was no difference between farmers and
manufacturers.

Both were dealing with "exceptional circumstances", which meant the decision to
support farmers but not manufacturers was a political one, he said.

Henry Ergas, a regulatory economist who has worked at the Organisation for
Economic Co-operation and Development and Australian Trade Practices Commission
(now the ACCC), said farm assistance packages "rewarded" farmers that had not
adequately prepared for tough times.

"While there can be a strong case for easing the human suffering natural
disasters impose, that assistance must not undermine the care farmers take in
preparing for droughts and other adverse shocks." he said. "Unfortunately, to
date, drought assistance has not met that test, with the result that it can do
more harm than good."

Opposition agriculture spokesman Joel Fitzgibbon said Labor would welcome any
extension of the concessional interest-only loan scheme, but said he was still
in favour of emergency relief payments.

The National Farmers' Federation proposal for Newstart-style emergency relief
payments would not be part of the package, Agriculture Minister Barnaby Joyce
said.

Bank of America Merrill Lynch chief economist Saul Eslake said if farms were
viable under normal conditions, emergency relief was a legitimate use of
taxpayers support.

"But because I am not a climate change denier, some parts of the country that
were viable in the past may not be in the long term because of a shift in
climate," he said.

"I think it would be cruel to give them assistance of that nature."

Mr Eslake said temporary drought assistance should be made on a case-by-case and
area-by-area basis to ensure regions that no longer have viable farming industry
do not become reliant on corporate welfare.

Wool producer Dominic Burden, who owns a sheep property 25 kilometres north west
of Longreach, Queensland, said the federal government's drought assistance
package was "overall great" but now was an opportune time to discuss a long-term
plan for Australian farmers to combat drought.

"We need a national conversation about how to better deal with droughts," he
said.

MISSOURI

ST. LOUIS COUNTY

Westfall Targets Building Code Violations St. Louis County Executive George R.
"Buzz" Westfall wants the County Council to give health and building inspectors
the ability to get search warrants to check out reports of code violations.

County Counselor John Ross said Thursday that an ordinance will be introduced
soon to allow the county's municipal judges to issue such warrants in
unincorporated areas. Police would accompany inspectors in the searches;
detailed reasons would have to be provided in advance.

"Right now, an inspector can't get inside a house easily," Ross said. Ross said
he anticipates that the warrants would be sought mainly in situations considered
to be dangerous.

An example, he said, would be a health threat posed by a home repor tedly filled
with trash and a large number of pets. Ross said the Missouri Supreme Court
recently upheld the legality of such administrative search warrants. He said the
city of St. Louis already allows them.

KEARNEY, Mo.

Judge Allows Couple To Raise More Hogs

A judge has given a couple in Kearney, Mo., permission to triple the number of
hogs they raise, a ruling unpopular with neighbors who say the expansion will
harm the environment and property values.

The Clay County Commission sought an injunction barring Harley and Susie Bogue
from increasing production to 5,000 pigs from 1,500 a year on their farm near
this northwest Missouri town.

Clay County Circuit Judge Larry Harman recently ruled in favor of the couple.

Residents near the farm, east of Interstate 35 and north of Kearney, opposed the
expansion. They cited air pollution, devalued properties and environmental harm.


AP

NORTHWEST MISSOURI

Group OKs Emergency Loans For 6 Counties

The Farm Service Agency has approved emergency loans for six northwest Missouri
counties.

The Emergency Physical Loss Loans are to help farmers recover from damages
caused by heavy snowfall, high wind, flooding and freezing between April 5 and
April 13.

The loans were approved after severe weather caused loss to livestock, farms and
machinery in DeKalb, Harrison, Holt, Nodaway, Putnam and Schuyler counties,
where roofs collapsed on more than 80 buildings under the weight of a spring
snowfall. Farmers in contiguous counties may also qualify.

                              The Washington Post

                     March 19, 1982, Friday, Final Edition

Farm-State Democrats Assail Reagan Policies, Urge Rescue Measures

BYLINE: By Ward Sinclair, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: First Section; A4

LENGTH: 613 words


House and Senate farm-state Democrats, in a bitter assault on Reagan
administration farm policies, urged the president and Congress yesterday to
rescue agriculture from what they called a slide into economic depression.

A dozen senators, led by Walter D. Huddleston of Kentucky, the ranking Democrat
on the Agriculture Committee, introduced a resolution urging the administration
to take "emergency action" to stabilize the farm economy.

On the House side, another dozen members announced formation of a Farm Crisis
Group, headed by Reps. Thomas A. Daschle (D-S.D.) and Kent Hance (D-Tex.), which
is drafting emergency legislation aimed at propping up farm prices and easing
agricultural credit problems.

The farm-state legislators' push for relief coincides with other pressures on
the administration and Congress to provide help to the beleaguered housing and
savings-and-loan industries, among others.

As the Democrats were taking out after his farm policies, Agriculture Secretary
John R. Block, speaking at a luncheon observance of Agriculture Day, conceded
that farmers are in trouble. But he defended his program and urged that the
administration's economic policies be given time to work.

That line didn't play well on Capitol Hill, however.

"If the administration continues to sit on its hands and recite its unfulfilled
promise that relief is just around the corner, legislative action will clearly
be in order. Hooverisms are not enough," Huddleston said.

The resolution he and other Democrats introduced yesterday urges President
Reagan and Secretary Block to use existing authority to deal with a sagging farm
economy that is buffeted by high interest and inflation and the lowest net
income since the Depression era of the 1930s, while production booms.

They want payments to farmers who reduce their planting, higher price support
loans for grains, a more aggressive export program, deferral of federal loan
repayments and a moratorium on foreclosures, and an economic emergency loan
program.

"These actions we are proposing will provide immediate, although temporary,
relief to American farmers until such time as our overall national economy
begins to return to health," Huddleston said at a heavily attended news
conference.

The critical Democrats in the House said patience has worn thin, and frustration
on the farm is thick enough to cut with a knife. "Agriculture is in a
depression, not a recession or a temporary downswing, but a downright bona fide
depression," Daschle said.

"It's a full-scale depression," he added. "We are planning legislation out of
exasperation that there is no action by the administration . . . .We are
frustrated that our bipartisan request for a meeting with the president has been
turned down four times by the White House."

The Daschle-Hance group, with tacit approval from Rep. E (Kika) de la Garza
(D-Tex.), chairman of the Agriculture Committee, plans to begin drafting farm
support legislation next week, Daschle said. He indicated that Republicans will
join in their effort.

The latest rejection of a bid by more than 40 farm-state Republicans and
Democrats to meet with Reagan came last week from Michael K. Deaver, deputy
chief of staff. He wrote Rep. Byron L. Dorgan (D-N.D.) that Reagan was unable to
schedule the meeting they have sought repeatedly since January.

"I can't imagine why he won't meet with us to hear our concern about the farm
situation," Daschle said. "Since we asked for the meeting, he's had the National
Hockey League all-stars and the Clemson University football team in for visits.
If he has time for Clemson football, 42 congressmen should merit some kind of
attention."

                     The Pantagraph (Bloomington, Illinois)

                             August 12, 2005 Friday

Farmers tell Durbin of plight;
Seantor says Congress will discuss disaster aid

BYLINE: Chris Anderson

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. C1

LENGTH: 614 words


McLEAN -- Jack Holland and several of his fellow farmers told Sen. Dick Durbin,
D-Ill., Thursday they will need federal disaster payments to supplement their
income in light of a drought on par -- if not worse -- than the severe
conditions of 1988.

Durbin got the message loud and clear. Saying he didn't want to "overpromise"
assistance, Durbin said emergency disaster payments would not be unprecedented.

"We have had a lot of discussion about this in Washington. I wanted to hear from
you and see the situation firsthand," said Durbin, speaking to a machine shed
full of McLean County farmers on one of Holland's farms. "When we return to work
Sept. 6, we will see if there is enough impact around the country. The situation
in Illinois is so bad from top to bottom."

According to the Illinois Agricultural Statistics Service, 61 percent of the
state's corn is poor to very poor. About 41 percent of soybeans share the same
ranking.

Illinois farmers received emergency disaster payments in 1988 following one of
the worst Midwest droughts on record. Phil Nelson, Illinois Farm Bureau
president, noted a 2003-2004 disaster program already exists and won't expire
until September.

"You could use that program as a template or extend the program. Then you could
pass a supplemental appropriation," Nelson suggested.

Durbin said extension of the existing disaster program would not require as much
congressional time and action as implementing a completely new program. The
existing program pays farmers who document a 35 percent or higher yield loss.
Payments equal about 65 percent of the average 2004 crop prices.

Last month, all but one Illinois county was declared a federal agricultural
disaster area. The designation allows farmers to get low-interest loans.
Conservation Reserve Program acreage, removed from cropland for conservation
purposes, also was released for haying and grazing.

But Holland, who farms east of McLean, and several neighbors told Durbin those
forms of assistance don't do much to make up a severe income deficit.
Eligibility for some loans requires farmers to first be refused help by any
bank.

Landowners with CRP acreage are reluctant to spend money to harvest a poor
quality grass crop and lose 25 percent of their annual CRP rental payment as a
result.

Bill Graff, Illinois Farm Service Agency director, said FSA will offer emergency
low-interest loans at 3.75 percent over seven years to farmers who can prove a
30 percent loss for a single crop.

"I've been farming 30 years. In 1988, I got crop insurance payments and disaster
payments. That kept me farming," said Brad Necessary of McLean.

Nelson noted that the combination of insurance and disaster payments in 1988 was
not enough to make up for significant income losses. He added this year's crop
ranks among the most expensive ever planted. Petroleum price increases that
affect fuel and fertilizer costs for farmers caused a 35 percent to 40 percent
increase in crop costs this year, he said.

About 69 percent of the state's corn acreage and 65 percent of soybean acreage
is insured. Holland said he's not insured. In 30 years of farming, he said crop
insurance probably would have only paid once -- in 1988.

"Our costs were already up, and we've put anywhere from $12 to $19 per acre in
it (to prevent heavy yield losses due to insect feeding)," said Holland. "I had
220-bushel corn last year. If I get 100 bushels this year, I'll be tickled.

"I'm not looking for a handout, but it seems the government does so much for
other countries that you think it would do something for people who feed the
world. The whole business of farming is about looking ahead and staying in for
the long term."
