                             328 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                              The Washington Post

                    August 4, 1999, Wednesday, Final Edition

Maryland Plans Tough Curbs on Water Use; For Local Farmers, Parched Conditions
Wilting a Livelihood

Dan Eggen; Jessie Mangaliman, Washington Post Staff Writers

SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. A01

LENGTH: 1166 words


The 130 or so dairy cows that marched through the Williams brothers' milking
barn yesterday afternoon were thinner and slower than usual. The worst drought
in more than half a century was taking its toll.

The yearlong dry spell means that each cow gives 10 fewer pounds of milk a day,
amounting to $ 5,000 less each month for the 70-year-old Loudoun County farm. A
few have even died unexpectedly, apparent victims of the heat.

The dangerous lack of rainfall also has slashed the amount of hay available for
farm animals in Loudoun and throughout the mid-Atlantic, making it even more
expensive to keep a herd alive. Corn, soybeans and other crops wither while farm
wells are drying up.

If it keeps up much longer, the Williams brothers and other farmers say, they
may just have to sell everything and walk away. Some already have.

"The feeding costs haven't gone down," said Donald Williams, 55, chewing on a
cigar as he thrust a mechanical milker onto one of his cows. "The labor costs
haven't gone down. That money's got to come from somewhere, and that means our
pockets. It takes a real bite after a while."

As most Washington residents and suburbanites fret about their dry lawns and
dirty cars, those in the countryside whose livelihoods depend on moist, fertile
land are beginning to wonder whether they will make it through the year.

Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman has declared West Virginia and all bordering
counties in Maryland and Virginia disaster areas because of the prolonged heat
and drought. Yesterday, Virginia Gov. James S. Gilmore III (R) asked federal
agriculture officials to designate three more Virginia counties -- Warren,
Louisa and Montgomery -- as disaster areas, following a similar request Monday
by Maryland Gov. Parris N. Glendening (D) to add 14 counties to that state's
disaster list.

"The drought is laying a heavy hand on the state," said Roy Seward, spokesman
for the Virginia Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services.

Apples, corn, hay, peaches, soybeans, wheat and pine trees were among the
hardest hit crops in Virginia. If dry weather persists, farmers statewide face
an estimated $ 343.7 million in crop losses, according to USDA spokesman Matt
Kilbourne.

In Maryland, more than half of the crops are lost already, and farmers in
Frederick County are reporting losses of as much as 90 percent. In Southern
Maryland, the drought has taken its toll on corn and soybeans -- the main crops
in the region -- but it also has caused tobacco plants to wilt in the heat.

Tobacco plants weather droughts well, and rebound when rains finally come. But a
continuing dry spell is likely to affect the quality of leaves, meaning poor
prices at the market.

"I have some plants that are scorched, and those are a loss," said Betty
Russell, who farms 200 acres of vegetables, tobacco, corn and rye in Clements in
St. Mary's County.

Russell irrigated part of her 22 acres of tobacco fields with water from a pond.
But the ponds, too, are drying up, farmers said.

Maryland's Emergency Board met yesterday to finalize inclusion of the entire
state in the drought disaster area, said Connie Byler-Hsu, program specialist
for the U.S. Department of Agriculture Farm Service Agency's Maryland office in
Columbia. Byler-Hsu said the declaration will make available emergency loans to
farmers across the state affected by the drought.

But, she said, "there is help for farmers who are hurting now, without the
disaster declaration," such as other types of loans and federal farm subsidies.

In Virginia, agricultural extension agents and USDA workers are preparing damage
assessments for 21 counties and hope to have some completed as early as this
week. Don Davis, executive director of Virginia's USDA Farm Service Agency, said
Shenandoah, Page and Rockingham counties are among the hardest hit statewide.

"It's the most severe disaster we've ever had in that area of Virginia," Davis
said. "We have pastures where you could strike a match and it would burn."

Still, despite the damage being done, many farmers in the region don't plan to
apply for the emergency, low-interest loans offered by the federal government as
part of its disaster relief effort. Most are jittery at forecasts of continued
dry conditions through next year, worrying that taking on more debt now -- even
at low rates -- will only spell more trouble in the end.

"Why do that? You're just going in the hole," said Moke Anderson, 66, who has
been a farmer in Loudoun for most of his adult life. "If it's dry next year,
then what? Before long, you're losing the farm and the house and everything
else. That's not a real solution."

For Anderson and many others, the solution may be to sell their herds in order
to cut their losses.

At Wheatland Farms, where Anderson works, the land yielded half as much hay as
usual, and the relentlessly dry summer means no later cutting in most places. At
the same time, Anderson and others are feeding more hay than usual to their
cattle because they can't graze in parched pastures. The vicious cycle will come
to a head this fall and winter.

"We're probably going to have to sell the cows," said Al Burgess, 59, who
manages Wheatland. "Otherwise we'll run out of feed, if we don't run out of
water first."

In Chaptico in St. Mary's County, farmer Luther Wolfe is losing 300 acres of
corn and 300 acres of soybeans to the lack of rain.

Wolfe said the disaster declaration is likely to help many farmers, but he
doesn't plan to apply for low-interest emergency loans. "It's made me as
contrary as can be," Wolfe joked. "That's what my wife says."

But Mike Russell, who farms 800 acres in Clements, said he plans to take
advantage of the emergency loans, and hopes for emergency farm subsidies as
well. Russell said he's losing 60 percent of his corn and soybean crops to
drought. He did manage to salvage his 40 acres of tobacco with irrigation water
from his ponds.

"Running any business is stressful, and when you have to depend on weather, it's
even more stressful," said Russell, who has been farming for 22 years. "I'm
relying on past years' savings to stay in business. Without farm subsidies, I'd
be out of business."

The drought could have an additional impact in Loudoun, a rapidly developing
fringe suburb that ranks as one of the fastest-growing areas in the country.
Many say the extended dry spell only increases the pressure on farmers to sell
their land for subdivisions. The four Williams brothers, for example, may soon
make way for a wave of tract mansions encroaching on the north side of their
land.

"For traditional farms, for corn and cattle guys, this is an extremely serious
situation," said Warren Howell, a Loudoun haymaker who has already sold out his
entire year's stock.

"This is going to be the straw that breaks a lot of families' backs," Howell
said. "They just can't make a living anymore."



Staff writer Maria Glod contributed to this report.

                   Daily Examiner (Grafton, New South Wales)

                              July 7, 2014 Monday

SECTION: Pg. 12

LENGTH: 582  words


THERE is no question the farming communities of rural and regional NSW are
resilient and stoic in the face of adverse conditions - be they seasonal or
market driven.

However, the devastating seasonal conditions of the past two years have
stretched that resilience and stoicism to its limits in some regions.

I have visited much of drought-stricken NSW, including some parts where farmers
are experiencing the longest period of rainfall deficiency on record.

The NSW Liberals and Nationals government has allocated more than $30 million to
temporary emergency assistance measures since November 2013 to support our
drought-affected primary producers and regional communities.

For the first time, these emergency assistance measures included a waiver of
Local Land Services rates, from January 1 to June 30, 2014.

Unfortunately, due to the increased demand on the emergency drought support
package, this waiver was reduced from 12 months to six months to ensure more
targeted relief measures could be delivered to those farmers in greatest need.

Another issue we faced was that a number of primary producers outlaid capital to
install crucial water infrastructure, but did not lodge an application prior to
the popular $21 million Emergency Water Infrastructure Rebate becoming fully
subscribed.

To address this problem, the NSW Government has committed further money to fund
its contribution to the program for all applications received prior to July 4,
2014, for work completed on or before June 30, 2014.

On July 1 this year the new national drought program commenced, which sees the
NSW Government's role shift towards helping primary producers prepare for
drought and administering a number of Commonwealth Government assistance
measures.

The NSW Government's temporary emergency assistance measures concluded on June
30, 2014, ahead of the commencement of the new national drought program.

Looking to the future, we have allocated more funding to the Rural Support
Worker program and the Farm Innovation Fund, which provides primary producers
with long-term loans at concessional interest rates for on-farm drought
preparedness activities.

The NSW Liberals and Nationals Government has boosted staff numbers at the Rural
Assistance Authority, to ensure timely administration of the large amount of
applications received for emergency assistance measures.

The RAA and Local Land Services administer a number of Australian Government
programs, including the $100 million Drought Concessional Loans Scheme, the Farm
Finance Concessional Loans Scheme and pest management programs.

The NSW Department of Primary Industries continually invests in and facilitates
the latest research and development into programs which support drought
preparedness.

The NSW Government also produces the monthly Seasonal Conditions Report - a
valuable resource to assist primary producers to manage seasonal conditions.

I recognise that these measures only go so far in helping those primary
producers deal with drought.

The NSW Government has established the independent and expert Regional
Assistance Advisory Committee, which will continue to provide ongoing advice and
recommendations on seasonal conditions and support programs.

For information go to www.lls.nsw.gov.au; the RAA, www.raa.nsw.gov.au; and the
DPI, which also has plenty of practical information,
www.dpi.nsw.gov.au/agriculture/emergency/drought.

Katrina Hodgkinson MP

Minister for Primary Industries

Assistant Minister for Tourism and Major Events

                       The Dickinson Press (North Dakota)

                     Distributed by Tribune Content Agency

                           September 23, 2016 Friday

USDA designates Bowman County, neighboring counties as disaster area

BYLINE: The Dickinson Press, N.D.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 310 words


Sept. 23--WASHINGTON -- Bowman County was designated Friday by the U.S.
Department of Agriculture as a primary natural disaster area due to losses
caused by a recent drought.

Farmers and ranchers in Bowman County--as well as in neighboring Adams and Slope
counties in North Dakota, Fallon County in Montana, and Harding County in South
Dakota--qualify for natural disaster assistance.

"Our hearts go out to those North Dakota farmers and ranchers affected by recent
natural disasters," said Tom Vilsack, the U.S. Agriculture Secretary, stated in
a release.

The counties were designated natural disaster areas on Sept. 15, qualifying all
farm operators there as eligible for low-interest emergency loans from USDA's
Farm Service Agency, provided eligibility requirements are met.

Farmers in eligible counties have eight months from the date of the declaration
to apply for loans to help cover part of their actual losses. FSA will consider
each loan application on its own merits, taking into account the extent of
losses, security available and repayment ability. FSA has a variety of programs,
in addition to the emergency loan program, to help eligible farmers recover from
adversity.

"President Obama and I are committed to ensuring that agriculture remains a
bright spot in our nation's economy by sustaining the successes of America's
farmers, ranchers and rural communities through these difficult times," Vilsack
said in the statement. "We're also telling North Dakota producers that USDA
stands with you and your communities when severe weather and natural disasters
threaten to disrupt your livelihood."

Additional information is also available online at "
target="_blank">disaster.fsa.usda.gov.

                                Mint, New Delhi

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            April 12, 2012 Thursday

Banks asked to roll out new farm loan products

BYLINE: Dinesh Unnikrishnan, Mint, New Delhi

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 807 words


April 12--The finance ministry has asked public sector banks to devise products
for Indian farmers to ensure they get adequate funding in emergencies.

The government, the majority owner of such banks, wants them to roll out
products such as emergency loans to farmers that will be linked to savings
accounts, a weather index-based insurance product, and set up a credit guarantee
fund that will aid farmers in the event of crop losses during droughts or
natural calamities.

These products are intended to mitigate the risks faced by farmers, especially
when hit by uncertainties.

The ministry will meet the top brass of at least six large state-run lenders,
including State Bank of India (SBI), Canara Bank, Punjab National Bank and Bank
of Baroda, besides Life Insurance Corporation of India this week, to give the
final touches to the scheme, senior bankers said.

Traditionally, government-sponsored schemes through commercial banks and
regional rural banks (RRBs) have been the major source of funding for farmers.
Banks primarily lend to such borrowers under the so-called priority sector
lending. Under this, banks need to allocate 40% of their loans to agriculture,
exports and other weaker sections.

Recently, a Reserve Bank of India (RBI) committee under former Union Bank
chairman M.V. Nair had proposed that half of all agricultural credit should go
to small and marginal farmers.

The discussion with bankers will be based on a report prepared by the National
Bank for Agriculture and Rural Development (Nabard) and RBI's College of
Agricultural Banking. Nabard officials were not immediately available for
comment.

Nabard and the RBI wing reviewed the existing credit delivery mechanism to
farmers and suggested ways to improve the credit cover.

Once finalized, these products will be rolled out on a pilot basis by one of the
state-run banks in the next few months, said the chief of one of the banks
attending the meeting. He did not want to be named.

"The report has reviewed the lending to agriculture to seasonal operations and
has asked the banks to sit together and devise products that will meet the
additional requirements of the farmers," the banker said. In fiscal 2009, the
government waived loans worth '76,000 crore given to farmers who found it
difficult to repay bank money.

As of 24 February, banks had lent '4.7 trillion to agriculture and allied
activities, against '4.38 trillion in February 2011. This is 11.3% of the gross
credit in the banking system.

The report has proposed the emergency loan, the weather index-based insurance
product and the credit guarantee fund. The final contours of these products are
yet to be determined.

Currently, Nabard is the nodal agency of the government for rolling out
agricultural credit to farmers. With a view to scaling up the credit flow to the
sector, finance minister Pranab Mukherjee proposed to raise the target for
agricultural credit in 2012-13 by '1 trillion to '5.75 trillion in the Union
budget.

The budget also proposed to continue the interest subvention scheme to farmers
at 7% interest per year and an additional subvention of 3% to reward farmers who
repay loans promptly. The interest rate subvention is also available on
post-harvest loans of up to six months against negotiable warehouse receipts to
encourage farmers to keep their produce in warehouses.

The government has also proposed to set up a short-term RRB Credit Refinance
Fund to enhance the capacity of RRBs that give short-term crop loans to small
and marginal farmers. Besides, it is also modifying the Kisan Credit Card Scheme
to convert such cards into smart cards that can be used at ATMs.

Rising exposure to the agriculture sector could pose higher risk to the banking
sector as the chances of defaults are higher from such loans, analysts said.
According to Vaibhav Agrawal, vice-president (research) at Angel Broking Ltd,
60% of the total bad loans at public sector banks are priority sector related.
According to him, the country's largest lender, SBI, has seen around 9.5% of its
total agriculture loans turning bad.

"Exposure to (the) farm sector has always been an area of concern for PSBs
(public sector banks). While the government wants PSBs to directly lend to the
farming sector, that kind of lending will always have risks. This is already
visible with some of the banks like SBI," Agrawal said.

The proposed schemes are unlikely to add pressure to the asset quality of
state-run banks, said Naresh Makhijani, partner (finance) at KPMG.

"If it is for small farmers, bad assets are unlikely to be a major issue as the
poor have a better track record of prompt repayment," he said. "The only concern
is whether banks have the right mechanism to reach out to the right people."

Distributed by MCT Information Services

                    The Sedalia Democrat (Sedalia, Missouri)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           February 23, 2012 Thursday

Pettis, other counties get an agriculture disaster designation in aftermath of
August storms

BYLINE: Dennis Rich, The Sedalia Democrat, Sedalia, Mo.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 622 words


Feb. 23--Farmers in Pettis and surrounding counties are now eligible for
financial assistance through the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Farm Service
Agency for losses sustained during a series of storms last August.

According to the Pettis County FSA office, the U.S. Secretary of Agriculture
designated seven Missouri counties -- Pettis, Atchison, Gentry, Lafayette,
Nodaway and Platte -- as primary agricultural natural disaster areas due to
damages and losses caused by severe storms with hail and high winds that
occurred from Aug. 18-22. The same storm system forced the temporary closure of
the Missouri State Fair last year.

Steve Lair, a farm loan manager with the Pettis County FSA office, told the
Democrat on Wednesday the designation, which allows for low-interest loans and
some other assistance, is available to farmers with uninsured losses or whose
losses last year have made it difficult to secure credit to finance the current
season.

"The damage in Pettis County was not very widespread and was centered mostly in
western Pettis near La Monte and Dresden, and some additional damage in the
Green Ridge area," Lair said. "Anyone with a related loss may apply."

Pettis County Western Commissioner Larry Wilson, who maintains a farming
operation in Pettis County, said he was not aware of people who had suffered
serious losses due to the storms.

"We had some wind damage and it laid my corn down, but it wasn't so bad I
couldn't still combine it," Wilson said. "I don't think it affected too many
people."

According to an FSA press release announcing the designation, 17 counties --
Benton, Buchanan, Carroll, Clay, Clinton, Cooper, Daviess, DeKalb, Harrison,
Henry, Holt,Jackson, Johnson, Morgan, Ray, Saline and Worth   -- also were
designated as contiguous natural disaster areas. Producers in contiguous
counties may also be eligible for programs based on this designation.

All counties listed were designated natural disaster areas on Dec. 8, making all
qualified farm operators in the designated areas eligible for low-interest
emergency loans from USDA's Farm Service Agency, provided eligibility
requirements are met. Farmers in eligible counties have eight months from the
date of the declaration to apply for loans to help cover part of their actual
losses.

According to the release, loan applications will be approved on a case-by-case
basis, taking into account the extent of losses, security available and
repayment ability.

Loans for physical losses must be used to replace or repair damage to buildings,
fences or to compensate the farmer for losses of basic livestock, stored crops
or supplies on hand, equipment, etc., that was lost due to the disaster. Loans
for production losses also may be used to buy feed, seed, fertilizer, livestock
or to make payments on real estate or chattel debts. Generally, loans for
production losses cannot be approved until crops have completed their production
cycle or have been harvested.

In order to qualify, a farmer must have suffered a 30 percent loss in production
or an actual physical loss that was essential to the successful operation of the
farm.

USDA also has made a variety of other programs available to assist farmers in
recovering from the disaster, including the Supplemental Revenue Assistance
Program, which was approved as part of the Food, Conservation, and Energy Act of
2008; the Emergency Conservation Program; Federal Crop Insurance; and the
Noninsured Crop Disaster Assistance Program.

Interested farmers may contact the Pettis County FSA office at 826-3339, ext.
108, or online at fsa.usda.gov.

                                  City Edition

Tornado notebook

SECTION: B; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 930 words


'A MINISTRY OF PRESENCE'

They wear white shirts with patches on each sleeve.

The patch on the right sleeve signifies the Lincoln Police Department.

The patch on the left sleeve is for Lincoln firefighters.

Wearing these shirts, members of the Lincoln Police and Fire Chaplaincy Corps
walk with American Red Cross mental health workers in Hallam.

They hand out food, water, Gatorade. They listen. If anyone wants to, they pray.

"It's really whatever people want," said Andrew Wasmundt, the corps senior
chaplain and pastor of the United Pentecostal Church.

This is the first large disaster that the corps, which has been around since
1978, has responded to, he said.

They're used to responding to disasters affecting fewer people.

One of its 28 volunteers is on duty all the time, and police officers and
firefighters can call if a chaplain is needed.

Sometimes they go with officers who must notify a family that a loved one has
been killed.

Sometimes they help people whose houses burned.

And during the past week or so, they've done their best to help people whose
houses blew away.

Said Wasmundt of the corps: "We're a ministry of presence."

- By Leah Thorsen

JOHANNS ASKS FEMA TO INCLUDE MORE COUNTIES

Gov. Mike Johanns on Wednesday asked the Federal Emergency Management Agency to
name 25 Nebraska counties as disaster areas because of damage caused by severe
storms, tornadoes and flooding.

Four counties - Gage, Lancaster, Saline and Cass - were declared disasters by
FEMA last week, allowing federal assistance to be provided to residents affected
by storms there.

Johanns is asking for assistance for public property in the counties of Adams,
Blaine, Boone, Clay, Cuming, Dodge, Jefferson, Thayer, Washington, Webster and
York.

If granted, FEMA would reimburse local governments 75 percent of the costs for
debris removal, emergency services related to the disaster and repairing or
replacing damaged public facilities.

Johanns also is seeking assistance for individuals in the counties of Adams,
Clay, Douglas, Thayer, Buffalo, Butler, Dodge, Fillmore, Franklin, Hall,
Hamilton, Jefferson, Johnson, Kearney, Nuckolls, Otoe, Pawnee, Sarpy, Saunders,
Seward, Washington, Webster and York.

Individual assistance by FEMA includes grants and low-interest loans to help
with such things as home repairs and paying for temporary housing.

Both public and private assistance was given last week to the four counties hit
by tornadoes.

SEND FOUND STUFF TO HALLAM POST OFFICE: People who find items from Hallam,
Clatonia, Firth and other areas damaged by the tornadoes can mail them to a
Hallam post office box, and residents can go through the items to try to locate
things they've lost.

Items that have personal worth, such as photos, should be sent to the address,
said Lancaster County Sheriff Terry Wagner. Items still can be dropped off at
the sheriff's office at 575 S. 10th St., but Wagner said he would prefer people
mail items to the Village of Hallam, P.O. Box 81, Hallam, NE 68368.

NEW DEADLINE FOR FOODSTAMP ASSISTANCE: The federal United States Department of
Agriculture has approved Nebraska's request to extend the application period for
Disaster Food Stamps through Friday. The emergency program was expected to end
Tuesday.

People from Cass, Gage, Lancaster and Saline counties who were directly affected
by tornadoes or flooding, or lost wages because they were unable to get to work
or their employer temporarily closed because of the disaster, may qualify for a
month's worth of benefits.

As of Tuesday, 91 households had been approved for Disaster Food Stamp
Assistance.

For more information about Disaster Food Stamp Assistance, contact the Office of
Economic and Family Support at (402) 416-5421 or (402)471-9325.

USDA MAKES LOANS AVAILABLE TO FARMERS: Some Nebraska farmers can get emergency
loans from the U.S. Department of Agriculture to help recover from storm damage,
the executive director of the state's Farm Services Agency said Tuesday.

Brian Wolford said farmers in Lancaster, Cass, Gage, Saline, Butler, Jefferson,
Johnson, Otoe, Pawnee, Sarpy, Saunders, Seward, Thayer and York counties can
apply for the relief.

The most that can be borrowed is $500,000. The current interest rate on the
emergency loans is 3.75 percent. The money can be used to replace or repair farm
equipment, livestock or buildings that were damaged during the storms.

A FSA said farmers have until Jan. 25, 2005, to submit loan applications.

CLAY COUNTY DAMAGE NEARS $10 MILLION: Damage in Clay County from the May 22
tornadoes is approaching the $10 million mark as assessment and cleanup efforts
continue there, according to the county emergency manager.

Clay County Emergency Manager Bob Rose said damage assessment continues in such
areas as farm crop loss and the value of a train derailed.

The county also is awaiting word on whether it will be declared a disaster area,
he said.

Lancaster, Gage, Cass and Saline counties already have been declared federal
disaster areas.

WANTED: TORNADO STORIES, PHOTOS: When tornadoes struck Southeast Nebraska late
May 22, how did you survive the storms? What did you see in the aftermath? How
are you recovering?

We want to share your tornado stories -in your words - with our readers. And
we'd like to see photos you took the night of the tornadoes and during the days
that followed.

Send your stories and photos to citydesk@journalstar.com, or Tornado Stories,
Journal Star City Desk, 926 P St., Lincoln, NE 68508. Be sure to include your
name and phone number.

Questions? Call the Journal Star city desk at 473-7306.

We'll publish edited excerpts in a future edition.

Flood help is available

BYLINE: Janet Phelps, The Eagle, Bryan, Texas

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 326 words


Sep. 14--Help is available for Brazos Valley residents and local governments
whose property was damaged by early summer heavy rains and flooding, government
officials said.

President Bush announced last week that 44 Texas counties, including Brazos,
Burleson, Grimes, Leon, Madison, Milam and Robertson, qualify for federal
disaster relief from the U.S. Department of Agriculture and the Federal
Emergency Management Agency.

Farmers and other residents of Milam County are eligible to apply for individual
assistance from FEMA, which can include grants for temporary housing and home
repairs as well as loans, according to government documents.

Government-funded agencies can apply to FEMA for public assistance in Madison
and Milam counties, documents state.

To access applications for assistance from FEMA, visit the agency's Web site, at
www.fema.gov.

Aid from the Department of Agriculture is also available to farmers and small
businesses in the form of low-interest loans in Brazos, Burleson, Grimes, Leon,
Madison, Milam and Robertson counties.

Loans are available for as much as $500,000 at 3.75 percent interest, local Farm
Loan Manager Nathan Philipello said. No eligible resident has applied for aid,
he said.

The loans are fairly easy to obtain, he said, but most farmers and ranchers have
damage that is covered by private insurance or that exceeds the loan limit.

To apply for help from the Department of Agriculture, contact Philipello at the
Robertson County Farm Service Agency at 828-3338.

                       Florida Times-Union (Jacksonville)

                             June 28, 2011 Tuesday

Counties declared in need of drought relief;
Farmers will be eligible to apply for emergency loans and other benefits

SECTION: Pg. C-3

LENGTH: 218 words


BRUNSWICK, GA. U.S. Secretary of Agriculture Tom Vilsack has determined that 22
Georgia counties have suffered production losses due to drought great enough to
qualify for a natural disaster designation.

Vilsack made the designation in response to a request from Gov. Nathan Deal.

"I am grateful for Secretary Vilsack's quick response to my request," Deal said.
"With this designation, farmers and their businesses will qualify for
much-needed federal relief. It is my hope that this aid will relieve some of the
burden this drought has caused."

Farmers in those counties will be eligible to apply for emergency loans and
other benefits under the Food, Conservation and Energy Act of 2008.

Among the counties in Southeast Georgia are Appling, Atkinson, Bacon, Ben Hill,
Brantley, Brooks, Coffee, Jeff Davis, Lanier, Lowndes, Pierce and Wayne.

Vilsack also named 26 contiguous counties that qualify for benefits under the
Consolidated Farm and Rural Development Act.

Among the contiguous counties are Camden, Charlton, Clinch, Glynn, Liberty,
Long, McIntosh and Ware.

Like those in primary disaster counties, farmers in the contiguous disaster
counties may apply for assistance including Farm Service Agency emergency loans
and the revenue assistance programs. Farmers in the eligible counties have eight
months to apply.

                  The Press-Republican (Plattsburgh, New York)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           December 30, 2010 Thursday

Tri-county farmers eligible for emergency loans

BYLINE: Andrea VanValkenburg, The Press-Republican, Plattsburgh, N.Y.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 637 words


Dec. 30--PLATTSBURGH -- Tri-county farmers who suffered losses during the late
September and early October downpours may be able to quality for low-interest
emergency loans.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture designated Franklin, Cortland and Green
counties as primary natural-disaster areas due to the extensive rain and
flooding between Sept. 30 and Oct. 4.

DISASTER AREAS

Seventeen other counties -- including Clinton and Essex -- can also qualify for
disaster assistance because those areas border the three primary-disaster
counties.

The counties were designated as disaster areas Dec. 17, meaning all qualified
farm operators in those regions have eight months from that date to apply for
loans to help cover part of their losses.

The loans are being offered by the Agriculture Department's Farm Service Agency.

Officials say the heavy rains caused severe damage to certain crops and that the
loans can help those who suffered significant production losses.

Loan applications will be considered individually, taking into account the
extent of losses, security available and repayment abilities, officials said.

WIND STORMS

Clinton and Essex counties have also been declared eligible for disaster loans
for any losses incurred during the wind and snow storms that rocked the region
between Dec. 1 and 5.

Officials said farmers affected in that storm may be eligible for
production-loss loans of up to 100 percent of their actual losses or the
operating-loan amount needed to continue in business or a maximum principal
balance outstanding of $500,000, whichever is less.

Farmers must be unable to obtain credit from private commercial lenders.

The interest rate on emergency loans is 3.75%.

More information about the emergency-loan programs can be found at
disaster.fsa.usda.gov.

FLOOD INSURANCE

Homeowners living in areas designated as high-risk flood regions may soon have a
way to save on flood insurance.

Starting Jan. 1, the Federal Emergency Management Agency's National Flood
Insurance Program is offering a new insurance option that will allow property
owners to get lower-cost flood insurance for two years before they are required
to pay standard rates.

The program will make Preferred Risk Policies available for properties that have
been newly mapped into high-risk areas due to a 2008 flood map revision. Those
types of policies start at $129 a year and are typically available only for
properties in moderate-to-low-risk areas.

The revisions and newer maps provide detailed information about where flooding
is most likely to occur.

Costs for standard flood-insurance policies vary, with the average policy
running about $570 a year.

The Preferred Risk Policies provide the same quality of protection and can
include coverage on a building's contents, at a fraction of the cost.

More information can be found at www.floodsmart.gov and
www.floodsmart.gov/PRPExtension.

CHECK THE MAPS

Clinton County Emergency Services Director Eric Day said it's important for
landowners to review flood-insurance-risk maps to find out if they're in
flood-prone areas.

He said climate change and development projects can change the Earth's surface,
and "these changes can make an area prone to flash flooding during severe
weather where one may never have thought flooding was even possible."

Day feels "checking the mapping and looking into the National Flood Insurance
Program is something every landowner should consider."

production-loss loans of up to 100 percent of their actual losses or the
operating-loan amount needed to continue in business or a maximum principal
balance outstanding of $500,000, whichever is less.

Farmers must be unable to obtain credit from private commercial lenders.

The interest rate on emergency loans is 3.75%.

More information about the emergency-loan programs can be found at
disaster.fsa.usda.gov.

FLOOD INSURANCE

Homeowners living in areas designated as high-risk flood regions may soon have a
way to save on flood insurance.

Starting Jan. 1, the Federal Emergency Management Agency's National Flood
Insurance Program is offering a new insurance option that will allow property
owners to get lower-cost flood insurance for two years before they are required
to pay standard rates.

The program will make Preferred Risk Policies available for properties that have
been newly mapped into high-risk areas due to a 2008 flood map revision. Those
types of policies start at $129 a year and are typically available only for
properties in moderate-to-low-risk areas.

The revisions and newer maps provide detailed information about where flooding
is most likely to occur.

Costs for standard flood-insurance policies vary, with the average policy
running about $570 a year.

The Preferred Risk Policies provide the same quality of protection and can
include coverage on a building's contents, at a fraction of the cost.

More information can be found at www.floodsmart.gov and
www.floodsmart.gov/PRPExtension.

CHECK THE MAPS

Clinton County Emergency Services Director Eric Day said it's important for
landowners to review flood-insurance-risk maps to find out if they're in
flood-prone areas.

He said climate change and development projects can change the Earth's surface,
and "these changes can make an area prone to flash flooding during severe
weather where one may never have thought flooding was even possible."

Day feels "checking the mapping and looking into the National Flood Insurance
Program is something every landowner should consider."

Department of Agriculture (USDA) has designated two counties in Florida as

Nov. 05--U.S. Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack has granted Gov. Steve Beshear's
request for disaster assistance to Kentucky farm families in 91 counties --
including Daviess, Hancock, McLean, Muhlenberg and Ohio -- because of the severe
drought conditions that began Aug. 1.

"The current drought has critically impacted our agriculture sector, including

A secretarial disaster designation provides farm families, meeting eligibility
requirements, the opportunity to be considered for disaster assistance from Farm
Service Agency, including emergency loans and Supplemental Revenue Assistance
Payments.

assistance. SURE Program applications for 2010 crop losses will be accepted in
2011, when the 2010 farm revenue data becomes available.

                            The Philadelphia Inquirer

                    OCTOBER 11, 1997 Saturday DCITY EDITION

DROUGHT LEADS FARMERS TO ASK FOR HIGHER MILK PRICE / THE DEPARTMENT OF
AGRICULTURE DECLARED FARMERS THROUGHOUT THE STATE ELIGIBLE FOR EMERGENCY LOANS.

BYLINE: Walter F. Naedele, INQUIRER STAFF WRITER

SECTION: CITY & REGION; Pg. B02

LENGTH: 586 words


Pennsylvania dairy farmers have asked a state regulatory board for an increase
of 3 to 4 cents in the consumer cost of a gallon of milk.

The request follows a spring and summer of below-average rainfall that ravaged
crops across the state, including the crops that dairy farmers depend on to feed
their cows.

The crop damage led the U.S. Department of Agriculture this week to declare
farmers throughout the state eligible for emergency federal loans.

"This has been a very difficult summer for Pennsylvania farmers," said
Pennsylvania Agriculture Secretary Samuel E. Hayes Jr., who supported the price
increase.

The Pennsylvania Milk Marketing Board held an emergency hearing yesterday on
farmers' pleas to raise the price on each 100 pounds of milk from 80 cents to
either $1.20 or $1.25. The board is expected to rule within two weeks.

The average price of a gallon of milk sold in Pennsylvania is now $2.44, the
board said.

Hayes, speaking about the emergency loan declaration, said, "The drought,
coupled with the severe heat, put many of our farm families in a very serious
financial situation.

"Because of the delayed maturation of crops, stunted growth and low yields, many
farmers are facing a shortage of feed as they go into the winter months, in
addition to loss of income."

A farmer can obtain a federal loan of as much as $500,000, repayable at 3.75
percent interest over 30 years, said John R. Cameron, Pennsylvania
administrative officer for the USDA's Farm Service Agency.

To qualify, farmers have eight months to determine whether their farms suffered
at least a 30 percent loss of normal production in a single crop. They must,
among other things, be unable to obtain credit elsewhere.

"There are some real pockets of lousy [crop] production" in the state, said
Cameron of the Farm Service Agency. There are "some counties where
corn-for-grain has suffered 75 percent, 78 percent losses."

Cameron said Bucks, Chester and Montgomery Counties "have suffered very
substantial corn [and soybean] losses, and the hay crop has been very severely
affected."

Although a farmer can get as many as four cuttings of alfalfa hay during a good
year, Cameron said, in some parts of the state, "you're lucky if you get one -
that's largely where people are these days."

All three crops are used to feed dairy cows, which constitute the state's
largest business.

Pennsylvania is one of five states where a disaster declaration was issued for
an entire state this year.

A Farm Service Agency spokesman in Washington said the others were Delaware -
designated on Monday - and Montana, North and South Dakota, designated after
storms last winter.

"One of the frustrations of corn production in Pennsylvania," Greg Roth, a corn
specialist at Pennsylvania State University, said recently, "is drought is
becoming more common."

National Weather Service data shows annual rainfalls below normal in
Philadelphia in six of the last 10 years. As of midnight Thursday, 24.11 inches
had fallen this year, 27 percent below the 30-year average of 32.87 inches for
that date.

Last month, data from the USDA'S National Agricultural Statistics Services
showed that the state was producing the largest percentage of tainted corn of
the nation's 17 largest corn-producing states.

In new data released Oct. 5, the statistics unit reported that 13 percent of
Pennsylvania's corn was "very poor," 29 percent poor, 33 percent fair, 23
percent good and 2 percent excellent.

                    News Letter Journal (Newcastle, Wyoming)

  This content, including derivations, may not be stored or distributed in any
  manner, disseminated, published, broadcast, rewritten or reproduced without

                                 July 19, 2012

Waitin on a sign

BYLINE: News Letter Journal staff

LENGTH: 899  words


Agricultural producers in this region were hurting weeks before the Oil Creek
Fire destroyed a significant amount of forage through the heart of the county,
and local representatives of state and federal agencies say work had begun to
secure resources for drought and disaster relief well ahead of the blaze.

Peggy Livingston, the director of the United States Department of Agriculture's
Farm Services Agency, said she has been working to secure financial relief for
local producers for some time, but until the Secretary of Agriculture declares a
disaster because of the drought that has stricken the region this year, funds
won't be available.

"What we're waiting on right now, the big thing, is the Secretarial designation.
That's not ' finalized," she told the News Letter Journal, indicating that if a
designation is made, emergency loans will be available from FSA. There is also
the possibility that Emergency Conservation District Program funds, which don't
require repayment, could become available as well.

A disaster declaration from the Secretary of Agriculture will make all family
sized farm operators eligible to be considered for low interest emergency loans
from FSA.

"In addition, if you sell or exchange more livestock in a given year than you
normally would because of a drought or other weather-related conditions, you may
be able to postpone reporting the gain from the additional animal sales until
the following year," Livingston said.

To qualify, an individual has to farm as their principal trade or business, and
they have to use the cash method of accounting. They have to show that, under
their usual business practices, they would not have sold or exchanged the
additional animals this year except for the weather-related conditions.

"Always consult with your tax advisor to evaluate your individual situation,"
Livingston suggested.

The Weston County FSA Office has also submitted a request for Emergency
Conservation Program funds, but that request still needs to be approved at the
State FSA Office level before being forwarded to the national office.

"If received, this funding will provide cost share for producers who need to
restore fences, replace water tanks or storage tanks, and above-ground pipelines
that were destroyed in die fire. In addition to these practices, funding may
also be available for water enhancement measures to permit grazing of pastures
in which the normal water source is depleted. This may include well drilling for
livestock water plus one tank at the well sight, solar panels to provide power
to pump water for livestock or water hauling for livestock," Livingston
reported.

She indicated that she will publicize a disaster declaration in the News Letter
Journal if and when it comes, and will also let people know if Emergency
Conservation Program funding becomes available. She also suggested that passage
of the 2012 Farm Bill could reactivate other disaster programs that expired in
September of last year.

Secretary of Agriculture Tom Vilsack announced last week tiiat a package of
program improvements designed to deliver faster and more flexible assistance to
farmers devastated by natural disasters, including wildfires, has been
implemented.

"Secretary Vilsack announced three significant improvements to decades-old USDA
programs and processes related to Secretarial disaster designations: a final
rule that simplifies the process for Secretarial disaster designations and will
result in a 40 percent reduction in processing time for most counties affected
by disasters; a reduced interest rate for emergency loans; and lowers the
payment reduction on Conservation Reserve Program lands qualified for emergency
haying and grazing in 2012," a press release from the United States Department
of Agriculture reported.

The release also said Burned Area Emergency Response specialists are working in
a number of western states, including Wyoming, to prevent additional damage to
life, property or natural resources.

"They will be looking for changes in soil properties and the soil's capacity to
absorb precipitation to mitigate erosion potential. BAER teams are staffed by
specially trained professionals: hydrologists, soil scientists, engineers,
biologists, vegetation specialists, archeologists, and others who rapidly
evaluate the burned area and prescribe emergency stabilization treatments," the
release stated.

The release didn't indicate if any of the teams are active in Weston County, and
Livingston pointed out that a significant portion of the west was struggling
under drought conditions and being impacted by wildfires.

"Everybody is asking for these things, nationwide," she said, suggesting that
producers should get in their requests quickly if a disaster declaration is made
because the amount of resources available could be limited.

"It may give them a little bit of a bright spot, but nothing is a given here,
just because of the economic times," she said.

Regardless of whether or not a disaster declaration comes from Vilsack in the
near future, Livingston urges producers to stay in touch with her office, and
share information that could help assistance find its way here.

"I would encourage anybody who has any questions or concerns to contact me. I'm
documenting the things they've told us in die office to get a feel for this,
otherwise its difficult for me to even know how much money to ask for," she
encouraged.

White House Releases Funds for Farm Loans

BYLINE: AP

SECTION: Section A; Page 18, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 147 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 11


President Reagan today authorized the release of emergency funds and approved
other bookkeeping actions, allowing the transfer of $750 million so the
Government can keep up with the demand for farm operating loans this spring, a
White House spokesman said.

Albert R. Brashear, Deputy Press Secretary, said Mr. Reagan took the action
after , after he met this afternoon with his Economic Policy Council. The funds
would help the Farmers Home Administration meet the demand for operating loans.

''We think it will get us through,'' the spokesman said, although he noted the
funds available this year are only a fraction of what was transferred last year
before the 1985 farm bill put a $1.3-billion cap on the agency's emergency loan
fund.

About $1.5 billion was allocated for direct loans in the fiscal year that began
last Oct. 1, but heavy loan activity was using it rapidly.

Farm Briefs for Dec. 9

BYLINE: Chico Enterprise-Record

SECTION: LOCAL

LENGTH: 380 words


House Ag Committee has local members

WASHINGTON   Doug LaMalfa, R-Richvale; John Garamendi, D-Fairfield; and Jeff
Denham, R-Turlock will join the U.S. House Committee on Agriculture.

Jim Costa, D-Fresno, already serves on the committee.

Beef prices still on the rise

The latest Consumer Price Index report from USDA shows retail beef and veal
prices continued to rise in 2012, while most other food prices have stabilized,
Drovers CattleNetwork reported.

The projection is for a rise in prices from 5-6 percent next year.

The index for pork prices declined by 2.1 percent over the past 12 months, while
the index for poultry increased by 5.5 percent. The index for all meats, poultry
and fish increased by 2.4 percent during the same period.

Overall for 2012, USDA projects the CPI for all food will increase by 2.5
percent to 3.5 percent.

Talk on challenges to farmers, ranchers

A talk and breakfast on "building and sustaining profitability for north-state
farmers and ranchers" will be held from 8:30 a.m. to 1 p.m. Monday at Rolling
Hills Casino.

The goal of the day is to create a list of "next steps" for small and
medium-sized farmers to face challenges in Butte, Glenn and Tehama counties.

The event is sponsored by the Buy Fresh Buy Local, 3Core and Nortec.

Farm Bureau awarded for innovation

PASADENA   The Butte County Farm Bureau was given the Innovator Award during the
California State Farm Bureau Federation annual meeting in Pasadena last week.

The county held a member outreach luncheon with attendance of more than 100. The
goal was to gain more membership, as well as raise money for the state farm
bureau Family Farm political action committee. More than $4,500 was raised.

Emergency loans for drought

Butte and Glenn County farmers are among those eligible for USDA emergency farm
loans due to drought in 2012.

Growers have eight months to apply and need to show loss and be able to repay
the loans.

Free dairy seminars are available

ORLAND   California dairy management seminars will be hosted by the University
of California Agriculture and Natural Resources.

In Orland, the event is Thursday from 5:30-8:30 p.m. and includes dinner.
Location is the farm adviser's office, 821 E. South St.

Information, 865-1156,bmkarle@ucdavis.edu .

Other events will be held in Tulare and Modesto.

                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                           December 5, 1981 Saturday

Bogged down in discussions   Farmers flock for promised aid,   but only three
receive it so far

BYLINE: KEVIN COX; GAM

LENGTH: 564 words


By  KEVIN COX
   Despite a flood of applications for the low-interest emergency farm aid
 promised in the federal budget a month ago, only three farmers across the
 country have received any money from the program.

The program, set up to make $45-million available at 11.75 per cent
 interest to farmers in danger of losing their farms, has bogged down in
 discussions between bankers and federal officials.

Farmers can't apply for the federal money unless they have been turned
 down for a Small Business Development Bond first, and many banks have not
 been processing those applications because the federal Government has not
 made clear who is eligible for the bonds, which the budget made available
 to unincorporated farmers.
    "There's no question activity is not in full swing. Things are moving
 slowly," said Al Droppo, a spokesman for the Canadian Bankers Association,
 who met federal officials from the departments of Revenue and Finance
 Thursday.
    "We did succeed in getting our concerns across at the meeting, but the
 criteria for the bonds have to be clarified, and we were hoping to hear
 something on this today. Now we probably won't hear anything until
 Tuesday."
    Mr. Droppo said the banks need clarification from the federal officials
 on how the bonds, which make between $10,000 and $500,000 available at
 about 16 per cent interest, can be given out.

He said many farmers have applied for the bonds but the banks won't
 give out the bonds until the criteria are completed.

Stewart Given, Ontario director of the Farm Credit Corp., a federal
 farm financing agency, said the three farmers, all from Ontario, received
 emergency loans totalling $650,000, but many applications are on hold
 until the snags are worked out in the bond program.
    "We had quite a heavy run initially when this was announced and we have
 been quite busy with the applications, although it is tapering off now,"
 Mr. Given said.
    "There is still some delay with farmers having to go through the banks
 first. This program will really start whenever the banks are ready to
 start," he said.

Other provinces also have experienced a large number of applications,
 but Ontario farmers expect to get a large portion of the money because of
 the low livestock prices and the lack of provincial interest-rate
 assistance programs offered in other provinces.

The lack of action on the bond program has angered many farmers. At a
 press conference Thursday, Tom Slumskie, a Bruce County farmer, said the
 federal budget "kicked us in the teeth.
    "In our area not one of 300 farmers who needed a Small Business
 Development Bond just to get by has been able to get one," he said.

A Newmarket dairy farmer, Jochem Huisintveldt, who said the Canadian
 Imperial Bank of Commerce demanded payment of his loans of $659,000 in
 early November and is threatening to put the farm into receivership, said
 he applied for the emergency aid program.
    "The Farm Credit guy said I probably wouldn't get anything and I'd have
 to get turned down for the bond before I could get any help. It would take
 a couple of months to get everything processed," said Mr. Huisintveldt,
 who has until Jan. 15 to arrange refinancing for his farm or face losing
 it.

A Department of Finance spokesman said yesterday no announcement on the
 bond program would be made until next week and he knew of no major changes
 to the program announced in the budget.

County Farmers Eligible For Loans

BYLINE: Staff Report

SECTION: B; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 255  words

DATELINE: Lancaster, PA


Farmers in Lancaster County now qualify for natural disaster low-interest
emergency loans because of damage from Hurricane Irene and Tropical Storm Lee.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has designated Lebanon, Bradford and York
counties as natural disaster areas because of excessive rain, flooding and flash
flooding.

Lancaster County farmers qualify for natural disaster assistance because the
county is contiguous to Lebanon and York counties.

Local farmers qualify for the loans from USDA's Farm Service Agency provided
eligibility requirements are met.

Farmers in eligible counties have eight months from the date of the declaration
- Nov. 9 - to apply for loans to help cover part of their actual losses.

FSA will consider each loan application on its own merits, taking into account
the extent of losses, security available and repayment ability. FSA has a
variety of programs, in addition to the loan program, to help eligible farmers
recover from adversity.

USDA also has made other programs available to assist farmers and ranchers,
including the Supplemental Revenue Assistance Program, which was approved as
part of the Food, Conservation and Energy Act of 2008; the Emergency
Conservation Program; Federal Crop Insurance; and the Noninsured Crop Disaster
Assistance Program.

Interested farmers may contact their local USDA Service Center for further
information on eligibility requirements and application procedures for these and
other programs. Additional information is also available online at
http://disaster.fsa.usda.gov.

                         Star Tribune (Minneapolis, MN)

                             August 5, 2007 Sunday
                                 Metro Edition

Drought-relief request takes on urgency;
USDA's State Emergency Board recommends disaster assistance be available in 25
Minnesota counties.

BYLINE: Jackie Crosby, Staff Writer

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1B

LENGTH: 553 words


Morrison County farmer Ken Primus hasn't seen an inch of rain at one time since
he planted in early May. He's not yet in panic mode, but he's starting to get
worried.

"If we got half of a normal crop, I'd be happy," said Primus, whose 75-acre farm
is about 7 miles southwest of Little Falls. "My corn is still green yet, but
there's some fields around here that are brown all the way to the top."

Gov. Tim Pawlenty hopes federal aid will soon be on its way.

In a letter sent to U.S. Agriculture Secretary Mike Johanns on Friday, Pawlenty
asked the USDA to declare 25 Minnesota counties as agricultural disasters, which
would allow farmers and ranchers access to low-interest federal loans. A final
decision is made by the secretary of agriculture or the president.

The emergency loans, administered by the Farm Service Agency, can be used to
restore or replace property, pay production costs associated with the drought,
supplement living expenses, reorganize farming operations and refinance certain
debts.

Pawlenty said farmers in northern Minnesota are experiencing significant losses
to their hay and pasture, leaving many to worry about not having feed for
livestock over the winter.

"Corn and soybean crops are also losing value daily as the warm, dry weather
continues across the state," Pawlenty wrote in the letter.

Pawlenty included Roseau County in his request for aid because of an extensive
winter-kill of the county's perennial rye grass.

Last Tuesday, Pawlenty took a tour of distressed farms in central Minnesota and
asked the U.S. Department of Agriculture to assess the drought damage across
Minnesota. The department's emergency board recommended disaster assistance.

As an example of meager rainfall, Pawlenty last week pointed out the Little
Falls area had received 71 percent of its normal rainfall in May, 41 percent in
June and only 17 percent in July.

In late July, the National Drought Mitigation Center reported that a wide swath
of the state, running from the southwest to northeast, was suffering from
"severe" drought.

"When corn is shoulder high on up, it needs a third of an inch of water a day on
an 85-degree day," said Primus, who has about 60 acres of corn and 10 acres of
barley. "So with weather like we have now, that corn is using over 2 inches a
week. When you don't get any rain, that hurts."

Minnesota has two loan programs for farmers hit hard by the drought. The
Disaster Assistance Loan Program is for farmers in counties that receive the
disaster declaration and helps with the costs of watering, irrigation and other
drought mitigation systems.

The state's Loan Restructuring Program can help farmers pay their bills,
regardless of whether they live in a federally designated disaster area.

Primus said he has mixed feelings about the federal government stepping in.

"I've been here since 1978, and I've never had a government loan yet," he said.
"When you have a drought, it's kind of the checks and balances of the system. It
sounds kind of cruel, but that's part of the risk you take in agriculture."

Jackie Crosby - 612-673-7335

FEDERAL AID SOUGHT FOR THE FOLLOWING COUNTIES:

Aitkin, Anoka, Benton, Brown, Carlton, Cass, Cook, Crow Wing, Douglas, Hennepin,
Hubbard, Itasca, Kanabec, Lake, Mille Lacs, Morrison, Pipestone, Pope, Roseau,
St. Louis, Sherburne, Swift, Todd, Wadena, Wright.

                       The Keene Sentinel (New Hampshire)

                     Distributed by Tribune Content Agency

                             August 21, 2016 Sunday

In Midst of Drought, Local Farmers Focus on Hay and Irrigation

BYLINE: Isaac Stein, The Keene Sentinel, N.H.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 905 words


Aug. 21--It doesn't take hard-hitting reportage to show summers can be hot in
New Hampshire, and rainfall has been scarce this year. But the severity of the
weather this year is unusual, and, as of Wednesday, the N.H. Department of
Environmental Services listed the entire southern part of the state as in a
"severe" drought.

Naturally, local farmers have cause for concern. "I've heard talk from farmers
... who have been in this area a lot longer than us, and they said that they've
been here 30 years, and it's never been this bad. Ever," said Sarah Costa of
Manning Hill Farm in Winchester.

Interviews with four farmers, including Costa, who were at the Farmers' Market
of Keene Saturday morning suggest the impact of the drought varies considerably
from farm to farm. It also depends on whether a farm has access to water
independent of the rainfall, and what crops they're growing.

Provided they're properly watered, vegetables may "actually do better with dry
weather," said Frank Hunter, of Hillside Springs Farm in Westmoreland.

He said he has not sustained a significant economic impact from the drought, and
has actually experienced less "disease pressure" this year. Hunter specifically
mentioned less bottom rot on lettuce and leaf spot on tomatoes. He did note,
however, that his "hay crop was down."

The hay crop has "been crap," Susan Parke-Sutherland of Wingate Farm in Hinsdale
said. Parke-Sutherland said her farm is doing fine economically, but she
irrigates "crazy hours" to deal with the drought.

Her farm produces eggs, meat and flowers. But with hay, she said, there's "real
dollar amounts lost because of the drought." She added that most of the other
farmers she knows "were just going all out and irrigating, like as much as
possible."

However, not all farmers have irrigation systems, or irrigate all of their
crops. Susan Peters of Deer Ridge Farm in Guilford, Vt., irrigates the plants in
her greenhouse using water from a neighbor's spring, which has not been affected
by the drought. She said she was thankful for having a reliable water source,
and had the good fortune to get rain "basically when we've really needed it."

But the drought is severe, and the federal government is acting on the
situation.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has designated eight counties in New
Hampshire, including Cheshire County, as primary natural disaster areas,
according to a news release Friday. The designation is due to "losses caused by
freeze and unseasonably warm temperatures that occurred from Feb. 1, 2016,
through April 30, 2016," according to the release.

The news release added that farmers in those eight counties, as well as Carroll
and Coos counties, may apply for low-interest emergency loans from the USDA, and
applications will be approved based on criteria including the extent of losses
and repayment ability.

Farmers in several counties in Maine, Massachusetts, and Vermont are eligible
for the loans, too.

But none of the four farmers interviewed Saturday were particularly interested
in the USDA loans. Their main reasons varied considerably, but often hinged on
what they characterized as an inapplicability to small farms, and a reluctance
to take on additional debt.

Parke-Sutherland said she appreciates the USDA's involvement and thought it
"appropriate," but said she doesn't "utilize their emergency relief services,
even their crop insurance services, just because of our scale."

Hunter said farmers would be more interested in grants, not loans.

"It's borrowing from Peter to pay Paul, and I'm not sure that's a good route to
go down. I mean, farming is so marginal economically that I think probably
grants are probably what farmers are more interested in," he said.

Costa referenced the possibility of additional loans with a laugh. "We probably
won't do it. We already have a lot of loans," she said.

For Costa, the extreme weather has affected her livelihood, as Manning Hill Farm
is, among other industries, a hay producer. It also sells beef, pork, eggs and
dairy products. She said the farm's yield on its second cut of hay was less than
half of what it normally is, and the farm usually does "sell quite a bit, for
income."

According to Costa, the bad hay crop was more attributable to the drought than
the unseasonable temperatures earlier this year, both of which caused the grass
to "completely burn up" and not grow back.

"The alfalfa would just grow and then it turns yellow or brown and then just,
like, flops over. And some types of grasses were just not growing at all,
because there's no rain," she said.

Overgrazing also would have killed the grass, she added, so the farm was placed
in a Catch-22. Ultimately, Manning Hill took its animals off the pasture and put
them in the barn, where they are eating hay, normally reserved for winter,
instead of grass.

Costa expressed concern about the farm's hay supply going into the end of year,
noting that the farm is saving what it has for its own use. With a breath of
optimism, she had a message on her plan for adapting to the weather
circumstances.

"You just keep moving forward. That's kind of what farming's all about, because
there's so many odd things about it."

SOUTH BEND

Radio show to discuss sexual orientation

The call-in radio program "Providing Options" this Sunday will talk about what
can be done to prevent discrimination based on sexual orientation.

The guests will include Rhonda Redman, who is lesbian, and possibly others who
can speak about psychology and Christian ministry.

The show also will address general questions of what it means to be gay or
lesbian or transsexual.

This comes up in light of an ordinance that may be proposed this year in the
South Bend Common Council. The ordinance would make sexual orientation a class
protected by the South Bend Human Rights Commission.

The radio show will air at 8:05 p.m. Sunday on WSBT-AM (960). Listeners may call
in at (574) 282-2696.

SOUTH BEND

Three face charges in weapons, drug bust

 Charges have been filed against two men and one woman arrested during a
Wednesday morning drug and weapons raid at a home on Brick Road.

Investigators discovered explosive materials, an assault rifle, ammunition,
cash, cocaine, marijuana and drug paraphernalia at the residence in the 15100
block of Brick Road, less than 1,000 feet from Prairie Vista Elementary School.

Court documents allege drugs were being used by occupants and sold from the
home.

Ronald J. Newhouse, 23, is charged with dealing cocaine within 1,000 feet of a
school, possession of cocaine within 1,000 feet of a school and possession of
marijuana.

Jack A. Maike, 48, and Ann Parks, 41, are charged with maintaining a common
nuisance.

All three are being held at the St. Joseph County Jail, a jail official said.

A third man arrested during the raid was not charged.

SOUTH BEND

12-year-old remains at juvenile center

 The 12-year-old boy who brought a loaded gun to Navarre Intermediate Center
admitted Friday to the charge filed against him in juvenile court.

The boy is charged with carrying a handgun on school property, a Class C felony
punishable by two to eight years in prison in adult court.

The boy's lawyer, Andr Gammage, asked that the boy be allowed to return home,
but St. Joseph Probate Court Magistrate Harold Brueseke ruled the boy should
remain in detention at the Frederick Juvenile Justice Center until his
sentencing May 17.

The case is the boy's first juvenile matter.

The boy has said he brought the loaded gun to school for protection because he
had been bullied by some youths after school. He told police he never intended
to use it or shoot anyone.

Before the disposition of his case, the boy will undergo a psychological
evaluation.

The sixth-grader will be expelled from school under the South Bend Community
School Corp. weapons policy.

KNOX

Farmers can apply for emergency loans

Farmers in Marshall, Starke and St. Joseph counties may be eligible for
emergency loans because of severe winter storms and flooding that occurred from
Jan. 1 through Feb. 11.

The Farm Service Agency-Farm Loan Programs, the U.S. Department of Agriculture
agency accepting the loans, is urging farmers to return their applications for
the loans as soon as possible to avoid a backlog that could occur by the
deadline of Oct. 3.

Generally, farmers who suffered physical and production losses are eligible for
the emergency loans. Contact Daniel L. Walsh, farm loan manager, at the Farm
Service Agency-Farm Loan Program office, 1406 S. Heaton St., Knox. The phone
number is (574) 772-3066.

Virginia: TWO VIRGINIA COUNTIES - BATH AND HIGHLAND - RECEIVE PRIMARY DISASTER
DECLARATIONS FOR DROUGHT IN 2014

LENGTH: 317  words

DATELINE: Richmond


Virginia Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services has issued the
following news release:

The Virginia Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services (VDACS) announced
today that Highland County received U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA)
designation as a primary disaster area due to drought that occurred from June 1
through October 31, 2014. Bath County received a similar designation due to
drought that occurred from August 22 through October 15, 2014. Alleghany,
Augusta and Rockbridge Counties were named contiguous disaster counties, meaning
they border a county named as a primary disaster area.

A federal Secretarial disaster designation makes farm operators in both primary
and contiguous counties eligible to be considered for assistance from the
federal Farm Service Agency (FSA), provided eligibility requirements are met.
This assistance includes FSA emergency loans. Local FSA offices can provide
affected farmers with further information.

Farmers in eligible counties have eight months from the date of a Secretarial
disaster declaration to apply for emergency loan assistance. FSA will consider
each emergency loan application on its own merits, taking into account the
extent of production losses, security available and repayment ability. Local FSA
offices can provide affected farmers with more information.

Sandra J. Adams, VDACS Commissioner, said, "I am grateful that the USDA has
declared these two counties as disaster areas eligible for federal assistance,
and that other localities have been designated as contiguous disaster areas. Any
assistance farmers can get will be appreciated."

VDACS posts all of its news releases on Facebook and Twitter. To receive
immediate updates, follow us on Twitter@VaAgriculture or like us on
facebook.com/VaAgriculture.

                           Investor's Business Daily

                               September 23, 1998

E D I T O R I A L S Farmers Plow For More Subsidies

SECTION: Editorial; Pg. A32

LENGTH: 596 words



It's an election year, so it must be time to bail out farmers. Responding to
falling grain prices, drought and crop disease, Congress is set to lavish
farmers with billions in aid.  It's the easy answer. It's also the wrong one.

With aid on the way, there are only two questions: how much and in what form?
Democrats like marketing loans that float cash to farmers until they sell their
crops. They unveiled a plan Monday to provide $ 7.1 billion in emergency aid.

The GOP prefers direct payments worth about $ 4 billion.

Both distort free markets but marketing loans are worse than direct handouts.

They are designed to protect farmers from low prices. They also allow farmers to
store crops until prices go higher.

Farmers repay the loans with proceeds from crop sales. If they sell for less
than the loan rate, they keep the difference.

Many farmers dislike direct payments. They see them as blatant welfare. They
prefer loans that disguise the nature of the aid. Loans look more like a
legitimate cash advance than welfare.

But loans actually hurt farmers because they bring down prices over the long
term. When they have loans, farmers tend to hold on to crops in anticipation of
higher prices. The result is an eventual market glut that keeps prices low.

Sen. Pat Roberts, R-Kan., says the loans cause an endless cycle: They're
continually used to combat the low prices they create.

Loans also drive down a farmer's income in another way. A Kansas State
University study showed storage costs and interest on the federal loans negate
any extra revenue brought by waiting for higher prices.

Despite rhetoric about saving family farms, the real beneficiaries of government
largesse are the biggest farms. The largest 15% - think corporate farms - get
two-thirds of the farm payments.

Yes, there are some family farmers having a tough time. But they're not alone.
Business cycles brought about by government interference in the marketplace
affect everyone. Corporate earnings are down due to government-inspired problems
in Japan, Korea, Indonesia and elsewhere. But only a favored few get a federal
bailout.

That will be ignored, though, as will farmers' current gorging at the federal
trough. Since '85, federal price supports have reached $ 370 billion. That's
enough to buy all the farmland in 41 states, says author James Bovard.

And under the '96 Freedom to Farm Act, farmers have received $ 6 billion more in
subsidies than they would have gotten under the old law.

Part of the money is from transition payments as the old subsidies are phased
out. The rest is from loan deficiency payments that automatically kick in when
some crop prices fall below a set price.

Last month the government unleashed more than $ 5 billion - a year's worth of
regular payments - in emergency aid. This funding comes from next year's budget.

That alone should be enough for Congress to reject more aid.

Yet a bigger bailout's coming. The House has already voted to excuse this farm
aid from the spending caps agreed to in last year's balanced budget act.

Why? Farmers enjoy political clout disproportionate to their numbers. Only about
2.5% of Americans farm, but farmers can be found in all but a few highly urban
congressional districts.

With nearly every lawmaker from a farm district or farm state, farmers tend to
get what they want. They should instead get what they need: a free market to
protect them from the vicious cycle of government aid.

                            The Blade (Toledo, Ohio)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             August 17, 2012 Friday

Local farms part of drought disaster area

BYLINE: Tyrel Linkhorn, The Blade, Toledo, Ohio

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 781 words


Aug. 17--Several recent rainstorms have improved drought conditions in most of
northwest Ohio, but for this year's corn crop the rain came too late to make
much of a difference.

"The drought is having a serious impact, even though things look green out here.
Our corn yields will be less than half of what they normally are," said Roy
Norman, Ohio Farm Bureau organization director for Fulton, Henry, Defiance, and
Williams counties.

Mr. Norman said many farmers in the counties he covers are anticipating losing
50 to 70 percent of their normal corn crop. In general, farms to the east are
faring better, while farms to the west are doing worse.

The federal government acknowledged the dire situation in Ohio this week as the
U.S. Department of Agriculture declared nine counties as natural disaster areas
because of the drought.

Included among them were Defiance, Fulton, Henry, Paulding, Putnam, and Van Wert
counties. The other three counties in Ohio named primary disaster areas are
Butler, Hamilton, and Preble. Williams County was declared a disaster area last
week. Fourteen other counties, including Allen, Hancock, Lucas, and Wood have
been named contiguous disaster counties.

The declaration allows eligible farmers to take out emergency loans at low
interest rates.

"If a producer is facing financial difficulty, the banker, for example, won't
lend," said Steve Maurer, Ohio executive director for the Farm Service Agency.
"Then we can play a role, charging a lower interest rate and helping people get
through a tough time."

Mr. Maurer said it's too early to say how many farmers will take advantage of
the loans, but he expects the number of those eligible to increase significantly
in coming days.

"Within days there will probably be many more counties added to that list that
came out [Wednesday]," he said. "I expect most of Ohio to be declared."

Other emergency assistance programs, such as Farm Service Agency disaster
assistance programs, have historically used disaster designations as an
eligibility requirement trigger.

But while low-interest loans can help, they can't do a thing to fix the root of
the problem, Mr. Norman said.

"In the large scheme of things," he said, "you can't replace that crop out there
you lost."

The most recent update of the U.S. Drought Monitor, released Tuesday, actually
shows improvement in northwest Ohio. Most of the region -- including all of
Defiance, Henry, Fulton, and Paulding counties -- went from severe drought to
moderate drought. The small pocket of extreme drought in Williams County was
reduced to moderate or severe.

It's too late for rains to improve the corn crop, but the additional moisture is
at least preventing fields from getting worse.

"I think we have stabilized," said Chet Phillips, general manager of Gerald
Grain Center Inc. in Napoleon. "We may be improving the [soy]beans. But we've
stabilized the corn. We've stopped the bleeding."

Wauseon-area resident Beverly Ayers, who along with her husband grows corn,
soybeans, and wheat, has counted 3.2 inches of rain since Aug. 5.

"It's very good rain. This is what we should have been having all along," she
said.

Still, she's not sure what they'll have come harvest time. Right now they're
figuring about half their soybean crop will be lost, and maybe 75 percent of the
corn crop.

Mr. Phillips said he expects to see a market area average of 100 to 105 bushels
of corn per acre. Often, local yields average 150 to 160 bushels per acre, he
said. The agriculture department last week cut U.S. overall yield projections to
123.4 bushels per acre. Still, with record planting this year, the crop is
expected to be a solid one of 10.8 billion bushels -- which the agency points
out is well above the 4.9 billion bushels produced in 1988, the drought to which
this year's has often been compared.

The rain does seem to have helped perk up the soybean crop.

"The beans look good," Mr. Phillips said. "We don't know how much damage or how
many pods we lost during that dry spell, but they've certainly put on more pods.
We've got high hopes for them."

If conditions hold, the soybean crop may net a near-normal yield in many
northwest Ohio fields. That could prove many farmers' saving grace.

"About half of them at least have insurance," Mr. Phillips said. "Beans I think
are going to be good, and I think [farmers] realize beans are going to take care
of them. I think we can be thankful for that. I think they know they'll get by.
Last year was a good year. In a way, it'll average out."

Contact Tyrel Linkhorn at: tlinkhorn@theblade.com or 419-724-6134.
