                           Pittsburgh Tribune Review

                           September 19, 2004 Sunday

Some may pay dearly for flood damage

BYLINE: Brian C. Rittmeyer

LENGTH: 398 words


Homeowners without flood insurance could find themselves high and dry when it
comes to repairing their water-ravaged homes, unless a federal disaster is
declared.

Carolyn Gorman of the Insurance Information Institute said homeowners insurance
does not cover damage from rising water -- flooding.

"People should remember that flooding occurs everywhere, not just in flood
zones, and they should look into buying flood insurance," she said. "Many claims
come in from areas where it was not a designated flood zone."

Gov. Ed Rendell has asked for federal aid for 34 counties, including Allegheny,
Armstrong, Beaver, Butler, Washington and Westmoreland.

In a letter to President Bush, Rendell sought help for individuals, legal
services, emergency food stamps, unemployment assistance, crisis counseling and
loans.

Rendell made the request based on damage reports to the state Emergency
Operations Center. Representatives of the Federal Emergency Management Agency
surveyed the area by air Saturday, said Maria Smith, press secretary for the
Pennsylvania Emergency Management Agency.

The state and county disaster declarations, for the most part, suspend only
bidding rules, allowing local governments to expedite cleanup and repair.

Because there are no state disaster-help programs, the only aid would come from
a federal declaration, Smith said.

"All the money comes from the federal government. The state administers some
programs, but it's not our money," said Justin Fleming, deputy press secretary
for PEMA. "As it stands now, nothing can happen in terms of assistance" to
homeowners or renters.

A federal declaration would allow homeowners, renters and business owners to get
grants and take out loans. The loans typically carry interest rates lower than
those offered by banks and credit unions -- between 2.5 percent and 5.5 percent.

PNC Bank announced it will provide low-interest loans to flood victims beginning
Monday. For individuals, the bank will offer up to 20-year home equity loans
with a fixed 3.99 percent interest rate and fees waived. For small businesses,
the bank will offer a minimum $2,500 line of credit with a fixed 2.99 percent
interest rate and three- and five-year loans with a fixed 5.25 percent interest
rate.

State Farm policyholders can call (800) 732-5246 to report property damage as a
result of Hurricane Ivan.

Staff writer Mike Wereschagin contributed to this report.

                            The Philadelphia Inquirer

                  AUGUST 12, 1999 Thursday CNEW JERSEY EDITION

N.J. FARMS: RECOVERY IS YEARS AWAY NOT ONLY IS THE DROUGHT'S TOLL ON CROPS
EXTENSIVE, BUT U.S. LOANS ARE DEPLETED.

BYLINE: Suzette Parmley and Melody McDonald, INQUIRER STAFF WRITERS

SECTION: LOCAL; Pg. A01

LENGTH: 996 words


Anthony Grasso, a 36-year-old peach farmer in Elm in Camden County, has very
little to show for his labor in this year's harvest. With the drought and heat,
he expects to gather maybe only 5 percent to 10 percent of the crop.

Grasso's wife, Lori, 35, is encouraging the couple's two children, ages 11 and
4, to seek higher education so they will have something to fall back on should
they choose their father's shaky profession.

"It's a tough career," said Lori Grasso, who keeps the books for the
family-owned farm, which of late has had nothing but mounting expenses, such as
$125,000 for fertilizers and chemicals. "My husband doesn't feel like there is
much of a future in farming."

More than extensive crop damage is at stake as the drought continues its drain
on the state's nearly $1 billion-a-year agriculture industry. With New Jersey
declared a farm disaster area Tuesday by U.S. Agriculture Secretary Dan
Glickman, state officials said yesterday that it would take years to recover
from the drought's economic impact.

Another setback is that farm-loan programs in Washington have been depleted
because of the number of states that have applied for emergency assistance, due
to last year's drought in some areas and this year's.

All of Connecticut was declared a farm disaster area yesterday, along with 19
counties in Maryland, six in New York, five in Virginia, and one in New Mexico.
West Virginia was designated a farm disaster area last week, as were 87 counties
in Ohio on Tuesday.

In Pennsylvania yesterday, Gov. Ridge again appealed to Glickman to declare his
state a farm disaster area. Because 34 counties in New York were designated
disaster areas Tuesday along with 19 in New Jersey, 10 adjacent Pennsylvania
counties became eligible for federal low-interest loans.

Politicians in New Jersey and Pennsylvania asked Congress this week to
distribute grants and direct cash payments in addition to federal low-interest
loans to drought-stricken farmers. Grants and such payments would not have to be
paid back.

But officials at the U.S. Department of Agriculture said yesterday that the
back-to-back drought years had depleted their coffers. The agency spent its
entire fiscal 1999 budget of $287 million for emergency loans by June.

"Right now, we have no emergency loan money to distribute," said Carolyn
Cooksie, department administrator for farm-loan programs at the Farm Service
Agency. "We fund on a first-come, first-serve basis, and because of
weather-related disasters in '98 and '99, there's not a penny left."

Cooksie said her agency would appeal to Congress for additional funding because
it still has a backlog of applications from last year's drought, which wiped out
farmers in several Western and Southwestern states.

While there are no dollar figures on this year's crop damage in Pennsylvania,
the National Agricultural Statistics Service of the USDA has estimated that only
12 percent of the state's corn crop and only 1 percent of its pasture land are
in good condition.

In New Jersey, farmers are enduring financial hardships not seen 20 years. State
officials are estimating that damage to the state could reach $500 million
before the drought is over.

"Every day that this goes on, the losses grow exponentially," said a somber John
Rigolizzo Jr., president of the State Farm Bureau. "It's really stark. You see
burned-up fields up and down the state, just like toast."

Hay and field crops have nearly been destroyed by the dry spell and heat,
Rigolizzo said.

Fruit and vegetable growers have lost 25 percent to 50 percent of their crops,
he said, while grain and forage farmers have lost about half of their acreage to
the drought.

Rigolizzo said the conditions were so bad that it could take five or six years
before new peach and apple trees start producing fruit.

Farmers are already knee-deep in debt from last year's dry conditions, and
Rigolizzo said many had approached him about possibly asking lending
institutions to adjust their policies to take natural disasters into
consideration.

"Government works very slow," he said. "With [federal] assistance programs, it's
like a slow death. We need different forms of help. There are guys out there who
haven't received last year's aid. Now is the time to be looking for grants."

Virgil Eachus, a grain and dairy farmer who runs Wellacrest Farms Inc. in
Mullica Hill, will need at least $150,000 to break even this year. He is
ineligible to apply for federal loans, saying he is maxed out. "You can only
borrow so much," he said.

Eachus, 61, is counting on disaster-aid grants to get him through the year. The
fourth-generation farmer milks 300 cows and farms 1,500 acres of corn and
alfalfa, used mainly to feed the cows. This year, he won't have enough grain to
feed the cows and will have to buy corn to sustain his herd.

"We plant 930 acres of corn, and it is all burned up," he said. "It was too hot
to pollinate, and it didn't make any grain."

Severe weather and mounting debt have left Paul Hlubik, 39, disillusioned. He
farms more than 1,000 acres of grain and hay in Burlington, Monmouth, Mercer and
Ocean Counties. He said that 350 acres of crops were dead and that the rest were
producing about a third of what they normally would. He estimates he has lost
$100,000 to $200,000.

Making matters worse, Hlubik has found himself at an "unfair disadvantage" in
qualifying for federal assistance. He must be denied by his regular lender
before he can apply for federal low-interest loans. His good credit is working
against him.

"I'm not saying that I'm not grateful for the loans, because I am," he said.
"But a low-interest loan is not for everyone. It's for those who have been
denied by their regular lender."

Hlubik is grateful for one thing: He doesn't have children.

"If I had kids, I wouldn't want them to farm," he said. "And now I know why my
mom always pushed me away from it."

                            Buffalo News (New York)

                            WESTERN NEW YORK EDITION

LOCAL NEWS BRIEFS

SECTION: LOCAL; Local News Briefs; Pg. D3

LENGTH: 500 words


Loans offered to farmers to cover storm losses

Family farmers in Erie, Cattaraugus and Chautauqua counties have been declared
eligible for Farm Service Agency disaster emergency loan assistance to cover
damages and losses caused by the June 16 hail and wind storm.

Farmers who had at least 30 percent of their crops damaged or destroyed by hail,
winds or rain in the storm may be eligible for the emergency loans.

The interest rate is 3.75 percent. Farmers must be unable to obtain credit from
private commercial lenders to qualify.

Under the loan program, farmers may be eligible for production loss loans of up
to 100 percent of their actual losses, the operating loan needed to continue in
business or the maximum principal balance outstanding of $500,000, whichever is
the least.

Applications for the loans will be accepted until April 13. The FSA offic is
located at 3542 Turner Road, Jamestown 14701. For more information, call
664-2351.

***

State's senators secure rail and trail funding

JAMESTOWN -- The U.S. Department of Transportation is providing $640,000 for the
Jamestown Train Station and Riverwalk Connector Trail along the Chadakoin River.

"This is a huge victory for the future of the historic Jamestown Train Station,"
U.S. Sen. Charles Schumer said Friday when he and U.S. Sen. Hillary Rodham
Clinton announced the funding. "This much-needed project would revitalize the
region and reconnect it to its waterfront." "This investment is a tremendous
boost to the ongoing development in Jamestown," Clinton added. "The Intermodal
Center [train station] and Riverwalk Connector Trail will not only help to
revitalize Jamestown, but at a time of record ridership on public transit, this
project will help to modernize the transportation infrastructure in Jamestown to
help meet demand," she said.

***

Exhibit on African AIDS runs through Tuesday

JAMESTOWN -- Hillcrest Baptist Church and Bemus Point United Methodist Church,
in conjunction with the Jamestown Partnership, are sponsoring the "World Vision
Experience: AIDS" exhibit at the Jamestown Savings Bank Ice Arena today through
Tuesday.

The public is invited to go through the free, multimedia, interactive exhibit.
More than 200,000 people are expected to visit the exhibit during the 2007-08
tour.

The exhibit is a unique, multimedia, interactive exhibit that allows Americans
to step into the lives of children affected by HIV and AIDS in the hardest-hit
region of the world, Sub-Saharan Africa, where about 25 million people are
infected with HIV.

Visitors walk through a replica of an African village and experience the effects
of the disease in a real way as they listen to a personal audio track relating
the story of one of four children -- Kombo, Babirye, Emmanuel, and Mathabo.

The exhibit, which is slated to visit 80 cities during its national tour, will
be open to the public from 9 a.m. to 9 p.m. today; noon to 10 p.m. Sunday and 10
a.m. to 8 p.m. Monday and Tuesday. The exhibit will be at the ice arena, 318 W.

Golden Valley County in USDA designation

BYLINE: The Billings County Pioneer staff

LENGTH: 287  words


WASHINGTON - The U.S. Department of Agriculture has designated 22 counties in
Montana as primary natural disaster areas due to losses caused by severe winter
storms, blizzards, excessive moisture and flooding that began Jan. 1 and
continues. Some counties in North Dakota also qualify for assistance because
they are contiguous to the Montana counties.

Some of the Montana counties are: Dawson, Fallon and Wibaux.

Farmers and ranchers in the following counties in North Dakota and South Dakota
also qualify: North Dakota - Bowman, Golden Valley, McKenzie, Slope, Williams;
South Dakota - Butte and Harding. All counties listed above were designated on
Aug. 23, making all qualified farm operators in the designated areas eligible
for low interest emergency loans from USDA's Farm Service Agency, provided
eligibility requirements are met. Farmers in eligible counties have eight months
from the date of the declaration to apply for loans to help cover part of their
actual losses. FSA will consider each loan application on its own merits, taking
into account the extent of losses, security availability and repayment ability.
FSA has a variety of programs, in addition to the EM loan program, to help
eligible farmers recover.

USDA also has made other programs available to assist fanners and ranchers,
including the Supplemental Revenue Assistance Program (SURE), which was approved
as part of the Food, Conservation, and Energy Act of 2008: the Emergency
Conservation Program; Federal Crop Insurance; and the Noninsured Crop Disaster
Assistance Program. Interested farmers may contact their local USDA service
centers for further information on eligibility requirements and application
procedures for these and other programs.

                  The State Journal-Register (Springfield, IL)

                           February 27, 2001 Tuesday

Consultant doesn't see new farm bill until 2002

BYLINE: CHARLYN FARGO AGRIBUSINESS EDITOR

SECTION: MARKETPLACE; Pg. 27

LENGTH: 576 words


It will be spring 2002 before farmers see a farm bill out of Washington,
according to Jim Wiesemeyer.

Wiesemeyer, a consultant with Pro Farmer, spoke Monday at the 2001 Governmental
Affairs Leadership Conference of the Illinois Farm Bureau. The meeting continues
today at the Crowne Plaza Hotel.

"It just won't happen this year," Wiesemeyer said.

However, he said, with the number of senators and members of the Senate
Agriculture Committee up for re-election, he's pretty sure farmers will see a
farm bill next year.

Wiesemeyer said he often hears that the new farm bill will amount to $9 billion
more than the base for fiscal year 2001 and $9 billion to $12 billion for FY
2002.

"If they're successful, farmers will have to go to confession if they come back
for more emergency funding after that," Wiesemeyer said.

"The (current bill) has not been perfect, but it hasn't ever been allowed to
work. Going back and asking for $24 billion (in emergency funding) in the past
three years means the farm bill needs to be tweaked. It just hasn't been the
rousing success it could have been."

Debate on the 2002 farm bill has already begun. American Farm Bureau Federation
president Robert Stallman is expected to testify before the Senate Agriculture
Committee Wednesday.

Wiesemeyer expects next year's farm bill to keep the current bill's planting
flexibility as well as loans and market loan provisions.

New elements may include counter-cyclical payments for years when farm income
dips low, he said, adding that he expects renewable fuels such as ethanol to
play a big part, too. "Ethanol continues to be a motherhood-and-apple-pie
issue," said Wiesemeyer. "I see MTBE (a natural-gas-based fuel additive)
eventually being phased out, and that will be beneficial for ethanol. If there's
a growth industry, it's ethanol."

Ron Warfield, president of the Illinois Farm Bureau, said the group's long-term
objective is for farmers to receive income from the marketplace rather than from
the government.

"If we had an energy policy that promoted renewable fuels, we wouldn't need to
spend the baseline of the farm program," said Warfield. "The same thing with our
trade policy. If we're aggressive with a trade policy, we won't be needing farm
income from the government. But in the meantime, we need money there to prop up
income levels for farmers."

Warfield also believes farmers need to sell value-added products in the
marketplace and to have voluntary incentives in place for conservation of land.
"Give us the right incentives and producers will provide clean air, clean water
and soil conservation," said Warfield. "My challenge is to put the emphasis
where it should be - to get income from the marketplace. But so far, we've not
had the farm policies to do that."

This year, however, because of continued low commodity prices and rising
production costs, the American Farm Bureau and 22 other farm groups have asked
congressional leaders for increased emergency funding.

In a Feb. 6 letter to House Agriculture Committee chairman Larry Combest,
R-Texas, and the Senate committee chairman, Richard Lugar, R-Ind., the farm
groups asked them to urge the House and Senate budget committees to provide
additional agricultural funding "equal to at least the same level of emergency
economic loss assistance" that was provided for the 2000 crop. The requested
funding would be in addition to Congressional Budget Office projections for farm
program outlays.

                     Deseret Morning News (Salt Lake City)

                            July 23, 2014 Wednesday

Farmers in 5 Utah counties qualify for drought aid

LENGTH: 246 words


WASHINGTON, D.C. - Wasatch County farmers are eligible for disaster assistance
as the U.S. Department of Agriculture has designated the county as a primary
natural disaster area due to recent drought.

Farmers and ranchers in Duchesne, Salt Lake, Summit and Utah counties also
qualify for assistance because they border Wasatch County.

"Our hearts go out to those Utah farmers and ranchers affected by recent natural
disasters," said Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack.

"We're also telling Utah producers that USDA stands with you and your
communities when severe weather and natural disasters threaten to disrupt your
livelihood."

All five counties were designated natural disaster areas last week, making all
qualified farm operators in the designated areas eligible for low interest
emergency loans from USDA's Farm Service Agency.

Farmers in eligible counties have eight months from the date of the declaration,
which was July 16, to apply for loans to help cover part of their actual losses.

Additional programs available to assist farmers and ranchers include the
Emergency Conservation Program, The Livestock Forage Disaster Program, the
Livestock Indemnity Program, the Emergency Assistance for Livestock, Honeybees,
and Farm-Raised Fish Program, and the Tree Assistance Program.

Interested farmers can contact local USDA service centers for further
information on eligibility requirements and application procedures. Additional
information is available at disaster.fsa.usda.gov.

                    The Wilson Daily Times (North Carolina)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                          September 21, 2013 Saturday

Wilson, other counties receive disaster declaration

BYLINE: The Wilson Daily Times, N.C.

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 632 words


Sept. 21--Wilson County is one of 13 counties in North Carolina designated as a
primary natural disaster area due to damages and losses caused by excessive rain
and flooding this year.

The other counties are Avery, Cleveland, Henderson, Rutherford, Brunswick,
Columbus, Madison, Transylvania, Buncombe, Durham, Orange and Watauga.

The designation was declared by the U.S. Department of Agriculture.

In early June, Wilson County some farmers had one of the prettiest crops started
that growers had seen in years. Wilson County fared OK when a tropical storm
blew through in early June. But after the tropical storm, it kept raining and
raining.

Officials said during a two-week period in late June into early July, Wilson
County received rain 12 out of 14 days. The county received two to three times
the normal amount of rainfall for this time of year limiting growers in what
they could do.

Some operations came to almost a complete standstill.

Farmers and ranchers in these additional counties in North Carolina also qualify
for natural disaster assistance because their counties are contiguous. Those
counties are: Alamance, Chatham, Jackson, New Hanover, Robeson, Ashe, Edgecombe,
Johnston, Pender, Wake, Bladen, Gaston, Lincoln, Person, Wayne, Burke,
Granville, McDowell, Pitt, Wilkes, Caldwell, Greene, Mitchell, Polk, Yancey,
Caswell, Haywood and Nash.

All counties listed above were designated natural disaster areas Sept. 18, 2013,
making all qualified farm operators in the designated areas eligible for low
interest emergency loans from USDA's Farm Service Agency (FSA), provided
eligibility requirements are met.

Farmers in eligible counties have eight months from the date of the declaration
to apply for loans to help cover part of their actual losses. FSA will consider
each loan application on its own merits, taking into account the extent of
losses, security available and repayment ability. FSA has a variety of programs,
in addition to the EM loan program, to help eligible farmers recover.

Additional programs available to assist farmers and ranchers include the
Emergency Conservation Program, Federal Crop Insurance, and the Noninsured Crop
Disaster Assistance Program. Interested farmers may contact their local USDA
Service Centers for further information on eligibility requirements and
application procedures. Additional information is also available online at
http://disaster.fsa.usda.gov.

"Our hearts go out to those North Carolina farmers and ranchers affected by
recent natural disasters," said Tom Vilsack, federal agriculture secretary, in a
statement. "President Obama and I are committed to ensuring that agriculture
remains a bright spot in our nation's economy by sustaining the successes of
America's farmers, ranchers and rural communities through these difficult times.
We're also telling North Carolina producers that USDA stands with you and your
communities when severe weather and natural disasters threaten to disrupt your
livelihood."

Vilsack also reminds producers that Congress has not funded the five disaster
assistance programs authorized by the 2008 Farm Bill. These are SURE; the
Livestock Indemnity Program (LIP); the Emergency Assistance for Livestock, Honey
Bees, and Farm-Raised Fish (ELAP); the Livestock Forage Disaster Program (LFP);
and the Tree Assistance Program (TAP). Production losses due to disasters
occurring after Sept. 30, 2011, are not eligible for disaster program coverage.

Contact the Wilson County FSA office at (252) 237-5147, ext. 2 or visit the
Office located at 1806 Goldsboro Street, SW, Wilson, NC for additional
information concerning FSA programs and opportunities.

                                 The Bond Buyer

Senate Set to Debate Legislation to Aid Banks With Heavy Farm, Energy Loans

                            March 27, 1986, Thursday

By Joan Pryde

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 26


The Senate late today was poised to consider legislation that would put into law
an initiative by federal regulators to aid troubled commercial banks with large
amounts of agricultural and energy loans.

The desire of many farm state senators up for re-election this year to pass an
aid bill was expected to smooth the way for passage, but a last-minute snag may
have developed that may not allow the bill to come up before the Senate leaves
for its weeklong Easter recess. The recess is scheduled to begin tomorrow.

An aide to Senate majority leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., said, ''A lot of senators
are looking at it'' and want to consider the bill more carefully before voting
on it. ''It's not likely it will come up before we leave,'' the aide said.

The legislation, which the Senate Banking Committee approved late Tuesday,
applies to federally insured commercial banks that have loans to farms, or to
oil and gas companies, in excess of 25% of their total outstanding debt.

The bill would codify actions the regulators - the Federal Reserve, the
Comptroller of the Currency, and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. - announced
March 11, including allowing troubled agriculture banks to operate below minimum
capital requirements and encouraging banks to stick with troubled farm loans and
restructure farmers' debts. In addition, the bill endorses a little-used
provision in federal financial accounting standards that allows troubled banks
to account for renegotiated loans so they are not immediately recorded as
losses.

After the committee approved the bill, an FDIC official said in a brief
interview that the regulatory agencies continue to believe legislation was not
necessary to implement their plan, but the agencies had worked with the
committee to get as much flexibility for themselves as possible in implementing
the law.

Treasury assistant secretary for finance Charles O. Sethness said although the
Reagan administration had been ''part of the process'' in developing the
legislation, ''it would be best to leave it at no comment'' as to whether the
Treasury supported the bill.

In its action Tuesday, the committee added a provision to the bill that extends
for three months a law allowing the emergency acquisition of failed banks and
savings and loans with assets of more than $500 million by out-of-state
institutions. The law currently is set to expire April 15.

One sticking point to Senate passage of the bill is a provision the committee
added that would place a moratorium on approvals by federal regulators of
applications to set up limited-service banks. The provision apparently was added
because of concern that a court-ordered injunction against such approval by the
Comptroller of the Currency may be lifted soon.

Another hurdle is the possibility that Sen. Phil Gramm, R-Tex., a member of the
banking committee, will seek to amend the emergency-acquisition law by making it
include banks that have incurred heavy losses but have not failed and by
lowering the minimum assets of troubled banks covered by the law. The senator
unsuccessfully tried to add his amendment during the committee's consideration
of the bill Tuesday.

Late today, an aide to Mr. Gramm said it was not likely the senator would try to
add his amendment when the Senate considers the bill because he had received
assurances from the committee leadership they would consider the question of
expanding the emergency-acquisition law during the next three months, if the
bill is extended.

In fact, Sen. Jake Garn, R-Utah, the banking panel chairman, said during the
committee's consideration of the aid bill he hoped to have a ''comprehensive''
banking bill ready for the committee's consideration in late May. ''I may not be
able to achieve that, but that's my goal at this point,'' the senator said.

Mr. Garn said that bill can be expected to include provisions for deposit
insurance reform and a longer-term extension of the emergency acquisition law.
Mr. Garn also has repeatedly said he hopes to include expanded powers for banks
in such a bill.

                                    The Land

                            March 19, 2015 Thursday

Major parties deal with drought

BYLINE: JESSIE DAVIES

SECTION: EARLY GENERAL NEWS; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 577 words


AS DROUGHT rolls on in the North West and with no decent rain in sight,
assistance will be top of mind for many farmers heading to the polls on March
28.

The Coalition has released a drought preparedness package totalling $300
million, funded from existing revenue, but Labor is yet to release costings of
its policies, which feature a return to drought declarations and a large
investment in water infrastructure.

Low-interest loans

THE centrepiece of the government's policy is a $250m package for low-interest
loans, plus $45m for vocational training and farm business planning to prepare
for future droughts.

The loans cover the cost of permanent capital works which will have a
significant benefit to land, long-term profitability of the enterprise and
address adverse seasonal conditions.

They cover up to 100 per cent of the net cost of the works to a maximum of
$250,000, with a total of $250,000 outstanding at any one time.

The interest rate for the loans is administered by the Rural Assistance
Authority and depends on when the loan is approved and is fixed thereafter.

Primary Industries Minister Katrina Hodgkinson said more than 300 loans,
totalling $40m, had been approved under the program to date.

Labor primary industries spokes- man Steve Whan said the low-interest loans
championed by the Coalition could not be accessed by some of the hardest-hit
farmers ("Focus on Ag Policy", March 5, 2015).

"There are farmers in the north of the state who can't afford to access the
low-interest loans," Mr Whan said.

Water infrastructure

THE Coalition has delivered an extra $20m towards the funding of its Emergency
Water Infrastructure Rebate (EWIR) scheme, which had become fully subscribed in
July, 2014.

The federal government has announced an additional $3m from its coffers for the
scheme.

The EWIR is a temporary rebate for up to 50pc of the cost of purchase and
installation of emergency water infrastructure, capped at $20,000.

To be eligible, farm businesses are required to be experiencing a one-in-50-year
rainfall deficiency or worse.

Eligibility will be determined by the Bureau of Meteorology's rainfall
deficiency ranking system, which classifies where there has been less rainfall
over 12 and 24 months in the latest two years, compared with similar periods
over the historical period since 1900.

Ms Hodgkinson said the program had a finite amount of funding and needed to be
shared as equitably as possible across all farmers in the state.

Almost $35m had already been delivered under EWIR to more than 2900 farm
businesses since November, 2013.

An extra $2.5m has been allocated to enhance the network of weather stations
across the state, which is aimed at increasing the accuracy of the data gathered
by the bureau.

Labor said if elected, it would match the Coalition's $20m water infrastructure
scheme.

Transport subsidies

THE Coalition is providing $5m across five years for transport assistance for
animal welfare and donated fodder within NSW.

Labor will fund up to 50pc of stock, fodder and transport costs to a maximum of
$20,000 a year for farmers in drought for nine months or more.

Labor has not yet released the total cost of its policy.

Ms Hodgkinson said the Coalition's transport subsidies were more equitable than
the previous scheme, which during the millennium drought delivered $169m to
fewer than 25pc of eligible producers.

Mr Whan said the Coalition's policy excluded the assistance farmers needed to
keep their core breeding stock alive.

                      Times of India (Electronic Edition)

                            August 6, 2014 Wednesday
                               hyderabad Edition

No merit in AP, T loan waiver call: RBI guv

SECTION: THE TIMES OF INDIA

LENGTH: 814 words


Reserve Bank of India governor Raghuram Rajan on Tuesday indicated that
conditions for farm loan waiver in Andhra Pradesh and Telangana have not been
met and has warned against `moral hazard' brought about by such promises. RBI
has said that harvest data disproves claims made by both states and it is now
asking them, "where is the distress?" Speaking on the issue during his
bi-monthly monetary policy announcement here, Rajan said, "We have been quite
categorical on talking about waivers because it creates the possibility that
anticipating such waivers, the ultimate beneficiaries and those who think

they may have a chance of benefiting will stop paying."

He added that RBI had got some assurance that the scheme will not reward
nonpayers and won't encourage `moral hazard'. "But right now there is no scheme
on the table. I think there are statements and discussions but nothing has been
concrtetised," said Rajan.

According to the gover

nor, the central bank's master circular allows some loans to be restructured if
there is catastrophic weather or other damage. "Typically a rule of thumb has
been, if yields fall or are anticipated to fall below 50%, the district
collector can declare a state of emergency which triggers the possibilty of loan
restructruing," said Rajan. He added that while

such restructuring is voluntary for banks, RBI relaxes regulations and does not
force banks to treat them as non-performing assets.

"What has happened in AP and Telangana is that because of a variety of factors
no such emergency was declared and no request for restructuring was made and
subsequent to that we have had the full harvest come in.In this situation we had
the harvest after cylcone Phalin, so we asked for the numbers and are looking at
them. Prima facie it does not look like any of the districts have met the 50%
criteria," said Rajan. He added that while this was not a hard and fast rule
this was a rule of thumb adopted by RBI.

We are in discussion with the state governments to ask where exactly is the
distress, so that we can take more reasoned and focused view. It does not appear
to be from the production data that the cyclone had caused widespread damage,
but we need the governments to tell us how a more focused assessment can be
made," said Rajan.

The governor's statement comes at a time when banks are seeing rising defaults
in agri loans in AP and Telangana. Andhra Bank last week reported a 54% drop in
net profit last week after agri NPAs tripled following non-payment by farmers in
anticipation of a loan waiver.

However, both AP and Telangana said they will go ahead with the loan waiver even
if the RBI does not back it and urged the farmers not to panic due to the RBI's
stance.

"Crop loss due to Phailin is not the only factor for us to announce the loan
waiver.There were several other fac

tors including the low market rate after the crop was raised.Besides, it was a
poll promise and the TRS government intends to honour it. In fact, the RBI does
not know the ground reality. We will produce photographs and video of damaged
crops and convince the RBI governor. The farmers need not panic," said Telangana
chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao in reaction to the RBI governor's statement
while addressing a rally in Karimnagar on Tuesday evening.

On its part, AP disputed the RBI's assertion that there was no crop damage last
year

and before that. "Unseasonal rains and two cyclones \xAD Laila (May 2010), Jal
(Nov . 2010) hit the state in 2010-11. There was severe drought in 2011-12
affecting 22 out of the 23 districts. During 2012-13, cyclone Nilam (Nov . 2012
affected many districts and caused extensive damage. In 2013-14, there was
severe drought as well as unseasonal rains/cyclones in succession \xAD Phailin,
Helen and Lehar (Oct-Nov 2013) causing undue hardship to the farming community
," the AP government said in a letter to the RBI on Tuesday .AP government
sources too urged the farmers not to pan

ic and said it intends to honour its poll promise.

During the recent Assembly and general elections, Chandrababu Naidu and
Chandrasekhar Rao had promised farm loan waivers.While the farm loan waiver bill
in AP is pegged at Rs 87,000 crore, it is over Rs 40,000 crore in the new state.
On the massive non-payment problems in AP and Telangana, Rajan said even if some
package gets announced, the RBI will make sure that the nonpayers do not
benefit.

The AP government had last month announced that it would waive farm loans of up
to Rs 1.5 lakh per family , a move that is likely to result in a financial
burden of Rs 35,000 crore on the cashstarved state exchequer.

In addition, the government also decided to write off loans amounting to Rs
7,600 crore given to women selfhelp groups (SHGs). Another Rs 300 crore loans
given to weavers, scheduled castes and other small artisans, too would be
waived, chief minister Chandrababu Naidu had said.

                         Albert Lea Tribune (Minnesota)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                              July 12, 2013 Friday

USDA declares Freeborn County as disaster area

BYLINE: Sarah Stultz, Albert Lea Tribune, Minn.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 412 words


July 12--Farmers eligible for low-interest loans

Qualified Freeborn County farmers who suffered damages or losses because of
weather-related conditions earlier this year are now eligible for low-interest
emergency loans from the U.S. Department of Agriculture.

The USDA this week designated 20 counties in Minnesota -- including Freeborn,
Faribault, Mower and Steele counties -- as primary natural disaster areas
because of the combined effects of heavy rainfall followed by freezing
temperatures and multiple periods of thawing and refreezing from Jan. 1 through
May 15.

"Our hearts go out to those Minnesota farmers and ranchers affected by recent
natural disasters," said Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack. "President Obama and
I are committed to ensuring that agriculture remains a bright spot in our
nation's economy by sustaining the successes of America's farmers, ranchers and
rural communities through these difficult times."

Farmers in Worth and Winnebago counties in Iowa also qualify for natural
disaster assistance because their counties are contiguous.

The assistance will come from the USDA's Farm Service Agency provided
eligibility requirements are met.

The farmers in eligible counties have eight months from July 10 to apply for
loans to help cover part of their actual losses. The Farm Service Agency will
take into account the extent of losses, security available and repayment
ability.

Additional programs to assist farmers and ranchers are the Emergency
Conservation Program, Federal Crop Insurance and the Noninsured Crop Disaster
Assistance Program.

"I am happy to see the Department of Agriculture stepping up for our
communities," said District 27 Sen. Dan Sparks. "This will be very beneficial to
many Minnesota families."

He said as the chairman of the Agriculture Committee in the Senate, he has heard
from many farming families that were hit hard by the tough conditions.

"It was a long and difficult winter and spring for Minnesota farmers."

Farmers can contact their local USDA service centers for further information on
eligibility requirements and application procedures. Or people can go online to
http://disaster.fsa.usda.gov.

Freeborn County is also seeking a presidential disaster declaration for damages
sustained to public infrastructure from storms and flooding June 20-26.

                              Delaware State News

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           September 18, 2007 Tuesday

Delaware farmers eligible for emergency drought loans

BYLINE: Nora Engel, Delaware State News, Dover

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 471 words


Sep. 18--DOVER -- For many people, a dark gray cloud followed by a heavy
downpour of rain would ruin a nice summer afternoon.

However, such a day would have been cause for celebration for local farmers this
past season.

"The drought was devastating. I suffered a 90 percent reduction of my corn and
soybean crops," said Richard Wilkins, a farmer from Harrington and board member
of the Kent County Farm Bureau. "Not in recent memory have I suffered such a
loss."

Wilkins said he was grateful to have crop insurance, although he said it won't
make up completely for the loss.

He said it will pay the difference between what he actually has and 70 percent
of what a normal crop would have been.

The farmers who did not invest in crop insurance might be happy to learn that
the U.S. Department of Agriculture Secretary Mike Johanns approved Gov. Ruth Ann
Minner's request to issue a drought disaster designation as a result of
significant crop losses due to the drought.

This means Delaware farmers will be eligible for low-interest emergency loans
from the Farm Service Agency.

A bad crop season not only impacts farmers, but also the poultry industry.

According to figures from the Delmarva Poultry Industry, 78 million bushels of
corn and 28 million bushels of soybeans were needed in 2006 to feed chickens on
Delmarva.

The trade group's figures said last year's feed bill on Delmarva totaled more
than $518 million.

It said Delmarva-produced chicken is shipped to nearly three dozen states and
many foreign nations.

Wilkins said farmers without crop insurance will probably need to apply for a
loan and should apply for crop insurance next year.

"You have to have water for the plants to grow, and this past season those of us
who don't have an irrigation system had a substantial loss," he said.

"A lot of the hay fields died from lack of moisture. And we had some problems
with spider mites in the soybeans. We tried to use treatments but they just
couldn't withstand the dry heat."

The USDA determined that all three counties in the state qualified as a primary
natural disaster area due to crop losses from heat and drought.

Wilkins said he wanted to buy an irrigation system this year, but because of his
recent financial loss, he said he will have to put that plan on hold for another
year.

For more information on the drought declaration or the low-interest emergency
loans, contact the Farm Service Agency at 678-4250.

                                August 31, 2012

FSA provides assistance to livestock producers

BYLINE: Hidalgo County Herald staff

LENGTH: 291  words


Lawrence Rael, State Executive Director for the New Mexico State Farm Service
Agency (FSA) today announced that special provisions will made to the FSA
emergency loan program and to the Risk Management Agency (RMA) federal crop
insurance program in order to provide greater flexibility for livestock
producers facing forage and feed shortages as a resalt of drought.

On August 22, 2012, Secretary Vilsack announced that modifications will be made
to the emergency loan program allowing them to be made earlier in the season. In
the past, emergency loan eligibility was determined after the production cycle.
Producers will no longer have to wait until the end of the production cycle to
obtain a loan. This change will support producers who currently need assistance
to help offset high production costs.

Vilsack also announced that a special provision will be made to the federal crop
insurance program through RMA that will allow producers to hay or graze cover
crops without forfeiting crop insurance eligibility on planted 2013 spring
crops. This change is beneficial to livestock producers making forage and feed
available this fall and winter. However, before making any plans to plant crop
cover, producers should consult with their insurance agent, according to RMA.

"Adding more flexibility to current program requirements will make much needed
assistance more readily available to producers affected by disaster," said Rael.
"These changes in particular should benefit livestock producers who are facing
higher feed costs or are at risk of liquidating their herd due to the drought,"
he said.

For more information regarding special provisions to the emergency loan program,
please contact your local County FSA office or visit www.fsa.usda.gov

                            September 5, 2014 Friday

Durbin, Kirk Announce Federal Disaster Declaration In Six Eastern Illinois
Counties

LENGTH: 288  words

DATELINE: Washington


Office of the Senator Dick Durbin, U.S Government has issued the following news
release:

U.S. Senators Dick Durbin (D-IL) and Mark Kirk (R-IL) today announced that the
U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) has declared six counties in Eastern
Illinois federal disaster areas following severe hail storms on May 21st that
damaged the region's strawberry crop. Today's declaration ensures that farmers
in Vermilion, Champaign, Douglas, Edgar, Ford and Iroquois counties will be
eligible to apply for loans from the Farm Service Agency (FSA), a division of
the USDA.

"Today's federal disaster declaration will help Illinois farmers whose
strawberry crops were destroyed by severe, powerful hail early this summer. This
declaration will give a helping hand to farmers whose crops are wiped out due to
extreme weather and forces outside their control," Durbin said.

"Having seen firsthand the damage a natural disaster can cause families and
farmers in a small town, I applaud the Department of Agriculture for making this
opportunity available to our Illinois farmers," Senator Kirk said. "This
declaration will provide needed economic relief to those whose strawberry crops
were affected by May's hail storm."

Though the storm severely damaged strawberry fields, farmers are eligible to
apply for loans no matter what crop they grow. Farmers in the affected counties
will have eight months to apply for emergency loans from the FSA. FSA considers
each emergency loan application on its own merits, taking into account the
extent of production losses on the farm, and the security and repayment ability
of the operator.

                           Grand Haven Tribune, Mich.

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           December 11, 2010 Saturday

Disaster designation for Ottawa County over spring freeze, crop loss

BYLINE: Mark Brooky, Grand Haven Tribune, Mich.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 533 words


Dec. 11--Ottawa County farmers may be eligible for emergency federal loans to
recoup losses related to a spring chill.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture announced Friday that it has designated 32
Michigan counties as primary natural disaster areas due to losses caused by
frost and freezing weather that occurred March 1 through May 16.

Carlos Garcia-Salazar, a small-fruit educator for the Michigan State University
Extension office in Ottawa County, said some fields in the county at the
beginning of the growing season were seriously affected by frost.

"Especially those related to early-season varieties," he said. "Some had 20- to
30-percent losses in some cases."

Bill Smith, the county's emergency services manager, said the USDA's
designations of disaster areas often lag behind the actual event for many
months. In this case, he said the agency waits until after harvest time for
evaluation of the impact from an event to "compare what should have been and the
end-results."

"President Obama and I understand these conditions caused severe damage to field
crops as well as a wide variety of specialty fruit and vegetable crops, and we
want to help," U.S. Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack said in Friday's press
release. "This action will provide help to hundreds of farmers who suffered
significant production losses."

Muskegon, Kent and Allegan counties were also named as primary natural disaster
areas for the frost and freeze period.

Sue McIntosh of the USDA's office in Grand Haven Township said farmers who can
document crop production losses of at least 30 percent during the period should
apply for the emergency loans from the federal department's Farm Service Agency.
The loans can be used to restore or replace property associated with the
disaster period, and can sometimes refinance debt, McIntosh explained. Producers
can borrow up to $500,000 in actual production or physical losses at a
3.75-percent interest rate.

The local Farm Service Agency office can be reached at 842-5852.

In a separate announcement on Friday, the USDA designated 36 Michigan counties
-- as well as extreme northern Indiana and Ohio -- as primary natural disaster
areas due to losses from severe storms "that began Jan. 22 and continues." While
Ottawa County was not named as a primary area, farmers and ranchers in the
county may be eligible for loans for that designation because Ottawa County is
adjacent to three counties that were named primary areas: Muskegon, Kent and
Allegan.

In a third disaster area designation announcement on Friday, the USDA said it
will make emergency loans available for 21 Michigan counties, two northern
Indiana counties and a small portion of Wisconsin for "unseasonably warm late
winter and early spring temperatures that began Jan. 1." West Michigan was not
included in that designation.

Online:

http://disaster.fsa.usda.gov

                              Chicago Daily Herald

                            July 20, 2005 Wednesday
                           Lake Edition; Cook Edition

Land's dry, and the crops are in trouble Farmers soon may need to ask for aid

BYLINE: Mick Zawislak, Daily Herald Staff Writer

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 450 words


Searing heat and drought conditions are wrecking Lake County crops, scorching
corn from the ground up and causing thirsty spider mites to attack soybeans.

The conditions are intensifying at a crucial time when corn is pollinating to
form kernels on the cob and soybeans have begun to flower. At this point, half
the crop may be lost and farm bureau officials are exploring extraordinary
measures to seek relief for farmers.

"I honestly can't tell you what's keeping it going," said Pete Tekampe, Fremont
Township supervisor, who farms 750 acres of corn. "I don't know if we're going
to get any pollination."

An assessment last week showed as much as half of the corn and 40 percent of
Lake County's soybean crops are damaged.

Soybeans are just coming into blossom, but spider mites are invading the plants
seeking what little moisture is available.

"It just looks awful. The outlook for our crop this season is bleak," said Greg
Koeppen, Lake County Farm Bureau manager. He said Lake County is among the worst
hit in a widening drought affecting Illinois and parts of Iowa, Indiana and
Wisconsin.

"I describe our corn field in Lake County like a pineapple field in Hawaii," he
said. Corn should be 6 feet tall by now but is far short. "The leaves are
turning brown and dying. It's called firing."

Like his counterparts in many other counties, Koeppen already has applied for
low-interest loans from the U.S. Department of Agriculture. He also has been
talking with Lake County's Emergency Management Agency regarding other options.

That agency is best known for assisting in floods, tornadoes and other natural
disasters.

"If there's another avenue, I'm going to find it," said Dave Christensen,
director of the county's Emergency Management Agency. "But everything I've been
told by the state is we're following the protocol."

Koeppen contacted Christensen after learning of Will County's "proclamation of
agricultural emergency" issued Tuesday. That asks the Illinois Emergency
Management Agency to ask the federal government for grants and loans.

Christensen said he was uncertain whether anything beyond the normal channels
was available, and that Will County's action was more to bring attention to the
problem.

Besides farmers, the drought is causing private wells to dry up, he said, adding
another layer of concern.

Meanwhile, Lake County farmers like Scott Petersen are trying to buck up,
knowing the best seed, equipment and care means little at this point.

"It kind of takes the steam out of you," said Petersen, whose family has been
farming for generations and currently cultivates about 1,600 acres.

"It's just Mother Nature threw us a curve we can't dodge," he said.

"We'll make it. We'll never give up."

                                January 7, 2010

County designated natural disaster area;
Farmers eligible for assistance programs

BYLINE: BY BRAD DEVEREAUX

LENGTH: 779  words


The U.S. Department of Agriculture designated Big Horn and Park Counties in
Wyoming as a primary natural disaster area due to losses caused by an early
freeze that occurred during the period of Oct. 6-13, 2009.

Farm operators in Fremont, Johnson, Teton, Hot Springs, Sheridan and Washakie
counties in Wyoming also qualify for natural disaster assistance because their
counties are contiguous along with Big Horn, Carbon, Gallatin and Park counties
in Montana.

All counties listed above were designated natural disaster areas Monday, Jan. 4,
2010, making all qualified farm operators in the designated areas eligible for
low interest emergency (EM) loans from USDA's Farm Service Agency (FSA), if
eligibility requirements are met.

Farmers in eligible counties have eight months from the date of the declaration
to apply for loans to help cover part of their actual losses. FSA will consider
each loan application on its own merits, taking into account the extent of
losses, security available and repayment ability. FSA has variety of programs,
in addition to the EM loan program, to help eligible farmers recover from
adversity.

USDA has also made other programs available to assist farmers and ranchers,
including the Supplemental Revenue Assistance Program (SURE), which was approved
as part of the Food, Conservation and Energy Act of 2008; the Emergency
Conservation Program; Federal Crop Insurance; and the Nonin-sured Crop Disaster
Assistance Program (NAP).

To be eligible for SURE, farmers must have every insurable crop on their farm
insured with federal insurance, according to Bryan Schoenfelder of the BHCFSA
office in Greybull. Farmers will not be eligible to sign up for SURE in regard
to losses incurred in 2009 until the fall of 2010, he said, because the program
looks at national averages that are calculated after the entire crop is sold.

Interested farmers may contact the Big Horn County FSA Office at (307) 765-2663
for further information on eligibility requirements and application procedures
for SURE and other programs. Additional information is also available online at:
http://disaster.fsa.usda. gov.

For more information on EM loans, Lovell area farmers should contact the farm
loan department at the Park County FSA office in Powell at 754-9411.

REQUESTING THE DECLARATION

The Big Horn County Commissioners voted Tuesday, Oct. 20, 2009, to send a letter
and resolution to Governor Dave Freudenthal seeking a disaster declaration to
assist sugar beet, dry beans and alfalfa seed growers.

In a letter dated Oct. 23, Gov. Freudenthal asked Secretary of Agriculture
Thomas Vilsack for assistance in securingan agri-business disaster designation
in Big Horn, Park, Platte and Sheridan Counties.

Gov. Freudenthal released a statement Monday, thanking Vilsack for approving the
disaster declaration request the governor made in October.

"Secretary Vilsack's action restores some measure of confidence to agricultural
producers in Wyoming that suffered from severe weather in 2009," the governor
said.

"We were pained to watch, week after week in late 2009, the unfolding problems
with the sugar beet harvest in the Big Horn Basin. A harvest estimated to be the
largest ever was decimated by a freeze in early October," the Governor said.
"These disaster declarations are only one step in a long process of recovery for
many farmers in the state. But they represent an important step, which opens
doors for affected producers to begin seeking federal aid."

The USDA also declared Platte County in southeast Wyoming a primary natural
disaster area after hailstorms caused widespread damage to crops in the county.
Albany, Converse, Goshen, Laramie and Niobrara counties have been named
contiguous disaster counties.

Senator John Barras-so (R-Wyo.) issued a statement Tuesday regarding the
disaster declaration.

"The USDA's disaster designation recognizes that farmers and ranchers in the Big
Horn Basin faced tough times in 2009. Severe frosts in early October have taken
a significant toll on Wyoming producers," Barrasso said. "I'm pleased to see
that farmers and ranchers in the designated counties will get the help they
need,"

Ric Rodriguez, a Park County farmer and the vice chairman of the Western Sugar
Board of Directors, said he didn't know much about the emergency loan programs
Tuesday, but added, "anything is going to help."

He said it has been difficult for Lovell district farmers this year. However,
refined sugar has been selling at estimated record bulk prices of $38 to $40 per
ton, Rodriguez said, which will help farmers receive solid payments for the
beets they were able to harvest. He said two years ago, refined sugar was
selling in the $25 range.

                              The American Banker

WASHINGTON WATCH: IBAA Lends a Hand To Victims of Flooding

                             July 16, 1993, Friday

By BILL ATKINSON


THE INDEPENDENT BANKERS Association of America and five affiliated state banking
trade groups are recruiting members to bail out flood victims in the Midwest.

The bankers are helping farmers, business owners, and homeowners whose property
has been damaged by the flood fill out complicated government forms to get
federal disaster relief.

"We decided we should move ahead and do something to help out," said IBAA
president James R. Lauffer, chairman and chief executive of First National Bank
of Herminie, Irwin, Pa. "This is a case of neighbor helping neighbor."

The effort, dubbed "Operation Good Neighbor," began a week ago when the
Washington-based trade group started working with its Wisconsin affiliate. From
there the effort expanded to Illinois, Iowa, Minnesota, and Missouri.

The IBAA is supplying its affiliates with phone numbers of disaster field
offices set up by the government and the names of the people running the
offices. It has also provided the Federal Emergency Management Agency and the
Small Business Administration with the names and phone numbers of its
affiliates.

"What we are trying to do is get our people in the field as much information as
possible," said Herb Spira, the IBAA's tax specialist.

In Wisconsin, about a dozen bankers have signed on to help, said Heidi Sabel,
spokeswoman for the Independent Community Bankers Association of Wisconsin.

Ms. Sabel said the trade group sent out facsimile messages to members last week,
notifying them that the SBA was looking for bankers to process loans.

"It's more of a service to them (government officials), so they don't have to go
out knocking on doors," she said.

Ms. Sabel said more bankers are likely to join the effort, and more may have
already been recruited by government officials. The affiliates are looking for
bankers who can quickly help flood victims fill out federal loan applications to
get funds to the hardest-hit areas.

There are several kinds of loans available to flood victims, including
low-interest SBA loans to repair houses, rebuild and restart businesses, and
repair public facilities.  Alternatives for Family Farmers

Family farmers can also apply for low-interest Farmers Home Loan Administration
emergency farm loans, 20-year farm loans at 4.5% interest to cover crop losses,
and for loan forgiveness up to $300,000.

Ronald Ence, the IBAA's director of agricultural finance, who spends about 25%
of his time on the project, said filling out the forms is a daunting task. And
answers from the government can take weeks or months when there are mistakes.

"If you are not used to dealing with federal red tape and federal requirements,
it (filling out the forms) can really be a scary situation," he said. "The
bankers are able to cut through mistakes and get the application completed."

                              The Washington Post

                   November 14, 1981, Saturday, Final Edition

Farm Bill Gets New Provisions;
Conferees Support Embargo Protections 6

BYLINE: By Ward Sinclair, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: First Section; A2

LENGTH: 639 words


Warnings echoed that they were going too far, but congressional conferees backed
a series of steps yesterday to protect farmers from export embargoes, elevator
bankruptcies and economic emergencies.

The big addition to the new farm bill, still several days from completion, was a
plan that could cost as much as $30 billion if a major agricultural embargo were
declared.

That provision, along with an emergency loan program that was reauthorized,
brought new warnings that a final version of the four-year bill will meet
additional resistance in Congress and at the White House over money and policy
issues.

The conference chairman, Sen. Jesse Helms (R-N.C.), said he was increasingly
concerned and that the conferees may have to go back and scale down other
program costs.

Added Sen. Robert J. Dole (R-Kan.): "We have to get the genie back in the bottle
. . . . We have got to take another look at sugar, peanuts, sunflowers and so
forth."

The White House has indicated it wants a bill that costs less than the Senate
version, but the conferees have added about $250 million in commodity outlays
over the life of the bill, according to the Agriculture Department.

The newest element of budgetary concern arose yesterday with a one-year
extension of loan guarantees up to $600 million for farm emergencies, under a
proposal by Sen. Thad Cochran (R-Miss.).

The administration's representative at the conference, USDA economist William
Lesher, told the conferees they were "adding another problem" to the bill with
the extended credit scheme.

Costs of that program, however, would be minimal compared with the potential
expense of the embargo protections. Lesher said the administration wasn't
concerned, repeating its pledge never to impose a selective embargo on
agricultural exports.

But the conferees, recalling similar pledges from the Carter administration
before its partial embargo on grain sales to the Soviet Union, were buying no
promises.

They argued bitterly among themselves for several days, then yesterday bought a
Senate provision that would require loans and direct payments to farmers if any
major agricultural embargo were declared for national security or foreign policy
reasons.

That action came in the wake of two Senate votes late Thursday on trade
embargoes. One would give Congress 60 days to veto any selective embargoes after
1984. The other would authorize a total trade embargo in the event of Soviet or
Warsaw Pact military action against Poland.

USDA estimated that the conferees' compensation plan for farmers could cost
between $10 billion and $30 billion, but Lesher said no one should worry
"because we're not going to have any selective embargo."

Despite his assurances, even Republicans were skeptical. Rep. William M. Thomas
(R-Calif.) argued that the language would give farmers a "windfall" and he tried
without luck to have the national-security and foreign-policy stipulations
stricken.

Another Republican, Sen. Roger W. Jepsen of Iowa, accused Thomas of "trying to
pull the wool over peoples' eyes." He said the amendment would strip the
provision of meaning. "With this," he said tartly, " Secretary of State Al Haig
obviously has done his homework overnight."

Thomas was voted down and the House conferees then voted 10 to 3 for the
Senate's tougher language, as Rep. Paul Findley (R-Ill.) predicted it "will rank
even higher in urban members' eyes than sugar or peanuts as another reason to
defeat this bill."

In another stretching of the safety net for farmers, the conferees accepted an
amendment by Dole that would give farmers preferential federal help if they have
grain stored in bankrupt elevators. Dole said the problem is growing in the
Midwest because court rulings have prevented farmers from regaining access to
their grain while litigation goes on.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

four-year farm bill, still several days from completion. By James K. W. Atherton
-- The Washington Post

                               September 17, 2010

Eddy, Chaves, Otero on USDA alfalfa disaster list

BYLINE: Clovis Livestock Market News staff

LENGTH: 276  words


WASHINGTON - The U.S. Department of Agriculture has designated Eddy County in
New Mexico as a natural disaster area due to adverse weather conditions that
resulted in an outbreak of alfalfa cutworm occurring June 30 - July 31, 2010.

Farmers and ranchers in the following counties in New Mexico also qualify for
natural disaster assistance because their counties are contiguous: Chaves, Lea,
and Otero.

Farmers and ranchers in the following counties in Texas also qualify for natural
disaster assistance because their counties are contiguous: Culberson, Loving and
Reeves.

All counties listed above were designated natural disaster areas Sept. 14, 2010,
making all qualified farm operators in the designated areas eligible for low
interest emergency (EM) loans from USDA's Farm Service Agency (FSA), provided
eligibility requirements are met. Farmers in eligible counties have eight months
from the date of the declaration to apply for loans to help cover part of their
actual losses. FSA will consider each loan application on its own merits, taking
into account the extent of losses, security available and repayment ability. FSA
has a variety of programs, in addition to the EM loan program, to help eligible
farmers recover from adversity.

USDA also has made other programs available to assist farmers and ranchers,
including the Supplemental Revenue Assistance Program (SURE), which was approved
as part of the Food, Conservation, and Energy Act of 2008; the Emergency
Conservation Program; Federal Crop Insurance; and the Noninsured Crop Disaster
Assistance Program. Interested farmers may contact their local USDA Service
Centers for further information.

                       Lake County Leader, Polson, Mont.

                     Distributed by Tribune Content Agency

                             July 16, 2015 Thursday

Lake County added to statewide disaster list for drought relief

BYLINE: Trip Burns, Lake County Leader, Polson, Mont.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 874 words


July 16--Lake County officials will request that Gov. Steve Bullock declare the
county a "Natural Disaster," due to the extreme weather and damage to
commodities this season.

The Lake County commissioners will soon send the paperwork to the governor's
office to be eligible for relief through the Farm Services Agency.

Jack Stivers, an agent at the Montana State University's extension office and
liaison between the commissioners and the state government, said that enough
damage has been done to warrant such a request. "I don't think the rain will
stop anything," he said.

Stivers said he will complete the necessary paperwork referencing low yield
percentages of crops from the drought but also the late freezes in spring.

"The button's been pushed," he said. The next step will be sending the paperwork
to the commissioners, who will then send a formal request to Bullock.

The severity of the drought means that the nine counties in Montana might be
eligible for assistance from the Farm Service Agency. The assistance would be in
the form of emergency loans to farmers in the area. The assistance is the result
of such counties being declared in a "Natural Disaster" status by the U.S.
Department of Agriculture secretary Thomas Vilsack, in accordance with section
321(a) of the Consolidated Farm and Rural Development Act.

The Department of Natural Resources and Conservation have been in contact with
the county commissioners whose counties are designated "Extreme Drought" by the
U.S. Drought Monitor. On July 16 Lt. Gov. Angela McClain will meet in Helena
with leaders of affected counties to see if the severity warrants a natural
disaster.

If Lake County is designated a natural disaster, farmers will have eight months
to apply for emergency loans. Farmers are encouraged to consult with nearby Farm
Service Agency offices.

If approved, the Farm Service Agency will contact the commissioners for the
logistics of emergency money being given to those affected, Stivers said.

Weekend rain helped to bring moisture and relief to the land, but not enough to
bring Lake County and the Flathead Indian Reservation out of the drought
affecting the area and Northwest Montana.

Last week the National Weather Service moved Lake County and nearby counties to
the category of "Extreme Drought." The National Weather Service divides the
weather designation into five categories: Abnormally Dry, Moderate Drought,
Extreme Drought, and Exceptional Drought. Lake County conditions were designated
as "Moderate Drought" for over a month.

Montana also has different classifications and has Lake County listed as "Severe
Drought," the highest level of drought. The department of Natural Resources and
Conservation designated nine other counties as such: Silver Bow, Deer Lodge,
Granite, Powell, Mineral, Sanders, Lake, Flathead and Lincoln.

The weather phenomenon El Nino, during which warm winds from the Pacific Ocean
flow inland as part of a pattern, is one of the main reasons why Lake County and
Northwest Montana are experiencing the drought, according to meteorologist Jeff
Kitsmiller at the National Weather Service in Missoula.

Montana's overall dryness is due to Pacific winds blowing weather systems north
and south of the Mission mountains, Kitsmiller said, but El Nino pushes the
weather systems further north and south.

During these times, rainfall is much needed here in the valley, but predicting
where and when is difficult, he said.

"There isn't a good signal whether it will be dry or wet during the summertime,"
he said.

July could be a month with above average precipitation, which will help not only
with water usage and dryness, but also help stop the spread of dangerous
wildfires.

"We've got some pretty good weather systems coming up," he said.

Predicting how dry the winter will be remains uncertain, but there are data
indicators that meteorologists use to determine the effects of dry weather, not
just El Nino.

Last September, when the first signals of El Nino were appearing, the National
Weather service predicted a drier than usual winter for Lake County. As a
consequence of El Nino, the Mission Valley experienced milder temperatures and
reduced snowpack.

Kitsmiller said the current El Nino pattern, which started last September,
usually lasts 15 months, and will also affect the snowpack during this upcoming
winter, mostly during the months of December, January, and February. The
previous El Nino that caused reduced snowpack occurred during the 2009-2010
winters.

Lake County's reservoirs such as the Mission reservoir in St. Ignatius and the
Pablo reservoir are currently showing signs of fatigue, causing water
restrictions such as two weeks ago, when water usage was restricted and rotated
for over a week in parts of the valley.

Irrigators began using water from the reservoirs weeks earlier than usual to use
on crops, due to the unusually warm temperatures in spring, coupled with the
mild winter preceding it.

Visit www.drought.gov for updated information provided by the state with
in-depth resources for Lake County and other counties affected by the drought.

                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                           October 29, 1981 Thursday

Farmers urge Cabinet   to declare emergency

BYLINE: GAM

LENGTH: 406 words


The Ontario Government should declare an immediate state of emergency to
 cope with the economic crisis in farming, agricultural leaders have told
 the Cabinet.

Ralph Barrie, president of the Ontario Federation of Agriculture, told
 Government ministers that record rainfall has delayed the corn harvest and
 ruined many crops, worsening problems caused by high interest rates and
 low prices.
    'There are many desperate, disillusioned farmers out there who have
 been counting on this harvest to make ends meet. All this adds up to a
 depressing and intolerable situation," Mr. Barrie said.

To help farmers over the crisis, the group said, the province should
 provide interest-subsidized loans based on need. A federation brief said
 all farmers should be eligible for interest assistance on bank loans
 issued at rates of more than 12 per cent.

The group said statistics showing farmers are not in trouble are not
 accurate. A recent survey of bankers said that only 0.5 per cent of
 Canadian farmers are in financial difficulty, and Ontario Agriculture
 Minister Lorne Henderson has said only one per cent of the province's
 farmers are in trouble.

With net farm income in Ontario down 29.5 per cent in 1980 over 1979,
 there are obviously many more farmers in serious difficulty, Mr. Barrie
 said. 'If the bankers' association survey . . . shows 1,000 farmers in
 dire straits, I would be inclined to multiply that by ten to get a truer
 indication of the problem."
    Premier William Davis told the farm group he does not need to be
 persuaded that farmers are facing significant problems. However, he said,
 a major cause of those problems - high interest rates - is a federal
 responsibility.
    'It is not a case of just passing the buck . . . . Since last March, I
 have been pressing for a meeting of first ministers on economic issues and
 interest rates as they affect homeowners, farmers and business," Mr. Davis
 said.

The province wants to be selective in any aid to farmers, and a plan to
 help young farmers has not been rejected, he said.

The farmers said they badly need aid from the province, not just
 'token handouts." The federation brief said that although Ontario has
 better soil and climate than Quebec, Quebec farmers' incomes rose in 1980,
 while Ontario farmers earned less.
    'We contend the major reason was that Quebec farmers were protected to
 a greater degree from the high interest rates in 1980 than Ontario
 farmers," the brief said.

                           November 17, 2005 Thursday

Chinese province gets special loan to help fight bird flu pandemic

LENGTH: 251 words


Text of report in English by official Chinese news agency Xinhua (New China News
Agency)

Urumqi, 17 November: China Development Bank (CDB) Xinjiang Branch announced
Thursday [17 November] that it had provided Urumqi, one of the two counties
reported with bird flu case in Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region, northwest
China, with 5m yuan (616,500 US dollars) in emergency loan to combat the avian
pandemic there.

Hao Gang, deputy head of the office with the CDB Xinjiang Branch, said they were
also discussing details of providing emergency loans to Zepu County, the other
county in Xinjiang also spotted with bird flu case, with representatives of the
relevant county departments.

By August, CDB has granted 260m yuan of short-term emergency loans across China
since the latter half of 2003, when it began granting loan support to meet a
urgent demand cropping up in infrastructure, basic industries, backbone
industries and its supportive projects following various kinds of emergencies.

The Chinese Ministry of Agriculture (MOA) Tuesday disclosed that China's
National Avian Flu Reference Laboratory had found the deadly H5N1 strain of bird
flu in the dead fowls sent from some family farms in Zepu and Urumqi counties,
both in southern Xinjiang.

In the two counties hit by the bird flu pandemic, 322,500 domestic fowls within
a radius of three km have been culled, and poultry and products markets within
10 kms have been closed, said the ministry.

                      The Vancouver Sun (British Columbia)

                            October 16, 1999, FINAL

Disaster program to help Alberta farmers struck by drought: Adverse weather
conditions over the past few years have taken a toll on many farm families.

BYLINE: Ashley Geddes

SECTION: News; B2

LENGTH: 492 words

DATELINE: EDMONTON


EDMONTON -- Hundreds of drought-stricken Alberta farms will be saved by a new
provincial $100-million-a-year disaster program, say agriculture and government
representatives.

Apart from saving many farms outright, the program will bring emergency relief
of varying degrees to an estimated 10,000 to 12,000 producers, says Agriculture
Minister Ty Lund.

The province unveiled the program Thursday as a mixture of low-interest loans
and direct financial disaster relief for northern Alberta.

Lund said adverse weather conditions over the past few years, coupled with low
commodity prices for grain and hogs, have taken a toll on many Alberta farm
families. He said some farms were facing extinction without some immediate
assistance.

Rod Scarlett, executive director of the Wild Rose Agricultural Producers
association of farmers and ranchers, endorsed Lund's estimate that the program
may save hundreds of farms.

Scarlett said his organization was hoping for a more generous assistance
program. But he called the package ''a step in the right direction,'' adding
producers remain hopeful Ottawa will soon be forthcoming with financial relief
for western farmers as well.

''This program helps but there's still more that could be done,'' said Scarlett.

Lund agreed, acknowledging that the new dollars are aimed at a short-term remedy
but ''in the long term this will probably fall short.''

Still, Lund said the Conservative caucus decided many farmers in the northwest,
northeast and Peace regions of the province are in a crisis situation and
require help.

Agriculture is the province's second biggest industry with one in three people
employed directly or indirectly in spin-off businesses, Lund said.

Currently 24 municipalities are considered disaster areas due to drought, with
another three or four regions plagued by severe drought conditions.

The government estimates that in the worst-hit areas, 3. 7 million cropland
acres out of a total of 5.4 million acres are hit by drought-related stress.
Another 4.1 million acres out of 5.9 million hay and pasture lands are also
suffering severe drought difficulties.

''So there are real problems,'' said Lund. ''When you look at the value of
agriculture in this province, I think it's really important to maintain that
base.''

He said there are two groups requiring help -- those with severe cash-flow
problems needing immediate assistance and those with intermediate difficulties.

The new assistance involves expansion of existing farm income disaster relief
and loan programs.

Under the loan program, farmers who have suffered severe income loss in at least
two of the past three years qualify for loans of up to $100,000 for individuals
or up to $300,000 for three or more people operating a farm together.

The interest rate will be five per cent amortized over 12 years. Interest and
principle payments are deferred for the first two years.
