                            The Philadelphia Inquirer

                      July 30, 2004 Friday JERSEY EDITION

Farmers may lose half their crop;
A federal report puts flood damage at more than $2 million.
But the extent of crop losses won't be seen until fall harvest.

BYLINE: Frank Kummer INQUIRER STAFF WRITER

SECTION: SOUTH JERSEY; Pg. B01

LENGTH: 526 words


Farmers growing the most vulnerable crops in recently flooded areas could lose
half their harvest, according to a federal report released yesterday.

In all, the July 12 flood caused more than $2 million in damage to farm
buildings, equipment and land, according to the report prepared by the USDA's
Farm Service Agency.

But dollar losses to crops are separate and not yet calculated. Officials say
the full extent of that loss won't be known until the fall harvest.

Still, farmers in the flood zone, mostly in Burlington County, are already
reporting roughly 50 percent losses in a variety of fruits and vegetables.

The most vulnerable crops would be those lowest to the ground, such as
cranberries and tomatoes. Among the hardest-hit areas are Pemberton, Tabernacle,
Southampton and Medford.

The state's Agriculture Department released the information yesterday from the
federal report.

Paul Hlubik, executive director of the state's Farm Service Agency office, said
that the damage, however, was "not a blow to the industry as a whole."

"This was devastating to a few farmers in isolated areas," he said, "but it's
not devastating to the industry."

The storm dumped more than a foot of rain in some areas and sent 800 people from
their homes. Last week, state officials said it had caused at least $50 million
in property damage throughout Burlington and Camden Counties. That did not
include the newly released farm damage figure.

Jeff Beach, a state agriculture department spokesman, said that Burlington
County farms took the biggest hit and sustained about $1.75 million in land and
farm equipment damage. Camden County suffered to a lesser degree.

The damage, for example, came in the form of erosion, washed-out dams and
collapsed walls at irrigation ponds.

At least seven cranberry farms were affected, making them among the hardest-hit.
The names of those farms were not released.

"In what has otherwise been a banner year for crops in New Jersey, this
localized event in Burlington and Camden Counties has made us all aware of the
unpredictable impact weather can have on our agricultural industry," said state
Agriculture Secretary Charles M. Kuperus.

The state Agriculture Department has mailed letters to 380 farmers so far,
notifying them of the availability of aid.

President Bush has declared parts of Burlington and Camden Counties federal
disaster areas, which made farmers eligible to apply for emergency loans at 3.75
percent interest through the Farm Service Agency.

Contact staff writer Frank Kummer at 856-779-3220 or fkummer@phillynews.com.

How to Get Aid for Flooded Farms

Federal emergency loans of 3.75 percent through the Farm Service Agency,
609-267-1639.

Cost-share services on a 50-50 basis for farms permanently preserved or in the
eight-year agricultural commitment under the Farmland Preservation Program.
Division of Agricultural and Natural Resources,

609-292-5532.

Dam repair loans at 2 percent interest from New Jersey Department of
Environmental Protection, 609-984-0859.

For other information, call the Federal Emergency Management Agency,
1-800-462-7585.

                         Portland Press Herald (Maine)

                      March 10, 2002 Sunday, Final Edition

Tapping into disaster aid takes creativity;
The federal agency charged with emergencies has never dealt with drought. But
there are funds out there.

BYLINE: BART JANSEN Staff Writer

SECTION: FRONT; Pg. 1A

LENGTH: 1696 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


The broad relief that the Federal Emergency Management Agency provides victims
of floods, hurricanes and other natural disasters may be unavailable to
communities ravaged by a drought that extends from Maine to Florida. Instead,
the U.S. Department of Agriculture is taking the lead role in drought relief.
But the grants and loans that the USDA provides are generally aimed at helping
with crop damage. The agency does not deal with such problems as aiding
communities that run out of potable water, a growing issue in Maine towns that
rely on wells or reservoirs.

Federal statute authorizes FEMA to assist in disasters that overwhelm state
resources, including "hurricane, tornado, storm, high water, wind-driven water,
tidal wave, tsunami, earthquake, volcanic eruption, landslide, mudslide,
snowstorm or drought."

Money has poured from the agency in times of great need. FEMA has spent $1.8
billion to $4.3 billion a year during the last decade on disasters such as the
Northridge earthquake in California and the Red River floods in the Midwest.
Agriculture's domain

But the agency has never handled drought as a disaster.

"Never," said Janice Melton, a regional FEMA spokesman. "FEMA hasn't
historically been involved because it has fallen under the direction of
agriculture, except when it affects unemployment."

FEMA's lack of experience in this area concerns Maine officials because the
agency historically has broad powers to deploy ample assistance. FEMA has the
authority to pay up to 75 percent of certain costs a community suffers in a
declared emergency.

At issue in Maine and other states is a drought that started in 2001 and is
causing mounting hardship. Private and community wells in some parts of Maine
have run dry. The town of York is considering a proposal to buy water from
neighboring communities as its surface water supply runs low. State legislators
are facing emergency bills to waive the sales tax on bottled water and to
streamline the permitting process for homeowners to have companies drill
additional wells on their properties.

Maine, New Jersey and South Carolina are being particularly hard hit by the dry
spell, though states along the Eastern Seaboard are experiencing problems.

Melton declined to speculate on whether FEMA could find a way to aid states with
drought relief in 2002.

Even without financial assistance, Maine officials say they appreciated FEMA's
interest in drought conditions here. The agency last week sent three officials
to meet with members of a state drought task force that monitors local relief
efforts.

"It was two days of mutual education," said Lynette Miller, a spokeswoman for
the Maine Emergency Management Agency.
Creative federal help

Federal officials meanwhile have found several creative ways to help Mainers
cope with the ongoing drought. The different streams of funding mostly pay for
drilling wells where water supplies have run dry.

The obscure funding programs flow from the U.S. Department of Agriculture and
the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

If Agriculture Secretary Ann Veneman declares a farm emergency for the drought,
the result will be low-interest loans for farmers and not the kind of broad
relief that FEMA provides.

Gov. Angus King wrote Veneman a letter Jan. 14 requesting a disaster
declaration. Part of the justification was damage that crops suffered last year
and part was in anticipation of dry weather for the rest of 2002. A decision is
expected soon.

"We're expecting to hear any day," said Dave Lavway, state director of the Farm
Service Agency, which coordinates disaster relief. "I think the awareness is
beginning to hit that we might have a problem for the next year or so."

If Veneman declares a farm disaster, farmers could borrow up to $500,000 at 3.75
percent over seven years to cover damage from the drought.
Livestock farmers hit

In a survey two weeks ago, officials heard from 102 livestock farmers in Maine
who reported problems with dry wells or slow recharge. Dairy cows drink a lot of
water.

"Anecdotally, we have heard that they are coming in a lot more in the last week
or so," said Brent Mullis, program specialist for the Farm Service Agency.

Farm officials notified a state drought task force Thursday about approval of a
$400,000 grant program that will match farmer costs to install wells or water
pipelines. This conservation program will pay 64 percent of a farmer's costs to
truck water to his property temporarily or half the cost of permanent
improvements such as a well.

Federal officials in Maine also have steered funding for drought relief from
unusual sources. The common thread is financial assistance for housing.

Agriculture, for example, has a rural-development program that helps homeowners
repair and upgrade property, usually with roofs and siding. But participants
don't have to be farmers - like with a disaster - and the advantage over some
other federal programs is that individuals can get assistance for their own
homes.

Mostly the program serves elderly homeowners with low income. Residents younger
than 62 can get loans up to $20,000 at 1 percent interest for 20 years.
Residents at least 62 years old can get grants up to $7,500. To qualify, a
family of two in York County must earn less than $18,150.

"People are calling and telling us they've been out of water for four months and
they've been lugging water and need assistance," said Veronica Johnson, a loan
assistant who handles York County cases. "Some of the ladies will put buckets
out on the porch to catch melting snow to fill their toilets. Then they'll buy
water in the store to drink. They say they have done it for four or six months."

Last year, the program distributed nearly $1.1 million in grants and loans
statewide, and $358,938 this fiscal year since July 1.

The drought is consuming a growing share of the program, with $233,412 in grants
and loans so far this year paying for 48 new wells, said Debora Berry, who works
with the program covering seven counties in southern Maine.
Community projects

"I think we do some unique things to get out there to sell the programs," said
Berry, who attends educational programs to promote the program.

Southern Maine accounted for a majority of the projects.

Androscoggin, Cumberland, Franklin, Kennebec, Oxford, Sagadahoc and York
counties had 10 grants and 24 loans worth a total of $169,240. Applications for
four more grants and three loans totaling $39,420 are still pending.

Recipients are grateful for the assistance. "I get lots of hugs," Johnson said.

Community projects are also funded through the program. In the past week North
Haven received a $175,000 grant to expand the town's water system and the Alfred
water district got a $1.1 million loan to expand and upgrade its system.

Two other experimental programs are under the U.S. Department of Housing and
Urban Development.

Tapping the programs for drought relief is unusual, with regional and national
spokesmen for the program saying they hadn't heard of this strategy in other
states.

One program is called community development block grants, typically used for
economic development. Under an experimental program in Washington and Aroostook
counties, residents are grouping together to replace wells and septic systems,
said Mike Baran, technical assistant manager at the state Department of Economic
Community Development.

The program is just getting started in Jonesport. But in the northern tip of the
state, from Presque Isle to Madawaska, the Northern Aroostook Well and Septic
Project drilled 33 new or replacement wells and installed 44 septic systems at a
total of 65 homes.

The group assembled $300,000 from the housing department with $780,000 from
agriculture's rural-development program and the state Department of
Environmental Protection.

An initial requirement is that an entire community must organize to apply for
the funding. Income limits also apply to participants, at $32,400 for a family
of four. But there is still a waiting list of 50 more applicants seeking
assistance.

"They are expecting this time around to have more polluted wells or nonexistent
wells or dry wells," Baran said. "The goal is to help the worst stricken and the
neediest of the needy."

The Maine State Housing Authority also has an experimental program in
Cumberland, Washington and Knox counties that uses federal money for home
repairs including drought relief. The program is for people looking to fix a
leaky roof, replace bad wiring, remove lead-based paint - or drill a new well.

One hitch is that all parts of a house must be brought up to federal standards
under the program, not just the water supply, according to Roger Bondeson, the
authority's housing services manager.

"It would be difficult to divert funds away from that to just the wells," he
said. "With federal money comes a lot of strings."

Residents earning below a certain amount - $43,100 for a family of four in the
Portland area - could get a loan for up to $15,000 at 1 percent interest for 15
years. People with even lower incomes can get loans forgiven if they live in the
same house for five years.

So far, the program has given 15 loans and has five pending, with two for wells.
Bondeson said six of the 25 inquiries he got about the program since Jan. 1 were
about wells.

The Maine Rural Water Association, which is funded by Environmental Protection
Agency grants and membership fees, has held five seminars about the short water
supply, where some of these federal officials trade notes and get the word out
about their programs. The next is March 19 in Freeport.

But Carlton Gardner, training specialist for the group, said the forecast for
emergency funding is no more promising than the weather.

"Right now, if any of our public water supplies run out of water, there is no
emergency source of money that I know of," he said. "We're just trying to get
the word out and saying you need to make emergency preparations."

Staff Writer Bart Jansen can be reached at 202-488-1119 or at:

bjansen@pressherald.com

USDA Designates Sutton County and Contiguous Counties as Drought Disaster Area

LENGTH: 244  words

DATELINE: Washington


Office of the House of Representative Will Hurd, U.S Government has issued the
following news release:

On Wednesday, the Secretary of the United States Department of Agriculture
announced that Sutton County and six additional contiguous Texas counties are
designated as primary natural disaster areas due to recent drought conditions.
These additional counties include Crockett, Edwards, Kimble, Menard, Schleicher
and Val Verde. Previously designated primary natural disaster areas in the 23rd
Congressional District of Texas include Bexar, Frio, Medina, Uvalde and Zavala
counties.

Congressional District and the impact of this drought on our families is very
real," said U.S. Representative Will Hurd (R-Helotes), who represents each of
these counties in Washington. "Families, farms and ranches have struggled in
these counties due to this drought and it's important for them to get any
federal assistance they are eligible to receive."

The disaster designation makes farm operators in these counties eligible to be
considered for certain assistance from the Farm Service Agency (FSA), including
emergency loans. Farmers have eight months to apply for these emergency loans.
According to USDA Secretary Thomas Vilsack, local FSA offices can provide
additional information.

                        Topeka Capital-Journal (Kansas)

                             July 14, 2007 Saturday

Few flood victims covered

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. 7

LENGTH: 650 words


By Roxana Hegeman

THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

COFFEYVILLE - While his flooded neighbors faced an uncertain future, homeowner
Bob Foust was already well under way this week repairing the water damage to his
house upstream of the refinery's oil spill.

Not only did his house escape the oily gunk carried by floodwaters, but Foust
had a very rare commodity in this southeast Kansas city - flood insurance.

Torrential rains in late June swelled the Verdigris River to historic heights -
cresting 4 feet higher than the 26.5-foot levees that have protected this
community since the 1960s. The city's misery was compounded when an oil spill
from the Coffeyville Resources refinery was spread by floodwaters.

Few homeowners in this low-income city carried flood insurance.

When Foust refinanced his house in November, the bank's loan agent - his cousin,
Leigh Foster - noticed he wasn't carrying flood insurance and insisted over his
strenuous objections that Foust insure the property for flooding before
approving his loan.

"I tried to talk her out of it," Foust said. "I owe my insurance to my cousin
for not looking the other way and letting me get my loan. ... I feel fortunate,
I really do."

But most home- and business owners in this now oil-sodden city are depending on
government disaster assistance - and any settlement they can get from the
refinery for damage. Individuals are applying for grants from the Federal
Emergency Management Agency or loans from the Small Business Administration and
the Kansas Farm Service Agency.

Insurance adjusters for the Coffeyville Resources refinery have been assessing
damage to downstream properties while fielding hundreds of claims for damage.
Its spokesman, Steve Eames, said the company has "adequate insurance" to repair
damage to its own facility, as well as handle claims.

At the Kansas Farm Bureau insurance agency in Coffeyville, numerous customers
have been coming in to get letters documenting that they didn't carry the added
flood insurance, a requirement before they can file for government disaster
assistance.

Homeowner Larry Quigley clutched his letter as he left the insurance office. He
needed it to apply for a U.S. Small Business Administration loan that he hoped
to use to relocate to another area. He had no flood insurance.

"I am in a 500-year flood plain - I thought my risk was low," Quigley said.
"I've lived there 36 years, and I didn't have a problem."

Farm Bureau agent Heath Higbie has been grappling with frustrated policyholders
since floodwaters rose. About 100 of his customers lived in the flooded
neighborhoods, but only four or five of them carried flood insurance, he said.

The dozens of vehicles flooded by rapidly rising water would be covered,
however, under comprehensive auto insurance policies, Higbie said.

"We have been spoiled by the levee - it's never been an issue, except for flash
floods," Higbie said. "I don't have anybody with flood insurance that wasn't
required by a lender. I expect that to change."

Several customers have already told him to remind them to ask about flood
insurance.

Higbie does not expect the southeast Kansas floods to affect premiums.

"It is large to us, but on the national scheme it is not big enough to affect
it," Higbie said. "They pool the money nationwide. It is a federally backed
insurance program."

Neither the refinery nor disaster officials could estimate the financial costs
of the flood.

Coffeyville homeowner Pete Gonzalez looked helplessly at his flooded home when
he saw it for the first time this week. He had hoped to be able to do the
repairs himself, but the home was a total loss - floors were buckled, and oil
covered everything. A red placard warned the house was unsafe and could not be
occupied.

"I don't know what I am going to do," Gonzalez said in Spanish.

Gonzalez, a foundry worker, found only a few framed photos high on the walls
that he could salvage.

He had no flood insurance.

                                  City Edition

8 counties designated disaster areas by USDA

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 7A

LENGTH: 144 words


The U.S. Department of Agriculture on Monday designated eight Oklahoma counties
as disaster counties, paving the way for farmers in the region to seek low
interest emergency loans.

The USDA identified Grant and Kay counties as primary disaster counties as a
result of high winds and hail damage from April 21 to June 2.

Alfalfa, Garfield, Noble and Osage counties also were declared "continguous" or
surrounding disaster counties.

Jackson and Tillman counties also were designated as continguous disaster
counties for damages sustained in bordering Texas counties from June 2-8.

Gov. Brad Henry said that means farms in the eight counties could be eligible
for federal disaster relief, mainly in the form of low-interest emergency loans
from the Farm Service Agency.

Farmers interested in seeking assistance are asked to contact their local county
Farm Service Agency office.

                     The Santa Fe New Mexican (New Mexico)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           January 10, 2013 Thursday

Santa Fe County farmers hurt by drought eligible for disaster aid

BYLINE: Staci Matlock, The Santa Fe New Mexican

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 478 words


Jan. 10--Santa Fe is among 19 drought-stricken counties in New Mexico designated
as primary natural disaster areas by the U.S. Department of Agriculture.

Farmers and ranchers in those counties -- plus nine contiguous ones -- qualify
for low-interest emergency loans that can help pay production costs, living
expenses or planting expenses.

New Mexico's counties were among 597 in 14 states declared disaster areas
Wednesday by Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack due to drought and heat. It was
the 71st time in the last decade that portions of New Mexico qualified for
disaster relief because of drought, snow, flood or fire, according to Lawrence
Rael, executive director of the state office of the Farm Service Agency.

In 2012, the Department of Agriculture designated 2,245 counties in 39 states as
disaster areas due to drought, or 71 percent of the United States.

The department offers low-interest loans with terms of one to 10 years and
interest rates from 1.25 percent to 3.1 percent, Rael said. He said the loans
are a safety net for producers who've lost crops, land or livestock to natural
disasters.

Many farmers already operate on a knife-thin profit margin. One or two bad years
can wipe out any savings. In addition, producers have to plan months in advance
how many acres to plant with what crop or how many livestock to raise. If they
take out a loan, they and the lender are betting on selling enough crops or
livestock the next year to pay it back. It is a risky bet, especially in the
last few years, when weather patterns have shifted dramatically, affecting water
for crops and grazing for livestock, Rael said. Most conventional lenders won't
take that bet.

Some producers carry insurance to help them through a disastrous season, but not
all.

Last year, producers asked for only $150,000 in disaster-relief loans, and most
were from the southeastern or eastern part of the state. No producer in Santa Fe
applied for a loan, Rael said. He thinks the number of loan requests could go up
this time, since producers are coming off consecutive severe drought years.

The New Mexico counties that qualify for the disaster loans include Chaves, De
Baca, Lea, Rio Arriba, Santa Fe, Cibola, Eddy, McKinley, Roosevelt, Taos,
Colfax, Guadalupe, Mora, San Juan, Union, Curry, Harding, Quay, San Miguel,
Bernalillo, Lincoln, Otero, Socorro, Valencia, Catron, Los Alamos, Sandoval and
Torrance.

Farmers in eligible counties have eight months from the date of the disaster
declaration to apply for emergency loan assistance. For information, call the
New Mexico State Farm Service Agency at 761-4900.

Contact Staci Matlock at 505-986-3055 or smatlock@sfnewmexican.com Follow her on
Twitter @stacimatlock.

                               The New York Times

              February 23, 1985, Saturday, Late City Final Edition

BLOCK ANNOUNCES AUSTERE FARM BILL

BYLINE: By SETH S. KING

SECTION: Section 1; Page 7, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1611 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22


Agriculture Secretary John R. Block today disclosed details of a farm bill that
would gradually reduce farm subsidies, eventually end Government storage of crop
surpluses and eliminate direct farm loans from the Government.

Mr. Block conceded that, on the basis of earlier accounts of the Reagan
Administration bill, Congress had already given it scant chance of passage in
its current form. He acknowledged that members of Congress would probably change
many details of the bill.

''But I'm convinced,'' he said, ''that if we can come out with our basic
objectives, not every detail of them, we'll achieve what we are asking for.''

The current farm law expires this fall. Congress must pass new farm legislation
this year or price support programs will be governed by the Farm Act of 1949,
which neither the Administration nor farm commodity groups likes.

No Impact on Farms This Year

However, any farm legislation that is eventually passed will have no effect this
year on the faltering farm economy. Nor will its credit sections have any
bearing on the immediate farm credit problem.

In a news conference at the Department of Agriculture, Secretary Block said
these were the basic objectives of the Administration's bill:


- To provide a longterm, ''market- oriented'' agricultural policy with
Government price and income supports based on average free market prices,
instead of the current system of basing them on farmers' production costs as
estimated by Congress.


- To design this policy to make American grain, cotton and dairy products more
competitive in world markets.


- To provide a five-year transition period from current farm aid programs,
gradually weaning farmers away from Government props.


- To apply these changes to most basic farm commodities, including tobacco and
peanuts, both of which are now supported differently.


- To reduce by at least half the Government's farm aid costs.

Opposition From Congress

In the past week, as parts of the Administration's plan became known, farm state
Senators and Representatives of both parties objected to any cuts in farm aid
and deplored Mr. Reagan's timing in proposing such sweeping changes in the farm
law when the agricultural economy was still in a deep recession.

Even so, Representative Edward R. Madigan of Illinois, the ranking Republican on
the House Agriculture Committee, will introduce Mr. Reagan's bill there Monday.
Senator Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican who heads the Senate
Agriculture Committee, will introduce the bill next week in the Senate.

Congress reacted to the Admistration's new farm program with coolness or
outright scorn.

Senator Charles E. Grassley, an Iowa Republican seeking re-election next year,
said the plan ''simply won't fly in Congress, and the Administration knows
that.''

Representative E. (Kika) de la Garza, the Texas Democrat who heads the House
Agriculture Committee, said the Administration's proposals would be considered,
but added that ''whatever legislation we produce will be on the basis of
preserving American agriculture, not on how many dollars can be chopped out of
the budget.''

New Price Support Loan Levels

There were no surprises today in the steps the Administration proposed taking to
achieve its objectives. Most of them had been discussed by Mr. Block in earlier
interviews and were included in Mr. Reagan's Budget Message earlier this month.

For many grain and cotton farmers, the most important of these steps would be
setting 1986 price support loan levels at 75 percent of the average free market
price in the last three years. The Secretary of Agriculture now sets per-bushel
or per-bale loan level rates each year based on a complex formula that considers
the supply on hand and farmers' production costs.

The current loan levels are usually above world market prices. Thus, they tend
to establish a price floor under American grains and cotton, since a farmer who
has taken a loan at the prescribed rate, using his crop as collateral, will not
sell that crop in the open market at a price lower than the loan rate, but will
forfeit the crop to the Government as payment of the loan.

But if the loan level was kept below the average market price, it would serve
only as a distant safety net in the event the market fell more than 25 percent
below the loan level. Otherwise, a farmer would sell his crop to repay the loan
instead of turning it over to the Government, which would be stuck with the cost
of storing it and eventually disposing of it.

Cut in 'Deficiency Payments'

The farmer would be getting less income from the sale than from a loan under the
current system, but the price of his crops, Mr. Block contends, would be more
realistic in the world market.

Under the Administration's bill, grain and cotton subsidies, called ''deficiency
payments,'' would be based next year on 100 percent of the three-year average
market price. This percentage would be reduced each year until 1991, when it
would reach 75 percent.

Under the current law, ''target prices'' have been set by Congress in each of
the last four years. When the year's average market price falls below the target
price level, a farmer eligible for subsidies is given the difference between the
target and market prices on a certain portion of his crop, whether he sells it,
stores it or takes a loan on it.

For example, last year the target price on wheat was $4.38 a bushel, while the
average market price was $3.38 a bushel. Thus, eligible farmers received per
bushel and the Government spent about $1.1 billion for wheat subsidies alone.
These subsidy payments, Mr. Block says, have been encouraging overproduction and
increasing price-depressing surpluses.

To be eligible for loans and subsidies under the new plan, as under the old,
farmers would have to reduce the acreage they plant in grains or cotton in 1986,
1987 and 1988. After that, there would be no more planting restrictions.

Milk Price Support Program

The Administration would continue the current milk price support program for the
next two years, but would reduce the support price each year if dairy product
surpluses increased. Beginning in 1988, it would provide direct payments to
dairy farmers based on gradually declining target prices, just as grains and
cotton would be treated.

Peanut prices are now supported under a restrictive quota system that guarantees
a higher price for peanuts grown for domestic edible use and at a much lower
price for those non-quota peanuts exported or crushed for oil. The
Administration wants to gradually end this system and set loan rates of 75
percent of the average three-year market price. All peanut growers would be
eligible for these loans, even if they did not have quotas. Quota holders would
get direct payments based on a percentage of the average market price.

The Administration, in return for Senator Helms's promise to introduce its bill,
withdrew a section dealing with tobacco.

''We will write a separate tobacco bill,'' Mr. Block said today, ''and it will
lower price support levels and open production to growers who do not at present
have acreage quotas.''

Limit on Price Support Loans

As one means of directing most farm aid benefits to the middle-sized farmers,
the Administration would set an annual limit of $200,000 per farmer on price
support loans in which the farmer could foreit his crop to pay the loan. Above
$200,000, the loan would have to be repaid in full in cash, plus interest. There
is no limit now on price support loans.

The bill would also set annual limits per farmer on subsidies, holding them to
$20,000 next year and reducing that to $15,000 in 1987 and to $10,000 in 1988
and succeeding years. Under the current law, there is a $50,000 limit.

The limits on both loans and subsidies would be far below today's annual
payments. In some years, farmers with very large holdings have received more
than $1 million in subsidies and price support loans.

The proposed reductions in subsidy payments would have little effect on outlays
from the budget for the fiscal year 1986, since many of the subsidy payments on
1985 crops are made after Oct. 1, when the fiscal year 1986 begins. But Mr.
Block said the reductions in subsequent years, plus the lower loan rates and the
limits on loans and direct payments, would reduce commodity supports costs from
$10.5 billion next year to $3 billion to $5 billion for the 1987-89 period.

Emergency Farm Loans

One of the most controversial sections of the bill would, beginning next year,
shift all future emergency farm operating loans from the Government's Farmers
Home Administration, the lender of last resort, to commercial banks, with the
Government guaranteeing a percentage of these loans. This plan would be similar
to the current emergency loan guarantees to commercial banks that agree to
reduce debt service charges on troubled farm loans they hold.

Mr. Reagan has provided $650 million for the current program. The bill would
make up to $3 billion available next year for such guarantees on new loans.

Another major component of the proposed Agricultural Adjustment Act of 1985, Mr.
Block said, would be a commitment by the United States to promote open access to
all world markets and reduce the restrictive trade practices that now allow some
exporting countries to subsidize their farm products and undersell this
country's.

''In the event our negotiations to remove or reduce these barriers, including
export subsidies, are not progressing satisfactorily,'' Mr. Block said, ''we
will recommend tough actions to offset them.''

THE OPEN FORUM - Letters to the editor

SECTION: DENVER & THE WEST; Pg. B-06

LENGTH: 1147 words


Low-interest loans for farmers who lost cattle Re: "Ranchers deserve federal
aid," Feb. 14 editorial.

The Denver Post's editorial did not accurately reflect the position or action of
the U.S. Department of Agriculture in response to the recent blizzards.

Colorado farmers and ranchers suffered significant livestock losses in recent
blizzards. The governor requested that the USDA use a Secretarial Disaster
Declaration for low-cost emergency loans. But when Colorado's snow-covered
damages couldn't be established at 30 percent loss required under disaster laws,
the USDA looked deeper and gave Colorado's farmers and ranchers the exact same
benefit as the Secretarial Disaster through another means.

The USDA has a variety of tools in its tool box, but each tool has its own set
of limitations imposed by regulation or statute. U.S. regulations require a 30
percent loss in the production of a major crop in a county in order to issue a
USDA Secretarial Disaster declaration. Obviously, a natural disaster that hits
outside of the growing season is not likely to heavily impact crop production.
However, we all realized that producers had suffered losses. To respond
positively, the USDA's Colorado Farm Service Agency pursued another option, an
Administrator's Notice of Physical Loss, which provides access to the same
low-interest emergency loans for physical losses. Physical losses include dead
livestock and collapsed buildings. The USDA state director's Jan. 23 request for
Colorado farmers and ranchers was approved in Washington, D.C., the next day.

So, the exact benefit being requested by the governor was provided back in
January, through a different process. It is because the USDA recognized the need
that we explored several options for providing access to emergency loans and
found one that fit.

Teresa Lasseter, Farm Service Agency, Administrator, U.S. Department of
Agriculture, Washington, D.C.

---------------------------------------- Merit-pay plan at Metropolitan State
College

Re: "Metro looks into merit pay," Feb. 12 news story.

The Post reports that the trustees of Metropolitan State College of Denver are
considering a "pay for performance" plan for faculty. The proposed plan would
use tuition and some state funds to fund this $3 million program. Why, I ask,
should we pay faculty $3 million when we aren't contractually obligated to do
so?

Let's give those "superior" faculty the opportunity to sell their lecture series
to the university for that "bonus." Then, those superior lectures would be
online, available to all Metro State students (or a wider audience), whose
tuition paid for the bonuses in the first place. And the excellent teachers
would be remunerated for their excellent work. That way Metro students and
taxpayers would get something for the extra cost.

Patrick Mieritz, Colorado Springs

---------------------------------------- Amendment 41 and special interests

Re: "Lobbyist's view of Amend. 41," Feb. 16 guest commentary.

Despite the problems resulting from the wording of Amendment 41 - which will get
sorted out eventually - I am insulted by the message presented in the commentary
by lobbyist Donnah Moody. She argues that pre-election warnings about the
amendment "were dismissed as tainted because of our \ vested interest in the
process. This ignores the fact that all Coloradans have vested interests,
because all of us have a stake in some special-interest group."

Well, I believe that all Coloradans have an interest in good, clean, ethical
governance and that this is not a special interest but a general one. Citizens
are fed up with government by, for and of the special interests. Whatever
happened to governance by, for and of the people?

We elect our representatives to represent all of us and to enact policies that
serve the common interests of all citizens. Any system of government that offers
up laws and policies favoring special interests of the highest bidder is not a
democracy.

Phillip Bugg, Colorado Springs

...

Donnah Moody's remark that "all Coloradans have vested interests" is, of course,
correct. Most of us, however, have only our periodic voting to make our wishes
known to government officials, while lobbyists are paid to spend time and money
seeking out a legislator's public preferences and private weaknesses in order to
gain advantage. The appeal of Amendment 41 was the chance it gave those of us
without deep pockets to offset some of that paid-for influence on the
legislature. It was never about scholarships, Nobel Prizes, justly earned awards
of merit, or any of the other red herrings Moody mentions.

William V. Burgess, Westminster

Smoking on Capitol Hill

                          The Monitor (McAllen, Texas)

                             June 3, 2010 Thursday

Hispanic farmers 'insulted' by $1.3 billion settlement offer

BYLINE: Jeremy Roebuck, The Monitor, McAllen, Texas

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 1080 words


Jun. 3--MCALLEN -- A $1.3 billion offer to settle claims that the U.S.
Department of Agriculture discriminated against Hispanic and women farmers
applying for emergency loans does not go nearly far enough to make up for years
of inequity, a group of Rio Grande Valley farmers said.

The Justice Department made the proposal last week in hopes of ending a
decade-old lawsuit in which the farmers from across the United States claimed
that USDA loan programs were systemically stacked against minorities.

But the offer comes on the heels of a similar $2.15 billion government payout to
black farmers who have filed complaints on similar claims -- even though there
are nearly twice as many Hispanic-owned farms in the United States as those
owned by blacks, according to federal agricultural census data.

"Our farmers are hopping mad about this," said Stephen Hill, an attorney
representing Hispanic farmers from across the Southwest in the lawsuit. "They
are going to be notifying members of Congress and the (Obama) administration to
let them know exactly what they think about this really unfortunate proposal
that doesn't even begin to treat Hispanic farmers equally and on par with black
farmers."

Created in the 1930s as part of the New Deal legislation, the USDA loan program
was intended to help small farmers who didn't qualify for private credit obtain
the financing they needed to keep their farms operating.

But the decentralized system set up to distribute those loans and highly
subjective qualifying criteria allowed anti-minority bias that existed in many
rural communities at the time to taint the application process.

Minority farmers were routinely discouraged from applying for government
assistance, rejected outright or experienced severe delays in receiving their
promised funds. All the while, their Anglo peers received loan after loan
without a hitch, the lawsuit's plaintiffs allege.

And no one in the government disputes the facts. Since at least Bill Clinton's
presidency, agriculture secretaries have openly condemned their agency's history
of racism -- including current Secretary Tom Vilsack, who ordered an independent
review of USDA field offices and the creation of a task force to review past and
pending civil rights complaints.

"I intend to lead the department in correcting its past errors, learning from
its mistakes and moving forward to a new era of equitable service and access for
all," he said in an April 2009 memo to staff outlining the changes.

But as recently as 1994, an internal USDA study found, the county-level
committees charged with reviewing loan applications were overwhelmingly
dominated by Anglos. Ninety-four percent had no female or minority
representation.

Guadalupe Garcia Jr., the lead plaintiff in the Hispanic farmer's suit, alleges
that lack of representation cost him his 630-acre farm in New Mexico. He applied
four times for loans or emergency assistance from 1986 to 1998 only to be turned
down each time after his local committee deemed him unsuitable on criteria such
as whether he had the "character or industry" to operate a successful farm or
the "commitment to carry out his undertakings and obligations."

A county committee in Fresno, Calif., told another of the case's plaintiffs -- a
single mother with a college education in agricultural economics -- that farming
was "not a proper business for a woman, much less a Mexican woman with two
kids."

More than 40 farmers in the Rio Grande Valley have signed on to the lawsuit,
claiming similar stories of discrimination ranging from being discouraged from
even applying to being challenged when they asked for assistance in filling out
complicated loan application forms.

Hill, the lead attorney on the suit, estimates as many as 4,600 local farmers
may have been affected.

But the current administration's rhetoric of reform doesn't match up to what the
Hispanic and women farmers were offered in their settlement agreement last week,
local farmers said.

"I think accepting it is out of the question," said Juan Villanueva, of McAllen,
who was forced to give up his 7,000-acre plot in Duval County a decade ago after
drought wiped out his crops and he was unable to secure an emergency loan. "It's
not what we're looking for."

Under the terms of the settlement agreement, the Justice Department would cap
payouts to individual plaintiffs at $50,000. The total $1.3 billion sum would be
split among all of the current plaintiffs in the Hispanic farmer and women
farmer lawsuits, despite the fact that they were filed separately.

Those who have not already signed up as plaintiffs in either suit would have to
file a separate lawsuit to pursue discrimination claims -- a process that can
come with hefty filing and attorney's fees that might discourage already
cash-strapped small businessmen from participating.

"The irony of all of this is that an administration that's pledged to be
progressive has really proposed something that smacks of the old poll tax," said
Hill. "Farmers are going to have to pay a fee to participate in a settlement
process to be compensated for discrimination they already paid for in dollars."

And while $50,000 may sound like a hefty sum to some, Raymondville farmer David
Cantu said, when it comes to running a business it doesn't amount to much.

"That $50,000 wouldn't give me a down payment on a tractor," he said. "I know
people who have lost farms valued at close to $1.2 million. People might have a
preconceived notion that we're getting greedy, but we just want to be made whole
again and put back in place."

So far, the Justice Department has not publicly confirmed the terms of its
offered settlement. Hill agreed to discuss the proposal only after The
Associated Press, quoting an unnamed Obama administration source, reported on it
last week and said he views the leak as yet another discriminatory government
move.

"This was a calculated, cynical ploy to bum rush these victims figuring they
would stampede to grab what sounds like a lot of money," he said. "They have
grossly underestimated the intelligence of these farmers."

http://www.themonitor.com. Copyright (c) 2010, The Monitor, McAllen, Texas

AgriBusiness Briefs

Agents with bureau plan Medicare events

Dubuque County Farm Bureau agents will hold meetings for farm bureau members to
explain Medicare changes Monday through Wednesday at the Midway Hotel in
Dubuque. The meetings also will be held Tuesday and Wednesday at the Comfort Inn
in Dyersville, Iowa.

To register or for more information, call 563/583-7309 or 563/875-7586. Cascade
(Iowa) Service Center clients can call 563/852-3505 for details.

Dubuque County team 2nd in judging contest

MADISON, Wis. - An Iowa 4-H Dairy Judging team from Dubuque County has finished
second in the National 4-H Dairy Judging Contest at World Dairy Expo in Madison.

The Iowa team, coached by Jeff Hammerand, scored 2,058 points, which was eight
points behind Wisconsin and six points ahead of third-place Pennsylvania. Iowa
team members include Tim Rauen, of Farley; Todd Wolf, of Holy Cross; Kurt Wolf,
of Epworth; and Sara Bahl, of Dubuque.

Operators may apply for emergency loans

EPWORTH, Iowa - Farm operators who have suffered major forage/crop production or
physical losses caused by drought from Jan. 1 might be eligible for an emergency
loan.

Applicants must be unable to obtain credit from other usual sources to qualify
for the Farm Service Agency Farm Loan Program assistance. The interest rate for
the loan is 3.75 percent.

Applications can be completed at the Dubuque County Farm Service Agency office,
210 Bierman Road in Epworth. The final date for making applications is May 15.

Participants sought for pork-farming project

AMES, Iowa - A new project to help niche pork farmers with production issues is
seeking participants.

The three parts of the Niche Pork Herd Health and Production Cost Management
Project are: production, cost management and herd health diagnostics.

For materials and application forms, or for more information, contact Gary Huber
at 515/232-5661, extension 103.

Funding for the project comes from a USDA grant awarded to the Iowa Pork
Industry Center.

Financing available for youth program

OMAHA, Neb. - Farm Credit Services of America announced its 2005-2006 Youth in
Agriculture Program last week. Students may obtain financing for 4-H and FFA
production projects through its Youth in Agriculture Program until April 1.

For more information, visit www.fcsamerica.com.

Expert issues reminder about soil temperature

AMES, Iowa - As the 2005 harvest season winds down, John Sawyer, Iowa State
University Extension soil fertility specialist, reminds farmers who are planning
for the upcoming harvest to take caution when applying anhydrous ammonia
fertilizer.

He said it is important that farmers wait until the soil temperature has cooled
to 50 degrees and is continuing to cool before applying this fertilizer.

When applied to warmer soils, Sawyer said a chemical process can quickly convert
it into nitrate, which then can be leached from the soil.

To view daily soil temperature updates for each county in Iowa, go to
http://extension.agron.iastate.edu/NPKnowledge/.

                       Alamogordo Daily News (New Mexico)

                           January 16, 2014 Thursday

NM delegation secures drought assistance for Otero County

BYLINE: By John Bear jbear@alamogordonews.com @johnbearwithme on Twitter

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 482 words


New Mexico's congressional delegation announced on Wednesday that multiple New
Mexico counties, including Otero, will qualify for emergency loan assistance
from the Farm Service Agency because of the ongoing drought.

Sens. Tom Udall and Martin Heinrich, along with U.S. Rep. Steve Pearce, Ben Ray
Lujcn and Michelle Lujan Grisham, announced that 27 counties in New Mexico will
qualify for assistance.

According to a press release issued by Udall's office, the designation makes
producers, farmers and ranchers in these counties eligible for FSA emergency
loans, provided eligibility requirements are met.

Funds are available for up to a maximum of $500,000 and may be used to restore
or replace essential property, pay all or part of production costs associated
with the disaster year, pay essential family living expenses, reorganize the
farming operation and refinance certain debts.

The counties were declared by the U.S. Department of Agriculture as "primary
natural disaster areas" after suffering from droughts of severe, extreme and
exceptional intensity during the growing season for eight or more consecutive
weeks or as "contiguous counties" because of they were nearby and considered to
face similar circumstances.

"New Mexico farmers and ranchers continue to face great challenges due to the
prolonged drought and I am glad the USDA continues to recognize the need for
federal disaster assistance in our affected counties," Udall said. "We need to
do all we can to support farm operators, especially in rural communities, who
continue to be devastated by consecutive years of drought."

Heinrich said farmers and ranchers help drive the economy and have shaped the
state's history, as many growers in New Mexico come from families that have
cultivated land for generations.

"These disaster declarations are a good first step to ensure they receive the
necessary federal resources they need to recover from last year's natural
disasters," he said

Pearce also said agriculture is a vital part of New Mexico's economy, and this
year's drought has "imposed enormous hardships on our farmers and ranchers."

"Today's announcement was the right decision and will provide much-needed
relief," Pearce said. "I look forward to continuing to work closely with farmers
and ranchers across southern New Mexico to make sure they receive the support
and resources they need."

Through the FSA emergency loan program, farm operators can borrow up to 100
percent of actual production or physical losses. To qualify, they must have
suffered at least a 30 percent loss in crop production or a physical loss to
livestock and livestock products, real estate or chattel property, the release
states.

Farm operators have eight months following the date of the disaster declaration
to apply and are encouraged to do so through their local Farm Service Agency
office.

Otero Counnty's FSA office can be reached at 437-3100.

                   Mississippi Business Journal (Jackson, MS)

                             August 19, 2011 Friday

USDA declares nine Mississippi counties disaster areas

BYLINE: MBJ Staff

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 311  words


The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) has designated nine counties in
Mississippi as primary natural disaster areas due to damage and losses caused by
flooding that occurred April 15-July 1, 2011.

The counties are Adams, Claiborne, DeSoto, Humphreys, Jefferson, Quitman,
Warren, Wilkinson and Yazoo.

Farmers and ranchers in the following counties in Mississippi also qualify for
natural disaster assistance because their counties are contiguous: Amite;
Holmes; Sharkey; Attala; Leflore; Sunflower; Coahoma; Lincoln; Tallahatchie;
Copiah; Madison; Tate; Franklin; Marshall; Tunica; Hinds; Panola; Washington;
and, Issaquena.

All counties listed above were designated natural disaster areas Aug. 8, 2011,
making all qualified farm operators in the designated areas eligible for low
interest emergency (EM) loans from USDA's Farm Service Agency (FSA), provided
eligibility requirements are met. Farmers in eligible counties have eight months
from the date of the declaration to apply for loans to help cover part of their
actual losses. FSA will consider each loan application on its own merits, taking
into account the extent of losses, security available and repayment ability. FSA
has a variety of programs, in addition to the EM loan program, to help eligible
farmers recover from adversity.

USDA also has made other programs available to assist farmers and ranchers,
including the Supplemental Revenue Assistance Program (SURE), which was approved
as part of the Food, Conservation, and Energy Act of 2008; the Emergency
Conservation Program; Federal Crop Insurance; and, the Noninsured Crop Disaster
Assistance Program.

Interested farmers may contact their local USDA Service Centers for further
information on eligibility requirements and application procedures for these and
other programs. Additional information is also available online at
disaster.fsa.usda.gov.

                         Portland Press Herald (Maine)

                             August 20, 2006 Sunday
                                 Final Edition

Help wanted;
Maine faces a shortage of veterinarians who work with large animals such as
horses and cows. Efforts to attract new vets to the state have made little
impact.

BYLINE: CRISTINA BAUTISTA Staff Writer

SECTION: FRONT; Pg. A1

LENGTH: 1256 words


Wiscasset veterinarian Tammy Doughty faced a dilemma last week.

She received two emergency calls, one right after the other - one for a newborn
alpaca struggling to stay alive, another for an animal that was gushing blood
from a deep cut.

"Both were truly emergencies," she said. "I had to prioritize because there's no
one else I can send."

It's a common scenario, according to veterinarians and farmers across the state.
Maine has a shortage of veterinarians who treat sheep, goats, alpacas, horses
and cows. The result is limited emergency care for animals, high levels of
on-the-job stress for vets and difficulty recruiting and retaining new talent in
Maine.

There are two programs that use financial incentives to attract these vets to
Maine, but they have made little impact in stopping the statewide shortage,
veterinarians said.

One program is a loan for Maine residents in various medical fields.

The other program, a partnership with Tufts University's veterinary school,
selects one Maine resident a year and provides him or her with a
$12,000-per-year loan. The student must study to become a large-animal
practitioner, and the loan is forgiven if the student completes four years of
service after graduation in an underserved area in his or her home state, said
Cathy Kimball, manager of customer relations for the Finance Authority of Maine.

Since 1993, 17 veterinary students have utilized the health loan, and only four
or five students have actually used the loan forgiveness seat at Tufts since
that program started in 1999, Kimball said.

Most often, there are not enough Maine residents interested in going into large
animal practice for there to be any competition over the one seat, said Barbara
Berman, assistant dean of student affairs at Tufts University.

"We'd love to have them beat down our doors, but we don't typically have that
type of issue," Berman said.

Maine is not alone. According to a June 2006 study by Kansas State University
researchers, the number of unfilled large-animal veterinary positions at clinics
and farms nationwide is expected to grow by 4 percent to 5 percent per year.
Fewer students showing interest in large-animal practices, as well as declining
rural populations, are cited as factors in the study.

There are about 30 to 40 large-animal veterinarians practicing in Maine, and
only a few dedicate their work solely to the large-animal population, said State
Veterinarian Donald Hoenig of the Maine Department of Agriculture. The
large-animal veterinary field then segments further as some vets treat only
horses, leaving the pool of providers for sheep, cows and other animals very
slim, he said.

Several counties, including Hancock and Washington, have only one veterinarian
who treats large animals, and the midcoast area from Bucksport south is
underserved, Hoenig said.

Neither the Maine Department of Agriculture nor the Maine Veterinary Medical
Association keeps records of the numbers of large-animal veterinarians
practicing in Maine, but Hoenig estimates the number of vets providing large
animal care has dropped by at least 50 percent over the past decade following a
sharp decrease in the number of dairy farms.

According to the Maine Department of Agriculture, the number of dairy farms in
the state has decreased from 685 to 355 farms in the last nine years. The
decline has driven many large-animal veterinarians out of the field and into
small-animal practices, which treat dogs, cats and other small pets.

It's also had the effect of making the state a less attractive location to work
for recent graduates, who are often tens of thousands of dollars in debt.

Maine does not have any in-state accrediting veterinary schools, so all students
would need to go to an out-of-state institution for four years to get their
licenses. The national average tuition for the class of 2009 is $27,541 for
out-of-state students, not including living or additional educational expenses,
said Michael Chaddock of the Association of American Veterinary Medical
Colleges.

The average debt load for 2005 graduates after four years of veterinary graduate
work was $82,731, which does not include debt incurred from getting a bachelor's
degree, he said.

"Essentially, someone coming out of school with a huge debt load for college and
four years of veterinary school will go into an area that has a lot of farms,"
Hoenig said. "People used to be able to set up a practice in the York and
Cumberland county areas - there just isn't the population there anymore."

Turner veterinarian Becky Myers covers all of Androscoggin and Cumberland
counties and works in some areas of Franklin, York and Kennebec counties. She
said she has attempted to hire several assistants over the 17 years she has
practiced in Maine, and none has stayed longer than four years.

The sheer nature of large-animal practice requires long commutes to farms, but
having to do it all alone significantly cuts down the amount of clients that can
be seen in a day, she said.

"Six to eight stops a day is a really busy day for me because I sometimes have
to drive two hours just to get someplace," she said. "If I could hire more
people, we could cover more ground."

The long commutes have also led some veterinarians to begin instructing farmers
on how to conduct many basic procedures by giving instructions over the phone or
drafting up pamphlets. Owners are often uncomfortable doing these procedures,
which can later lead to euthanasias if the animals pose too much trouble,
Doughty said.

Terri Suchar, who owns Terrus Farms in Lewiston with her husband, has had to
administer basic procedures like vaccinations to her dairy cows because her
veterinarian was swamped with work.

While her farm has always been able to secure emergency care when needed, she
said the vet shortage is a concern weighing on the minds of the local farmers
she knows.

"I just looked at the pamphlet and tried to follow the procedures the best I
could," she said. "You just have to try to be flexible with your vet and not get
upset about it."

In a small-animal clinic, veterinarians can treat about 20 to 25 animals a day,
Myers said. The number of animals seen daily in a large-animal clinic is
significantly lower, and so is the amount of daily revenue, she said.

The lack of revenue only perpetuates the veterinarian shortage, as many vets can
simply not afford to hire another person in their practices, Myers said.

Physical conditions can also turn away potential hires at large-animal
veterinary clinics because working conditions can be harsh.

Small-animal vets often stay in the clinics and may not be on-call, while some
large-animal veterinarians say they are called to barns in the middle of the
night, work in frozen or scorchingly hot conditions and risk getting seriously
hurt if kicked, scratched or bitten by a large animal.

"There are definitely things more appealing than to be out in February in
subzero weather working out in middle of a field," Doughty said.

While large-animal veterinarians said that the large-animal practice can be the
least lucrative and most difficult type of veterinary field to join, the
personal satisfaction gained from the job makes it worthwhile.

"It's a huge struggle, a huge endeavor," said Doughty, who integrated a
large-animal practice with her small-animal practice a little over a year ago.
"But I just love working with the different species, and it's just a lot of fun
to be able to see a variety of animals everyday."

Staff Writer Cristina Bautista can be contacted at 791-6365 or at:

cbautista@pressherald.com

LOAD-DATE: August 22, 2006

vets practicing in the state.

                      Saint Paul Pioneer Press (Minnesota)

                    October 29, 2003 Wednesday CITY EDITION

PRODUCE FARMERS SET TO SEEK AID
PROCESS FOR DROUGHT RELIEF IS STILL UNCLEAR

BYLINE: LEE EGERSTROMPioneer Press

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. C1

LENGTH: 504 words


Vegetable farmer Wang Kou Vang watched the summer drought drive his produce
harvest down by 60 percent to 70 percent in Dakota County and by 40 percent in
Washington County -- meaning his revenue from this year's sales at the St. Paul
Farmers' Market won't cover his $300-an-acre land rent and costs for seed,
fertilizer and tillage.

Harvesting fresh produce stopped at both Vang's sites in mid-August, ending a
selling season that normally runs late into September, the Ramsey County
resident said.

He will be among several metropolitan-area farmers seeking federal drought
disaster loans this year.

"This is really important," Vang said of the loan program.

But just how the program will work remains unclear.

Nuts and bolts details of the disaster loan program are expected within a few
days at the United States Department of Agriculture's Minnesota state office,
and may change from previous disaster programs, said Warren Pommier, director of
Farm Service Agency loan programs.

What is clear is that farmers in 62 Minnesota counties have been certified as
disaster eligible, meaning they had at least a 30 percent loss for one or more
crops. Farmers in adjoining counties who can show appropriate crop losses also
will be eligible for low-interest loans to tide them over until another growing
season and harvest.

That means that fruit and vegetable growers in the Twin Cities area who have
commercial gardens and farmland across the border in neighboring Wisconsin
counties also will be eligible for disaster loans, Pommier said. Twin Cities
metro area counties are included in the disaster declaration.

The USDA notified members of the Minnesota congressional delegation and
Minnesota state officials last Friday that Minnesota's request for a disaster
declaration has been approved. Unless Congress changes the benefits, the
disaster declaration should qualify Minnesota farmers for emergency 3.75
percent-interest emergency loans, Farm Service Agency officials said.

Washington County and Dakota County offices of the Farm Service Agency will
handle loan applications for the small number of farmers in Ramsey County who
have also been certified as eligible for the program.

Brian Hartman, a farm loan program specialist with the Farm Service Agency state
office in St. Paul, said the program will need to find ways to quantify crop or
income losses for metro area farmers. This has rarely if ever been done, he
said, "but it's doable."

In contrast, farmers who grow major field crops such as corn, soybeans, wheat
and sugar beets have established yields registered with federal agencies or
insurance programs, making disaster loan applications routine.

Farm Service Agency loan officers will probably need to consult with insurance
agents and other reliable sources such as local markets and the St. Paul
Farmers' Market to determine what normal yields would be for vegetable crops,
Hartman said.

Lee Egerstrom can be reached at legerstrom@pioneerpress.com or 651-228-5437.

                             396 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                              The Washington Post

                    December 16, 1983, Friday, Final Edition

Family Farmers Will Not Lose Loan Preference

SECTION: First Section; The Federal Report; A21

LENGTH: 369 words


The Farmers Home Administration (FmHA) apparently has reversed plans to hand out
money on a first-come, first-served basis when it resumes a $600 million
emergency farm loan program next week.

The reversal means that FmHA will continue to observe a congressionally imposed
requirement that family farmers, rather than large corporate operators, be given
preference.

FmHA sources indicated that the agency, part of the Agriculture Department, had
intended to resume loan-making without observing the family-farm preference.

Those reports brought calls of protest and complaints from around the country
last week, and farm-state legislators put out queries to the agency for more
information.

"There is more than symbolism to this," said Gene Severens of the Center for
Rural Affairs in Walthill, Neb., a small-farmer advocacy organization that
monitors FmHA activities. "It shows how callous they can be, how willing they
are to disregard these interests."

Economic emergency loans were stopped in fiscal 1982 by Secretary John R. Block
after he declared that farm credit conditions had improved sufficiently to make
the program unnecessary.

But U.S. District Judge Thomas A. Flannery, in a suit brought by Minnesota
farmer Willie Ole Knute Kjeldahl, ordered the loans resumed, saying Block had
"abused" his discretionary power over the program. FmHA decided to reopen the
program after members of Congress urged the department not to appeal.

Sarah Vogel, a Grand Forks, N.D., attorney involved in the case, worried that if
FmHA dropped the family-farmer preference, the $600 million fund might be
consumed quickly by larger farmers seeking loans up to the $400,000 limit.

"It would have been another slap in the face," she said. "It took us so long to
free up this money, and then they wanted to ignore the family-farm preference.
There still is not much concern for small farmers at FmHA."

Rep. Ed Jones (D-Tenn.), chairman of a House Agriculture subcommittee on credit,
said: "These are strange times when American farmers are forced to seek relief
from their government in the federal courts, instead of relying on the
administration to use good judgment in administering its farm programs."

                                 The Advertiser

                            October 31, 1986 Friday

Call for frost area state of emergency

BYLINE: JIM MCCARTER

LENGTH: 425 words


A call has been made for a state of emergency to be declared to help central
Eyre Peninsula cereal growers devastated by last week's extreme frost.

Mr Dunn, MLC, whose own farm at Rudall was hit by the frost, said some farmers
would be wiped out unless they received assistance in the form of low-interest
loans.

He believed Federal funding could be made available under a state of emergency
at an interest rate of 4 p.c., or 8 p.c. when State administration costs were
included.

But a spokesperson for the Minister of Agriculture, Mr Mayes, said the State
Government would have great difficulty persuading the Federal Government that
the frost situation should be categorised as a state of emergency under the
usual natural disaster criteria which applied mainly to events such as bushfires
and floods.

Nonetheless, Mr Mayes would examine the possibilities for obtaining Federal
assistance.

As far as State assistance was concerned, the Minister was still waiting for a
detailed assessment by the Department of Agriculture. Conflicting reports were
reaching him on its extent, he said.

The area affected by the frost was extended yesterday after damage was reported
in the Warramboo area, north of Lock.

Mr Dunn said the effect of the frost was similar to a bushfire having gone
through the region.

It was having a disastrous effect on farm families which had been under great
strain in trying to cope with soaring interest rates and falling returns.

"One farmer at Murlong, who owes $100,000, has lost 99 p.c. of his crop," Mr
Dunn said.

"He will have nil income this year, apart from some minor returns from wool, and
will have to leave his farm with just his shirt on his back unless he gets some
emergency assistance."

Another farmer, who had outlaid about $50,000 to sow 570 hectares of crop, also
had lost the lot. Another had lost nearly 250 hectares.

Both had said they would go to the wall unless they could get cheaper finance to
carry on.

Mr Dunn said reports reaching him suggested many other farmers in the area could
be in similar trouble.

"These farmers are really looking down the barrel," Mr Dunn said. "They
certainly cannot afford to borrow funds at today's commercial interest rates -
19.5 p.c. for loans under $100,000 and 19.75 p.c. for loans over $100,000."

The Department of Agriculture's agronomist at Cleve, Mr David Lewis, said a
frost-damage field day for farmers in the Warramboo district would be held on
Monday, starting from Kopi, south of Warrambook, at 10 a.m.

                     The Lebanon Daily News (Pennsylvania)

                           September 14, 2010 Tuesday

Farmers eligible for assistance loans

BYLINE: Lebanon Daily News

SECTION: LOCAL; News

LENGTH: 265 words


Farmers in 38 Pennsylvania counties, including Lebanon County, are eligible for
emergency loans following a U.S. Department of Agriculture declaration designed
to help producers recover from crop losses associated with dry weather
conditions this summer, Agriculture Secretary Russell C. Redding has announced.

"Dry conditions experienced throughout much of the state this summer have
resulted in considerable crop loss for Pennsylvania farmers, affecting their
ability to maintain profitable businesses," Redding said in a news release.

Sixteen counties were declared primary disaster areas, including Bucks, Carbon,
Chester, Dauphin, Franklin, Fulton, Lehigh, Luzerne, Monroe, Montgomery,
Northampton, Northumberland, Schuylkill, Snyder, Union and York.

Twenty-two additional counties that border the primary disaster area were named
contiguous disaster areas. Contiguous counties include Adams, Bedford, Berks,
Centre, Clinton, Columbia, Cumberland, Delaware, Huntingdon, Juniata,
Lackawanna, Lancaster, Lebanon, Lycoming, Mifflin, Montour, Perry, Philadelphia,
Pike, Sullivan, Wayne and Wyoming.

Farmers in the primary and contiguous drought counties may apply for
low-interest emergency loans through their county farm service agency, provided
they meet eligibility requirements. Producers have eight months from the date of
the disaster declaration to apply. The agency will consider each application on
its own merit based on losses, available resources and repayment ability.

To receive a loan application, farmers should contact their local farm service
agency or visit www.fsa.usda.gov.

                             399 of 1000 DOCUMENTS

                              The American Banker

Iowa Moratorium May Be Little Help

                           October 3, 1985, Thursday

By ANDREA BENNETT and RICHARD RINGER

DATELINE: CHICAGO


Few of Iowa's financially distressed farmers are expected to benefit immediately
from a foreclosure moratorium they can now request.

The limited impact is likely because of expected legal challenges and confusion
over what types of farm loans the moratorium covers. In addition, many
commercial bankers say they already have a self-imposed moratorium as they help
farmers struggling with debt payment problems.

The moratorium, nonetheless, brings national attention to the farm financial
crisis, which some observers say is the real intent of the suspension.
Additional attention could be gained if other states follow Iowa's lead, and
Nebraska may do just that.

Iowa farmers can seek a one-year postponement on foreclosure as a result of Gov.
Terry Branstad's decision to declare on Tuesday an ''economic emergency'' in the
state. The governor had contemplated such a declaration for months, and his
press aide, Susan Neely, said he was forced to make it because Congress has
failed to produce a meaningful 1986 farm bill.

Some observers, including several bankers, said Mr. Branstad's action was taken
to enhance his political future. His term ends next year, and it is widely
expected that he will seek re-election.

Mr. Branstad's state-of-emergency declaration put into effect a state law that
allows farmers to seek a moratorium, which must be approved by a district court
judge. The lender can petition to terminate a moratorium if it can be shown that
the lender has acted in good faith and helped the farmer use all available
federal and state programs, and if it can be proved that the farmer hasn't made
interest payments on the debt.

Pete Croghan of Woodbine, a farmer and president of the Iowa Farmers Union,
praised the governor's action. Mr. Croghan said that in discussions with the
governor's aides, he was told that an estimated 1,000 farmers could benefit from
the moratorium.

Of the 110,000 farmers in Iowa, 40% have severe financial problems, according to
the state agriculture department. Those farmers have a debt-to-asset ratio above
70%. Many analysts predict that farmers with debt-to-asset ratios above 40% have
only a slim chance of staying in business.  Could Affect Wide Range of Lenders

The moratorium potentially could affect a wide range of farm lenders, including
state-chartered commercial banks and the various agencies of the Farm Credit
System. After an early September meeting with top Farm Credit officials, Mr.
Branstad said that he feared the system was planning a ''massive liquidation''
of farmers in Iowa and three other midwestern states.

On Wednesday, Mr. Branstad's press aide said the Farm Credit System was studying
the Iowa moratorium, and that system officials may challenge the state's farm
loan foreclosure law. A spokesman for the Farm Credit Bank of Omaha, which has
lending authority in Iowa, could not be reached for comment.

Other legal challenges may focus on what kinds of farm loans are covered by the
moratorium. The Iowa law mentions only farm real estate loans. It is uncertain
whether that means direct loans to finance farm real estate or also farm
operating loans that are collateralized with farm real estate.

Rural commercial banks finance a large number of farm production loans, but they
generally don't finance loans for land purchases. Thus, if the moratorium covers
only loans to finance farm land purchases, the commercial banks won't be
affected much by the moratorium.

The Iowa Bankers Association, which for several years has opposed proposals for
a moratorium, said farmers will not be helped by the governor's decision. Once a
moratorium is lifted, interest payments and principal must still be made. And
lenders may be hesitant to extend credit to some farmers.

A moratorium ''will make it tough on us when we look at some loans,'' said Royce
Nelson, a vice president at Exchange State Bank in Collins. If the bank doesn't
have the option of seeking foreclosure on a farm loan that may sour, the bank
may be reluctant to make the loan. ''It will change the way we look at the loan,
'' Mr. Royce said.

Richard Halverson, executive vice president of Corwith State Bank, said he
doesn't expect the moratorium to have much effect because it covers the farm
borrowers the banks are most likely to work with. ''Most bankers in the state
feel if the farmer is in the position to pay the interest, we'll ride with him
for another year,'' he said.  Might Dry Up Credit

But he said he was afraid the moratorium might dry up potential credit for
farmers. He said he knew of a commitment by out-of-state insurance companies to
lend $1.3 million in his area so farmers could refinance Farm Credit System
loans at lower interest rates. He said there was a chance that those kinds of
commitments would disappear because of the moratorium.

''It could very definitely affect farmers' operating credit,'' said Paul D.
Dunlap, president of Hawkeye Bancorp. of Des Moines. Mr. Dunlap said he doesn't
expect the moratorium to have a major effect on the holding company, but he was
concerned that federal regulators would not show the same forbearance towards
farm loans that the state would now require banks to show.

At least two other states have some form of moratoriums on farm debt. In its
last legislative session, the Minnesota Legislature extended a law originally
enacted in 1983 that allows farmers to go to court to seek either a six-month or
12-month postponement of a foreclosure sale, said Jeff Torp, staff attorney with
the Independent Bankers of Minnesota.

Nebraska has a law that allows farmers to go to court for a nine-month stay of
foreclosure. On Tuesday, members of Nebraska Gov. Bob Kerrey's staff and the
Nebraska attorney general's office met to discuss legal issues surrounding
lengthening the time a farmer could postpone a foreclosure, said Bill Kerrey,
staff assistant to the governor.

He said the issue could arise at a special session that is expected to be called
sometime this year. No date for the special session has been set.

SECTION: AGRICULTURE LENDING; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1009 words
