                               December 22, 2009

Drought designation may make ranchers, farmers eligible for low-interest loans

BYLINE: Sam Williams, News Editor

LENGTH: 414  words


Area ranchers and farmers who have suffered actual losses caused by the drought
that began on Jan. 1, 2009 may be eligible for financial assistance from the
federal government.

At the Lassen County Board of Supervisor's meeting on Tuesday, Dec. 15, County
Emergency Services Chief Chip Jackson announced the U.S. Department of
Agriculture has granted a Secretarial disaster designation for Lassen County and
the contiguous counties of Modoc, Plumas, Shasta and Sierra.

"I know it's kind of a funny time to talk about this with snow on the ground,"
Jackson said, "but I wanted to bring it to your attention that on Nov. 13 the
secretary of the Department of Agriculture did declare Lassen County a primary
disaster area for drought, and our contiguous counties. Even with the snow out
there, we've still got a long way to go."

Jackson reminded the supervisors despite snow in previous years, drought
conditions in the county remain.

"This is a very good paving of the way for the county for this future year,"
Jackson said. "We'll see what happens with the drought situation. Having the
primary designation right now opens up several programs to small, family-sized
ranches for small business loans and things like that."

Jackson said if a presidential designation comes along in the future, the county
would ask to be a part of that designation as well.

District 1 Supervisor Bob Pyle pointed out the snow pack in the Northern Sierra
currently is only about 66 percent of normal.

Pyle acknowledged the recent precipitation, but he added, "Eight inches of dry
snow doesn't do much."

"Just look at Eagle Lake," said District 4 Supervisor Brian Dahle.

"We still have a very seri-, ous situation ahead of us," Jackson said.

Jackson distributed a letter from California Emergency Management Agency Program
Manager Karma Hackney advising of the supervisors of the designation.

According to the letter, emergency farm loans for actual losses as a direct
result of the disaster, up to $1.1 million, would be available to farmers and
ranchers who conduct family-sized farming operations.

The interest rate is 3.75 percent.

Farmers and ranchers interested in applying for the low-interest loans should
contact the local Farm Service Agency at 257-7272.

The deadline to apply is Tuesday, July 13, 2010.

Persons with disabilities who require alternative means of communication should
contact the USDA's TARGET Center at (202) 720-2600.

More information also is available at fsa.usda.gov/pas/disaster/as
sistance1/htm.

                                 FINAL EDITION

Senators urge help for distressed farms Udall and Bennet seek $810 million for
Farm Service Agency loans.

BYLINE: Miles Moffeit The Denver Post

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. B-07

LENGTH: 234 words


U.S. Sens. Mark Udall and Michael Bennet are seeking additional emergency aid
for ailing farms in Colorado, requesting that Congress replenish dwindling
government loan coffers squeezed by the credit crunch.

Citing a 200 percent surge in demand for Farm Service Agency loans, the
lawmakers are asking that $810 million be provided to refill the accounts
through an emergency appropriations bill under review by a Senate-House
conference committee.

In a letter to congressional leaders, the senators wrote: "It is very unlikely
that FSA will be able to help all farmers who meet the requirements for these
loan programs."

The request comes at a time when many Colorado farmers have been left without
credit after the April shutdown of New Frontier Bank, the state's leading
agricultural lender. And nationally, suicide hotlines are reporting a spike in
calls from farmers in emotional distress since commodity prices dropped.

"Farmers and ranchers are hurting in these tough times, and we need to do
whatever we can - and use whatever tools we have at our disposal - to help them
weather the storm," Bennet said.

The $810 million allotment supported by the senators is backed by the House. A
similar Senate proposal is for $585 million.

Weeks ago, the U.S. Department of Agriculture approved a separate request by the
Colorado delegation to boost loan funds.

Miles Moffeit: 303-954-1415

or mmoffeit@denverpost.com

Utah: USDA Designates 24 Counties in Wisconsin as Primary Natural Disaster Areas
With Assistance to Surrounding States

LENGTH: 475  words

DATELINE: Salt Lake City


Department of Agriculture Farm Service Agency, The State of Utah has issued the
following news release:

Department of Agriculture (USDA) has designated 24 counties in Wisconsin as
primary natural disaster areas due to damages and losses caused by the combined
effects of excessive rain, excessive snow, and multiple periods of thawing and
refreezing, resulting in winterkill that occurred Jan. 1 - May 21, 2013.


The counties are:


Brown

Eau Claire

Manitowoc

Pierce
Buffalo

Fond du Lac

Marathon

Shawano
Calumet

Green Lake

Marinette

Sheboygan
Chippewa

Kewaunee

Oconto

Trempealeau
Clark

Langlade

Outagamie

Washington
Dodge

Lincoln

Ozaukee

Waupaca


"Our hearts go out to those Wisconsin farmers and ranchers affected by recent
natural disasters," said Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack. "President Obama and
I are committed to ensuring that agriculture remains a bright spot in our
nation's economy by sustaining the successes of America's farmers, ranchers, and
rural communities through these difficult times. We're also telling Wisconsin
producers that USDA stands with you and your communities when severe weather and
natural disasters threaten to disrupt your livelihood."


Farmers and ranchers in the following counties in Wisconsin also qualify for
natural disaster assistance because their counties are contiguous. Those
counties are:


Barron

Forest

Michigan

All counties listed above were designated natural disaster areas July 3, 2013,
making all qualified farm operators in the designated areas eligible for low
interest emergency (EM) loans from USDA's Farm Service Agency (FSA), provided
eligibility requirements are met. Farmers in eligible counties have eight months
from the date of the declaration to apply for loans to help cover part of their
actual losses. FSA will consider each loan application on its own merits, taking
into account the extent of losses, security available and repayment ability. FSA
has a variety of programs, in addition to the EM loan program, to help eligible
farmers recover from adversity.


Additional programs available to assist farmers and ranchers include the
Emergency Conservation Program, Federal Crop Insurance, and the Noninsured Crop
Disaster Assistance Program. Interested farmers may contact their local USDA
Service Centers for further information on eligibility requirements and
application procedures for these and other programs.

                    The Wilson Daily Times (North Carolina)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           January 11, 2012 Wednesday
                              Correction Appended

Federal disaster aid targets farmers

BYLINE: Jon Jimison, The Wilson Daily Times, N.C.

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 741 words


Jan. 11--Wilson County has received more word on federal disaster assistance,
this time from the U.S. Department of Agriculture many months after the last
natural disaster struck here.

A total of 35 counties were named in U.S. Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack's
decision to issue natural disaster designations from tornadoes and Hurricane
Irene in 2011.

Wilson was hit by an F-2 tornado in April. The remnants of Hurricane Irene moved
through in late August, bringing with it heavy rain, winds, flooding, power
outages and major crop damage.

The USDA deferred making a disaster designation until further information was
available on total damages and production losses from the tornadoes and
hurricane, officials noted.

Vilsack's made two separate designations. The first covered the tornadoes that
hit April 16.

It notes the designation is for the primary counties of Cumberland and Johnston.
It goes on to say benefits are also available for the contiguous counties of
Wilson, Nash, Bladen, Harnett, Hoke, Moore, Robeson, Sampson, Wake and Wayne.

The second designation concerns Hurricane Irene, which affected the state from
Aug. 26 through Aug. 30.

The designation is for the primary counties of Wilson, Nash, Beaufort, Bertie,
Camden, Carteret, Columbus,Craven, Currituck, Dare, Duplin, Edgecombe, Franklin,
Greene, Halifax, Hyde, Johnston, Jones, Lenoir, Martin, New Hanover,
Northampton, Onslow, Pamlico, Pasquotank, Pender, Pitt, Sampson, Tyrrell, Vance,
Wake, Warren, Washington and Wayne.

Benefits are also available for the contiguous counties of Bladen, Brunswick,
Chatham, Cumberland, Durham, Gates, Granville, Harnett, Hertford, Perquimans and
Robeson.

Producers in both primary and contiguous counties are eligible to be considered
for Farm Service Agency (FSA) emergency loans (EM) and the Supplemental Revenue
Assistance Program (SURE). Those applying must meet certain requirements.

BUSY TIME OF YEAR

Kent Politsch, chief of public affairs for the USDA Farm Service Agency, told
The Wilson Times this type of assistance is vastly different from a Federal
Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) designation, which covers largely human
safety issues and recovery.

"It is to help the producers in the county recover their losses," he said.

The designation applies to farmers, allowing them to apply for low-interest
loans to recover the losses so they can get the cash flow going again, Politsch
said.

The goal is to keep active farmers in business, Politsch said.

In addition to loans, the farmer qualifies for program payments at a later date,
he said.

Crop losses take time to accurately assess, Politsch said.

"Payment on a loss isn't known until October of the following year," he said.

Many farmers such as cotton farmers are covered and some livestock producers as
well. But tobacco isn't covered under this, he said.

Although it has been a while since disaster struck here, now is a good time for
producers to have cash on hand because they have expenses this time of year.

"They have a lot of preparations, planning and budgeting," Politsch said.

Local farmers can contact a local FSA county office or www.fsa.usda.gov.

Sen. Kay Hagan's office made a statement regarding the designations:

"I am pleased that North Carolina farmers and ranchers impacted by the tornadoes
and Hurricane Irene will finally get the assistance they deserve," said Hagan.

"Following the tornadoes in April and the hurricane in September, I saw
firsthand the community spirit and widespread determination by our citizens to
rebuild their communities. My staff has steadily monitored restoration efforts
and I will continue to fight to ensure that our communities receive sufficient
federal aid to rebuild and recover."

MAJOR LOSSES

Norman Harrell, field crop agent, told Wilson County commissioners last year
that millions of dollars were lost due to Hurricane Irene.

"I think the thing that makes it sting even more so is that we really had a
great crop in the field this year," Harrell said.

Three crops that Harrell said took the worst beatings were tobacco, corn and
cotton.

Harrell said farmers lost 35 to 55 percent of their tobacco, which is about a
$17 to $22 million loss. He said there is a 25 percent loss in corn, which
amounts to $1.5 million, and a 15 percent loss in cotton, which is about a $3
million loss.

___ (c)2012 The Wilson Daily Times (Wilson, N.C.) Visit The Wilson Daily Times
(Wilson, N.C.) at www.wilsontimes.com Distributed by MCT Information Services

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

ACC-NO: 20120111-ZW-Federal-disaster-aid-targets-farmers-0111-20120111

CORRECTION-DATE: January 13, 2012



CORRECTION: Jan. 13--Tobacco growers are eligible to seek low-interest emergency
loans.

Information provided earlier this week from the U.S. Department of Agriculture
mistakenly indicated tobacco growers were not eligible for assistance.

David McBryde, who directs the Farm Service Agency office in Wilson County, said
what's happened is on Jan. 9 U.S. Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack issued a
secretarial disaster declaration that covers the tornado in April and Hurricane
Irene in August.

The secretarial disaster declaration makes it easier for farmers to qualify for
assistance. For example, under the SURE program farmers now only have to
demonstrate a 10 percent loss in one crop of economic significance.

Under the disaster declaration issued in September by President Barack Obama,
farmers had to demonstrate a 50 percent total farm revenue loss to be eligible
to apply for the same SURE funding, according to McBryde.

Sign up for SURE assistance won't start until after October 2012. This sign up
period will be for 2011 disasters.

Right now, McBryde and his staff are helping farmers sign up for disaster
assistance related to the 2010 crop. Area farmers had many crops in 2010
affected by drought. The current sign up period ends June 1.

                              The Bismarck Tribune

                              July 17, 2006 Monday

BYLINE: TOM RAFFERTY Bismarck Tribune Looking for relief

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1A

LENGTH: 685 words


Itmight take an act of Congress for some farmers and ranchers to survive the
drought, but many of them won't be able to wait that long.

In the meantime, state and federal officials have taken some immediate steps
they hope will provide a little relief for those affected.

Sen. Byron Dorgan, D-N.D., told reporters two weeks ago that he is trying to get
a disaster package through Congress, but he didn't make any promises in how
quickly the assistance would be approved if it is at all.

Dorgan said any disaster payments wouldn't be available until October at the
earliest.

"It's going to be months, not weeks, regrettably," Dorgan said Friday.

Dorgan said getting disaster funds through Congress has been a battle because
leadership in the House is against such a move and the president has already
threatened a veto if disaster aid moves through Congress. Dorgan is still trying
to get a disaster bill approved that would help farmers who suffered losses in
2005.

One of the immediate steps that has been taken by the federal government is
opening all Conservation Reserve Program land to grazing and haying. But even
before that was approved on Thursday, ranchers had been selling off their herds
because their pastures were barren and water was scarce.

Other assistance that has been put into place will help farmers and ranchers
restructure their debt.

The Bank of North Dakota recently extended a loan program for farmers, ranchers
and businesses affected by the drought.

Applicants who show losses because of drought can get a five-year loan at a 7
percent interest rate.

Bob Humann, senior vice president of lending, said 7 percent is low considering
that banks normally charge above the prime interest rate, which is currently at
8.25 percent.

"That's a pretty aggressive interest rate because rates continue to climb,"
Humann said.

The program that was announced last year to help those who suffered losses from
flooding expired June 30 of this year. Humann said about $18 million in loans
were given out for flood damage. The state bank cannot offer the loans directly
to applicants; they have to be administered through another financial
institution.

Although the loans can be helpful, Humann said farmers need to check other
options before applying.

If USDASecretary Mike Johanns declares a disaster, an even better loan program
will be offered.

This week the USDA will be conducting damage assessment reports that will be
used to determine if a disaster can be called.

"Before our loan program is triggered, we need a county to be declared a
disaster area," Gary Nelson, director of the North Dakota office of the federal
Farm Service Agency, said.

The USDA offers loans through the Farm Service Agency with fixed interest rates
of 3.75 percent for terms of several years.

Ryan Lindbom, a farm loan specialist with the FSA, said up to $500,000 can be
borrowed from emergency loans if farmers or ranchers can show at least a 30
percent loss from the drought or significant damage from natural disasters such
as tornados, floods and hail. Lindbom said loss includes ranchers having to cull
their herds earlier than normal because of drought.

Although the USDAis in the process of assessing the drought, Nelson said
assistance through loan programs probably wouldn't come until September. Gov.
John Hoeven has put pressure on USDAdirector Johanns to complete the assessment
quickly.

Hoeven also has taken action to provide some relief to farmers and ranchers. He
has directed the Department of Transportation to open former no-mow areas and to
adjust load restrictions on highways to help farmers hauling hay. Hoeven also
has enlisted the support of the Western Governor's Association and Midwestern
Governor's Association to urge Congress to support disaster funding.

Some of the things the Agriculture Department has done include requesting the
State Water Commission activate the Drought Disaster Livestock Water Supply
Assistance Program, activating a drought emergency task force and keeping
farmers updated on what programs are available.

(Reach reporter Tom Rafferty at 223-8482 or tom.rafferty@bismarcktribune.com.)

                     The Journal Record (Oklahoma City, OK)

                            August 9, 2012 Thursday

Agencies survey fire damage across Oklahoma

BYLINE: Brian Brus

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 511  words


Federal Emergency Management Agency officials joined other federal and state
agencies Thursday in surveying and estimating the damages from grassland fires
that have swept across the state.

Although it is still too early to produce a comprehensive figure, officials
said, the cost of barbed-wire fencing by itself provides some perspective of the
scale of the loss to farmers and ranchers.

Nearly 105,000 acres have been burned in the last week, damaging hundreds of
structures, farm machinery, feed and even livestock. The Oklahoma Farm Service
Agency has announced that ag producers that incurred damages might be eligible
for assistance under the Emergency Conservation Program, even the fences that
surround more valuable property.

"Assistance is available to restoring or replace permanent fences damaged during
the devastating wildfires," FSA Executive Director Francie Tolle said in a
statement. "I encourage everyone who had fences damaged or destroyed to visit
their local FSA office and learn more about ECP before repairs are started. "

According to the state Department of Agriculture, the average size of a farm in
Oklahoma is about 400 acres. That includes a wide range, from the majority of
producers who operate about 120 acres to the few who run up to 3,000 acres.

Rod Wanger, an FSA conservation programs specialist, estimated the average cost
of replacing barbed-wire fence at $1 per foot. That might not seem like much of
an expense to someone without experience in the field until a little geometry is
applied: An ag operation with 400 acres, if laid out as a square, would measure
about 4,200 feet to a side, so the full perimeter fence could cost about
$17,000.

Of course, not all grassland is fenced, and barbed wire is available in wide
range of grades, so Wanger said his department was reluctant to provide
estimates this early in recovery.

"We will definitely see a temporary increase in sales to replace field fencing
and barbed wire," said Lou Richards at Oklahoma Steel and Wire, a major
barbed-wire wholesaler. "But that uptick in business won't show in our profits.

"We don't like to increase our business because of fires, blizzards, floods,
hurricanes or any of that," he said. "We're not profiteers. We will not take
advantage of ag producers and I'd like to say I don't think retailers will,
either. "

The company contributes to several disaster relief programs and asks that its
distributors hold their prices in check during major recoveries.

"We want to earn money the old-fashioned way," he said. "And I know those
farmers have bigger problems on their minds right now. "

The ECP provides cost-share assistance to affected producers at a rate not to
exceed 75 percent of the eligible cost of restoration measures. Producers will
need to contact the local FSA office for a review of their situation before
repairs begin.

The agency also has an Emergency Loan Program available at a 2.25-percent
interest rate. An expedited loan process has been approved to process these
loans that involve feed losses such as hay destroyed by the wildfires.

As Congress Chases Tie-up, BJP Plans to Intensify Attack in Bangalore

DATELINE: BENGALURU


BENGALURU, Sept. 7 -- With the state government devoting its full time and
energy to strike a deal with the JD(S) to come to power in BBMP, the BJP is set
to exploit the situation by intensifying its agitation against the government
from Monday.

The party's core committee, which met here on Sunday, chalked out a

the people's mandate in BBMP which is in favour of the BJP".

At a joint press conference after the meeting, BJP state president and MP

state government."

Ugrappa and Jayamala) and nominated MLA Vinisha Nero in the voters' list for the

bar them from voting.

Yeddyurappa demanded waiver of farm loans obtained from cooperative societies
and waiver of interest on farm loans taken from nationalised banks in the
backdrop of the severe drought. He accused the chief minister of being
irresponsible in addressing the plight of farmers who are committing suicide due

and Mysuru. He has not bothered to visit the drought-affected areas and oversee
the relief works. Even Agriculture Minister Krishna Byre Gowda has confined
himself to Bengaluru. I have not seen such a shameless and irresponsible
government. There is no government in the state ... the government is dead,"
Yeddyurappa said.

He also demanded that the government convene an emergency session of the state
legislature to discuss the issue of drought and other problems.

                  The State Journal-Register(Springfield, IL)

                           February 27, 2001 Tuesday

Consultant doesn't see new farm bill until 2002

BYLINE: CHARLYN FARGO AGRIBUSINESS EDITOR

SECTION: MARKETPLACE, Pg. 27

LENGTH: 585 words


It will be spring 2002 before farmers see a farm bill out of Washington,
according to Jim Wiesemeyer.

Wiesemeyer, a consultant with Pro Farmer, spoke Monday at the 2001 Governmental
Affairs Leadership Conference of the Illinois Farm Bureau. The meeting continues
today at the Crowne Plaza Hotel.

"It just won't happen this year," Wiesemeyer said.

However, he said, with the number of senators and members of the Senate
Agriculture Committee up for re-election, he's pretty sure farmers will see a
farm bill next year.

Wiesemeyer said he often hears that the new farm bill will amount to $9 billion
more than the base for fiscal year 2001 and $9 billion to $12 billion for FY
2002.

"If they're successful, farmers will have to go to confession if they come back
for more emergency funding after that," Wiesemeyer said.

"The (current bill) has not been perfect, but it hasn't ever been allowed to
work. Going back and asking for $24 billion (in emergency funding) in the past
three years means the farm bill needs to be tweaked. It just hasn't been the
rousing success it could have been."

Debate on the 2002 farm bill has already begun. American Farm Bureau Federation
president Robert Stallman is expected to testify before the Senate Agriculture
Committee Wednesday.

Wiesemeyer expects next year's farm bill to keep the current bill's planting
flexibility as well as loans and market loan provisions.

New elements may include counter-cyclical payments for years when farm income
dips low, he said, adding that he expects renewable fuels such as ethanol to
play a big part, too. "Ethanol continues to be a motherhood-and-apple-pie
issue," said Wiesemeyer. "I see MTBE (a natural-gas- based fuel additive)
eventually being phased out, and that will be beneficial for ethanol. If there's
a growth industry, it's ethanol."

Ron Warfield, president of the Illinois Farm Bureau, said the group's long-term
objective is for farmers to receive income from the marketplace rather than from
the government.

"If we had an energy policy that promoted renewable fuels, we wouldn't need to
spend the baseline of the farm program," said Warfield. "The same thing with our
trade policy. If we're aggressive with a trade policy, we won't be needing farm
income from the government. But in the meantime, we need money there to prop up
income levels for farmers."

Warfield also believes farmers need to sell value-added products in the
marketplace and to have voluntary incentives in place for conservation of land.
"Give us the right incentives and producers will provide clean air, clean water
and soil conservation," said Warfield. "My challenge is to put the emphasis
where it should be - to get income from the marketplace. But so far, we've not
had the farm policies to do that."

This year, however, because of continued low commodity prices and rising
production costs, the American Farm Bureau and 22 other farm groups have asked
congressional leaders for increased emergency funding.

In a Feb. 6 letter to House Agriculture Committee chairman Larry Combest,
R-Texas, and the Senate committee chairman, Richard Lugar, R-Ind., the farm
groups asked them to urge the House and Senate budget committees to provide
additional agricultural funding "equal to at least the same level of emergency
economic loss assistance" that was provided for the 2000 crop. The requested
funding would be in addition to Congressional Budget Office projections for farm
program outlays.

                                 March 12, 2014

Drought designation will help entire state

BYLINE: Arizona Range News staff

LENGTH: 240  words


Starting this week, farmers and ranchers in 11 Arizona counties can seek
financial relief from the impact of the intense drought through the U.S.
Department of Agriculture (USDA). Despite the recent rainfall in the state, the
threat of the drought continues to hang over Arizona's agricultural industry.

With this federal designation, farm operators and ranchers in Apache, Coconino,
Greenlee, Mohave, Navajo and Yavapai counties - and neighboring counties of
Cochise, Gila, Graham, LaPaz and Maricopa - are eligible to apply for
low-interest emergency loans from the Farm Service Agency (FSA). The other four
counties - Pima, Pinal, Santa Cruz and Yuma were eligible starting on Feb. 27,
2014.

"This announcement is great news for Arizona farmers. The extreme drought
creates a host of issues for our agricultural partners including significant
land damage and financial losses," said Jack Peterson, Interim Director for the
Arizona Department of Agriculture. "No matter what the weather forecast is, we
have a significant hill to climb to emerge from this drought."

With the disaster designation, the USDA found that agricultural production
losses in the counties were sufficient to warrant federal assistance.

Eligible farm operators in the affected areas have eight months to apply for
low-interest emergency loans from the FSA, at which time the agency will
determine whether damages and production losses are sufficient to warrant the
funding.

                         Portland Press Herald (Maine)

                      March 29, 2002 Friday, Final Edition

Federal inspectors examine drought;
Maine officials say the state deserves FEMA funds because it lacks the
infrastructure to deal with the water crisis.

BYLINE: RYAN BLETHEN Staff Writer

SECTION: LOCAL & STATE; Pg. 1B

LENGTH: 476 words


Inspectors from the Federal Emergency Management Agency began visiting water
districts Thursday to gauge effects of the drought and decide if Maine should be
declared a disaster area.

The inspectors were dispatched to review plans the water districts are proposing
to deal with the drought, said Lynette Miller, spokesperson for Maine Emergency
Management Agency.

"The key is what costs (the districts) have incurred and what they are
responding with," she said.

The first water districts inspected were York and South Berwick. FEMA inspectors
also plan to visit water districts in Castine, Alfred, Buxton, Hollis, Kennebunk
and Bethel.

Inspectors in York were shown a plan that would construct a three-mile water
pipe from Belle Marsh Reservoir to Chases Pond. Belle Marsh is in York but
supplies water for Kittery. The proposal would pump untreated water to York's
water supply, Chases Pond, which has run low in the drought.

In South Berwick, FEMA inspectors were looking at wells used by the water
district.

If the disaster declaration is made, it will be the first time FEMA provides
funds for a drought-related disaster. To be eligible for drought assistance,
FEMA inspectors have to find $1.4 million in damage to public facilities.

On the surface it might seem surprising that Maine could be the first state to
be declared a drought disaster by FEMA. But when the state's reliance on wells
is taken into account, it makes sense, Miller said.

"It's happened because we are a water-rich state and have not had to build the
infrastructure to deal with intermittent droughts," she said.

The lack of infrastructure might help Maine receive the assistance it needs from
FEMA because other states have the mechanisms to help mitigate drought
conditions, said Art Cleaves, director of MEMA.

"We believe that has to weigh heavy," he said. "Our conditions have been worse
than other states' and our infrastructure is not there to accommodate it."

Water districts and well owners are not the only ones hurting. The Small
Business Administration has announced that loans will be available to assist
farm-dependent businesses hurt by the drought.

The SBA loans are for small, non-farm, agriculture-dependent businesses in Maine
and New Hampshire.

A disaster designation announced earlier this month by the U.S. Department of
Agriculture put in motion the loans, which can be as much as $1.5 million. The
loans come with a 4 percent interest rate lasting up to 30 years.

"These loans will target businesses that have faced the largest losses stemming
from the drought, but we will continue working to extend broader assistance
under the Federal Emergency Management Agency," said Sens. Olympia Snowe and
Susan Collins in a written statement.

Staff Writer Ryan Blethen can be contacted at 791-6329 or at:

rblethen@pressherald.com

                        Topeka Capital-Journal (Kansas)

                            September 3, 2012 Monday

USDA taking steps to help farmers

BYLINE: Ann Marie Bush.

THE CAPITAL-JOURNAL

LENGTH: 679 words


MAYETTA - Nick Bowser surveys his soybean crop.

The plants aren't tall enough. Some of them are dead, and there aren't enough
pods on the plants.

This year doesn't look good for the Jackson County farmer and other farmers
across the Midwest.

Bowser usually gets 30 to 40 bushels of soybeans per acre. He said he expects to
farm between 10 to 15 bushels per acre this year.

But farmers, Bowser said, are optimistic. And he, just like his brother, father
and grandfather, will get through this year.

"It's been depressing seeing the rains come and go," Bowser said.

The United States Department of Agriculture has called the 2012 drought the
worst in 50 years.

The Bowser family grows corn, wheat, grass hay and soybeans. They also raise
cattle.

Bowser, 31, remembers the summer of 1988, when he had to haul water to the
cattle.

His father, Mike, recalls a time in the late 1970s when the crops didn't fare
well.

Cecil Bowser, 83, Nick Bowser's grandfather, has encountered even more difficult
times on the farm. For instance, he remembers the summer of 1936.

"Things are a lot different than back then," Cecil Bowser said. "We didn't have
electricity."

He recalled that his mother would wet a towel and place it on the floor so he
and his siblings could nap comfortably.

Nick Bowser said his grandfather has told him about how the corn in 1936 would
get waist-high and then just fall over and die.

"There has been an improvement," he said. "Instead of outright failure, we are
at least producing something."

Times were tough enough in the 1930s that Cecil Bowser's father lost the family
farm.

"But we all survived," he said.

The family - as well as farmers across the country - are hoping to survive again
this year thanks to crop insurance and steps the government is taking to help
producers.

Michael Scuse, undersecretary of farm and foreign agricultural services for the
USDA, stopped by the Bowser family farm last week. Scuse has been touring the
country to see firsthand has the drought has impacted farmers.

Last week, USDA secretary Tom Vilsack announced a two-month expansion for
emergency grazing on conservation reserve program acres, freeing up forage and
feed for ranchers as they look to recover from the drought.

"This flexibility for ranchers marks the latest action by the U.S. Department of
Agriculture to provide assistance to producers impacted by the drought, which
has included opening CRP and other conservation acres to emergency haying and
grazing, lowering the interest rate for emergency loans, and working with crop
insurance companies to provide flexibility to farmers," a USDA news release
states.

It also states in the past seven weeks, USDA has designated 1,892 unduplicated
counties in 38 states as disaster areas - 1,820 because of the drought.

To help producers, USDA is permitting farmers and ranchers in drought-stricken
states that have been approved for emergency grazing to extend grazing on CRP
land through Nov. 30 without incurring an additional CRP rental payment
reduction.

The USDA also has announced intent to purchase up to $170 million of pork, lamb,
chicken and catfish for federal nutritional assistance programs; allowed
emergency loans to be made earlier in the season; authorized up to $5 million in
grants to evaluate and demonstrate agriculture practices that help farmers and
ranchers adapt to drought; authorized $16 million in existing funds from its
Wildlife Habitat Incentive Program and Environmental Quality Incentives Program
to target states experiencing exceptional and extreme drought; and simplified
the secretarial disaster designation process and reduced the time it takes to
designate counties affected by disasters by 40 percent.

Nick Bowser said the biggest benefit he will realize this year is his crop
insurance payment. He has harvested 35 to 30 percent of his corn crop.

"It's pretty bad," he said. "I think our best field will produce about 40
bushels per acre."

Usually, he has 90 to 100 bushels per acre.

"Farmers are an optimistic lot," Nick Bowser said. "If we don't produce a crop
this year, we have next year's crop."

                                  July 8, 2010

USDA grants Secretarial Disaster Designation to 86 Kentucky counties

BYLINE: Hart Countys News-Herald staff

LENGTH: 335  words


Special to The News-Herald Gov. Steve Beshear today announced that U.S.
Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack has granted his request for disaster
assistance to Kentucky farm families in 86 counties, due to severe storms and
flooding that occurred in early May.

"We are pleased that Sec. Vilsack has issued this disaster designation for
Kentucky's farm families," said Gov. Beshear. "The severe storms and flooding
impacted all facets of Kentucky's agricultural industry and assistance from the
USDA will help offset resulting income losses."

After review of Loss Assessment Reports and other information submitted by
Kentucky's Farm Service Agency Executive Director John Mc-Cauley, the USDA
determined that there were sufficient production losses to warrant a Secretarial
natural disaster designation in 38 counties. Primary counties in this area
included in this disaster designation are as follows: Barren, Edmonson, Grayson.

Also as a result of this designation, 48 contiguous counties are eligible for
assistance. Those counties in this area are as follows: Hart, Green, Larue,
Hardin, Metcalfe and Monroe.

A Secretarial disaster designation provides farm families, meeting eligibility
requirements, in both primary and contiguous counties the opportunity to be
considered for disaster assistance from FSA, including emergency loans and
Supplemental Revenue Assistance Payments (SURE) Program. Farmers in eligible
counties have until March 1, 2011 to apply for emergency loan assistance. SURE
Program applications for 2010 crop losses will be accepted in 2011 when the 2010
farm revenue data becomes available.

Information about USDA Disaster Assistance Programs and the Secretarial disaster
designation process are available at www.fsa.usda.gov by clicking on the
Disaster Assistance Program link in the left-hand column.

Local FSA offices can provide affected farmers with further information. To
locate the office that services your county, visit
http://offices.sc.egov.usda.gov/locator/ app?state=ky& agency=fsa.

                              The Washington Post

                  September 29, 1984, Saturday, Final Edition

FmHA Policies Speed Black Farmers' Ruin, Say Jackson, Activists

BYLINE: By Ward Sinclair, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: First Section; A2

LENGTH: 516 words


Jesse L. Jackson and a group of black southern rural activists charged yesterday
that Reagan administration policies have speeded a trend that, in about 15
years, could result in no blacks owning land they farm.

Their criticism was focused on lending policies of the Agriculture Department's
Farmers Home Administration (FmHA), which, they said, has reduced dramatically
farm operating and ownership loans to blacks since 1980.

Jackson described the situation as "a travesty" and Joseph Brooks, president of
the Emergency Land Fund, said Agriculture Secretary John R. Block has failed to
put into effect reforms proposed a year ago by a USDA task force on problems and
needs of black farmers.

The USDA has been under nearly constant fire since 1982, when the U.S. Civil
Rights Commission criticized Block and urged major policy changes to help black
farmers. The commission warned that, without help, the country's 57,000 black
farmers face gradual extinction.

More recently, the department has been probed by a House Judiciary subcommittee,
following a USDA inspector general's report that civil-rights and
equal-opportunity enforcement is at a standstill.

FmHA statistics show that, in fiscal 1981, whites received 87 percent of the
agency's loans for farm ownership, operating and rural housing. By 1984, whites
were receiving 91 percent of the loans.

Larger disproportions occurred in the area of farm-purchase and operating loans.
In 1981, minorities received 10 percent of operating loans and 6 percent of
ownership money. By 1984, it was 7 percent for operating and 4 percent for
ownership.

Jackson, an unsuccessful candidate for the Democratic presidential nomination,
said the "doom" facing black farmers "must be put in a context beyond race" -- a
context he described as Reagan tax and spending policies aimed at helping
corporations and the wealthy at the expense of the poor.

In agriculture, he said, the administration's payment-in-kind (PIK) program to
reduce grain surpluses was "a program for the rich that paid workers not to
work. It was a pickpocket program for the poor."

Jackson was joined by Rep. Edolphus Towns (D-N.Y.), Brooks and officials of the
Federation of Southern Cooperatives in criticizing the administration. The
Emergency Land Fund and the federation work to help blacks retain or acquire new
farm land and develop new markets for their farm products.

Brooks said the USDA task force suggested "some chance of reversing this crisis
. . . but we've heard nothing since September 1983 on what the secretary of
agriculture intends to do . . . . We call on the secretary to come forward with
what he intends to do and not wait until after the general election."

Federation Director Ralph Paige said, "USDA is doing business as usual. We made
recommendations to the department, but nothing has been done. It is a case of
too little, too late. We're asking for action now."

Jackson added: "This is classic vintage Reagan antiblack, antipoor behavior . .
. . One remedy to offset illegal negative action is to legally enforce
affirmative action."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Picture, Jackson: "classic vintage Reagan antiblack, antipoor
behavior." By James. K.W. Atherton--The Washington Post

                     Monroe County Appeal (Paris, Missouri)

                                 August 2, 2012

USDA top official visits local Monroe County farm

BYLINE: Monroe County Appeal staff

LENGTH: 817  words


On Friday, July 24, the top administrator of the Risk Management of the U.S.
Department of Sericulture told Monroe County farmers that the agency has relaxed
regulations to help farmers through a record-breaking drought.

Villiam J. Murphy of Washing-tom,D.C. visited with local farmers at-the
Stoutsville grain farm of-Monroe County Eastern District Commissioner Mike
Whelan arid his son, Aaron, as part of a statewide inspection of drought-plagued
farms. The younger Whelan serves as an Obama Administration appointee of
Missouri Farm Service Agency (FSA) State Committee.

"The administration is looking for ways to help with relief," Murphy told
approximately 40 farmers, bankers, crop insurance agents and elected officials.
Included in that relief package are 30-day extensions on payments without
penalties and operating loans with interest as low as 2.25 percent. Murphy said
U.S. Ag Secretary Tom Vil-sack is pushing to relax restrictions on CRP land, in
addition to pushing for passage of a new farm bill that would provide additional
drought relief. Additionally, deviations from standard procedures for insurance
agencies have been pre-approved to allow agencies to expedite claims.

The good news is that USDA is not limited by budgetary concerns for payouts to
farmers and there will be a great deal of flexibility in determining losses, he
said.

Farmers who pay for crop insurance will see some financial relief from failed
crops. But will that insurance be enough? "Crop insurance will help this year,"
he said. He said crop insurance alone may not be enough this year, depending
upon the level of coverage and whether the farmer had contracted on the futures
market to provide levels of grain that they are unable to produce.

Many farmers are cutting com into silage or "abandoning" crops by not spending
more money on production. Murphy urged farmers who are doing this to contact
their crop insurance agent before making either one of those decisions.

Farmers should also begin pulling production records now if they anticipate
losses over $200,000, Murphy said, to avoid fall delays. "It's not good to have
surprises at claims time," he said.

Cornfields are producing low yields with most ears producing only a few grains
this year, and there is no good news in store. Farmers face docking of prices
from elevators even if they do produce a crop, he said, as a result of emerging
signs of aflatoxin, a mold and fungus.

With no rain in sight, farmers also are facing the likely possibility of low
soybean yields this year. "Soybeans may look nice from the road, but when you
get out and look at them, they may have only 3-8 pods on them," he said. Ninth
District Missouri State Rep. Paul Quinn said he had never been through a drought
that destroyed both corn and bean crops. The last recorded drought for Monroe
County farmers was in 1988, he said, but this year's lack of rainfall is worse.
According to the National Weather Service, Monroe County received only 4.39
inches of rain from May 1-July 19. This is 7.69 inches less than the average for
this period. The January to May 2012 rainfall was 9.77 inches less than the
average, with the damage being compounded by back-to-back record-setting
scorching temperatures.

Rainfall has been so scattered that some farms have received even less than the
reported amounts.

Dan Engemann, deputy district director for Ninth District U.S. Rep. Blaine
Luetkemeyer, said there are a few pockets of green crops throughout the state,
but "they are few and far between."

Lynn Fodge, owner of Hopewell Farms of Paris, asked Murphy if any programs were
available to help Missouri's cattle producers. Because of the drought cattlemen
are facing severe shortages of hay for feed, and water sources are going dry.
Murphy said there are two new programs available to cattle producers and
information on these and other programs can be obtained by contacting the county
FSA office.

Tony Francis, executive director of FSA in Monroe County, said emergency haying
and grazing use of Conservation Reserve Program (CRP) acres is in effect, due to
recent extreme temperatures. The county is one of 73 Missouri Counties released
for emergency haying and grazing. For more information, contact him at
660-327-4137 or visit www.fsa.usda.gov/mo.

Eddie Joe Hamill, state director of the FSA, said farmers in Missouri's 114
counties can apply for emergency loans, usually only available at the end of the
season, that are available now. FSA Farm Loan Manager Bob Noellsch of Bowling
Green said applicants must be denied conventional financing before being
approved for low-interest loans. FSA representatives also can assist livestock
producers with a cost-sharing program for water, Hamill said.

"When you're looking at a 30 percent chance of rain at the end of the week,
you're in dire straits," Murphy said. And even if that rain comes, it likely
will be too little, too late.

                              The American Banker

New Loans Not Seen Helping Farmers

                             August 5, 1983, Friday

By ANDREW ALBERT

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


The president-elect of the American Bankers Association challenged the position
of many agricultural groups Thursday, insisting that more lending is not a cure
for the financially depressed farm belt.

''In general, farmers do not need more credit. They need better markets at
better prices,'' C. Robert Brenton, who becomes ABA president in October, told a
House Banking subcommittee on economic stabilization.

His comments reflect a growing debate that pits farmers against the Reagan
administration and some bankers.

The administration opposes any increase in the use of federal loan programs,
claiming that more credit will simply worsen farmers' repayment problems.
Instead, government officials say, farmers should concentrate more on finding
new foreign buyers for their goods.

Most agricultural groups reject that agrument. They contend the government must
first address immediate problems in order to prevent thousands of farm closings.

Joining other agribusiness experts, Mr. Brenton addressed the issue Thursday
while testifying the House panel. The subcommittee, headed by Rep. John J.
LaFalce, D-N.Y., plans to draft legislation later this year to help ''fill
capital gaps'' that exist in a number of industries, including agriculture.

''The price of credit may be higher than most borrowers would prefer, but credit
at some price is generally available from private or public sources,'' said Mr.
Brenton, who is also president of Brenton Banks Inc., a prominent agricultural
lender based in Des Moines, Iowa. He supports administration's argument for
restricting federal credit.

Depressed Commodity Prices

Mr. Brenton acknowledged that much of the farm belt was still suffering from
depressed commodity prices. But he said lenders are trying to be as flexible as
possible in arranging repayment plans.

''Some farmers should and will fail,'' said Mr. Brenton, but ''most will survive
and prosper.''

According to Paul Sacia, who handles credit matters for the Farmers Union trade
group here, Mr. Brenton's assessment of the farm economy failed to express the
urgency of the situation.

''The reality is that thousands of farmers are on the brink of going out of
business. If the government is concerned with keeping them in business, it
should look at short-term credit problems,'' Mr. Sacia said in an interview.

The Farmers Union is highly critical of the government's credit policy, but has
praise for commerical banks in ''bending over backwards'' to keep the farm
economy alive.

Government figures show that total agricultural debt outstanding is at a record
of more than $218 billion, with U.S. commercial banks holding more than 20% of
that.

''We just don't think the government is living up to their responsiblity,'' Mr.
Sacia said, referring to a number of federal credit programs he said are not
being fully used to provide aid.

Mr. Brenton told the lawmakers yesterday that he too believed that government
lending can be useful, but only as a last resort. ''Government and
quasi-government agencies should operate only in the areas where private
industry cannot do so,'' he said.

One producer group, the American Farm Bureau Federation, differs from other
agricultural organizations in siding with the administration. Mary Kay Thatcher,
the group's credit expert, said: ''In the end, higher prices and more export
markets will be the answer to prosperity. We don't want to pour in more money to
get farmers deeper and deeper in debt.''

The debate over the role of government in the area of agricultural credit
recently intensified in Congress as farm state representatives began fighting to
require more federal lending.

The House recently approved the Economic Emergency Agricultural Act of 1983,
which directs the federal government to dole out more from its lending coffers,
especially in emergency situations.

Congress has already appropriated funds for emergency farm loans this year, the
administration has for the most part refused to offer such credit, farm
lobbyists argue.

Mr. Sacia of the Farmers Union said the government has used only about half of
the $292 million available for the Limited Resource Loan Program -- which serves
the most needy farmers.

After the House passed the farm credit bill, H.R. 1190, some Senate members
tried unsuccessfully to adopt similar legislation, S. 24, which the White House
opposes.

Farm groups will try to promote the measure when Congress returns from its Labor
Day recess in mid-September. The recess begins at the end of business Friday.

The fate of the Senate bill is questionable because many oppose an increase in
the government's farm lending.

Testifying before the banking subcommittee yesterday, Marvin Duncan, vice
president of the Kansas City Federal Reserve Bank, summarized the growing
sentiment.

''There is little, if any, evidence from the agricultural sector that
government-administered generalized credit allocation has improved the sector's
performance,'' Mr. Duncan said.

                 Sampson Independent (Clinton, North Carolina)

                     Distributed by Tribune Content Agency

                           October 29, 2016 Saturday

Disaster Center set up in Sampson; myriad aid offered

BYLINE: Chris Berendt, The Sampson Independent, Clinton, N.C.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 1231 words


Oct. 29--A Disaster Recovery Center has opened in Sampson County for residents
suffering loss and damage due to Hurricane Matthew to obtain information about
available state and federal assistance.

The DRC opened Friday and will remain open as long as the community needs it.
The center is located in the upstairs conference room at the Sampson County
Human Services building in Clinton, located at 360 County Complex Road, Suite
200, Room 274.

It will be open Monday-Saturday, 9 a.m. to 7 p.m. and Sunday, noon to 5 p.m.,
until further notice.

DRCs are staffed with representatives from the Federal Emergency Management
Agency, N.C. Emergency Management and the U.S. Small Business Administration
(SBA). Staff will offer help applying for federal assistance and updates
regarding their application, as well as educate residents on what types of
assistance are available and the appeals process.

"A lot of people feel more comfortable with a face-to-face interaction," said
Debra Young, media relations specialist for FEMA. "Some come in after they apply
for assistance just to get more information on the process. We don't want anyone
to miss out on the assistance they need to get their life back on track."

FEMA grants do not have to be repaid. FEMA assistance is nontaxable and will not
affect eligibility for Social Security, Medicaid or other federal benefits.
Survivors should register even if they have insurance, Young noted.

For Matthew disaster victims who live in one of the North Carolina counties
designated for individual assistance -- Sampson is one of them -- and have
applied for help with FEMA, they may be referred to the SBA.

Low-interest disaster loans from the SBA are available for businesses of all
sizes, private non-profit organizations, homeowners and renters. Disaster loans
cover losses not fully compensated by insurance or other recoveries. Homeowners
and renters who submit an SBA application and are not approved for a loan may be
considered for certain other FEMA grants and programs that could include
assistance for disaster-related car repairs, clothing, household items and other
expenses.

Those receiving a loan application, even if they do not believe they need a
loan, should submit the application, said Karen Knapik, public affairs
specialist for the SBA's Office of Disaster Assistance.

Next to insurance, an SBA low-interest disaster loan is the primary source of
funds for real estate property repairs and for replacing contents destroyed in
the recent flooding. However, people should not wait on an insurance settlement
before submitting an SBA loan application, Knapik said.

A low-interest SBA disaster loan will help "bridge the gap," she noted. The loan
balance will be reduced by the insurance settlement for those receive one. SBA
loans may be available for losses not covered by insurance or other sources.

Knapik said $10 million has already been distributed for North Carolina, "and
that is just getting started." She said about 98 percent of that has gone to
homeowners. Those with no credit available elsewhere can get home loans at less
than 1.6 percent interest to help them repair or replace disaster-damaged real
estate and personal property, including automobiles.

"We are just trying to get the word out," said Knapik. "We will stay in
communities as long as they need us."

Through Friday afternoon, FEMA has had 59,380 people statewide register for
assistance, disbursing in excess of $52 million. Young said the traffic at the
Sampson DRC Friday was "kind of weak," but felt that as the word spread traffic
would pick up.

"The county has been great," Young said. "(Sampson assistant county manager)
Susan Holder has been great at helping get the word out."

To locate the nearest DRC nearest to you, call the FEMA Helpline at
1-800-621-3362, go online to www.fema.gov/drc or download the ReadyNC mobile
app. You may also apply online using the Electronic Loan Application via the
SBA's secure website at https://disasterloan.sba.gov/ela. The SBA Customer
Service Center can be reached at 800-659-2955 (800-877-8339 for the deaf and
hard-of-hearing), sending an email to disastercustomerservice@sba.gov or
visiting SBA's Web site at www.sba.gov/disaster.

For more information on the North Carolina recovery, visit the disaster webpage
at fema.gov/disaster/4285; or visit the North Carolina Emergency Management
website at ncdps.gov.

Children

In the aftermath of Hurricane Matthew, many residents continue to deal with
personal loss and challenging conditions. To assist in the recovery process, the
USDA is providing assistance to 32 North Carolina counties, including the
Clinton City Schools' Child Nutrition Services.

A memo provided by CCS Child Nutrition Director Jeff Swartz on Friday noted that
the benefits will include offering meals to all students of Clinton City Schools
at no charge from Oct. 17 through Nov. 11.

During this time, each student, regardless of his or her approved meal status
will be allowed one breakfast and one lunch per day at no charge, and the
student's accounts will be adjusted.

All meals will continue to meet USDA guidelines. Additional items, including
milk, may be purchased at the a la carte prices. Starting on Nov. 14, student
meals will return to regular pricing.

Parents and guardians who have not done so already may submit an application for
free or reduced meals benefits at any time throughout the school year. Only one
application is needed per household.

"Easy access to nutritious school meals will help keep students well-nourished
and ready to learn as our community continues to deal with the aftermath and
recovery from Hurricane Matthew," Swartz stated.

Agriculture

Secretary Thomas J. Vilsack of the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) signed
39 Primary Disaster Designations for North Carolina. Sampson County was one of
the areas named Friday.

"Our hearts go out to those North Carolina Farmers and ranchers affected by
recent natural disasters," Vilsack stated in a news releases from the USDA.

The USDA Farm Service Agency North Carolina State Executive Director Bob
Etheridge on Tuesday requested the Secretarial Disaster Designations for North
Carolina's most devastated counties post-Hurricane Matthew. Etheridge offered
his thanks to Vilsack for a "quick turnaround" of 48 hours following the
request.

Farmers in eligible counties are encouraged to apply for FSA Disaster Programs.
They have eight months from the date of the declaration to apply for loans to
help cover part of their actual losses.

The USDA reviewed the Loss Assessment Reports and determined that there were
sufficient production losses to warrant secretarial natural disaster
designations for primary disasters areas. Those reports indicate at least one
crop with losses in excess of 30 percent in those counties.

Qualified farm operators in the designated areas are eligible for low interest
emergency (EM) loans from USDA's Farm Service Agency (FSA), provided eligibility
requirements are met.

FSA will consider each loan application on its own merits, taking into account
the extent of losses, security available and repayment ability.

Reach Managing Editor Chris Berendt at 910-249-4616. Follow the paper on twitter
@SampsonInd and like us on Facebook.

JAMESTOWN Farmers somewhat in limbo ü The deadline for farmers to apply for Farm
Service Agency emergency loans is approaching, but delays in federal farm
legislation are hampering farmers who may be eligible for help. Farmers in
several counties became eligible for the loans after a presidential flood
disaster declaration last May. The deadline to apply is Jan. 16. Stutsman County
Agriculture Credit Manager Wynn Rasmussen said farmers cannot develop a plan if
they do not know what the federal farm bill will provide. ""If they don't know
what they're going to be planting, or what the program for 1996 is -- if they
can't tell us what it is -- they can't tell another commercial creditor that
they've been working with what their plan is, either,'' he said. To qualify for
the emergency loans, farmers must show they experienced a 30 percent loss in a
major crop or commodity due to the flooding. -- Associated Press

Transitional living program OK'd ü A governing board for the State Hospital has
approved a transitional living program on hospital grounds. The program will use
two vacant residential houses to allow people to learn daily living skills
before they get their own homes. ""It gives us an opportunity to say this is a
more homelike setting even though it's on a hospital campus, and this individual
is successful in these skills,'' said Supervisor Nancy Schulz. The houses need
about $5,800 worth of renovations, which should be done in February. The program
probably will get under way in March or April, Schulz said. Four males will be
in one house and four females in the other. Schulz said residents probably will
stay for up to six months. The program will cost about $300,000 a year, but
medical assistance and other federal payments should cover nearly all the cost,
Schulz said. -- Associated Pressü

FARGO Plant to hire technicians ü Operators of a new corn processing plant near
Wahpeton say they plan to hire about 70 technicians to help keep the plant
running. ProGold officials have scheduled orientation meetings in Wahpeton and
Fargo from Jan. 29 through Feb. 3, when they plan to distribute job
applications.The technicians will work 12-hour rotating shifts round the clock,
ProGold officials said. ""These people will be the backbone of our plant
workforce,'' said Richard Geurts, operations director for ProGold, ""and as
such, they will have a lot of responsibility to keep the plant running
efficiently while maintaining product quality.'' The co-op of corn growers that
was created to invest in the plant has scheduled its first annual meeting next
Thursday in Fargo. The Golden Growers co-op plans to elect one director from
each of five districts. The co-op has about 2,000 members in North Dakota,
Minnesota and South Dakota. Golden Growers is a partner in the ProGold plant,
along with American Crystal Sugar in Moorhead and the Minn-Dak Farmers
Cooperative of Wahpeton. -- Associated Press

Dead moose creates concern ü A 500-pound moose carcass hanging from a tree in
man's yard led to at least one call to local health officials. But sanitarian
Terry Ludlum said the frozen carcass doesn't pose any health problems. The moose
belongs to Rick Wagner, who bagged it Dec. 18 and hung it in the tree until he
can butcher it. Wagner said he plans to butcher the moose this weekend. --
Associated Pressü

BISMARCK Lamb cooperative considered ü Sheep ranchers in eastern North Dakota
are taking the first steps toward the formation of a lamb cooperative. Members
of the Valley Wool Growers Association will discuss the idea at their annual
meeting Jan. 15 in Page. The association already has a head start, since members
of its wool pool own about 10,000 stock ewes, said board member Dennis
Kubischta. Steele County commissioners and local economic development officials
have expressed interest in building a packing plant, he said. ""We have a county
that would like a plant, and they have a government agency in place that's
willing to look for funds to start it,'' he said. ""It's maybe one-half of 1
percent at the beginning, but it's a start.'' -- Associated Pressü

DEVILS LAKE County disputes audit report ü Ramsey County commissioners are
disputing an audit report that says the county owes about $297,000 to the
federal Environmental Protection Agency for overpayment on a rural water
project. The audit questions engineering costs. But commissioners said the
contractor did the best job possible under the circumstances, which included bad
weather and high groundwater. The state Health Department has backed the
county's analysis, saying it disagrees with the EPA findings. -- Associated
Press

Evaluation ordered for teen ü A psychiatric evaluation has been ordered for a
15-year-old who authorities say shot and killed a convenience store clerk.
Northeast District Judge Donovan Foughty said Friday he approved a request for
the evaluation, which was filed by the lawyer for Marlon Comes. The teen-ager is
charged with murder and robbery in the Dec. 14 shotgun slaying of Donald Jerome,
31, during an early morning robbery at a Devils Lake convenience store. Comes
and two other juveniles, 17-year-old Adrian Alex and 16-year-old Wayne
Greywater, were transferred to adult court earlier this week. All three are from
Fort Totten. Alex and Greywater also face murder and robbery charges.
Authorities say Comes was the triggerman. A fourth juvenile, who has not been
identified, was found guilty earlier in juvenile court of being an accomplice.
Authorities said he drove the getaway car. Scott Thompson, Comes'
court-appointed lawyer, said Friday that he requested the evaluation to
determine whether his client suffers from mental illness. The evaluation, which
will take place at the State Hospital in Jamestown, is expected to be completed
within 60 days, Thompson said. -- Associated Press

                         Telegraph Herald (Dubuque, IA)

Ag News Briefs

BYLINE: Telegraph Herald Staff

SECTION: Agriculture; Pg. b4

LENGTH: 583 words

DATELINE: EPWORTH, Iowa


Loan applications available in Epworth

Farm operators who have suffered major forage or crop production losses and/or
physical losses caused by drought from Jan. 1, 2005 and continuing, might be
eligible for emergency loans.

Applications for assistance should be completed at the Dubuque County Farm
Service Agency office, located at 210 Bierman Road in Epworth.

Applicants must provide an itemized list of all the claimed expenses incurred
and must be able to obtain credit from other usual sources to qualify for the
FSA Farm Loan Program assistance.

The interest rate on the emergency loans is 3.75 percent.

July 14 is the deadline.

Forage expo planned at college in Fennimore

FENNIMORE, Wis. - Southwest Wisconsin Technical College and the U.S. Department

Farm operators possibly eligible for emergency loans

BYLINE: Telegraph Herald

SECTION: A; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 84 words


Farm operators who have suffered severe physical losses caused by hail, high
winds or a tornado might be eligible for an emergency loan.

Loans may enable farmers to repair or replace damaged or destroyed property
essential to the farming operation, including buildings, real estate fixtures,
equipment, livestock and crops.

Applications for assistance can be completed at the Delaware County Farm Service
Agency, 200 S. 12th St. in Manchester. The final date for making applications is
Tuesday, Feb. 7, 2012.

                    The News & Advance (Lynchburg, Virginia)

                           December 13, 2008 Saturday

Thirteen Virginia counties designated natural disaster areas

BYLINE: The News & Advance, Lynchburg, Va.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 328 words


Dec. 13--Thirteen Virginia counties, including Albemarle, Buckingham and
Lunenburg, were designated Friday as primary natural disaster areas because of
drought, Gov. Timothy M. Kaine an-nounced.

The disaster designations make farmers eligible for low-interest loans and any
supplemental relief that might be pro-vided by Congress in the future, Kaine's
office said.

Ten other counties designated on the list were Caroline, Fluvanna, Franklin,
Goochland, Greene, Hanover, Henry, Isle of Wight, Powhatan and Rockbridge.

In October, farmers in Am-herst, Bedford, Campbell and Nelson counties became
eligible for federal assistance after being designated primary natural disaster
areas.

The cities of Lynchburg and Bedford received contiguous disaster status because
of their proximity.

Charlotte County is among a dozen other counties for which Kaine requested
disaster designa-tion. The federal government still is considering that request,
Kaine said, adding that he expected "the federal government will soon respond to
these additional requests."

The designations result from U.S. Department of Agriculture findings concerning
crop loss.

Disaster declarations make farm operators in both primary and contiguous
counties and cities eligible to be considered for low-interest emergency loans
from the Farm Service Agency of the USDA, provided they meet eligibility
requirements.

This assistance includes FSA emergency loans and the Sup-plemental Revenue
Assistance Program (SURE) that was approved as part of the Food, Con-servation
and Energy Act of 2008.

Aiken, Burke, Columbia, Richmond and Screven counties are on a list of primary
natural disaster areas, according to a letter from U.S. Department of
Agriculture Secretary Thomas Vilsack.

soil conditions for future harvests. It allows farm operators in designated

Chamber honors textile company

A Graniteville textile company was recognized by the state's chamber of commerce
Thursday as one of its top manufacturers.

The South Carolina Chamber of Commerce named Graniteville Specialty Fabrics as
its 2013 Manufacturer of the Year in the small company division.

The company makes awnings, tents and custom-coated marine fabrics. It has been
in the area since 1947.

"Our associates have worked diligently to effect a successful business
turn-around in a difficult economy by achieving significant improvements," said
company president Jim Egan.

The other two award-winners were treated lumber maker Cox Industries in
Orangeburg in the medium-sized company division and tire maker Michelin North
America in Greenville for the large-sized company division.

The chamber's award program recognizes companies that strive for manufacturing
excellence, have a positive economic impact and are outstanding community
stewards.

Nasdaq takes some blame for outage

NEW YORK -- Nasdaq OMX Group says a three-hour trading halt last week was partly
the result of issues within the company's control.

In a statement released Thursday, the company detailed some of its early
findings from an internal review. Nasdaq blamed "a confluence of unprecedented
events" that overwhelmed the exchange's system for handling price information.
It said high-speed trading played no role in the incident.

The outage cracked the midday calm of a quiet summer day on Wall Street, sending
brokers and traders scrambling to figure out what went wrong.

Counties to receive agricultural disaster funds

SECTION: Pg. B5

LENGTH: 282 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


The U.S. Department of Agriculture has approved a request to declare an
agricultural disaster in Oxford County, according to a press release from U.S.
Sens. Olympia J. Snowe and Susan Collins.

Maine Gov. John Baldacci requested the disaster designation to help farmers
recover from losses caused by excessive rain, flooding and a tornado that
occurred on Aug. 21.

The disaster designation makes farm operators in Oxford County, as well as the
contiguous counties of Androscoggin, Cumberland, Franklin and York as well as
Carroll and Coos counties in New Hampshire, eligible to be considered for Farm
Service Agency emergency loans and the Supplemental Revenue Assistance program.
Emergency loans are available to producers in these counties immediately. The
Farm Service Agency is in the process of developing software for the
Supplemental Revenue Assistance program that will be available soon.

The National Weather Service confirmed that a tornado touched down in Oxford
County during a severe thunderstorm on Aug. 21. Thousands of trees were uprooted
and numerous buildings were damaged or destroyed by high winds.

"This disaster declaration means necessary assistance will immediately be made
available to farmers and others in Maine's agricultural industry who suffered
losses during a terrible storm in August," Snowe and Collins said in the
release. "This funding can be used to help cover production and physical losses.
For more information on how to seek this assistance, farmers should contact
their local Farm Service Agency."

The Oxford County FSA can be reached at 743-5789, ext. 2; Cumberland-York County
FSA can be reached at 883-0159, ext. 2; and the Androscoggin FSA at 753-9400.

                        The Lakelander (Whitney, Texas)

                                  July 6, 2011

213 counties, including Hill and Bosque declared disaster areas;
Farmers, ranchers can now get USDA assistance

BYLINE: The Lakelander staff

LENGTH: 397  words


WASHINGTON - The U.S. Department of Agriculture has designated 213 counties in
Texas as primary natural disaster areas after one of the worst droughts in more
than a century. The state has sustained excessive heat, high winds and wildfires
that have burned hundreds of thousands of acres.

Bosque County was recognized as a primary natural disaster area, and Hill County
farmers and ranchers are also eligible for assistance because of their proximity
to the disaster area. With 213 counties declared primary disaster areas and the
remaining 41 qualifying for assistance because they are contiguous, the entire
state has been declared a disaster.

"Many producers have lost their crops due to the devastation caused by the
drought and wildfires," said Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack."President Obama
and I want these farmers and ranchers to know that we will support them through
the recovery process and help them once again become productive suppliers of
food, fibre and fuel that keep America prospering. This designation will help
provide that support." The drought, wildfires and other natural disasters--which
began Jan. 1, 2011, and continue--caused 30 percent or more loss of forage
crops, pasture, corn, oats and wheat in the 213 counties.

All qualified farm operators in the designated areas are eligible for low
interest emergency (EM) loans from USDA's Farm Service Agency (FSA), provided
eligibility requirements are met.

Farmers have eight months from the date of the declaration to apply for loans to
help cover part of their actual losses. FSA will consider each loan application
on its own merits, taking into account the extent of losses, security available
and repayment ability. FSA has a variety of programs, in addition to the EM loan
program, to help eligible farmers recover from adversity.

USDA also has made other programs available to assist farmers and ranchers,
including the Supplemental Revenue As-sistance Program which was approved as
part of the Pood, Conservation, and Energy Act of 2008; the Emergency
Conservation Program; Federal Crop Insurance; and the Non-insured Crop Disaster
Assistance Program.

Interested farmers may contact their local USDA Service Centres for further
information on eligibility requirements and application procedures for these and
other programs. Additional information is also available online at
http://disaster.fsa.usda.gov.

                       The Record ( Stockton, California)

                           February 10, 2015 Tuesday

Farmers eligible for drought aid

BYLINE: Reed Fujii, The Record, Stockton, Calif.

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 312 words


Feb. 10--Declaring 55 of California's 58 counties drought disaster areas,
federal farm officials have effectively opened relief programs to farmers and
ranchers throughout the state, as well as adjoining areas of Oregon, Nevada and
Arizona.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture declaration last week makes qualified
producers eligible for low interest emergency loans from the U.S. Farm Service
Agency. Producers have eight months to apply for such loans to help cover part
of their losses.

There are other programs from the FSA as well, including the Livestock Forage
Disaster Program, which helps offset the higher cost of feed when drought
deprives ranchers of their usual supply of natural forage.

Justin Oldfield, government relations vice president of the California
Cattlemen's Association, said all those programs can help ranchers affected by
the drought.

The biggest concern currently, however, is how much rain will the state receive
this year, he said.

California's cattle industry has seen its livestock count drop by an estimated
20 to 25 percent over the past few years because of the drought's impact on
pasture and forage.

"Is this the year we come out of drought and add more cows back to the cow
herd?" Oldfield asked.

With a wet December followed by a record dry January, the remaining weeks of the
rainy season will be key to answering that question, he said.

For information on emergency loans and other USDA programs, farmers may contact
their local USDA Service Center at 3422 W. Hammer Lane, Suite A, Stockton, or
telephone the office at (209) 472-7127. Help is also available online at
disaster.fsa.usda.gov.

-- Contact reporter Reed Fujii at (209) 546-8253 or rfujii@recordnet.com Follow
him on Twitter @ReedBiznews.

                            August 1, 2007 Wednesday

Minn. governor to ask for ag disaster declaration

SECTION: DAKOTA WIRE; Pg. 1b

LENGTH: 154 words


LITTLE FALLS, Minn. (AP) - After viewing crop damage at a central Minnesota farm
, Gov. Tim Pawlenty said on Tuesday that he's moving ahead with plans for a
possible disaster request for drought-stricken areas of the state.

Pawlenty said he'll ask for an agricultural disaster declaration for any county
that meets the U.S. Department of Agriculture threshold of more than a 30
percent crop loss.

The USDA State Emergency board meets on Thursday to make a recommendation to the
governor, after it reviews damage reports.

Pawlenty also said the Minnesota Department of Agriculture will offer two loan
programs to provide low-cost emergency and restructuring loans to farmers
affected by the drought. Pawlenty toured a farm near Little Falls Tuesday
morning to view the impact of the drought on crops and livestock. Except for
west-central and northwestern Minnesota, the state has drought conditions
ranging from moderate to severe.
