                           December 2, 2009 Wednesday

Disaster declaration made official

BYLINE: Vershal Hogan, The Natchez Democrat, Miss.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 434 words


Dec. 2--VIDALIA -- Some in the Concordia Parish farming community have been
saying it for months, but now the U.S. Department of Agriculture agrees -- it's
a disaster.

The disaster in question was heavy rain followed by no rain followed by heavy
rain, and USDA Secretary Tom Vilsack declared 53 parishes in Louisiana --
Concordia, Catahoula and Tensas among them -- as primary disaster areas Monday.

"It rained nearly every day for six or seven weeks, but in June and July it just
got dry," Concordia Parish Extension Service Director Glen Daniels said. "Then,
when it came time to harvest, it started raining again."

That rain caused a delay in harvesting a crop already damaged by the long dry
spell.

"It was such a tremendous loss in quality and yield," Daniels said. "A lot of
the crop deteriorated, a lot of the beans rotted, the cotton rotted -- it all
went down with this bad weather."

The declaration means that farmers have until July 26, 2010, to apply for
emergency assistance loans to help with losses incurred between April 1 and Oct.
30, Concordia Parish Farm Service Agency Director Kevin Case said.

The declaration also guarantees that the parish will have a Supplemental Revenue
Assistance Program, he said.

"SURE is a grant type program, whereas an emergency loan is a loan that has to
be repaid over a series of years," Case said. "A person applies for SURE and is
paid due to their eligibilities -- it's kind of a subsidy program to help them
get through the current crisis."

The SURE program is authorized through the 2008 Farm Bill, and one of its
requirements is that farmers maintain a certain level of crop insurance.

Daniels said that grant programs are especially needed right now.

"If it is just low interest loans, that's not going to be much of a help to
farmers in the parish," he said. "Refinancing debt is not going to be a
tremendous help to a lot of farmers."

Concordia and Tensas parishes were already considered contiguous disaster areas
due to a declaration about flooding related to the rain in Mississippi, and the
latest declaration reciprocates that action and places Adams, Jefferson and
Wilkinson counties in the contiguous disaster area category.

                              The American Banker

Iowa Governor Expected to Reach Decision on Moratorium;
Four Other Midwest States Considering Emergency Stays of Debt Payments on Farm
Loans as Crisis Deepens

                           February 11, 1985, Monday

By ANDREA BENNETT

DATELINE: CHICAGO


Iowa Gov. Terry Branstad is expected to announce this week whether he will use
emergency powers to trigger a debt moratorium on real estate loans in the state.
Farm groups have been pushing for such a moratorium, but insiders say the
governor will probably decide against it.

''The governor and legislators...are all looking for different alternatives,''
said Susan Neely, press secretary to Gov. Branstad. ''There's been a lot of talk
that [a moratorium] is the wrong way to go.''

Gov. Branstad's decision is coming as other farm states begin to explore the
possibility of imposing moratoriums on farm debt. Legislators in Indiana,
Minnesota, and North Dakota are considering bills that would impose debt
moratoriums. In Nebraska, where state laws are too restrictive to allow a
moratorium, legislators are looking at alternatives that would have the same
effect.

''There's a lot of noise for one,'' said Harry J. Argue, executive director of
the North Dakota Bankers Association.

A recent study by Farm Journal magazine found that 21% of the farmers in the
Farm Belt face a high risk of being forced out of business this year. As time
runs out for these farmers, they are putting increasing pressure on state
legislators for a stay of execution.

Moratoriums seek to halt foreclosure proceedings on farm debt for a specific
period of time. Exactly how they are imposed and what debt they cover varies
from state to state. For example, in Iowa, if the governor declares an economic
emergency, a moratorium on real estate foreclosures goes into effect.The
moratorium allows a borrower to petition a judge to postpone - but not cancel -
foreclosure proceedings. Interest continues to accrue on the debt during the
postponement.

Traditional Opposition of Bankers

Bankers traditionally oppose moratoriums. They claim moratoriums do not help
farmers and may, in fact, worsen conditions as lenders become more cautious
about making loans.

''A debt moratorium only makes things worse unless there is a chance of
(economic) circumstances changing,'' said William B. Brandt, general counsel for
the Nebraska Bankers Association. ''We think it is counterproductive not only
for lenders but debtors as well.''

Some farm groups favor moratoriums as a way of getting breathing room and
allowing them to continue to farm while debt restructuring plans are worked out.

Not all farm states are getting severe pressure for debt moratoriums.  Bankers
in Illinois, Kansas, Michigan, and South Dakota said calls for moratoriums had
not been as urgent as in other Midwest states.

They attributed the lack of activity to more divergent economies in their states
than in primarily agricultural states such as Iowa, more diversity in
agricultural production in their state, and good communication between farm and
lender groups.

But other states are considering moratoriums. They include:

* Indiana - Proposals for mortgage foreclosure relief backed by farm and
citizens groups are in committee in both the Senate and House of Representatives
but have not been scheduled for hearings.

* Minnesota - A bill that calls for a voluntary 120-day moratorium on farm
foreclosures passed the Senate in late January. But the House of
Representatives, which is considering the bill, has deleted the grace period,
said Norbert A. McCrady, executive vice president of the Independent Bankers of
Minnesota He was uncertain if a voluntary moratorium provision would be
reinserted at a later date.

Failure to pass a voluntary moratorium might increase pressure for a mandatory
one-year moratorium, he believed. ''There is definitely pressure for it,
although people who are pushing for it are taking a watch-and-see attitude to
the 120-day grace period,'' he said.

* Nebraska - Bill Kerrey, agricultural advisor and brother of Nebraska Gov. Bob
Kerrey, said the governor has looked at the legality of moratoriums and
concluded that because the Nebraska constitution is so restrictive on provisions
for impairment of contracts, ''it would be virtually impossible for the governor
to declare an across-the-board moratorium on farm foreclosures.''

However, a bill has been introduced in the state's unicameral Legislature that
would allow courts to grant additional stay periods on farm foreclosures.
Current law allows courts to grant a nine-month stay on the sale of farm real
estate if the debtor requests one.

Mr. Kerrey said the governor has not decided whether he will support the bill.
''He's just looking at it at this time,'' he said.

* North Dakota - A modified foreclosure moratorium is part of a five-point
agricultural relief plan outlined by North Dakota Gov. George Sinner that is
being considered by the state Legislature. Under the plan, a moratorium would go
into effect in one or more of eight counties if the county was determined to be
in state of economic emergency. Harry Argue of the NDBA said that could mean a
moratorium might be imposed that was not statewide.

The plan would set up credit review boards in the eight regions that would
review foreclosure proceedings and could impose a six-month halt on foreclosures
of any ''farm-related'' debt.

''There could be a very broad definition as to what is related to farming,'' he
said.  ''It's not just restricted to real estate and heavy machinery.''

The bill would have a two-year sunset clause. Mr. Argue said there was also
pressure by farm groups and some legislators for a statewide moratorium.

             Journal Record Legislative Report (Oklahoma City, OK)

                            August 9, 2012 Thursday

Agencies survey fire damage across Oklahoma

BYLINE: Brian Brus

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 513  words


Federal Emergency Management Agency officials joined other federal and state
agencies Thursday in surveying and estimating the damages from grassland fires
that have swept across the state. Although it is still too early to produce a
comprehensive figure, officials said, the cost of barbed-wire fencing by itself
provides some perspective of the scale of the loss to farmers and ranchers.
Nearly 105,000 acres have been burned in the last week, damaging hundreds of
structures, farm machinery, feed and even livestock.

The Oklahoma Farm Service Agency has announced that ag producers that incurred
damages might be eligible for assistance under the Emergency Conservation
Program, even the fences that surround more valuable property. "Assistance is
available to restoring or replace permanent fences damaged during the
devastating wildfires," FSA Executive Director Francie Tolle said in a
statement. "I encourage everyone who had fences damaged or destroyed to visit
their local FSA office and learn more about ECP before repairs are started. "
According to the state Department of Agriculture, the average size of a farm in
Oklahoma is about 400 acres. That includes a wide range, from the majority of
producers who operate about 120 acres to the few who run up to 3,000 acres. Rod
Wanger, an FSA conservation programs specialist, estimated the average cost of
replacing barbed-wire fence at $1 per foot. That might not seem like much of an
expense to someone without experience in the field until a little geometry is
applied: An ag operation with 400 acres, if laid out as a square, would measure
about 4,200 feet to a side, so the full perimeter fence could cost about
$17,000. Of course, not all grassland is fenced, and barbed wire is available in
wide range of grades, so Wanger said his department was reluctant to provide
estimates this early in recovery. "We will definitely see a temporary increase
in sales to replace field fencing and barbed wire," said Lou Richards at
Oklahoma Steel and Wire, a major barbed-wire wholesaler. "But that uptick in
business won't show in our profits. "We don't like to increase our business
because of fires, blizzards, floods, hurricanes or any of that," he said. "We're
not profiteers. We will not take advantage of ag producers and I'd like to say I
don't think retailers will, either. " The company contributes to several
disaster relief programs and asks that its distributors hold their prices in
check during major recoveries. "We want to earn money the old-fashioned way," he
said. "And I know those farmers have bigger problems on their minds right now. "
The ECP provides cost-share assistance to affected producers at a rate not to
exceed 75 percent of the eligible cost of restoration measures. Producers will
need to contact the local FSA office for a review of their situation before
repairs begin. The agency also has an Emergency Loan Program available at a
2.25-percent interest rate. An expedited loan process has been approved to
process these loans that involve feed losses such as hay destroyed by the
wildfires.

                              The American Banker

As Drought Lingers, Banks Push for Farm Bailout

                           September 16, 2002, Monday

BY BEN JACKSON



With the help of their banks, farmers have largely weathered the drought that
has half the country in its grip, but agricultural bankers say that without a
government bailout, many of their customers could soon be out of business.

The full effect of the drought likely will not be known until after the fall
harvest, but many agricultural bankers have been restructuring debt to help
farmers and ranchers get through the year. Still, bankers say that the emergency
relief package approved by the Senate, but strongly opposed by the Bush
administration, is crucial, because only that will provide income to farmers who
have lost most of their crops or livestock.

In Montana, where farmers are facing their fifth year of drought, small
communities are suffering because the farmers are not spending money, according
to Michael E. Grove, the president of Countricorp's $56 million-asset Bank of
the Rockies in White Sulphur Springs, Mont.

"The farmers have been struggling to stay alive through government payments and
crop insurance," Mr. Grove said.

Ray E. Purdy, the Garden City, Kan., branch president of the $570 million-asset
HNB Corp. of Arkansas City, said he has seen four families quit the farming
business over the past two years and has advised at least two others to consider
selling their farms. Ranchers have suffered the most, because they cannot get
crop insurance, he said.

At the end of July 49% of the land in the lower 48 states was in moderate to
extreme drought, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's National
Climatic Data Center in Asheville, N.C., reported. The worst hit states have
been Kansas, Nebraska, Wyoming, Colorado, Montana, and the Dakotas.

Bankers, of course, are concerned that, if drought continues and crop output is
diminished, farmers and ranchers will be unable to repay their loans.

Even nonagricultural banks have reason to be worried about the drought. In a
Securities and Exchange Commission filing last month, Fulton Financial Corp. of
Lancaster, Pa., said that it had made $14.5 million of loans to a real estate
developer who had been denied water and sewer permits for a construction project
because of the drought.

Though the loans were not yet classified as nonperforming, the $7.9
billion-asset company indicated that they are at risk.

Agricultural bankers are counting on relief from the federal government. Last
week the Senate passed an amendment to the Interior Department appropriations
bill that would provide an estimated $5.95 billion of emergency relief to
farmers.

Because the amendment, offered by Senate Majority Leader Thomas Daschle, D-S.D.,
provides for emergency spending outside of the regular budget, it is not
required by law to be offset by spending cuts elsewhere. However, it could face
opposition when House leaders sit down to hammer out the appropriations bill in
a conference committee.

And even if the amendment gets through the conference, the bill may face a veto.
The Bush administration opposes spending for farmers that is not offset by
spending cuts elsewhere.

George Beattie, the executive vice president of the Nebraska Bankers
Association, said the administration should view the drought as it would any
other natural disaster.

"If we had a hurricane or flooding or fire, there wouldn't be any question
about" emergency aid, he said.

Agricultural banks are in better position to deal with drought and other
disasters than they were in the 1980s, when many of them failed. Jim Maag, the
executive vice president of the Kansas Bankers Association, said that banks are
better capitalized than they were then, so they have the flexibility to change
loan terms and absorb losses. Also, land prices are strong, so there is
collateral to refinance loans if necessary.

Still, Mike Nelson, the president of the Nebraska trade group and chairman of
Compass Bank Nebraska, said that agricultural banks are taking steps to protect
themselves, such as constantly updating their cash-flow projections from farm
operations to keep track of repayment schedules.

Banks are also looking for government loan guarantees and adding to their loan
-loss reserves, he said.

                       The Oklahoman (Oklahoma City, OK)

                             July 28, 2011 Thursday
                                 Drive Edition

USDA declares disaster in all but three counties

BYLINE: MICHAEL MCNUTT, Capitol Bureau

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 3A

LENGTH: 237 words


The U.S. Agriculture Department issued a disaster declaration Wednesday for most
of Oklahoma's counties, where farmers are reeling from wildfires and the ongoing
drought.

The declaration covers 74 of the state's 77 counties. Nowata, Craig and Ottawa
counties in far northeastern Oklahoma are not covered.

It is in response to a June 10 request by Gov. Mary Fallin, who asked the
federal agency to issue a disaster declaration in order to help farmers who are
adversely affected by drought and wildfires.

The governor had asked that all 77 counties be covered in a disaster
declaration. The Agriculture Department replied that it was "unable to make a
complete and accurate determination of production losses" for counties not
included under the declaration, according to the governor's office.

It said "a decision ... will be deferred until the loss information becomes
available" regarding the three counties not included.

The Agriculture Department's disaster designation makes farmers in approved
counties eligible to be considered for federal assistance from the Farm Service
Agency.

Such assistance would include Farm Service Agency emergency loans and
eligibility in the Supplemental Revenue Assistance Payments Program.

Farmers in designated counties have eight months to apply for emergency loan
assistance. Farmers interested in requesting additional information should
contact their local Farm Service Agency office.

Louisiana: USDA Designates Natural Disaster Areas

LENGTH: 246 words

DATELINE: Lahore



 Baton Rouge: Louisiana Department of Agriculture and Forestry, The state of
Louisiana has issued the following news release:





 Agriculture and Forestry Commissioner Mike Strain, D.V.M., said the U.S.
Department of Agriculture (USDA) declared Natchitoches Parish a primary natural
disaster area due to a recent drought.



 In accordance with section 321(a) of the Consolidated Farm and Rural
Development Act, additional areas were named as contiguous disaster parishes.
They are: Bienville, Desoto, Grant, Rapides, Red River, Sabine, Vernon and Winn.




 Strain said farmers and ranchers located in both primary and contiguous
parishes are eligible for low-interest emergency loans from the Farm Service
Agency (FSA), provided eligibility requirements are met. Farmers in eligible
areas have 8 months from the disaster declaration date, Sept. 30, 2015, to apply
for the emergency loans.



 &ldquo;Our farmers and ranchers face great challenges with every seed they sow
and animal they nurture all for the purpose of providing food and fiber for
people like you and me,&rdquo; Strain said. &ldquo;This assistance will provide
much needed relief to producers.&rdquo;



 Strain urged farmers and ranchers who may be eligible to contact their local
parish FSA office for further information. Additional information is also
available online at http://disaster.fsa.usda.gov.

                      The Atlanta Journal and Constitution

                     July 15, 1998, Wednesday, ALL EDITIONS

Further disaster aid available for Georgia farmers;
Designated areas: Federal low-interest loans extended to farmers in 155 counties
to counter assault weather.

BYLINE: Peter Scott

SECTION: LOCAL NEWS; Pg. 02B; Pg. 02B

LENGTH: 452 words


Georgia farmers whose crops have drowned, burned and withered under a continued
assault of weather maladies are now eligible for continued disaster benefits.

Federal officials are extending a disaster designation to make low-interest
loans available to farmers in 155 of Georgia's 159 counties, the state announced
Tuesday. The relief is an extension of benefits made available to counter the
negative impact of last summer's drought, the heavy rains of fall and winter and
the storms and tornadoes in the spring. It comes as a result of the broiling
summer heat and dry conditions that are currently damaging the state's crops.

"This has been one of the wackiest weather years I've ever seen," said Buzz
Weiss, a spokesman for Georgia Emergency Management Agency (GEMA).

The disaster declaration from the U.S. Department of Agriculture covers all
Georgia counties except Cobb and Douglas in the Atlanta area and Chatham and
Camden on the coast, said Commissioner of Agriculture Tommy Irvin Tuesday.  The
four counties are urban and did not experience as much weather damage as others,
state officials said.

Irvin said the current drought will mean a $ 400 million loss to the state's
economy.  He made a personal appeal for help to President Bill Clinton during
Clinton's visit to Atlanta last week.

With the extended designation, farmers affected by the weather will be eligible
for low-interest loans to help them rebuild their crops and save their farms, as
well as other benefits, said Gary W. McConnell, director of the Georgia
Emergency Management Agency. Farmers who wish to apply for benefits should
contact a local Farm Service Agency office.

More than loans are needed, however, Irvin said. He is seeking emergency federal
relief money from Congress that could help the hardest hit of the state's
farmers. Loans, even low-interest ones, place additional burdens on farmers who
have lost crops, and crop insurance is often inadequate and based on recent
harvests that have been smaller than normal, he said.

The disaster designation is used as a fallback for some farmers, such as
64-year-old Grady 'Bud" Hodges of Newton County, about 40 miles east of Atlanta.
Hodges hopes his crop insurance will meet his operating needs, but he is glad to
know there will be loans available.

The relentless heat and drought that hit the South in early summer burned up 15
acres of corn Hodges planted, and he now uses it to feed the 200 head of cattle
he raises. He has been able to harvest crops from his 300 acres of land set
aside for wheat, but doubts if he will see more if the drought continues. He
planted only 50 of the 200 acres set aside for soy beans but those that came up,
died.
